title: NVDA doesn't announce button names
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

_How the feature works now and what you'd like to change_?  
  
**This problem is related to Chrome based browsers only**

NVDA screen reader gives different results in different browsers for toggle buttons:

*   In Firefox it has been properly announcing button names for all toggle buttons e.g. "Bold toggle button not pressed".
*   In Chrome based browsers is has just been announcing "toggle button not pressed" without specifying button names.

We should check whether there is any aria attribute we can add so that names are properly announced for these types of buttons.  
  
\----  
**This problem is related to all browsers**

When dealing with split buttons e.g. bulleted list, highlight or numbered list, the menu part is just announced as "Menu button collapsed sub-menu" and "Expanded" one it is opened. There is no information to which button this submenu belongs to.

We should check whether it is possible to add any aria attribute to improve that.  
The same happens when using JAWS so either this is how it has to be or this is editor a11y problem in general.

\----

**This problem is related to all browsers**

For menu buttons like font family it is not announced when menu is opened. The button is read as "Menu Font-family button sub-menu" but if you press down arrow nothing is announced. 

We should check whether it is possible to add any aria attribute to improve that.  
The same happens when using JAWS so either this is how it has to be or this is editor a11y problem in general.

## 📃 Other details

*   Browser: Chrome, New Edge, Opera
*   OS: Windows
*   CKEditor version: 29.0.0
*   Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers such as NVDA cannot identify the purpose of toggle, split‑button, or menu‑button controls in Chrome‑based browsers. The controls are announced only as generic “toggle button” or “menu button”, lacking the descriptive names that are available in Firefox. This omission prevents users from understanding the function and state of these controls, causing confusion and difficulty when navigating or manipulating the editor’s interface.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers such as NVDA cannot identify the purpose of toggle, split‑button, or menu‑button controls in Chrome‑based browsers. The controls are announced only as generic “toggle button” or “menu button”, lacking the descriptive names that are available in Firefox. This omission prevents users from understanding the function and state of these controls, causing confusion and difficulty when navigating or manipulating the editor’s interface.
models.thread_tldr: NVDA (and other screen readers) fail to announce the names of toolbar toggle and split buttons in Chrome‑based browsers, reporting only generic labels such as “toggle button not pressed.” The issue was reported with two subsequent comments but no resolution or fix has been documented.
models.thread_problem: In CKEditor 29.0.0, when used in Chrome, Edge, or Opera on Windows, NVDA and other screen readers do not provide an accessible name for toolbar toggle buttons or for split buttons (e.g., bulleted list, numbered list, font family). Instead, the screen reader announces generic phrases like “toggle button not pressed” or “Menu button collapsed sub‑menu” without indicating which button the submenu belongs to, leaving users without the necessary context to interact with the controls. This gap violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.5.1 (Names, Values, and Help) and related naming/labeling guidelines.
models.thread_timeline: #1 bbenjamin: Suggested that the issue may be the same as a previously reported split button problem and advised updating the issue name to reflect broader screen reader support. #2 mabryl: Added that NVDA (and other screen readers such as Windows Narrator) do not announce toolbar button names when the mouse hovers over them, highlighting the same accessibility gap.
models.thread_links: ( no external references provided)

models.text: The Find and Replace button lacks an accessible name, so screen readers announce nothing when the element receives focus, preventing users who rely on assistive technology from understanding its purpose.
models.acr_note: The Find and Replace button lacks an accessible name, so screen readers announce nothing when the element receives focus, preventing users who rely on assistive technology from understanding its purpose.
models.dev_note: Use a native `<button>` element with visible text or an `aria-label`/`aria-labelledby` to supply an accessible name. For example:
models.thread_tldr: A user reported that the Find & Replace button in CKEditor 29.0.0 is not announced by screen readers. A single follow‑up comment claims the issue cannot be reproduced on NVDA, Chrome, and VoiceOver, and no further discussion has occurred. The barrier’s status is therefore uncertain and unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The Find & Replace button fails to provide an accessible name that a screen reader announces when it receives focus, leaving users who rely on assistive technology unable to identify the button.
models.thread_timeline: #1 bbenjamin: Can't reproduce. Screenshot is from NVDA/Chrome/Win 10. Also tried in Chrome/VoiceOver and it also worked.

title: Drag and drop should indicate that dropping in given place is disallowed
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Currently it is impossible to drop a table in image caption. However drag and drop doesn't indicate that it won't have any effect:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5353898/127451064-7bb2ccc7-293d-433d-ad1f-ff93388b2d2a.mp4

An example solution to this would be to denote it by with this fake caret - changing color and adding a no-no sign (as we should avoid conveying information by color alone, that's accessibility issue). Even better would be to show a small tooltip that dropping in this place will not have an effect.

You can test it out in https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/29.0.0/examples/builds/document-editor.html

For example on Windows if you drag over things that will not take an effect it denotes it with cursor:

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5353898/127450378-3c9c12e2-5025-4704-9414-5c8df0041374.png)

It' possible to achieve the same effect with DOM API (AFAIR it was drop effect back in a day).

## 📃 Other details

*   Browser: Any
*   OS: Any

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Users cannot see a clear cue that dropping a table onto an image caption will have no effect, so they may attempt a drop and experience confusion or wasted effort. This lack of non‑color visual feedback and absence of an accessible alternative (e.g., text or tooltip) can hinder users who rely on screen readers, high‑contrast modes, or who are cognitively impaired.
models.acr_note: Users cannot see a clear cue that dropping a table onto an image caption will have no effect, so they may attempt a drop and experience confusion or wasted effort. This lack of non‑color visual feedback and absence of an accessible alternative (e.g., text or tooltip) can hinder users who rely on screen readers, high‑contrast modes, or who are cognitively impaired.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor’s drag‑and‑drop interface does not visibly indicate when a drop target is invalid, potentially confusing users of assistive technology. No resolution or follow‑up discussion is documented in the thread.
models.thread_problem: Dragging an element (e.g., a table) into certain parts of a CKEditor document (such as an image caption) has no effect, yet the UI fails to provide any visual cue that the drop will be rejected. This lack of feedback can prevent users from understanding the consequences of their actions, particularly those relying on screen readers or other assistive devices that cannot perceive visual changes.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [Demo video of invalid drop in CKEditor](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5353898/127451064-7bb2ccc7-293d-433d-ad1f-ff93388b2d2a.mp4): Illustrates the lack of visual feedback when dropping in a disallowed area. - [Cursor image for invalid drop zone](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5353898/127450378-3c9c12e2-5025-4704-9414-5c8df0041374.png): Example of a cursor used on Windows to indicate non‑drop targets. - [CKEditor5 Document Editor example](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/29.0.0/examples/builds/document-editor.html): Live demo where the issue can be reproduced.

title: Accessibility Conformance Report

In anycase, best to align with WCAG rather than the old, old Section 508 guidelines. Plus, CKEditor 5 vs 4.

title: Use <em> instead of <i> for italicized text
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

The italic plugin is using 'i' to indicate italicized text but this is not the preferred method in HTML any more (see https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_i.asp).  While 'i' still works just fine in most browsers, I happen to be using a themed wrapper on my site that has decided to use the 'i' tag for icons.  Apparently Facebook HTML and Twitter bootstrap also use the 'i' tag for icons.  I don't agree that they should, but nevertheless it is creating an issue in my CKEditor5 implementation.  I've worked around it but would prefer to not to have to ... especially since the use of the i tag is not exclusive to italic any more in the standards.

Is this change a reasonable request?

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The issue is that the editor’s italic formatting uses the `<i>` element, which is also being used in the site’s CSS for iconography. This dual use leads to markup that is semantically incorrect and can create confusion during editing or when styling is applied, potentially making it harder for developers and assistive technologies to interpret the content accurately.
models.acr_note: The issue is that the editor’s italic formatting uses the `<i>` element, which is also being used in the site’s CSS for iconography. This dual use leads to markup that is semantically incorrect and can create confusion during editing or when styling is applied, potentially making it harder for developers and assistive technologies to interpret the content accurately.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor5 uses the <i> tag for italicized text, which conflicts with a themed wrapper that repurposes <i> for icons, potentially causing accessibility problems. The reporter suggests switching to <em> for italics to align with modern HTML practices. No further discussion or resolution is visible in the thread.
models.thread_problem: The use of the <i> tag for italicized text creates semantic ambiguity because the same tag is also used for icons, which may impede screen reader interpretation and violate WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships). Switching to <em> for italicized text would provide clearer semantic meaning and improve accessibility.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed the initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [i element](https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_i.asp): Shows that <i> is not the preferred element for italicized text in modern HTML.

title: VoiceOver doesn't read toolbar option labels in Chrome
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Activate VoiceOver on Mac (command + F5)
2. Navigate to CKEditor text editor by tab
3. Navigate to toolbar options (option + F10)

### ✔️ Expected result

VoiceOver should read "bold, button", if focus is on the bold formatting option in the toolbar.

(There seems to be a similar problem with JAWS on Chrome/Windows too. In VoiceOver on Safari/Mac it works as expected though.)

### ❌ Actual result

VoiceOver only reads "button", which leaves screen reader users unaware of what the button does.

### ❓ Possible solution

Did just give it a quick try and put aria-label="bold" directly on the button-element instead of an aria-labelledby reference like the current solution. Worked both in Chrome and Safari.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome
* OS: MacOS Big Sur
* First affected CKEditor version: 28.0.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins:  Bold, Italic, Paragraph, PasteFromOffice

models.text: VoiceOver (and JAWS) in Chrome announces toolbar buttons only as “button”, omitting the button’s function (e.g., “bold”). This prevents screen reader users from understanding the purpose of each toolbar control.
models.acr_note: VoiceOver (and JAWS) in Chrome announces toolbar buttons only as “button”, omitting the button’s function (e.g., “bold”). This prevents screen reader users from understanding the purpose of each toolbar control.
models.thread_tldr: VoiceOver on Chrome for Mac does not read the descriptive labels of CKEditor toolbar buttons, reporting only “button” and leaving users unaware of the button’s function. No resolution or follow‑up discussion is recorded.
models.thread_problem: The accessible name for toolbar buttons is not announced by VoiceOver in Chrome, violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value).

title: Keyboard Navigation : User unable to access 'Insert link' alert dialog which is displayed by invoking 'Insert Link' control present in 'Rich text editor toolbar using CKEDitor5
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

Using Keyboard Controls (Tab key)

### ✔️ Expected result
Using keyboard navigation -User should be able to access control present in 'Rich text editor toolbar.
Ex: Once the dialog is displayed, keyboard focus should land on the edit field present in the dialog.


### ❌ Actual result
User unable to access  control present in 'Rich text editor toolbar.
Ex:

2.Keyboard focus is not at all moving to the bttons/links present in the richtexteditor.
### ❓ Possible solution

_If you have ideas, you can list them here. Otherwise, you can delete this section._

Browser: MIcrosoft Edge (Chromium) & Google Chrome

https://codepen.io/amneerajm/pen/OJjepxj

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The user is unable to navigate to the CKEditor5 toolbar and its controls (e.g., the “Insert link” button) using the Tab key, and when a dialog opens the keyboard focus lands on the close button instead of the first interactive element. This prevents keyboard‑only users from accessing essential editing functions and interacting with dialog content.
models.acr_note: The user is unable to navigate to the CKEditor5 toolbar and its controls (e.g., the “Insert link” button) using the Tab key, and when a dialog opens the keyboard focus lands on the close button instead of the first interactive element. This prevents keyboard‑only users from accessing essential editing functions and interacting with dialog content.
models.thread_tldr: A user reports that the Tab key cannot reach CKEditor 5 toolbar controls, preventing the “Insert link” dialog from opening or being focused. No subsequent discussion or fixes are recorded.
models.thread_problem: Keyboard focus cannot move to any toolbar button or link in CKEditor 5’s rich‑text editor when using the Tab key. Consequently, the “Insert link” dialog cannot be opened, and once displayed, focus remains on the close button instead of the dialog’s input field. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 2.4.8 (Keyboard focus order) and 2.4.10 (Keyboard Accessible).
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. No further discussion recorded.

title: Unnecessary tabstop on the scroll container of the editor in Firefox
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://onlinemarkdowneditor.dev/ in Firefox.
2. Tab through elements until you land on "Syntax guide for markdown" link (or on the mouse icon with the "scroll" label if your viewport is big enough to trigger its appearance).
3. Press <kbd>Tab</kbd> once more.

### ✔️ Expected result

The focus is inside the editing area and you can edit the text.

### ❌ Actual result

The focus is on the `.ck-editor__main` element that is used to scroll the editor's content.

### ❓ Possible solution

Moving the scrolling logic directly to the editable element should remove the unnecessary tabstop in Firefox.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Firefox
* OS: Windows, macOS
* First affected CKEditor version: …
* Installed CKEditor plugins: …

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

### ❌ Actual result

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The reported behavior causes keyboard users to land on the editor’s scroll container (`.ck-editor__main`) instead of the editable area after tabbing past the “Syntax guide for markdown” link. Because the scroll container is not interactive, this extra, non‑functional tab stop forces users to press Tab an additional time before they can edit, creating confusion and slowing navigation.
models.acr_note: The reported behavior causes keyboard users to land on the editor’s scroll container (`.ck-editor__main`) instead of the editable area after tabbing past the “Syntax guide for markdown” link. Because the scroll container is not interactive, this extra, non‑functional tab stop forces users to press Tab an additional time before they can edit, creating confusion and slowing navigation.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that pressing Tab in Firefox on the online markdown editor moves focus to a non‑editable scroll container instead of the editor’s content area, disrupting keyboard navigation. No follow‑up discussion or resolution is recorded in the thread.
models.thread_problem: When tabbing after the “Syntax guide for markdown” link, focus lands on the `.ck-editor__main` element used for scrolling the editor’s content. This causes keyboard users to stop on a non‑interactive element instead of being able to edit the markdown, violating expected keyboard focus order (WCAG 2.2 2.4.3) and obscuring the editable region (WCAG 2.2 2.4.7).
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

title: Mentions plugin accessibility support
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Screen Readers like JAWS don't read the Mention popup with available options:

> Issue 1: The expectation is that the screen reader software like JAWS will read the count of the number of records found when the mention popup or hashtag popup is opened and also when the suggestions are filtered based on user input which is not happening.
> 
> Issue 2: When the mention or hashtag popup opens, although the focus is there on the popup, the screen reader (JAWS) doesn’t recognise that the popup is opened and hence, the content of the popup is also not read when we use key-down to traverse through the records.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Firefox
* OS: Windows
* CKEditor version: 4.18.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: mention

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers such as JAWS cannot receive verbal feedback when the mention or hashtag popup opens or when the list of suggestions is filtered. The screen reader does not announce the number of results found, nor does it read the content of the popup as the user navigates it, preventing users from understanding available options and making selections.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers such as JAWS cannot receive verbal feedback when the mention or hashtag popup opens or when the list of suggestions is filtered. The screen reader does not announce the number of results found, nor does it read the content of the popup as the user navigates it, preventing users from understanding available options and making selections.
models.thread_tldr: The Mentions plugin never receives focus, causing screen readers to read only the text before the marker and not announce the suggestion popup or the count of results. Two users have commented—one reporting the same issue with NVDA and another confirming the problem—yet no fixes or updates have been posted.
models.thread_problem: The Mentions plugin fails to transfer keyboard focus to the suggestion popup and does not announce the popup’s content or the number of suggestions. This prevents screen‑reader users from hearing the available options, violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info, Relationships, and Properties).
models.thread_timeline: #1 antoniolucasnobar: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 Gambinha: Added a comment confirming the issue.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#info-relationships): Requirement that information and relationships must be made available to assistive technologies.

title: Accessibility improvements
context:

title: Table is a focus trap
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1.  Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/table.html
2.  Place the cursor in the last cell of the table
3.  Press <kbd>Tab</kbd>.

### ✔️ Expected result

The focus should go outside of the table

### ❌ Actual result

It's not possible to leave the table using keyboard only.

The same is true for the first cell and pressing <kbd>Shift</kbd> + <kbd>Tab</kbd>.

### ❓ Possible solution

Pressing <kbd>Esc</kbd> can switch from "edit mode" to "navigation mode" and allow to escape the table without sacrificing adding new rows after pressing <kbd>Tab</kbd> at the end of the table.

## 📃 Other details

*   Browser: all
*   OS: all
*   Installed CKEditor plugins: table

See also: #1709.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The CKEditor table editing mode traps keyboard focus inside the table: pressing Tab or Shift + Tab from the first or last cell never moves focus to the next interactive element. Keyboard‑only users (including those using screen readers) are unable to navigate out of the table, which limits their ability to continue working on the page.
models.acr_note: The CKEditor table editing mode traps keyboard focus inside the table: pressing Tab or Shift + Tab from the first or last cell never moves focus to the next interactive element. Keyboard‑only users (including those using screen readers) are unable to navigate out of the table, which limits their ability to continue working on the page.
models.thread_tldr: The CKEditor 5 table editing interface traps keyboard focus, preventing users from tabbing out of the table. No discussion or resolution is recorded beyond the initial report.
models.thread_problem: In CKEditor 5’s table editing mode, pressing Tab (or Shift + Tab) on the last (or first) cell does not move focus outside the table, creating a focus trap. This violates the WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.1.1 (Keyboard Accessible) which requires that all functionality be operable using a keyboard.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [#1709](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/1709): Related issue about table navigation.

title: Placeholder is treated as regular text (at least in voiceover)
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open [full-featured editor](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/examples/builds-custom/full-featured-editor.html).
2. Delete all editor contents so the placeholder appears: _Type or paste your content here_.
4. Run voiceover to read the editor contents.

### ✔️ Expected result

Voiceover reads the text _Type or paste your content here_ but it points out that this is a placeholder.

### ❌ Actual result

Voiceover just reads the text _Type or paste your content here_ as it was a normal content.

### ❓ Possible solution

See https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/11848#issuecomment-1141147567

## 📃 Other details

We need make sure that this fix gets also applied to other placeholders:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5353898/171000693-e863867e-e34b-4bb9-bdd6-6e8c860e27a5.png)

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The screen reader reads the placeholder text “Type or paste your content here” as normal content, which can confuse users by making them believe it is part of the document rather than a hint for input.
models.acr_note: The screen reader reads the placeholder text “Type or paste your content here” as normal content, which can confuse users by making them believe it is part of the document rather than a hint for input.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that VoiceOver reads the editor’s placeholder text as normal content, failing to announce it as a placeholder. The thread contains only the original reporter’s comments and no evidence of a resolution or additional contributors.
models.thread_problem: Screen readers such as VoiceOver do not identify placeholder text in CKEditor 5’s full‑featured editor, treating “Type or paste your content here” as regular content rather than a placeholder. This prevents users relying on assistive technology from understanding that the field is empty and ready for input.
models.thread_timeline: #1 mlewand: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 mlewand: Suggested using the `aria-placeholder` attribute and cited the ARIA spec and MDN page. #3 mlewand: Noted past visual placeholder issues and urged careful testing, proposing an ADR. #4 mlewand: Indicated that further work and refinement are needed for the fix.
models.thread_links: - [WAI‑ARIA 1.2 aria-placeholder](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.2/#aria-placeholder): Definition of the `aria-placeholder` attribute. - [MDN: aria-placeholder](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Attributes/aria-placeholder): MDN documentation for the attribute.

title: Word / characters count not reported / inaccessible
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1.  Open [full-featured editor](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/examples/builds-custom/full-featured-editor.html).
2.  Try to navigate to words/characters count section with a keyboard.
3.  Run voiceover for the editor, try to move focus to the words/characters count section (e.g. using CapsLock + arrow-right)

### ✔️ Expected result

Words/characters count section is accessible and easy to navigate.

### ❌ Actual result

**Keyboard**: it's not possible to navigate to this section.

**Voiceover**: it is possible to navigate to the section and that's great, but if we had a lot of contents including several tables inside the editor then it would take too much time to go through all of them down to the bottom just to check the current words/characters count. It should be much easier/quicker.

### ❓ Possible solution

_If you have ideas, you can list them here. Otherwise, you can delete this section._

## 📃 Other details

*   Browser: …
*   OS: …
*   First affected CKEditor version: …
*   Installed CKEditor plugins: …

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Users who rely on keyboard navigation cannot locate the words/characters count within the editor, and screen‑reader users must traverse an excessive number of elements to reach it, causing a significant accessibility barrier that reduces productivity and usability.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on keyboard navigation cannot locate the words/characters count within the editor, and screen‑reader users must traverse an excessive number of elements to reach it, causing a significant accessibility barrier that reduces productivity and usability.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor 5’s word/character count is not easily accessible via keyboard or screen‑reading navigation, making it difficult for users to verify document length. Only the initial report exists; no follow‑up or resolution has been documented.
models.thread_problem: The word/character count UI in CKEditor 5 is not reachable using keyboard navigation, and while a screen reader can locate it, the process is overly time‑consuming, especially for documents with many embedded elements. This barrier impedes users who rely on assistive technology or keyboard‑only interaction to quickly ascertain text length.
models.thread_timeline: #1 mlewand: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps and noted that CKEditor 5 exposes only an API for word/character count, requiring implementers to make the information accessible.

title: Missing labels for all the widget editables
context:
## :memo: **Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)**

1.  Open e.g. https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/table.html#basic-table-features
2.  Launch VoiceOver or other screen reader
3.  Focus the table cell.

### :heavy\_check\_mark: **Expected result**

The editable should be announced as an appropriate element (e.g. table cell).

### :x: **Actual result**

There is no label.

### :question: **Possible solution**

Solution to all the different widget editables should be based on the results from the #11837 issue.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a :+1: reaction to this post.

models.text: The lack of an accessible label on CKEditor5’s editable cells causes screen‑reader users to receive no contextual information when navigating a table, resulting in a loss of understanding of the content’s location and purpose.
models.acr_note: The lack of an accessible label on CKEditor5’s editable cells causes screen‑reader users to receive no contextual information when navigating a table, resulting in a loss of understanding of the content’s location and purpose.
models.thread_tldr: A screen‑reader user is unable to hear that they are focused on a table cell because the cell lacks an accessible label. The issue was reported but no resolution or follow‑up discussion has been documented.
models.thread_problem: The editable table cells are announced with no identifying label or role, causing screen‑reader users to miss the element type. This failure violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value) for perceivable information.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

title: Table Properties and Cell Properties panels should be made accessible for screen readers
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Enable a Screen Reader like JAWS
2. Try to open Table properties panel


### ✔️ Expected result

Screen reader should announce where user is or how to get to the panel.

### ❌ Actual result

Screen reader doesn't announce anything

### ❓ Possible solution

_If you have ideas, you can list them here. Otherwise, you can delete this section._

Panels like table properties could be presented as popups or dialogs so that screen reader could properly announce it. 

Something to consider: The INSERT + F6 allows screen reader like JAWS listing headers in the page. Perhaps popup title could be such a header as well so that it is also possible to access it that way.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Any
* OS: Any
* First affected CKEditor version: N/A
* Installed CKEditor plugins: widget, table

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.thread_problem: When a screen reader‑enabled user activates the Table Properties or Cell Properties panel, the screen reader fails to announce the panel, its title, or its controls. models.acr_note: Screen‑reader users who enable JAWS cannot highlight or copy text in CKEditor using Shift + Left/Right arrow keys, which limits their ability to read, edit, or interact with content.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that users cannot select text using Shift + Left/Right arrows while JAWS is active in CKEditor 5. Discussion notes a pull request that may resolve the problem, but no confirmation of merging or functional validation has been provided. Current status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: In CKEditor 5, when the JAWS screen reader is running, pressing Shift + Left or Shift + Right arrow keys does not allow text selection within the editor. This barrier prevents users who rely on keyboard and screen‑reader navigation from selecting and manipulating text, potentially violating WCAG 2.2 success criteria related to keyboard operability and accessible text manipulation.

title: Default Headings configuration causes accessibility issues
context: ## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any) 1. Open https://ckeditor.com/collaboration/real-time-collaborative-editing/demo 2. Insert couple of headings with text 3. Read those heading with JAWS (it will read heading level 1, 2, 3 ) 4. Export contents to PDF 5. Open PDF and try reading those headings with JAWS ### ✔️ Expected result It should read heading level 1,2,3 ### ❌ Actual result It reads heading level 2,3,4 This is caused by default Heading configuration and while it works fine in CKEditor which outputs HTML, it causes a11y issue when editor content is exported to other formats: https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/blob/master/packages/ckeditor5-heading/src/headingediting.js#L39-L45 https://ckeditor.github.io/editor-recommendations/features/headings.html More details in ZD ticket no. 75576 ### ❓ Possible solution _If you have ideas, you can list them here. Otherwise, you can delete this section._ You need to change feature configuration - https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/headings.html#configuring-heading-levels ## 📃 Other details * Browser: Firefox, Chrome * OS: Windows * First affected CKEditor version: N/A * Installed CKEditor plugins: heading --- If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

Otherwise, you can delete this section._ You need to change feature configuration - https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/headings.html#configuring-heading-levels ## 📃 Other details * Browser: Firefox, Chrome * OS: Windows * First affected CKEditor version: N/A * Installed CKEditor plugins: heading --- If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers experience incorrect heading level information when content edited with CKEditor is exported to PDF; headings are announced as one level higher (e.g., level 2 instead of level 1). This misleads users who navigate documents by heading hierarchy, reducing content comprehension and usability.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers experience incorrect heading level information when content edited with CKEditor is exported to PDF; headings are announced as one level higher (e.g., level 2 instead of level 1). This misleads users who navigate documents by heading hierarchy, reducing content comprehension and usability.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor’s default heading configuration causes heading levels to shift when content is exported to PDF, leading to incorrect announcements by screen readers. Only two comments exist—one asking for status and one pointing to a reusable pattern—so the thread shows no resolution or further work.
models.thread_problem: CKEditor’s default heading plugin assigns levels 1–3 in the editor but exports them as levels 2–4, so assistive technology announces headings incorrectly. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info & Relationships) by providing a misleading heading structure.
models.thread_timeline: #1 harisejaz10p: Filed initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 mgifford: Noted that the [A11yfirst](https://a11yfirst.gitlab.io/custom/a11yfirst.html) pattern already provides a solution.
models.thread_links: - [CKEditor 5 Heading Editing Source](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/blob/master/packages/ckeditor5-heading/src/headingediting.js#L39-L45): Shows the default heading level configuration causing the issue. - [CKEditor Editor Recommendations – Headings](https://ckeditor.github.io/editor-recommendations/features/headings.html): Provides guidance on configuring heading levels. - [A11yfirst – Headings Pattern](https://a11yfirst.gitlab.io/custom/a11yfirst.html): Offers a reusable pattern for accessible heading implementation.

title: Wrong focus after pressing `Esc` in splitbutton
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1.  Go to the pre-\`35.0.0\` `release` branch (68118a2).
2.  Open a manual test with splitbutton like highlight (e.g. http://localhost:8125/ckeditor5/tests/manual/all-features.html).
3.  Open the highlight splitbutton.
4.  Press `Esc`.

### ✔️ Expected result

Focus moves to the dropdown arrow:

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10883184/181234461-ce9a6b0b-79da-476a-b725-e7d879072896.png)

### ❌ Actual result

Focus moves to the main button:

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10883184/181234566-abbd8669-578b-4dba-994d-e5db0f7dcb36.png)

### ❓ Possible solution

AFAICS, the `closeDropdown()` function always focuses the dropdown's `buttonView`. For splitbuttons like highlight we should override this behaviour.

## 📃 Other details

*   Browser: any
*   OS: any
*   First affected CKEditor version: dev version of `35.0.0` - 68118a2
*   Installed CKEditor plugins: any with splitbutton.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The Esc key does not return focus to the splitbutton’s arrow (dropdown trigger) as expected; instead, focus moves to the main button. This mis‑directed focus hinders keyboard‑only users from continuing to interact with the splitbutton’s options and may disrupt efficient keyboard navigation.
models.acr_note: The Esc key does not return focus to the splitbutton’s arrow (dropdown trigger) as expected; instead, focus moves to the main button. This mis‑directed focus hinders keyboard‑only users from continuing to interact with the splitbutton’s options and may disrupt efficient keyboard navigation.
models.thread_tldr: In a splitbutton component, pressing Esc incorrectly moves focus to the main button instead of the dropdown arrow, which is the expected behavior. The issue was filed by mmotyczynska and no further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: The CKEditor splitbutton component fails to return focus to the dropdown arrow when the Esc key is pressed after opening the dropdown. Instead, focus moves to the main button, disrupting the expected keyboard navigation flow for users relying on focus order.
models.thread_timeline: #1 mmotyczynska: Filed initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: In Safari, clicking the Insert Media button twice causes the ClassicEditor toolbar—normally visible when a selection is made—to disappear. This unexpected loss of the toolbar removes the user’s access to formatting controls, disrupting workflow and causing confusion for both mouse‑ and keyboard‑only users.
models.acr_note: In Safari, clicking the Insert Media button twice causes the ClassicEditor toolbar—normally visible when a selection is made—to disappear. This unexpected loss of the toolbar removes the user’s access to formatting controls, disrupting workflow and causing confusion for both mouse‑ and keyboard‑only users.
models.thread_tldr: In Safari, the CKEditor Classic Editor toolbar disappears after a user opens and then closes the media embed dropdown with the mouse. The issue has been reported once and only one comment has been made; no resolution or further discussion is present.
models.thread_problem: The reported barrier is that, when using Safari, selecting text in the Classic Editor and clicking the Insert Media button twice (to open and then close the dropdown) causes the toolbar—which should remain visible—to hide. This inconsistent visibility can hinder users who rely on the toolbar for contextual actions and may affect accessibility, though the issue description does not explicitly cite a WCAG 2.2 Level AA success criterion.

models.thread_links: None.

title: Mark grid UI components with semantical markup
context:
So far we have handled only keyboard interaction for grids in #11851 but in order to make grids accessible we also need to provide proper semantic annotation for it.

Most importantly user needs to have semantic information that this is a two dimensional widget (columns and rows).

We need to ensure that all grid components already existing in the editor gets this improvement.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.
description:
So far we have handled only keyboard interaction for grids in #11851 but in order to make grids accessible we also need to provide proper semantic annotation for it.

Most importantly user needs to have semantic information that this is a two dimensional widget (columns and rows).

We need to ensure that all grid components already existing in the editor gets this improvement.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The current grid components lack semantic markup, so assistive technology users cannot identify the widget as a two‑dimensional grid or discern its rows and columns. This prevents effective navigation, orientation, and interaction for screen‑reader users and others who rely on programmatic identification of content structure.
models.acr_note: The current grid components lack semantic markup, so assistive technology users cannot identify the widget as a two‑dimensional grid or discern its rows and columns. This prevents effective navigation, orientation, and interaction for screen‑reader users and others who rely on programmatic identification of content structure.
models.thread_tldr: The issue highlights that grid UI components in the editor lack proper semantic markup, preventing assistive technologies from conveying the two‑dimensional structure. Three contributors discuss potential solutions, but no resolution has been recorded and the thread remains open.
models.thread_problem: Grid components are currently implemented with only custom keyboard handling and no semantic markup (e.g., ARIA roles or attributes). As a result, screen‑reader users cannot perceive the widget as a two‑dimensional grid, violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships) which requires that information, structure, and relationships be made available to users of assistive technologies.
models.thread_timeline: #1 mlewand: Filed the initial accessibility report and began research on suitable markup for grid components. #2 Comandeer: Discussed dynamic row handling issues and proposed an `aria‑owns`‑based solution that works across NVDA, VoiceOver, and JAWS. #3 jmegginson: Highlighted that arrow‑key navigation for special character buttons does not convey navigability to screen‑reader users and referenced an extended ARIA grid role approach.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 – Info and Relationships](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#info-and-relationships): Relevance to providing semantic structure. - [ARIA Grid Role – W3C](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.2/#grid): Reference for the grid role and related attributes. - [MDN – Using the `aria-owns` attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/ARIA_Techniques/Using_the_aria-owns_attribute): Example of dynamic row handling approach discussed.

models.text: Users of NVDA are not notified when the balloon toolbar appears after selecting text, preventing them from discovering available toolbar functions and keyboard shortcuts, which hinders efficient interaction.
models.acr_note: Users of NVDA are not notified when the balloon toolbar appears after selecting text, preventing them from discovering available toolbar functions and keyboard shortcuts, which hinders efficient interaction.
models.thread_tldr: NVDA does not announce the activation of the balloon toolbar in Chrome on Windows, preventing screen‑reader users from learning that the toolbar is present or how to access it via keyboard. The issue was reported with reproduction steps, but only a single follow‑up comment exists and no fix or resolution is documented.
models.thread_problem: When text is selected in Chrome while NVDA is active, the balloon toolbar appears but NVDA fails to announce the toolbar’s presence or provide information on the keyboard shortcuts needed to interact with it. This lack of notification for dynamic content likely violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value) for identifying changes in the user interface.
models.thread_timeline: #1 tony1377: Asked about turnaround for the issue. No further discussion recorded.

title: Behaviour of arrow keys in color pickers.
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. visit eg. full featured editor
2. Click either `Font Color` button or `Font Background Color` button
3. Use arrow keys

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69513154/186437972-4ba75fe7-4418-4c84-959d-8a3a2e40e892.png)

### ✔️ Expected result

Expected behaviour in this case is up to debate.

### ❌ Actual result

- `→` and `↓` do nothing
- `←` exits back to the toolbar
- `↑` puts the focus on the black tile, and then the color grid can be traversed
  - in case that `Document colors` section is present, the focus is put on a tile there instead

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.
description:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. visit eg. full featured editor
2. Click either `Font Color` button or `Font Background Color` button
3. Use arrow keys

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69513154/186437972-4ba75fe7-4418-4c84-959d-8a3a2e40e892.png)

### ✔️ Expected result

Expected behaviour in this case is up to debate.

### ❌ Actual result

- `→` and `↓` do nothing
- `←` exits back to the toolbar
- `↑` puts the focus on the black tile, and then the color grid can be traversed
  - in case that `Document colors` section is present, the focus is put on a tile there instead

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Users who rely on keyboard navigation cannot move within the color picker using the arrow keys, which hinders their ability to select colors efficiently. The current behavior (left key exits the picker, up key only sets focus on a single tile, and right/down keys are ignored) creates an accessibility barrier for keyboard‑only users and users of assistive technologies that emulate keyboard input.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on keyboard navigation cannot move within the color picker using the arrow keys, which hinders their ability to select colors efficiently. The current behavior (left key exits the picker, up key only sets focus on a single tile, and right/down keys are ignored) creates an accessibility barrier for keyboard‑only users and users of assistive technologies that emulate keyboard input.
models.thread_tldr: An accessibility report documents that arrow keys in a color picker behave inconsistently (left key exits the toolbar, up key jumps to a tile). No follow‑up discussion or resolution has been recorded, and the platform source cannot be confirmed from the provided data, so links to comments cannot be generated.
models.thread_problem: The arrow keys fail to provide expected keyboard navigation within the color picker grid, preventing users from moving focus between color swatches using the keyboard. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.4 (Keyboard focus order) by restricting keyboard access to component controls.
models.thread_timeline: #1 mlewand: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The link toolbar cannot be reached or activated using the keyboard, preventing users who rely on keyboard navigation (e.g., screen reader users, users with motor impairments) from accessing the toolbar’s link actions.
models.acr_note: The link toolbar cannot be reached or activated using the keyboard, preventing users who rely on keyboard navigation (e.g., screen reader users, users with motor impairments) from accessing the toolbar’s link actions.
models.thread_tldr: The link toolbar in the editor cannot be opened or interacted with using only the keyboard, creating a barrier for keyboard‑only users. Discussion has focused on whether to expose the toolbar via a hotkey, but no solution has been implemented or confirmed. Status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The link toolbar (link balloon) is not reachable via keyboard; keyboard users cannot open the toolbar, edit the link URL, or access the editing controls. This violates WCAG 2.2 Level AA success criterion 2.1.1 Keyboard (operation must be operable via keyboard) and 2.5.1 Pointer and Keyboard Focus (focus must be managed to allow keyboard access).
models.thread_timeline: #1 oleq: Filed initial accessibility report and described the missing keyboard interaction for the link toolbar. #2 Acrophost: Explained that the toolbar appears only after a click and that keyboard navigation does not trigger it. #3 oleq: Suggested using Ctrl+K to open the toolbar and asked for feedback. #4 Reinmar: Agreed on the observation and questioned whether other contextual panels should follow the same pattern. #5 oleq: Discussed the hybrid nature of the balloon and whether it should be treated as a toolbar. #6 Comandeer: Supported the idea of treating all balloon toolbars uniformly and questioned inconsistent key handling. #7 mlewand: Proposed using Alt+F10 as a universal hotkey to focus the link balloon.
models.thread_links: - [Link toolbar video](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/66953380/186476300-c6c629ff-6c32-4810-8244-214a4721b615.mov): Demonstrates that the link toolbar cannot be opened via keyboard.

models.text: Users navigating the todo list with a keyboard cannot discover that the checkbox can be toggled using the Ctrl + Enter shortcut, which hinders task completion and causes frustration for keyboard‑only users.
models.acr_note: Users navigating the todo list with a keyboard cannot discover that the checkbox can be toggled using the Ctrl + Enter shortcut, which hinders task completion and causes frustration for keyboard‑only users.
models.dev_note: Use native form markup: wrap each task in a `<li>` inside a `<ul>`, and provide a `<label>` for the `<input type="checkbox">`. Add a visible hint or description next to the checkbox, such as “Complete (Ctrl+Enter)”, or reference the shortcut via `aria-describedby` if the text is too long. Ensure the checkbox is focusable and activatable with the Space key (the native method); add a keydown handler for Ctrl+Enter only if you implement a custom component. Keep markup semantic; apply ARIA only when native semantics are insufficient. Refer to WCAG 2.2 3.3.2 for required labels/instructions and the WAI‑ARIA 1.2 guidance on `aria-describedby`.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that todo lists do not display the keyboard shortcut (Ctrl + Enter) for selecting checkboxes, creating a barrier for keyboard users. No further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: Todo lists lack clear information on the keyboard shortcut required to toggle checkboxes, making it difficult for users who rely on keyboard navigation to interact with the list. This lack of discoverability violates WCAG 2.2 Level AA Success Criterion 2.1.1 (Keyboard).
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

title: Table toolbar can't be focused by keyboard when nested image is selected
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1.  Go to https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/examples/builds-custom/full-featured-editor.html.
2.  Insert image into a table.
3.  Put selection **inside the table**.
4.  Select the image.
5.  Press `alt/option+F10` multiple times.

### ✔️ Expected result

Focus moved between image toolbar, table toolbar and editor toolbar.

### ❌ Actual result

Table toolbar is out of the chain and can't be focused. It appears though when focus is in the editor toolbar.

## 📃 Other details

What can be even more interesting, if in step 3. you put selection **outside the table** and select an image then, all three toolbars are accessible. See the recording.

![toolbarswitching](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10883184/188084585-92a8319f-16ae-4f59-a46c-8517732eb7da.gif)

*   Browser: any
*   OS: any
*   First affected CKEditor version: 35.1.0
*   Installed CKEditor plugins:

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: When a user places the cursor inside a table, selects an image within that table, and then uses the keyboard shortcut `alt/option+F10` to cycle through available toolbars, the table toolbar does not receive focus. This omission means keyboard‑only users cannot access the table toolbar, limiting their ability to manipulate the table. The editor toolbar and image toolbar are reachable, so the issue is a focused navigation barrier.
models.acr_note: When a user places the cursor inside a table, selects an image within that table, and then uses the keyboard shortcut `alt/option+F10` to cycle through available toolbars, the table toolbar does not receive focus. This omission means keyboard‑only users cannot access the table toolbar, limiting their ability to manipulate the table. The editor toolbar and image toolbar are reachable, so the issue is a focused navigation barrier.
models.thread_tldr: The reported barrier prevents keyboard focus from reaching the table toolbar when an image inside a table is selected, breaking expected focus navigation between toolbars. No resolution or follow‑up has been documented; the issue remains unaddressed as of the last available comment.
models.thread_problem: In CKEditor 5, when the selection is inside a table that contains an image and the user activates the image toolbar (e.g., via Alt + F10), the table toolbar is omitted from the focus order. As a result, keyboard users cannot move focus to it, violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 1.1.1 (Content must be operable by keyboard), 2.1.1 (Keyboard Accessible), and 2.4.7 (Focus Visible).
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. No further discussion recorded.

title: List styles buttons should use the `aria-pressed` attribute
context:

Currently, our buttons for the list styles don't use the `aria-pressed` attribute, depending on the button state. It should be added to improve the accessibility of this feature.

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.thread_problem: Buttons used to switch list styles do not expose their toggle state via the `aria‑pressed` attribute. Without this attribute, screen‑reader users and other assistive‑technology users cannot reliably perceive whether a particular list style is active, potentially violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria that require perceivable state information for UI components.

title: Balloon rotators UX is confusing
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Take for instance this situation

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1099479/192230840-a88db437-de05-4628-bce7-672e7a950648.png)

Is the "1 of 2" rotator about moving between different annotations (document navigation)? Or is it about moving between totally different features in the context of the same selection (table vs unknown feature)?

The latter (which is table \<-> comments BTW) is correct but it does not change the fact that unless you click it, you'll never learn what is what. And you may not want to click it because you fear that it will move you to an annotation far way in the document or something. 

We need to rethink this UX. We could have tabs there that would clearly say what options are available. Or we could have better labels. I'm pretty sure there's a room for improvement there.

Edit: As a side thought, I suppose the a11y of this solution is also totally broken. 

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The “1 of 2” rotator is unclear to users. It is not obvious whether the control navigates between annotations or toggles between different feature panels (e.g., table vs comments). This ambiguity can prevent users—especially those relying on keyboard or screen readers—from understanding the control’s purpose or predicting the result of activating it, potentially leading to confusion or accidental navigation.

models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that the balloon rotator UI element is confusing, as it is unclear whether it controls annotation navigation or feature switching, and users cannot discover its purpose without interacting. No follow‑up discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: The rotator lacks clear accessible labels and instructions, making it ambiguous whether it switches between document annotations or between different feature contexts (e.g., table vs comments). This uncertainty can cause users to unintentionally navigate to unrelated document locations and prevents them from reliably interacting with the UI. The barrier likely violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 3.3.1 (Info & Relationships) and 3.3.2 (Labels & Instructions).

models.thread_problem: The visual focus indicator obscures adjacent text (“Start at” label), which may impair keyboard‑navigating users’ ability to perceive the label clearly. This visual conflict could contravene WCAG 2.2 Level AA criteria that require clear focus visibility and unobstructed content.

title: JAWS doesn't recognize the image at the end of the document
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1.  Hit the Enter key and type in some dummy text and then insert an image.
2.  Start JAWS and tab through the elements until focus reaches the editor content.
3.  Use the arrow down key and JAWS will read the first line of text.
4.  Arrow down key will now position at the end and read ‘blank’ .
5.  Hit arrow down again to reach the image and it reads ‘ed’

### ✔️ Expected result

Have an announcement that we reached an image, reads out the properties and that a toolbar is available.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The issue concerns keyboard navigation order. When a `<textarea>` with a custom `tabindex` is replaced by the editor, the `tabindex` value is lost. This can alter the expected tabbing sequence for keyboard‑only users, leading to confusion and potentially causing the editor to receive focus unexpectedly. The barrier is the loss of a user‑defined focus order, impacting the usability of forms and page navigation.
models.acr_note: The issue concerns keyboard navigation order. When a `<textarea>` with a custom `tabindex` is replaced by the editor, the `tabindex` value is lost. This can alter the expected tabbing sequence for keyboard‑only users, leading to confusion and potentially causing the editor to receive focus unexpectedly. The barrier is the loss of a user‑defined focus order, impacting the usability of forms and page navigation.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that initializing CKEditor on a `<textarea>` does not preserve the element’s `tabindex` attribute, which can disturb keyboard focus order. Only the initial report is visible; no further discussion or resolution is recorded.
models.thread_problem: When CKEditor is instantiated on a `<textarea>`, the existing `tabindex` value is dropped. This loss can interfere with logical focus sequencing for keyboard‑only users, thereby presenting a potential barrier to keyboard navigation.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. No further discussion recorded.

title: Consider using Listbox pattern for dropdowns
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

This improvement is about considering using the [Listbox pattern](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/listbox/) for dropdown buttons, e.g. "Text alignment", "Font family", "Font size" and "Font color" in the toolbar.

Things to consider:

*   Follow the semantics and interactions recommended in the ARIA Listbox pattern. 
    *   For example, for a listbox that functions similarly to a native \<select> element, the Collapsible Dropdown Listbox Example would be the best choice, which uses a \<button> element to trigger a popup listbox element.
*   On the triggering button element: 
    *   Ensure that the element has an id. 
    *   Add an aria-haspopup="listbox" attribute. 
    *   Add an aria-labelledby attribute which references a visible label before the button, and the button itself; this will announce the control label and then the current value. 
    *   Ensure that the \<button> element has an aria-expanded attribute set to "true" when the pop-up is displayed
*   On the list of options: Add a role="listbox" attribute. Add an aria-labelledby attribute, referencing the visible label. Add a role="option" attribute to each option within the listbox.

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

Things to consider:

*   Follow the semantics and interactions recommended in the ARIA Listbox pattern. 
    *   For example, for a listbox that functions similarly to a native \<select> element, the Collapsible Dropdown Listbox Example would be the best choice, which uses a \<button> element to trigger a popup listbox element.
*   On the triggering button element: 
    *   Ensure that the element has an id. 
    *   Add an aria-haspopup="listbox" attribute. 
    *   Add an aria-labelledby attribute which references a visible label before the button, and the button itself; this will announce the control label and then the current value. 
    *   Ensure that the \<button> element has an aria-expanded attribute set to "true" when the pop-up is displayed
*   On the list of options: Add a role="listbox" attribute. Add an aria-labelledby attribute, referencing the visible label. Add a role="option" attribute to each option within the listbox.

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

title: Improve the accessibility of the Heading plugin
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

We received a report regarding an accessibility issue with how the Heading plugin deals with labeling the different types of headings. This can cause confusion when using a screen reader. Customer's report available below:

>  We are looking at the heading plugin and it's labelling. At the moment the toolbar item is labelled by the currently selected option only, meaning it doesn't provide context for the menu itself, e.g. screen readers read out "Paragraph menu button collapsed sub menu" but doesn't notify the user that the dropdown selector is for heading levels. This can cause confusion to users.
> 
> Something like “Heading level collapsed sub menu” – > “Heading 2 menu button selected” , would make it easier for users to understand the menu they are on, what it does and the selection that is currently active. This would then meet the WCAG AA success criterion 2.4.6 Headings and labels. - Headings and labels provide topic or purpose.

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

This failure to convey the purpose and current selection of the control contravenes WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.4.6 (Headings and Labels).

title: Implement best practices from A11yFirst
context:
## Build good accessibility defaults

A11yFirst has done a good job highlighting how CKEditor could be built more accessibly. Including elements like:
- User guidance on headings
- Support for Language of Parts
- Show blocks (structural elements) & xpath like display
- Accessible tables (headings/caption/summary)
- Support for decorative, informative & complex images
- Separating block structures vs formatting structures
- A11yFirst Help
- Maybe more...  A lot of thought went into this package.

As the [We4Authors Cluster](https://accessibilitycluster.com/) highlighted, many accessibility issues are caused by giving the author more authority than they perhaps require. 

### ✔️ Expected result

- All [demos of CKEditor 5](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/) don't need to include accessibility, but there should be one that does.
- The default install should be set up for accessibility best practices. Most website builders will just use the default, whatever it is -- so make it inclusive by default.
- Setup the [Internationalization Demo ](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/internationalization/)to support the [Language of Parts](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/language-of-parts.html) - good internationalization support isn't just one of many languages, but many combinations of many languages. CKEditor can do this, [so show it](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/language.html#demo).
- Provide support for either [axe](https://github.com/dequelabs/axe-core), or [Editoria11y](https://editoria11y.princeton.edu/2021/03/introducing-editoria11y/) or [Sa11y](https://sa11y.netlify.app/) directly.

### ❌ Actual result

- Well, there aren't a lot of accessibility best practices baked into the demos. 
- There seems to be [support for Abbreviations](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/framework/plugins/abbreviation-plugin/abbreviation-plugin-level-3.html), but not a lot of documentation about that
- [Not sure what this is about ](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/spelling-and-grammar-checking.html#accessibility)"The spell and grammar check is compliant with WCAG 2.1 and Section 508 accessibility standards." 
- "CKEditor 5 provides support for alternate image text" but [what is the default](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/images/images-text-alternative.html#additional-feature-information)? What about decorative, informative or complex images?
- There's talk of using [CKEditor 5 plugins](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/installation/plugins/plugins.html#common-use-cases) to "Adding semantic value to the content, like annotations or accessibility features." but where are they?
- Thanks for catching the [color contrast issues](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/updating/guides/update-to-35.html#changes-to-the-color-palette-in-the-ui) in the interface "In this release, several changes were made to improve the accessibility and overall contrast of the UI."

### ❓ Possible solution

- There is a great example to build on using CKEditor 4 plugins. Use it.
- Focus on making the defaults accessible and it will benefit everyone
- Check for accessibility early in the development process
- Look for ways to be a best practice authoring tool that is following ATAG 2.0 & following the guidance in the We4Authors Cluster study.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

### ❓ Possible solution

- There is a great example to build on using CKEditor 4 plugins. Use it.
- Focus on making the defaults accessible and it will benefit everyone
- Check for accessibility early in the development process
- Look for ways to be a best practice authoring tool that is following ATAG 2.0 & following the guidance in the We4Authors Cluster study.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

title: Keyboard only bug report
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

[[How to make CKEditor 5 usable without a mouse (for accessibility)?](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/72027613/how-to-make-ckeditor-5-usable-without-a-mouse-for-accessibility)](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/72027613/how-to-make-ckeditor-5-usable-without-a-mouse-for-accessibility)

This isn't a good answer:
"Found an answer: Left Alt + F10 is widely used by visually impaired and can be used to focus the toolbar."

There is no reason why someone using a sip/puff, keyboard or screen reader shouldn't need to use this. 

Someone shouldn't have to press Shift + F10 to get Windows to show the context menu.

### ✔️ Expected result

Users should be abler to tab to the authoring interface without using a mouse or keyboard shortcuts.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

title: Keyboard users can't get to action buttons ("Edit source", "Save changes" or "Cancel") from HTML snippet
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)
1. Insert an HTML snippet and type some content
2. Try to reach the "Save changes" or "Cancel" button using the keyboard

### ✔️ Expected result
I expected to be able to move focus into the snippet widget sidebar using a keyboard shortcut. I figured out that `Alt+F10` (or `Option+F10` on Mac) allows a user who is focused on an image widget to enter the image toolbar. I expected this to be the case for the HTML snippet as well. 

That, or hitting `Tab` - but that seems less likely inside an HTML editor since you might expect to be able to indent your code using tab.

### ❌ Actual result

#### Tab key
Moves focus to the next widget in the focus order

#### Toolbar shortcut (`Alt+F10`)
Moves keyboard focus into the main toolbar, not the HTML snippet sidebar

#### Arrow keys
Only moves the cursor inside the snippet editing area

### ❓ Possible solution
Extend the "Enter toolbar" shortcut to include the snippet editor, or include the toolbar buttons in the focus order.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Firefox
* OS: Mac

models.text: Keyboard users are unable to reach the “Edit source”, “Save changes” or “Cancel” buttons within the HTML snippet editor sidebar. Because those buttons are not in the tab order and the Alt+F10 shortcut targets the main toolbar instead of the snippet toolbar, keyboard users cannot perform the necessary actions to edit, save, or cancel changes. This limits keyboard‑only interaction with the widget.

models.thread_tldr: Keyboard users cannot reach the action buttons (Edit source, Save changes, Cancel) of the HTML snippet editor. The issue was filed on GitHub and no subsequent discussion or resolution has been posted, so the status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: Keyboard users cannot access the HTML snippet editor’s action buttons. The Alt + F10 shortcut focuses the main toolbar instead of the snippet sidebar, Tab jumps to the next widget, and arrow keys only navigate within the code editor. This omission prevents keyboard navigation to the snippet’s controls, violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.1.1 (Keyboard Accessible).

title: For accessibility purposes, can table header rows be added by default when you add a table?
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the new feature

_What is the expected behavior of the proposed feature?_

--- This feature would make it so that when a user inserts a table, the table automatically has a header row, which is required for [WCAG 2.0 compliance](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/F91.html). 

We'd like to see this feature added because we have hundreds of editors who create and edit pages using ckeditor. Although we train these users on accessibility rules, unless table headers are added automatically they will almost never remember to add them.

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The current behavior of CKEditor does not insert a header row when a table is created, leaving tables comprised solely of `<tr>` rows with `<td>` cells. Without a header row and proper `<th>` elements, assistive technologies cannot establish column or row relationships, making the table’s content difficult or impossible to interpret for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive devices.
models.acr_note: The current behavior of CKEditor does not insert a header row when a table is created, leaving tables comprised solely of `<tr>` rows with `<td>` cells. Without a header row and proper `<th>` elements, assistive technologies cannot establish column or row relationships, making the table’s content difficult or impossible to interpret for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive devices.
models.thread_tldr: This issue proposes adding a default header row when inserting a table to meet WCAG 2.0 accessibility requirements. The thread contains only the initial report and no subsequent discussion, so the current status is unresolved.
models.thread_problem: When a user inserts a table, the resulting table lacks a header row, preventing the table from satisfying WCAG 2.0 Technique F91 for accessible tables. Without header cells, screen‑reading technology cannot convey column relationships, making it difficult for users with visual impairments to interpret the table.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.0 Technique F91](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/F91.html): Technique for ensuring tables have header rows for accessibility.

title: Unable to focus the table toolbar when an image is inserted into a table cell
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Create a table that consist of a single cell
2. Insert an image into the cell
3. Try to access the table toolbar

### ✔️ Expected result

You should be able to focus the table toolbar and change the options available there.

### ❌ Actual result

You can only focus the image toolbar:

![image](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/72079603/21ff952d-c202-47e7-8aae-fa140c1fba14)

You can switch the focus to the table toolbar with the `Alt + F10` (for Windows) or `Option + F10` (for macOS) keyboard shortcut but not by using the mouse.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: cross-browser
* OS: cross-OS
* First affected CKEditor version: N/A
* Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.
