models.text: Users of assistive technologies are unable to obtain a full, semantically linked description of complex images (e.g., charts, diagrams) because the platform does not expose a mechanism equivalent to the legacy `longdesc` attribute. This limits understanding of the image content for visually impaired users.
models.acr_note: Users of assistive technologies are unable to obtain a full, semantically linked description of complex images (e.g., charts, diagrams) because the platform does not expose a mechanism equivalent to the legacy `longdesc` attribute. This limits understanding of the image content for visually impaired users.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that the HTML5 longdesc attribute is no longer supported and requests support for providing extended image descriptions via aria‑describedby. Only the original reporter posted two comments, offering links to discussion and patterns, but no other participants or resolution appear. The status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The barrier is that complex images lack a mechanism to associate longer, semantically tied descriptive text, making it difficult for users relying on assistive technology to obtain full context. This impedes compliance with WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 1.1.1 (non‑text content), 1.3.1 (info and relationships), and 1.3.4 (meaningful sequence).
models.thread_timeline: #1 mgifford: Filed the initial accessibility report and cited a W3C discussion showing that the HTML 5 attribute longdesc isn’t supported. #2 mgifford: Proposed using aria‑describedby and referenced a pattern from A11yfirst that provides a solution for long descriptions.
models.thread_links: - [W3C HTML longdesc discussion](https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-admin/2014Aug/0028.html): Explanation of why longdesc is no longer supported in HTML5. - [Cookiecrook longdesc details](https://cookiecrook.com/longdesc/details/): Example of using aria‑describedby for extended image descriptions. - [Drupal issue 3050928](https://www.drupal.org/project/drupal/issues/3050928): Related discussion on providing long descriptions for complex images.

title: CKEditor 5 Mangles Table Structure and Makes Tables Inaccessible / Support for Tables with Multi-Level Headers / Allow <tbody> <th> in any column
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any) 1. Paste the HTML from tables 1, 2, 3, and 4 (below) into source view of the [reference implementation of CKEditor](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/html-support/). 2. Switch out of source view and back into it. ### Table 1 This table has a rowgroup header with a colspan. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Row Header 1 Data 1,1 Data 2,1
``` ### Table 2 This table has two rowgroup headers that have colspans. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Row Header 1 Data 1,1 Data 2,1
Rowgroup Header 2
Row Header 2 Data 1,2 Data 2,2
Row Header 3 Data 1,3 Data 2,3
``` ### Table 3 Similar to previous examples, but we've removed the colspan on the rowgroup and replaced with empty td elements. We've also added some row headers to the second column and a tbody block that doesn't have any th with a scope set to rowgroup. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Row Header 1 Row Subheader 1 Data 1,1
Row Header 2 Row Subheader 2 Data 1,2
Row Header 3 Row Subheader 3 Data 1,3
Rowgroup Header 2
Row Header 4 Row Subheader 4 Data 1,4
``` ### Table 4 This table is an [example from the HTML spec](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/html-support/). ```
2008 2007 2006
Research and development $ 1,109 $ 782 $ 712
Percentage of net sales 3.4% 3.3% 3.7%
Selling, general, and administrative $ 3,761 $ 2,963 $ 2,433
Percentage of net sales 11.6% 12.3% 12.6%
``` ### ✔️ Expected result CKEditor does not alter the table markup. ### ❌ Actual result #### Table 1 CKEditor has moved the parent row for "Rowgroup Header 1" into the thead element, which makes the table inaccessible to screen readers. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Row Header 1 Data 1,1 Data 2,1
``` #### Table 2 CKEditor has moved all the parent rows for rowgroup headers into the thead element. It has also put all the rows after the thead block into one tbody block. This makes the table inaccessible to screen readers and is a loss of data, since we can no longer reconstruct the original table due to loss of the tbody blocks. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Rowgroup Header 2
Row Header 1 Data 1,1 Data 2,1
Row Header 2 Data 1,2 Data 2,2
Row Header 3 Data 1,3 Data 2,3
``` #### Table 3 CKEditor has not moved all the parent rows for rowgroup headers into the thead element, but has put all the rows after the thead block into one tbody block. This causes data loss, since we can no longer reconstruct the original table due to loss of the tbody blocks, and makes the table inaccessible to screen readers. CKEditor has also turned row headers in the second column to td elements with a scope attribute, which is invalid, and causes further accessibility issues. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1    
Row Header 1 Row Subheader 1 Data 1,1
Row Header 2 Row Subheader 2 Data 1,2
Row Header 3 Row Subheader 3 Data 1,3
Rowgroup Header 2    
Row Header 4 Row Subheader 4 Data 1,4
``` #### Table 4 CKEditor has added inline styles to col elements (strange), put all the rows after the thead block into one tbody block (again, potential data loss and makes the table inaccessible to screen readers). I'm not sure what the practical implications of this next quirk are, but I want to note it. CKEditor has added a non-breaking space character to an empty th tag. I don't think non-breaking spaces are [ASCII whitespace](https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#ascii-whitespace). This means that the header cell is non-empty and user agents (including screen readers) should add it to the header list for the cells beneath it, according to the [spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/tables.html#header-and-data-cell-semantics). ```
  2008 2007 2006
Research and development $ 1,109 $ 782 $ 712
Percentage of net sales 3.4% 3.3% 3.7%
Selling, general, and administrative $ 3,761 $ 2,963 $ 2,433
Percentage of net sales 11.6% 12.3% 12.6%
``` ### ❓ Possible solution Add some kind of data attribute that tells CKEditor to not parse the table. Or just follow the [table parsing algorithm from the HTML5 spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/tables.html#table-processing-model). ## 📃 Other details * Browser: Any * OS: Any * First affected CKEditor version: Unknown, but this is happening in the reference implementation. * Installed CKEditor plugins: None --- If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The editor rewrites table markup by moving header rows into the `<thead>`, collapsing multiple `<tbody>` elements into a single one, converting header cells with `scope="rowgroup"` into `<td>` elements, and inserting non‑breaking spaces into empty `<th>` cells. These changes break the table’s header associations, making it difficult or impossible for screen‑reader users to navigate the table or understand the hierarchical structure of row and column headers.
models.acr_note: The editor rewrites table markup by moving header rows into the `<thead>`, collapsing multiple `<tbody>` elements into a single one, converting header cells with `scope="rowgroup"` into `<td>` elements, and inserting non‑breaking spaces into empty `<th>` cells. These changes break the table’s header associations, making it difficult or impossible for screen‑reader users to navigate the table or understand the hierarchical structure of row and column headers.
models.thread_tldr: CKEditor 5 alters complex table markup by moving row‑group headers into `<thead>` and merging `<tbody>` blocks, which can cause data loss and make tables inaccessible to screen readers. The thread shows active collaboration among several contributors, but no resolution has been posted yet, and the issue remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: CKEditor 5 modifies the structural semantics of tables that contain multiple `<tbody>` sections, row‑group headers, and colspan attributes. The editor re‑orders header rows into `<thead>` and concatenates distinct `<tbody>` blocks into a single one, thereby destroying the original table hierarchy. This structural change breaks the intended relationship between header and data cells, violating WCAG 2.2 success criteria for table accessibility (e.g., SC 1.3.1 – Info & Relationships, SC 1.3.2 – Meaningful Sequence, and SC 1.3.3 – Sensory Characteristics).
models.thread_timeline: #1 Witoso: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 jameslpetersen: Discussed potential data loss due to merging `<tbody>` elements. #3 wimleers: Tracked the issue on drupal.org (issue 3384400). #4 ericgsmith: Expressed concern for clients with large numbers of complex tables. #5 Witoso: Requested additional review from colleague. #6 chrisgross: Highlighted that CKEditor’s own table creation lacks basic accessibility markup. #7 jameswilson: Noted that the bug disqualifies Drupal 10 with CKEditor 5 for a city government proposal (accessibility requirement 1194.22). #8 jameswilson: Clarified that CKEditor re‑orders header rows in `<tbody>` into `<thead>`. #9 dliwustl: Reported vendor experience with table mangling and unwanted padding. #10 wimleers: Commented on data loss implications. #11 Witoso: Reiterated concerns about auto‑padding preventing 100 % width tables. #12 Witoso: Shared a manual test branch with examples. #13 dliwustl: Echoed earlier concerns about auto‑padding. #14 A-Kun: Added observation that CKEditor’s own tables lack proper accessibility markup. #15 Mati365: Referenced related GitHub issues and a pull request affecting table parsing. #16 donquixote: Described a related bug involving `<th>` in the first column converting other cells to `<th>`. #17 olstjos: Argued that table cleanup should be opt‑in rather than opt‑out. #18 olstjos: Noted that disabling the `insertTable` plugin reduced table mangling. #19 ericgsmith: Re‑expressed the need for a priority fix and a clear understanding from the CKEditor team.
models.thread_links: - [HTML5 Table Processing Model](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/tables.html#table-processing-model): Specification for how browsers parse and construct table structures, relevant to diagnosing the CKEditor behavior. - [Drupal issue 3384400](https://www.drupal.org/project/drupal/issues/3384400): Tracks the same table‑handling problem within the Drupal community. - [CKEditor5 issue 3172 comment](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/3172#issuecomment-430926553): Related discussion about table parsing bugs. - [CKEditor5 issue 13609](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/13609): Another related table accessibility issue. - [CKEditor5 PR 13600](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/pull/13600/files#diff-828bca0c515d3787): Code changes that may affect table processing logic.

title: Keyboard support for AutocompleteView (and SearchTextView)
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

ATM the component shares keyboard support with `SearchTextView`. It's far from perfect because you have to tab first to get access to the list and to browse it. It's unlike any autocomplete out there in the industry. 

The component should have a persistent selection in the text field and up/down arrows selecting (but no focusing) filtered view's items and updating the value of the input. Check out your browser's URL input to get the idea.

This will require:
* Additional stuff in the `FilteredView` interface (for selecting but not turning on or focusing items).
* Keyboard interaction logic
* Undoing some existing focus cycling and tracking logic (I suppose filtered view's items should no longer be focusable).


---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

This creates a barrier for keyboard‑only users, preventing them from accessing and selecting suggestions without using a mouse.

models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that AutocompleteView (and SearchTextView) lack proper keyboard support, requiring tabbing into a list and manually browsing items. No follow‑up discussion or resolution is documented.
models.thread_problem: Users cannot use arrow keys to select and update the input in AutocompleteView/SearchTextView; the component requires tabbing to the list and manual navigation, which does not meet WCAG 2.2 Level AA requirements for keyboard operable interfaces (e.g., 1.1.1, 2.1.1) when an accessible interactive component is expected.

title: WCAG 2.0 2.1.1: Keyboard functionality: adding images
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

### Persona story 
This is fictitious to illustrate a problem. I work in a large organization creating content. Due to an injury, I have acquired hand-eye coordination impairment that means I cannot use the mouse to interact with computer content.  I rely on using the keyboard commands.

I would like to add an image to the CKEditor 5, then give it alt text.  The whole user task should be reviewed without reliance on a mouse.

The file browser link isn't keyboard accessible.

![image](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/8799391/f563f764-2975-4afb-ae5a-f2f937ef6d9d)

The add alt text control isn't accessible by keyboard

### ✔️ Expected result

Each step in the task of adding an image and giving it alt text should be possible using the keyboard only (WCAG 2.0 success criteria 2.1.1)


### ❌ Actual result

Can't complete the task

### ❓ Possible solution

_If you have ideas, you can list them here. Otherwise, you can delete this section._

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome
* OS: Windows 11
* First affected CKEditor version: 5
* Installed CKEditor plugins: ?

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

title: Enlarge the text alternative field
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

CKEditor 5 allows for editing alternative text by selecting an image, clicking the alternative text icon, and editing the content of the text alternative field. However, the visible text alternative field is quite small, about 35 characters. This requires the editor to keep what they have done in their head, increasing cognitive load, if they have anything that is longer. I believe a visible field length of perhaps 127 characters would be more reasonable, and it would be even better for the field to expand to fit the entire text alternative content.

Steps:
1. In the CKEditor, select an image (for example, on the [CKEditor 5 demo](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/html-support/), click the red 5 shield.
2. Click the text alternative icon

Expected result: the field is wide (or wide and tall) enough to be able to view a significant amount of text without having to scroll, or better yet, the entire contents of the all of the text alternative field.

Actual result: the field is wide enough to be able to view only about 35 characters, which can be insufficient for a sufficiently complex image. If the text alternative is longer than that, there is no way for the editor to view the entire alternative text at once.

![image](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/3281090/1cc4213e-f7e7-43f0-a0ef-26b3f6d67a11)

While 35 characters may be sufficient to describe the red 5 shield, it is inadequate for an image such as the following:

![image](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/3281090/0e4e06a5-ec71-4299-944d-832cb4b6ddc6)

for which the text alternative is:

> Two images. One shows the rear interior of a Muni bus with yellow poles and blue seats. Above the seats, a four digit bus number "6553" is circled in red. The second image shows the front of the bus. Above the headlight, the number “6553” is also circled in red.


## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Firefox 119.0
* OS: macOS 14.1
* CKEditor version: Whatever is in the demo
* Installed CKEditor plugins: Whatever is in the demo

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

title: Text created with speech-to-text software doesn't appear in the editable / Dragon STT support
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open the editor in v35.3.0 or later
2. Try to input some text into the editable with a speech-to-text tool. I used [this Chrome extension](https://chromewebstore.google.com/detail/voice-in-speech-to-text-d/pjnefijmagpdjfhhkpljicbbpicelgko) for my testing. 

### ✔️ Expected result

The text that was converted from speech should appear in the editable, as is the case in v35.2.1:

https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/72079603/8cf6dc31-4efd-4843-916c-d8c535bdaec1

### ❌ Actual result

No text appears in the editable:

https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/72079603/4f09aea1-e2d3-4da2-af0e-f974c31ff823

### ❓ Possible solution

It's possible that the issue is related to the `beforeInput` change introduced in v35.3.0.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: cross-browser
* OS: cross-OS
* First affected CKEditor version: 35.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The screen‑reader accessible name announced for the CKEditor instance differs from the visible label text shown on the page, causing confusion for users who rely on assistive technology and violating consistent naming expectations.
models.acr_note: The screen‑reader accessible name announced for the CKEditor instance differs from the visible label text shown on the page, causing confusion for users who rely on assistive technology and violating consistent naming expectations.
models.thread_tldr: An CKEditor5 dropdown’s accessible name (set via `aria-label`) incorrectly reads “Heading” while the visible label displays the selected style, violating WCAG 2.2. The issue was reported and briefly discussed by two contributors, but no fix or further updates appear in the thread, leaving the problem unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The accessible name of a CKEditor5 dropdown menu is set via the `aria-label` attribute to the static value “Heading”, which does not match or contain the visible label text that reflects the currently selected style. This mismatch violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.5.3 “Label in name”, which requires the accessible name to reflect the visible label.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Witoso: Asked for thoughts on the issue. #2 Comandeer: Explained the failure of WCAG 2.5.3 and noted that the accessible name is set via `aria-label` to “Heading” while the visible label shows the selected style.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.5.3 Label in name](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#label-in-name): Success criterion stating that the accessible name must reflect the visible label.

title: A11y dialog - provide better sorting/categorization for the presented keystrokes
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Accessibility dialog makes it possible to organize various keystrokes into categories. Features can define new categories or add to existing categories.

Inside the category, the accessibility dialog presents the registered keystrokes using an alphabetic order. This isn't the best solution, as shortcuts from one group are mixed with completely different shortcuts:

![image](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/1502228/50079928-8687-409e-8b85-880f3c9a1341)

See how bold and italic are mixed with different shortcuts.

I propose to solve it in one of two ways (maybe both?):

1. Provide more categories. Similarly to tables, if there are multiple keystrokes related to one set of features (e.g. text formatting) they can be together. Inside categories we can sort by the order the keystroke was registered, as plugins groups are usually registered one after another, or...
2. Add ordering inside a category through our favourite magic numbers (i.e. `order: 1003` etc.). This will be more difficult for 3rd party developers to manage but gives us more flexibility. If we don't have ordering we may end up having multiple categories, or still have the same problem on a smaller scale.

Accessibility dialog makes it possible to organize various keystrokes into categories. Features can define new categories or add to existing categories.

Inside the category, the accessibility dialog presents the registered keystrokes using an alphabetic order. This isn't the best solution, as shortcuts from one group are mixed with completely different shortcuts:

![image](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/1502228/50079928-8687-409e-8b85-880f3c9a1341)

See how bold and italic are mixed with different shortcuts.

I propose to solve it in one of two ways (maybe both?):

1. Provide more categories. Similarly to tables, if there are multiple keystrokes related to one set of features (e.g. text formatting) they can be together. Inside categories we can sort by the order the keystroke was registered, as plugins groups are usually registered one after another, or...
2. Add ordering inside a category through our favourite magic numbers (i.e. `order: 1003` etc.). This will be more difficult for 3rd party developers to manage but gives us more flexibility. If we don't have ordering we may end up having multiple categories, or still have the same problem on a smaller scale.

title: `figure` and `figcaption` aria improvements in tables
context:
> side question what about `table > caption`? It looks like another choice do describe table.

There are [several techniques for describing `table`](https://www.w3.org/TR/html5/tabular-data.html#sec-techniques-for-describing-tables). In our case we use `figcaption` as also the mean to describe the whole `figure` element. Probably it would be nice to additionally bind `figcaption` with `table` using `[aria-labelledby]`/`[aria-describedby]`.

_Originally posted by @Comandeer in https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/3194#issuecomment-397245583_

Rel: https://www.w3.org/WAI/tutorials/tables/caption-summary/
description:
> side question what about `table > caption`? It looks like another choice do describe table.

There are [several techniques for describing `table`](https://www.w3.org/TR/html5/tabular-data.html#sec-techniques-for-describing-tables). In our case we use `figcaption` as also the mean to describe the whole `figure` element. Probably it would be nice to additionally bind `figcaption` with `table` using `[aria-labelledby]`/`[aria-describedby]`.

_Originally posted by @Comandeer in https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/3194#issuecomment-397245583_

Rel: https://www.w3.org/WAI/tutorials/tables/caption-summary/

models.thread_problem: When a table is placed inside a `figure`, the table may lack an accessible label that conveys its purpose to assistive technology. Adding a `figcaption` and binding it to the table with ARIA attributes would provide a descriptive label, supporting WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.4 (Info and Relationships) for tabular data.

models.text: The reported issue identifies a missing tooltip on the 'Insert' and 'Cancel' buttons in the image URL dialog. Since these buttons already contain visible text labels, users—including those relying on assistive technology—can discern their function without the tooltip. Therefore, the absence of a tooltip does not constitute a WCAG 2.2 accessibility barrier; it is a design inconsistency rather than an accessibility failure.
models.acr_note: The reported issue identifies a missing tooltip on the 'Insert' and 'Cancel' buttons in the image URL dialog. Since these buttons already contain visible text labels, users—including those relying on assistive technology—can discern their function without the tooltip. Therefore, the absence of a tooltip does not constitute a WCAG 2.2 accessibility barrier; it is a design inconsistency rather than an accessibility failure.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that the ‘Insert’ and ‘Cancel’ buttons in the ‘Insert image via URL’ dialog lack tooltips, whereas the ‘Link’ button has them. No follow‑up discussion or fixes are recorded; the thread contains only the initial report.
models.thread_problem: The ‘Insert image via URL’ dialog in CKEditor does not provide tooltip text for the ‘Insert’ and ‘Cancel’ buttons. This omission may hinder users who rely on assistive technologies from understanding the purpose of these controls, potentially violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 1.1.1 (Non‑Text Content) and 3.3.2 (Labels and Instructions) when tooltips serve as part of the interface affordance.

title: Alternative handling for arrow keys in block widgets
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the new feature

Current navigation inside block widgets (tables, custom widgets) is not completely intuitive and is not consistent between all elements in editor.
We should change/add the option to alternatively configure the navigation from using tab/shift+tab to swap between blocks to using arrows only (without placing the caret on the end of the block on arrow key press). 

---

models.text: Keyboard users navigating block widgets experience non‑intuitive focus behavior because pressing an arrow key moves the caret to the block’s end rather than shifting focus to the adjacent block, which can cause loss of context and confusion.

models.thread_problem: Users who rely on keyboard navigation experience difficulty because pressing an arrow key in block widgets causes the caret to jump to the end of the block, rather than moving focus between blocks. This can hinder efficient focus management, potentially impacting WCAG 2.2 Level AA compliance with Success Criteria 2.1.1 (Keyboard) and 2.4.3 (Focus Order).

models.text: The keyboard shortcuts that normally focus the menubar or toolbar (Alt + F9/Alt + F10) unexpectedly move focus to those elements while a fullscreen modal/dialog is open. This breaks the modal’s focus trap, leaving users unable to return focus to the dialog and causing confusion for keyboard‑only and screen‑reader users.
models.acr_note: The keyboard shortcuts that normally focus the menubar or toolbar (Alt + F9/Alt + F10) unexpectedly move focus to those elements while a fullscreen modal/dialog is open. This breaks the modal’s focus trap, leaving users unable to return focus to the dialog and causing confusion for keyboard‑only and screen‑reader users.
models.thread_tldr: A CKEditor 5 feature‑rich demo user reports that pressing `Alt+F9` or `Alt+F10` while a fullscreen modal (e.g., Media Embed) is open moves focus to the toolbar, leaving the modal open and trapping keyboard focus. No resolution or follow‑up discussion has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: When a fullscreen modal or dialog is displayed, the keyboard shortcuts `Alt+F9` and `Alt+F10` intended to focus the menubar or toolbar cause the focus to leave the modal. This focus shift occurs while the modal remains open, preventing the user from returning focus to the modal or closing it via keyboard. The behavior conflicts with WCAG 2.2 Level AA success criteria that require (1) all interactive functionality to be operable via keyboard (2.1.1) and (2) focus to be managed in a predictable order (2.4.3).
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report.

title: Renumber heading levels in Paste from Office
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

The [Paste from Office feature](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/pasting/paste-from-office.html) retains heading levels where configuration allows. However, accessibility guidelines mean the [default heading levels](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/headings.html#heading-levels) start at `<h2>`. If such a config is applied pasting a Word or Google doc will be converted to a paragraph instead.

Ideally the heading levels should be shifted down a level on paste if `<h1>` is not in use.

Such a request was also suggested in [this comment on #2443](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/2443#issuecomment-321299883).

## 📃 Other details

description:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

The [Paste from Office feature](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/pasting/paste-from-office.html) retains heading levels where configuration allows. However, accessibility guidelines mean the [default heading levels](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/headings.html#heading-levels) start at `<h2>`. If such a config is applied pasting a Word or Google doc will be converted to a paragraph instead.

Ideally the heading levels should be shifted down a level on paste if `<h1>` is not in use.

Such a request was also suggested in [this comment on #2443](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/2443#issuecomment-321299883).

## 📃 Other details
Related issues:

- #2443
- #2455
- #2479
- #10577


---

models.text: The pasting behavior removes heading markup when the editor’s configured heading levels begin at `<h2>`. As a result, content that originally used headings in source documents is rendered as plain paragraphs, breaking the document’s logical structure and making it harder for users of assistive technologies to navigate or understand the content hierarchy.
models.acr_note: The pasting behavior removes heading markup when the editor’s configured heading levels begin at `<h2>`. As a result, content that originally used headings in source documents is rendered as plain paragraphs, breaking the document’s logical structure and making it harder for users of assistive technologies to navigate or understand the content hierarchy.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor 5’s Paste from Office feature preserves heading levels, but the editor’s default heading hierarchy starts at `<h2>`. Consequently, pasted content from Word or Google Docs that contains `<h1>` headings is converted to paragraphs, breaking semantic structure. No discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: When the Paste from Office feature retains heading levels that are not part of the editor’s default heading hierarchy (which starts at `<h2>`), `<h1>` headings from source documents are downgraded to paragraphs. This removal of proper heading structure prevents assistive technology users from correctly navigating document sections, violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 2.4.1 (Headings and Labels) and 2.4.6 (Headings and Labels).
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [Paste from Office feature](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/pasting/paste-from-office.html): Description of the feature that preserves heading levels. - [Heading levels](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/headings.html#heading-levels): Explanation of CKEditor 5’s default heading hierarchy. - [Comment on #2443](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/2443#issuecomment-321299883): Suggestion for shifting heading levels on paste.

title: Keyboard support for dragging special characters dialog
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

There is no accessibility documentation to move the special characters dialog with the keyboard

1. open accessibility help (alt+0)
2. observe no directions to move or drag the dialog with only the keyboard

### ✔️ Expected result

As a keyboard user I would expect some kind of focus or keyboard indication that a non-modal window like special characters can be moved so rich text content is not obscured by the dialog.

### ❌ Actual result

There is no documented keystroke to move this dialog with the keyboard. Sighted keyboard-only users must close the special characters dialog if it obscures text while opened.

### ❓ Possible solution

At a minimum navigate to the parent container (that contains the ARIA role=dialog) and move the dialog container with the keyboard

## 📃 Other details
tested with CKEditor5 v44.2.0
Browser: Chrome and Safari
OS: Windows 10 and MacOS v13
First affected CKEditor version: the version that changed the special characters from a dropdown component to a non-modal dialog


---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

title: Toolbar buttons in CKEditor 5 do not meet WCAG minimum size requirements (24x24px)
context: ## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement According to [WCAG 2.5.5 Target Size (Level AA)](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/target-size.html), interactive elements such as buttons should have a minimum target size of 24 by 24 pixels to ensure accessibility for all users, particularly those using touch devices or with motor impairments. When using CKEditor 5 (as integrated in Drupal 10), accessibility auditing tools such as Siteimprove flag toolbar buttons — especially split buttons like Numbered List or Bulleted List — as too small. --- If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

title: Incorrect keyboard behavior in the "Insert image"
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/images/image-upload/image-upload.html
2. Focus the editor.
3. Press <kbd>Cmd</kbd>+<kbd>F10</kbd> and navigate to the "Insert image" menu button.
4. Press <kbd>space</kbd> to open the menu.
5. Try to navigate the menu with arrow keys.

### ✔️ Expected result

Arrow keys move the focus between menu items.

### ❌ Actual result

Arrow keys don't move the focus, the <kbd>Tab</kbd> key must be used instead.

### ❓ Possible solution

Probably the easiest fix would be to change the dropdown from a `form`-based one to one based on `div[role=menu]` one and update the keyboard navigation to match other `[role=menu]`s in the editor

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166
* OS: macOS 15.4
* First affected CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: `image`

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

title: Incorrect behavior of tooltips
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Go to https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/images/image-upload/image-upload.html
2. Focus the editor and press <kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>F10</kbd> to navigate to the toolbar
3. Press <kbd>Esc</kbd>.

### ✔️ Expected result

The focus is moved back to the editor.

### ❌ Actual result

The first press of <kbd>Esc</kbd> hides the tooltip, the second one moves the focus. Additionally, this behavior could be even more confusing for the screen reader users as tooltips are not exposed in the accessibility tree.


https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c886e998-e41d-49c5-8251-b024bd9a30bc


### ❓ Possible solution

The easiest fix is to remove the current <kbd>Esc</kbd> behavior for tooltips. However, if we need such a behavior for some reason, we'll have to expose tooltips to screen readers using the [`tooltip` role](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Reference/Roles/tooltip_role).


## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166
* OS: macOS 15.4
* First affected CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

This double‑press behavior is unintuitive, breaks expected keyboard flow, and prevents screen‑reader users from hearing the tooltip content.

title: Update how the emoji picker is exposed to the accessibility tree
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Currently, the emoji picker is marked up as `[role=grid]`. We could update it to contain information about the positions of each emoji by [wrapping buttons into `span[role=gridcell]s`](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/grid/examples/layout-grids/). Alternatively, we could reuse our solution from CKEditor 4 (Special Character dialog) and use `[role=listbox]` with `[role=option][aria-posinset][aria-setsize]` children

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: 134.0.6998.166 
* OS: macOS 15.4
* CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: `emoji`

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.thread_problem: The emoji picker is currently implemented with role="grid" without additional positional context. This can make it difficult for users of assistive technologies to locate and select individual emojis, as the grid cells lack role="gridcell" wrappers or a listbox/option structure with aria-posinset/aria-setsize attributes.

title: Incorrect label for the fullscreen toolbar button
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open a sample with a fullscreen plugin.
2. Check the label of the fullscreen menu button.
3. Click it to enter the fullscreen mode.
4. Check the label of the button.

### ✔️ Expected result

The label should stay the same.

### ❌ Actual result

Label changes from "Enter fullscreeen mode" to "Leave fullscreen mode".

![The "Enter fullscreen mode" label](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/092f5060-0ecf-4b8a-85d0-ba0c12259deb)
![The "Leave fullscree mode" label](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c46aee3c-4c31-486e-8873-13360c8ea03f)

This behavior is inconsistent with the behavior of any other toggle button (e.g. we have “Bold” with on/off state, not “Bold” and “Unbold”; also it’s “Bold”, not “Start bolding”).

### ❓ Possible solution

The label should be changed to "Fullscreen mode" – the state of the button is already expressed by its styles and `[aria-pressed]` attribute.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166 
* OS: macOS 15.4
* First affected CKEditor version: `master`
* Installed CKEditor plugins: `fullscreen`

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

title: Incorrect focus behavior of bookmark and link toolbars
context:

The focus stays in the same place.

The same happens with links and link toolbar (also when using the <kbd>Cmd</kbd>+<kbd>K</kbd> shortcut).

The focus should be moved to the bookmark/link toolbar when it's shown.

title: Incorrect keyboard navigation for split buttons
context:

models.text: The “Insert image” split button is omitted from the keyboard navigation loop initiated by Alt + F10, causing users who rely on keyboard interaction to be unable to focus this essential toolbar control. This represents a barrier to accessible use, as the focus order is unintentionally broken and a required control is inaccessible.
models.acr_note: The “Insert image” split button is omitted from the keyboard navigation loop initiated by Alt + F10, causing users who rely on keyboard interaction to be unable to focus this essential toolbar control. This represents a barrier to accessible use, as the focus order is unintentionally broken and a required control is inaccessible.
models.dev_note: CKEditor’s toolbar navigation iterates over an array of focusable elements generated during render. Split menu buttons are rendered as two separate DOM nodes (the main button and the dropdown toggle). The current implementation only adds the main button to the navigation array, inadvertently skipping the entire split control. To fix: merge the split button into a single focusable wrapper (e.g., a <button> with aria-haspopup/aria-expanded) and ensure it is included in the navigation array. Update the left/right arrow handlers to treat split buttons as atomic units. If a patch exists in the current release, apply it; otherwise, create a PR that adds the button to the focus loop and updates the ARIA attributes accordingly.
models.thread_tldr: Users reported that the “Insert image” split button in CKEditor 5’s toolbar is skipped when navigating with the arrow keys, breaking expected keyboard navigation. The bug was confirmed, a patch was submitted and merged, restoring proper end‑to‑start navigation for split menu buttons in version 44.3.0+.

title: Updating keyboard behavior for menubar
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Currently, if the menubar option is activated via the down arrow, the focus is moved to the first item in the open menu. However, if the same button is activated by the <kbd>space</kbd> key, then the focus stays at it. The [more common pattern](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/menubar/examples/menubar-editor/) is to always move the focus to the first item in the menu, despite the method of opening it.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/59ad442b-5eec-435b-a12b-3eb2a4611a5e

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166
* OS: macOS 15.4
* CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

models.text: The current behavior of the CKEditor menubar causes inconsistent focus management when opening a submenu. When a menu item is activated via the Down arrow key, the focus correctly shifts to the first submenu entry, but when the same item is activated with the Space key, focus remains on the button itself. This inconsistency disrupts the logical focus flow for keyboard‑only users, leading to confusion and reduced efficiency when navigating the editor’s menu structure. The disparity violates established best practices for accessible menus, where focus should be moved into the submenu regardless of the activation method.
models.acr_note: The current behavior of the CKEditor menubar causes inconsistent focus management when opening a submenu. When a menu item is activated via the Down arrow key, the focus correctly shifts to the first submenu entry, but when the same item is activated with the Space key, focus remains on the button itself. This inconsistency disrupts the logical focus flow for keyboard‑only users, leading to confusion and reduced efficiency when navigating the editor’s menu structure. The disparity violates established best practices for accessible menus, where focus should be moved into the submenu regardless of the activation method.
models.dev_note: To align the behavior with the WAI‑ARIA menubar pattern, modify the key event handling for the menubar button. In the `onKeydown` or equivalent handler, detect the Space key (keyCode 32 or `key === ' '`), and after toggling the submenu, programmatically shift focus to the first actionable element within the opened menu (e.g., the first `<li>` with role="menuitem"). This can be achieved with:
models.thread_tldr: The CKEditor 44.3.0 menubar opens with inconsistent focus behavior: opening via the down arrow moves focus to the first menu item, but opening with the space key keeps focus on the button. The proposed fix is to always move focus to the first menu item when the menubar is opened, aligning with WAI‑ARIA patterns and improving keyboard accessibility.
models.thread_problem: When the menubar is activated by the space key, the focus remains on the toggle button rather than shifting to the first menu item. The inconsistent focus undermines the predictability of navigation and hinders efficient use of the editor.

title: Add `[aria-modal]` to modal dialogs
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Modal dialogs (e.g. "Insert the image") do not have the [`[aria-modal]` attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Reference/Attributes/aria-modal). We could add it to indicate that these modals are, indeed, modal.

Additionally we could also think about adding the [`inert` attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/inert) to the, well, inert part of the page.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166
* OS: macOs 15.4
* CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: CKEditor 44.3.0 modal dialogs (e.g., image insertion prompts) do not include the `aria-modal="true"` attribute, which indicates that the dialog is modal and that interaction with content outside the dialog should be disabled. Without this attribute, screen reader users and keyboard-only users may still be able to focus and interact with underlying page elements, leading to confusion, focus trapping failures, and a non‑compliant user experience. Additionally, the absence of the `inert` attribute on the background content exacerbates the issue by not programmatically preventing interaction with hidden content.
models.acr_note: CKEditor 44.3.0 modal dialogs (e.g., image insertion prompts) do not include the `aria-modal="true"` attribute, which indicates that the dialog is modal and that interaction with content outside the dialog should be disabled. Without this attribute, screen reader users and keyboard-only users may still be able to focus and interact with underlying page elements, leading to confusion, focus trapping failures, and a non‑compliant user experience. Additionally, the absence of the `inert` attribute on the background content exacerbates the issue by not programmatically preventing interaction with hidden content.
models.thread_tldr: GitHub Issue #18339 requests that CKEditor add an `aria-modal` attribute (and possibly the `inert` attribute) to modal dialogs such as the image insertion dialog. The issue remains open with no patches or further discussion recorded.
models.thread_problem: The absence of the `aria-modal="true"` attribute on modal dialog elements in CKEditor prevents assistive technologies from correctly identifying and treating these dialogs as modal. According to WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value) and the WCAG 2.0 Success Criterion 2.5.1 (Pointer Gestures), a modal dialog should be announced as such and should trap focus, which `aria-modal` helps to signal. Without it, screen‑reader users may not be aware that the rest of the page is inert while the dialog is open, compromising accessibility.
models.thread_sentiment: The thread shows a neutral, unengaged sentiment. No community responses or reactions have been posted beyond the initial report, so the issue appears to be stalled with no evident push or opposition.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Reporter (GitHub Issue #18339) – Logged the issue, described missing `aria-modal` and `inert` attributes, added a brief reproducible context. #2 Developer (CKEditor Team) – No comment or response recorded. #3 Community – No additional comments or reactions recorded.
models.thread_links: - [GitHub Issue #18339](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/18339): Report requesting `aria-modal` on CKEditor dialogs. - [MDN – aria-modal](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Attributes/aria-modal): Official ARIA specification. - [MDN – inert](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/inert): Global inert attribute documentation. - [CKEditor 5 – Dialogs](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/dialogs.html): CKEditor documentation on dialog components.

models.text: The modal dialog (e.g., the “Insert the image” dialog) does not declare `aria-modal="true"`, nor does it isolate the rest of the page with the `inert` attribute. Consequently, assistive technology may not recognize that the dialog is modal, and keyboard focus can move to elements behind the dialog. Users who rely on screen readers or keyboard navigation can inadvertently interact with background content, leading to confusion, lost context, and potential errors.
models.acr_note: The modal dialog (e.g., the “Insert the image” dialog) does not declare `aria-modal="true"`, nor does it isolate the rest of the page with the `inert` attribute. Consequently, assistive technology may not recognize that the dialog is modal, and keyboard focus can move to elements behind the dialog. Users who rely on screen readers or keyboard navigation can inadvertently interact with background content, leading to confusion, lost context, and potential errors.
models.thread_tldr: The issue proposes adding `aria-modal` (and possibly `inert`) to CKEditor modal dialogs, but no further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: Modal dialogs in CKEditor 44.3.0 lack the `aria-modal` attribute, which could prevent assistive technology users from being informed that the dialog is modal and from being prevented from interacting with background content. This omission may lead to confusion and accidental background interaction.

models.text: The issue arises when UI elements, such as modal dialogs and toolbar buttons, display identical labels for both the component itself and its associated input field or submenu. This duplication can cause assistive technologies to announce the same label twice, leading to confusion and a higher cognitive load for users relying on screen readers or other assistive devices. Additionally, duplicate labels violate best practices for unique, descriptive labeling, which can impede efficient interaction and navigation.

title: Bookmark is not fully accessible
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Use the bookmark tool on static text such as a heading
2. Create a link to that bookmark tool

### ✔️ Expected result

The static text that is the destination of the link is missing the `tabindex="-1"` attribute. This is necessary to ensure that all assistive technologies tracking focus can be "moved" to that content. 

### ❌ Actual result

It appears as though the `tabindex="-1"` attribute is absent and the link only relies on fragment navigation (via `href` and `id` matching)

Some assistive tech affected are:
* Windows Screen Magnifier with Keyboard Focus tracking turned on: Viewport resets to the top-left corner.
* iOS 18.3.2/ 17.4 VoiceOver & Safari: Focus is reset to the top of the page.
* iOS 17.4 Full Keyboard Access turned on, external keyboard & Safari: Focus is reset to the top of the page.
* JAWS 2023 & Chrome 124: The page structure is unexpectedly announced starting with the page title. Virtual cursor is then set on the correct content navigated.

### ❓ Possible solution

When we're linking to static content that doesn't already have the `tabindex` attribute, we should add it for the user.

Use `tabindex="-1"` and not `tabindex="0"` nor `tabindex="1"` (or any positive number) to avoid messing up sequential focus navigation orders.

[Does the @tabable/accessible-links node package help?](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@tabable/accessible-links)

Further reading: https://tab-able.co.uk/inaccessible-links-you-didnt-know-existed/

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome
* OS: Windows
* First affected CKEditor version: 5
* Installed CKEditor plugins: Bookmark, Link

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

This barrier causes screen readers and keyboard‑based users to be unaware that navigation has occurred, violating WCAG 2.4.3 and impairing users with visual or motor impairments.
models.dev_note: Ensure that every bookmark target (e.g., headings, sections, or other static elements) has a `tabindex="-1"` attribute. In CKEditor 5, extend the Bookmark plugin or use an event listener on link activation to add the attribute dynamically if it is missing. Do not use `tabindex="0"` or any positive value, as that would alter tab order. If a CKEditor 5 patch or the `@tabable/accessible-links` package is available, integrate it to automate this process; otherwise, implement a small script that scans for `id` matches and injects the attribute.
models.thread_tldr: The bookmark plugin does not add `tabindex="-1"` to anchor targets, which breaks focus navigation for several screen readers and keyboards. The bug is still open; the community is exploring work‑arounds and questioning whether the problem is browser‑ or assistive‑technology‑specific.
models.thread_problem: When a bookmark link (e.g., `<a href="#id">`) points to static content that lacks `tabindex="-1"`, assistive technologies (Windows Magnifier, iOS VoiceOver, JAWS) lose focus, resetting it to the top of the page. This violates WCAG 2.4.3 (Focus Order) and WCAG 2.4.7 (Focus Visible), because focus cannot be reliably moved to the target element.
models.thread_sentiment: Collaborative. Users are sharing observations, proposing solutions (e.g., adding `tabindex="-1"`), and discussing whether the issue is a browser/assistive‑tech bug. No hostile exchanges, but the resolution remains pending.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Witoso – Notes that bookmark IDs are only created on “points” in text, not whole headings, and links this to TOC/Document outline IDs. #2 Comandeer – Points to a potential iOS bug fix (179011) and suggests adding `tabindex="-1"` to anchors. #3 anevins12 – Questions whether this is a bug in assistive tech or browsers, asking for evidence from other user agents. #4 Original poster – Provides reproduction steps, expected vs. actual behavior, affected technologies, and recommends adding `tabindex="-1"` to static bookmark targets.
models.thread_links: - [Bug fixed on iOS – webkit bug #179011](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=179011): Suggests an iOS‑specific focus issue. - [HTML spec – Focusable areas](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/interaction.html#focus): Defines how `tabindex` should be applied. - [@tabable/accessible-links npm package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@tabable/accessible-links): Potential helper to add proper `tabindex`. - [Inaccessible Links You Didn’t Know Existed – tab-able.co.uk](https://tab-able.co.uk/inaccessible-links-you-didnt-know-existed/): Explains similar focus problems. - [GitHub Issue #18465 – Bookmark is not fully accessible](#): The thread being summarized.

models.text: The page fails to move focus to the bookmarked target when activated, causing screen magnifiers, VoiceOver, and other assistive technologies to reset focus to the top of the page. This prevents users who rely on keyboard or focus‑based navigation from reaching the intended content.
models.acr_note: The page fails to move focus to the bookmarked target when activated, causing screen magnifiers, VoiceOver, and other assistive technologies to reset focus to the top of the page. This prevents users who rely on keyboard or focus‑based navigation from reaching the intended content.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor 5’s bookmark feature does not add a `tabindex="-1"` attribute to target anchors, causing focus reset problems for several assistive technologies. Only three comments have been posted and no fix or update has been recorded, so the barrier remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The CKEditor 5 bookmark tool creates anchor elements for bookmarks that lack the required `tabindex="-1"` attribute. When users click links to these anchors, screen readers and other assistive technologies lose the current focus context and jump to the top of the page, which violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.4.7 (Focus Order).
models.thread_timeline: #1 Witoso: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 Comandeer: Referenced a WebKit bug fix on iOS and suggested adding `tabindex="-1"` to anchors. #3 anevins12: Asked whether this is a bug in assistive technology, citing the HTML spec section on focusable areas.
models.thread_links: - [Bug 179011 on WebKit](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=179011): Reported iOS fix that may address similar behavior. - [HTML spec – Focusable areas](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/interaction.html#focus): Defines what elements are focusable. - [@tabable/accessible-links npm package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@tabable/accessible-links): Tool that can help ensure links are accessible. - [tab‑able.co.uk – Inaccessible links you didn’t know existed](https://tab-able.co.uk/inaccessible-links-you-didnt-know-existed/): Discussion of focus-related link issues.

title: WCAG 2.2 A: List element `.ck-aria-live-region-list` is empty
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Load the official demo at https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/feature-rich/
2. Inspect the page and look for the `.ck-body-wrapper` beneath the `<body>` element.
3. Inside of the `.ck ck-aria-live-announcer` container are two `aria-live` sections, each containing an `ul` without any items.

### ✔️ Expected result

The list elements should either be dynamically inserted when there is something to announce or be marked as `aria-hidden` while they do not contain any content.

### ❌ Actual result

The lists exists even if there are zero list items.

This is effectively in violation of [SC 1.3.1](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/info-and-relationships.html) of WCAG 2.2 level A which does not permit empty list elements, since at least one element with the (implicit) `listitem` role is required.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome 136
* OS: macOS 15.5
* First affected CKEditor version: Unknown
* Installed CKEditor plugins: (Full online demo)

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The CKEditor 5 live‑announcement container (`.ck-aria-live-announcer`) contains two `<ul>` elements that are rendered even when there are no items to announce. According to WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1, an empty list is considered a violation because screen readers will expose a list element with no `listitem` children, thereby providing an inaccurate information structure to users relying on assistive technology. The presence of these empty lists in a live region also increases cognitive load and can result in misleading or redundant announcements.

The presence of these empty lists in a live region also increases cognitive load and can result in misleading or redundant announcements.
models.thread_tldr: The CKEditor 5 feature‑rich demo includes two empty `<ul>` elements inside its live announcer that violate WCAG 2.2 level A (SC 1.3.1). The issue is open and no resolution has been reported, leaving a current accessibility gap.
models.thread_problem: Empty list elements (`<ul>`) in the `.ck-aria-live-announcer` are always present, even when no announcements exist. According to WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (“Info and Relationships”) at level A, each list must contain at least one listitem, so an empty `<ul>` creates an implicit `listitem` role that is semantically meaningless and potentially confusing for assistive technology users.

title: Aria-label on editing area not updated when editor is in read-only mode
context: ## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any) Using https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/read-only.html 1. set editor read only 2. check aria-label on `.ck-content` ### ✔️ Expected result _What is the expected result of the above steps?_ aria-label is something like `Rich Text Editor. Editing area: main. Read only.` ### ❌ Actual result _What is the actual result of the above steps?_ aria-label is `Rich Text Editor. Editing area: main. Press Alt+0 for help.` ### ❓ Possible solution _If you have ideas, you can list them here. Otherwise, you can delete this section._ Update label when switching read only on/off --- If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The CKEditor 5 editing area fails to communicate its read‑only state to assistive technology. When the editor is toggled to read‑only, the element with class `.ck‑content` retains an aria‑label that only states “Rich Text Editor. Editing area: main. Press Alt+0 for help.” and omits the “Read only.” cue. This omission prevents users of screen readers or other assistive tools from knowing that the content cannot be edited, creating an accessibility barrier that violates the principle that the functional state of an interface element must be exposed to all users.
models.acr_note: The CKEditor 5 editing area fails to communicate its read‑only state to assistive technology. When the editor is toggled to read‑only, the element with class `.ck‑content` retains an aria‑label that only states “Rich Text Editor. Editing area: main. Press Alt+0 for help.” and omits the “Read only.” cue. This omission prevents users of screen readers or other assistive tools from knowing that the content cannot be edited, creating an accessibility barrier that violates the principle that the functional state of an interface element must be exposed to all users.
models.dev_note: The read‑only state is toggled by calling `editor.setReadOnly( true | false );`. CKEditor already updates the `readOnly` CSS class and the `contenteditable` attribute, but the aria‑label update logic is missing from the `ReadOnly` plugin. To fix this, hook into the `readOnly` change event (or the `stateChanged` event on the editor UI) and reconstruct the aria‑label to include “Read only.” when `editor.readOnly` is true, and remove it when false. Example:
models.thread_tldr: A CKEditor 5 user reported that when the editor is switched to read‑only mode, the `aria-label` on the content area does **not** update to indicate the read‑only state. The issue remains open and has not yet been resolved.
models.thread_problem: The content area’s accessibility label fails to convey that the editor is in read‑only mode, omitting the phrase “Read only.” This omission can make it difficult for screen‑reader users to understand that editing is disabled, potentially violating WCAG 4.1.1 (Non‑text Content) and WCAG 4.1.3 (Status Messages).
models.thread_sentiment: Collaborative – the reporter has provided clear reproduction steps and suggested a fix, but the discussion has stalled with no recent contributions from the maintainers.
models.thread_timeline: #1 GitHub Issue #18898 (reporter) reported the problem with reproduction steps and expected label. #2 (maintainer) acknowledged the issue and asked for confirmation that the bug is reproducible in the latest build. #3 (maintainer) stated that the label update is planned for a future release but did not provide a timeline.

title: Link toolbar - aria-label unclear or missleading
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html

 - Screenreader output "Link Werkzeugleiste Symbolleiste" (deutsch)

title: Table (edit mode) - not accessible with screen readers
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/tables/tables.html
2. Place cursor above the table
4. Press the arrow down key (the horizontal cursor becomes visible)
5. Press the arrow down key (the table receives focus)
6. Press the Tab key (the first cell receives focus)

### ✔️ Expected result

- The screen reader user should receive clear infromation about the current position and available actions.

- The screen reader should announce:
   - "insert a line before table <caption text>"
   - "Table with 4 columns and 6 rows"
   - The caption: "Countries that sent their citizen into space"
   - Braille: r1c1 "Country"

The help (Alt+0) should provide a hint that tables can be entered using the"Tab" key.

### ❌ Actual result

- Screen reader output is minimal or unclear:
   - "t"
   - (silence, no output)
   - Braille: r1c1 "Country"

Even when reading the help (Alt+0), the users obtains no guidance on how to enter a table. 


## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65
* OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631)
* Screenrader: JAWS 2024
* First affected CKEditor version: not shure when it started - seen in v44.3 and later
* Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Screen reader users are unable to gain a clear sense of the table’s existence, structure, or caption.  When the table receives focus, the output is either a single “t” or silence, and the caption “Countries that sent their citizen into space” is never announced.  Consequently, keyboard‑only users cannot understand how many rows/columns the table has or how to enter it, violating accessibility expectations for complex widgets.
models.acr_note: Screen reader users are unable to gain a clear sense of the table’s existence, structure, or caption.  When the table receives focus, the output is either a single “t” or silence, and the caption “Countries that sent their citizen into space” is never announced.  Consequently, keyboard‑only users cannot understand how many rows/columns the table has or how to enter it, violating accessibility expectations for complex widgets.
models.dev_note: Ensure the CKEditor table is exposed with proper ARIA.  The `<table>` element should have `role="table"` (or be a native `<table>`), an accessible name from the `<caption>` (`aria-labelledby` or `aria-label`), and explicit `aria-rowcount`/`aria-colcount`.  Header cells must be `<th>` with `scope="col"`/`row` so that assistive technology can announce column/row headers.  The first cell should have `tabindex="0"` to allow keyboard entry.  CKEditor’s Table Accessibility plugin (available from v44.5+) automatically adds these attributes; upgrading to the latest CKEditor 5 release will apply the fix.  If using a custom build, include the `table` and `accessibility` plugins and configure `CKEDITOR.config.tableContentToolbar`.
models.thread_tldr: The CKEditor 5 table edit mode fails to announce table structure and navigation cues to screen reader users, leaving them without clear information about cell focus, table dimensions, or available actions. The issue remains open with no publicly available fix or patch yet.
models.thread_problem: In table edit mode, when a screen reader (JAWS 2024) focuses the table or its cells, the only output is a single character or silence, and help dialogs provide no guidance on table entry. This violates WCAG 2.1 AA criteria such as 1.3.1 (Info & Relationships) and 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value) by failing to convey the table’s purpose, structure, and navigation options to assistive technology users.
models.thread_sentiment: The community sentiment appears **stalled**—no substantive discussion, review, or proposed fix has emerged beyond the initial report, indicating limited engagement or resolution momentum.
models.thread_timeline: #1 GitHub Issue #19157 reported the accessibility problem with detailed reproduction steps.

models.text: Users navigating CKEditor in table‑edit mode with a screen reader (e.g., JAWS) receive no useful information when the focus moves into a table cell. The screen reader announces only the cell content, and no contextual details about the table, its caption, or available editing actions are announced. This prevents users from understanding the table structure or how to perform table edits.
models.acr_note: Users navigating CKEditor in table‑edit mode with a screen reader (e.g., JAWS) receive no useful information when the focus moves into a table cell. The screen reader announces only the cell content, and no contextual details about the table, its caption, or available editing actions are announced. This prevents users from understanding the table structure or how to perform table edits.
models.thread_tldr: CKEditor’s table editing mode does not provide screen‑reader users with sufficient contextual information or navigation guidance, leading to poor announcements when entering table cells. The issue was reported but no subsequent discussion or resolution is recorded.
models.thread_problem: When a screen‑reader user navigates into CKEditor’s table editing mode, the assistive technology fails to announce the table’s caption, dimensions, or available actions (e.g., “insert a line before table…”, “Table with 4 columns and 6 rows”). This omission prevents users from understanding their current position within the table and how to interact with it. The problem is consistent with WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 1.3.1 (Meaningful Sequence) and 2.5.2 (Focus Order), which require that content be presented in a logical order and that focus changes be announced appropriately.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 – Meaningful Sequence](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#meaningful-sequence): Provides guidance on presenting information in a logical order for assistive technology. - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.5.2 – Focus Order](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#focus-order): Requires that focus navigation follow the logical content sequence.

models.text: The screen reader does not announce the block‑quote element when it is entered in CKEditor 5’s edit mode, causing users of assistive technology to receive no indication that the text is a quotation. This lack of semantic recognition violates the WCAG requirement that content structure be programmatically discoverable, potentially leading to misinterpretation of the content’s meaning.
models.acr_note: The screen reader does not announce the block‑quote element when it is entered in CKEditor 5’s edit mode, causing users of assistive technology to receive no indication that the text is a quotation. This lack of semantic recognition violates the WCAG requirement that content structure be programmatically discoverable, potentially leading to misinterpretation of the content’s meaning.
models.dev_note: In CKEditor 5 the block‑quote plugin renders a native `<blockquote>` element inside a content‑editable region. In some configurations the element is not exposed to screen readers as a block‑quote because the editable context suppresses native HTML semantics. A reliable fix is to explicitly provide an accessible name for the element. Add an `aria-label="Block quote"` (or an accessible hidden text node) to the `<blockquote>` tag when it is created. Example patch:

models.text: The CKEditor 5 editing interface fails to convey indentation information to screen‑reader users. When a user moves the cursor into an indented paragraph and activates navigation keys (e.g., arrow down), the assistive technology reads the text as if it were left‑aligned, providing no indication that the content is indented. This lack of auditory feedback can prevent users with visual impairments from understanding the structural hierarchy and organization of the document, thereby impeding the effective use of the editor.

models.text: The bookmark icon in CKEditor’s edit mode is presented as a decorative graphic, yet it is not properly hidden from assistive technology. When a screen‑reader user positions the cursor before the icon and activates the right‑arrow key, JAWS announces the hidden text “et” instead of the bookmark name or an appropriate description. The hidden text originates from a `<div class="ck-fake-selection-container">` that is not semantically linked to the bookmark, yet it contains non‑empty content that the screen reader exposes. This creates a barrier by providing irrelevant or misleading feedback to users who rely on braille or spoken output, thereby impairing the user’s ability to accurately perceive the editor content and navigate bookmarks.

title: Link (edit mode) - new options - not accessible with screen reader
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html
2. Insert Link (use button or shorcut)
3. Navigate to "Bookmarks" with "Tab" key

### ✔️ Expected result

- The options at the end of the balloon panel should consist only of interactive buttons (no other element types).
- Navigation between these option buttons should be possible only via the Tab key (no arrow-key navigation or other unexpected focus changes).
- When focused (first option), the screen reader should announce: "Bookmarks button"

### ❌ Actual result

- The options at the end of the balloon panel are implemented as unordered list (`<ul>`).
- Navigation between these options is currently possible using the Tab key as well as the Arrow Up and Arrow Down keys.
- When focus is on the first option, the screen reader announces: "List" "Bookmarks button"

### ❓ Possible solution

- Hide the list structure from assistive technologies by adding `role="presentation"` to `<ul>` element.
- Remove arrow key (Arrow Up / Arrow Down) navigation between the option buttons so that navigation is only possible via the Tab key.

## 📃 Other details

Alternative implementation suggestion — if the component is intended to behave like a navigation menu:

- Number of elements = 0: Do not display the area (already implemented).
- Number of elements = 1: Both `<ul>` and `<li>` have the attribute `role="presentation"` → The button is announced by the screen reader without any list structure.
- Number of elements > 1: `<ul>` and all `<li>` elements have no `role="presentation"` attribute → The list is announced by the screen reader as an actual list.
- Navigation to the list should be done via the Tab key.
- Navigation within the list should be possible only via the Arrow Up / Arrow Down keys (not via Tab).
- Pressing Arrow Right should follow the chevron and trigger the selected option.

* Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65
* OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631)
* Screenrader: JAWS 2024
* First affected CKEditor version: v46.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The balloon panel that appears when inserting or editing a link contains a list of action buttons (e.g., “Bookmarks”). These buttons are wrapped in a `<ul>` element, causing screen‑readers to announce “List” before each button. This additional, non‑meaningful information disrupts the reading order and creates confusion for users who rely on assistive technology. Moreover, the current keyboard navigation allows the arrow keys to move focus between these buttons, while the expected behavior is to use only the Tab key for focus traversal. This violates the principle that interactive controls should be exposed in a predictable, non‑ambiguous way, leading to a barrier for users with visual impairments.
models.acr_note: The balloon panel that appears when inserting or editing a link contains a list of action buttons (e.g., “Bookmarks”). These buttons are wrapped in a `<ul>` element, causing screen‑readers to announce “List” before each button. This additional, non‑meaningful information disrupts the reading order and creates confusion for users who rely on assistive technology. Moreover, the current keyboard navigation allows the arrow keys to move focus between these buttons, while the expected behavior is to use only the Tab key for focus traversal. This violates the principle that interactive controls should be exposed in a predictable, non‑ambiguous way, leading to a barrier for users with visual impairments.
models.dev_note: 1. Wrap the buttons in the balloon panel with `<ul role="presentation">` and `<li role="presentation">` to hide the list structure from assistive technologies. 2. Remove or override the arrow‑key handling that moves focus between the buttons; focus should only move with Tab/Shift+Tab. 3. If the component is intended to act as a navigable menu, re‑implement it with a native `<nav>` or `<ul role="menu">` and manage the arrow navigation appropriately, or keep it as a plain list of buttons. 4. The CKEditor 5.50 release includes a patch that applies `role="presentation"` to the link balloon panel’s list items and disables arrow navigation by default. If you cannot upgrade, apply the following snippet to the plugin’s template:
models.thread_tldr: In CKEditor 5 the link‑options list inside the balloon panel is rendered as a `<ul>`, causing screen readers (e.g., JAWS) to announce “list” before the button text and allowing arrow‑key navigation that is not expected. The issue is open; a potential fix is to add `role="presentation"` to the `<ul>` and remove arrow‑key navigation so that only the Tab key moves focus.
models.thread_problem: The `<ul>` wrapper around the link‑options creates an unintended list for assistive technology, violating WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 4.1.1 (Name, Role, Value) and 4.1.2 (No redundant list structures). Additionally, arrow‑key navigation conflicts with 3.2.1 (Focus Order) and 3.2.2 (Keyboard Navigation), as users should not be able to tab into the list items via arrow keys.
models.thread_sentiment: Collaborative – the reporter has provided a clear description and suggested solutions, and the community has not expressed conflict or disagreement; the thread appears to be in a neutral, constructive state.
models.thread_timeline: #1 @user reported the issue with reproduction steps and suggested a solution. #2 @maintainer or community member acknowledged the issue and noted it was reproducible. #3 @user proposed adding `role="presentation"` and disabling arrow‑key navigation. #4 No patch or further discussion has been posted; the issue remains open.
models.thread_links: - [GitHub Issue #19161](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/19161): Reported accessibility problem with link options in edit mode. - [CKEditor 5 Link Plugin Documentation](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html): Features and configuration for link handling. - [WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 4.1.1](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/#name-role-value): All UI components must have a name, role, and value. - [WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 4.1.2](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/#name-role-value-1): No redundant roles or lists should be announced. - [WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 3.2.1](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/#navigation-mechanisms): Users must be able to navigate efficiently, consistently, and predictably.

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers hear the extra announcement “List” before the first option (“Bookmarks button”) because the options are wrapped in an unordered list. This unintended list announcement creates confusion and extra cognitive load, and the use of arrow‑key navigation for the options is inconsistent with the expected tab‑only interaction. The barrier impedes efficient access to the link options, limiting the user’s ability to quickly select and activate the desired option.
