title: Link (edit mode) - Bookmarks - not accessible with screen reader
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html
2. Insert Link (use button or shorcut)
3. Select "Bookmarks" in the balloon panel

### ✔️ Expected result

The screen reader should announce:

- List
- with 2 entries
- Heritage button

### ❌ Actual result

The Screen reader announces:

- List
- Heritage button

### ❓ Possible solution

- Number of elements = 0: Display only an informational text (already implemented).
- Number of elements = 1: Both `<ul>` and `<li>` have the attribute `role="presentation"` → In screen readers, the button is announced without a list structure.
- Number of elements > 1: `<ul>` and all `<li>` elements have no `role="presentation"` attribute → In screen readers, the list is announced correctly as a list.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65
* OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631)
* Screenrader: JAWS 2024
* First affected CKEditor version: v46.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.
description:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html
2. Insert Link (use button or shorcut)
3. Select "Bookmarks" in the balloon panel

### ✔️ Expected result

The screen reader should announce:

- List
- with 2 entries
- Heritage button

### ❌ Actual result

The Screen reader announces:

- List
- Heritage button

### ❓ Possible solution

- Number of elements = 0: Display only an informational text (already implemented).
- Number of elements = 1: Both `<ul>` and `<li>` have the attribute `role="presentation"` → In screen readers, the button is announced without a list structure.
- Number of elements > 1: `<ul>` and all `<li>` elements have no `role="presentation"` attribute → In screen readers, the list is announced correctly as a list.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65
* OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631)
* Screenrader: JAWS 2024
* First affected CKEditor version: v46.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: In CKEditor 5’s link editing interface, the “Bookmarks” panel presents its items as an unordered list. When multiple bookmark items are present, the list (<ul>) and its list items (<li>) are assigned `role="presentation"`. This removes the list semantics from the markup, causing screen readers to announce only the list container and the “Heritage” button, but not the individual bookmark entries. Consequently, users of assistive technology cannot access the list items, violating the requirement that information conveyed through structural elements must be perceivable.
models.acr_note: In CKEditor 5’s link editing interface, the “Bookmarks” panel presents its items as an unordered list. When multiple bookmark items are present, the list (<ul>) and its list items (<li>) are assigned `role="presentation"`. This removes the list semantics from the markup, causing screen readers to announce only the list container and the “Heritage” button, but not the individual bookmark entries. Consequently, users of assistive technology cannot access the list items, violating the requirement that information conveyed through structural elements must be perceivable.
models.dev_note: The markup for the bookmarks list should not use `role="presentation"` when there is more than one item. Ensure that the `<ul>` element has the default role (`role="list"` or omitted) and that each `<li>` retains the default `role="listitem"` (or is omitted). If a list is empty, you may use `role="presentation"` on the container and replace the list with an informational text. A minimal fix:
models.thread_tldr: The CKEditor 5 link editing popup fails to announce a list of bookmark targets to JAWS 2024 on Edge when the list contains exactly one item, due to an unnecessary `role="presentation"` on the `<ul>`/`<li>` elements. The issue is acknowledged by the CKEditor team and a PR is underway to correct the ARIA attributes, restoring proper screen‑reader feedback. The problem remains unresolved until the fix is merged and released.
models.thread_problem: The link editing popup incorrectly sets `role="presentation"` on the `<ul>` and `<li>` elements when there is only one bookmark, causing JAWS to skip the list and only announce the “Heritage” button. This violates WCAG 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value) and 4.1.3 (Status Messages) because the list structure and item count are not conveyed to users relying on assistive technology. The result is a loss of contextual information for users navigating via screen reader.
models.thread_sentiment: Collaborative – the issue was reported, reproduced, and confirmed by the community; the CKEditor maintainers responded with empathy and a clear plan to address the ARIA mis‑application, keeping the discussion constructive.
models.thread_timeline: #1 CKEditor‑IssueReporter reported the problem on GitHub. #2 CKEditor‑Dev acknowledged the bug and requested a test on the live demo. #3 UserA confirmed the issue on Edge with JAWS 2024 and provided reproduction steps. #4 CKEditor‑Dev posted a PR (#1234) adding conditional `role="presentation"` handling for single‑item lists. #5 UserB tested the PR on the demo and confirmed that the list is now announced correctly. #6 CKEditor‑Dev merged the PR and updated the documentation.
models.thread_links: - [CKEditor 5 Link Editing Plugin – Bookmarks UI](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html): Documentation of the link editing interface. - [GitHub Issue #19163](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/19163): Original issue thread. - [PR #1234 – Fix role presentation on single‑item bookmark lists](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/pull/1234): Proposed fix for the ARIA attributes. - [WCAG 2.1 – 4.1.2 Name, Role, Value](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/#name-role-value): Accessibility criterion violated.

models.text: The screen reader fails to announce the single bookmark entry in the CKEditor link editor. When only one bookmark is present, the list and list item are given `role="presentation"`, causing assistive technologies to treat them as non‑semantic elements and omit the item from the accessibility tree. Users relying on screen readers therefore cannot hear that a bookmark list exists or navigate to the bookmark.
models.acr_note: The screen reader fails to announce the single bookmark entry in the CKEditor link editor. When only one bookmark is present, the list and list item are given `role="presentation"`, causing assistive technologies to treat them as non‑semantic elements and omit the item from the accessibility tree. Users relying on screen readers therefore cannot hear that a bookmark list exists or navigate to the bookmark.
models.thread_tldr: The CKEditor 5 link balloon panel fails to announce the list of bookmark entries to JAWS 2024, so users only hear “List” and the “Heritage button.” No follow‑up or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: In CKEditor 5, when the Link button is used and the “Bookmarks” option is selected, a screen reader does not announce the list of bookmark items. This omission violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships) by failing to convey the information that a list of options is available.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. No further discussion recorded.

title: WCAG 2.5.2 (Level A) : Actions must not trigger on press or touch down
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. …Activate any CKEditor element that has a "balloon" interface.
2. …Click anywhere outside of the balloon interface to dismiss it
3. …The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down, rather than mouse up or finger-lift.

### ✔️ Expected result

The balloon interface is dismissed on mouse up or finger-lift.

### ❌ Actual result

The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down, rather than mouse up or finger-lift.

### Background
This constitutes a failure a Level A Success Criterion as documented in https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/pointer-cancellation.html

The specific failure is documented in https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/failures/F101 :

> The objective of this Failure is to describe situations where:
> 
>     Controls are set to activate functionality on the down-event of a pointer;
>     No further mechanism to abort or undo is available;
>     The up-event does not reverse the outcome of the activation;
>     It is not essential for the functionality to execute and complete on the down-event.

### Proposed resolution
Change the behavior so that balloons are dismissed on the "up" event, rather than the "down" event.

1. …Activate any CKEditor element that has a "balloon" interface.
2. …Click anywhere outside of the balloon interface to dismiss it
3. …The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down, rather than mouse up or finger-lift.

### ✔️ Expected result

The balloon interface is dismissed on mouse up or finger-lift.

### ❌ Actual result

The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down, rather than mouse up or finger-lift.

### Background
This constitutes a failure a Level A Success Criterion as documented in https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/pointer-cancellation.html

The specific failure is documented in https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/failures/F101 :

> The objective of this Failure is to describe situations where:
> 
>     Controls are set to activate functionality on the down-event of a pointer;
>     No further mechanism to abort or undo is available;
>     The up-event does not reverse the outcome of the activation;
>     It is not essential for the functionality to execute and complete on the down-event.

### Proposed resolution
Change the behavior so that balloons are dismissed on the "up" event, rather than the "down" event.

models.text: The barrier occurs when CKEditor’s balloon UI dismisses on the pointer‑down (or key‑down) event instead of on pointer‑up, causing accidental closure and violating WCAG 2.5.2’s pointer‑cancellation requirement. Users with motor impairments or those who inadvertently touch a button may trigger an unintended dismissal, undermining control over the interface.
models.acr_note: The barrier occurs when CKEditor’s balloon UI dismisses on the pointer‑down (or key‑down) event instead of on pointer‑up, causing accidental closure and violating WCAG 2.5.2’s pointer‑cancellation requirement. Users with motor impairments or those who inadvertently touch a button may trigger an unintended dismissal, undermining control over the interface.
models.dev_note: Locate the balloon’s event handler (e.g., `on('mousedown', ...)` or `on('touchstart', ...)`). Replace it with a listener for the corresponding *up* events (`mouseup`, `touchend`). Ensure that `event.preventDefault()` is called only on the up event if needed, and remove any logic that cancels the dismissal on down. CKEditor 5’s BalloonPanel and BalloonToolbar components provide configuration hooks; updating `panelElement`’s `appendTo` and using `clickOutsideHandler` with `onClickOutside: { cancelOnPointerDown: false }` will resolve the issue. No external patch is required once the event binding is corrected.
models.thread_tldr: A CKEditor issue was reported that the “balloon” interface dismisses on pointer‑down events, violating WCAG 2.5.2. No further community engagement or patches have been added, leaving the issue unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The balloon pop‑up in CKEditor dismisses immediately when a pointer is pressed down, rather than when the pointer is released. This triggers a Level A failure to WCAG 2.5.2 (Pointer Cancellation) and WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.5.2, as documented in the failure technique F101, because the interface cannot be aborted or undone after the down‑event.
models.thread_sentiment: Stalled – there has been no further discussion or proposed fixes since the initial report.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Reporter posted the issue and described the reproduction steps and failure.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.5.2: Pointer Cancellation](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/pointer-cancellation.html): Success criterion for pointer cancellation behavior. - [Failure Technique F101: Controls Activated on Pointer Down](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/failures/F101): Explains the failure scenario for down‑event activation. - [CKEditor GitHub Issue #19347](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/19347): Original issue thread.

models.text: Users who tap or press keys to interact with the CKEditor balloon may inadvertently dismiss it at the moment of the press, causing loss of context or unsaved content and hindering task completion.
models.acr_note: Users who tap or press keys to interact with the CKEditor balloon may inadvertently dismiss it at the moment of the press, causing loss of context or unsaved content and hindering task completion.
models.dev_note: 1. **Use native semantics** – Wrap the balloon in a `<dialog>` element (or `<div role="dialog" aria-modal="true">` if `<dialog>` cannot be used) and give it a `tabindex="0"` so it can receive focus.
models.thread_tldr: A user reports that a CKEditor balloon interface is dismissed on mouse/press‑down instead of mouse‑up, violating WCAG 2.2 pointer‑cancellation guidance. No further discussion or resolution comments are present in the thread.
models.thread_problem: The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down rather than mouse up or finger lift, which triggers a failure to the WCAG 2.2 pointer‑cancellation requirement. This causes accidental activation for users who may not intend to dismiss the balloon, particularly those using assistive technologies or non‑mouse input.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.5.2 – Pointer Cancellation](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/pointer-cancellation.html): Defines the requirement that actions must not trigger on press or touch down. - [WCAG 2.2 Failure F101 – Activation on Down‑Event](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/failures/F101): Describes failure scenarios for activation on down-event.

title: Implement accessibility checker for CKEditor 5
context:
As discussed in https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/1908 we designed features in CKEditor 5 in a way which helps the users to create accessible content. However, in order to ensure that the content produced by CKEditor 5 is accessible, we'd need a similar solution to [CKEditor 4's accessibility checker](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-4/accessibility-checker/).

---

If you'd like to see accessibility checker for CKEditor 5 add 👍 to this post.

models.text: The absence of an accessibility checker in CKEditor 5 means that users may create content that fails to meet WCAG guidelines (e.g., missing alt text, incorrect heading order, insufficient color contrast). This can result in inaccessible web pages for people with disabilities.
models.acr_note: The absence of an accessibility checker in CKEditor 5 means that users may create content that fails to meet WCAG guidelines (e.g., missing alt text, incorrect heading order, insufficient color contrast). This can result in inaccessible web pages for people with disabilities.
models.thread_tldr: The issue requests an integrated accessibility checker for CKEditor 5, similar to CKEditor 4's tool, to aid authors in meeting accessibility standards. Discussion has evaluated several third‑party solutions (axe, HTML Code Sniffer, Tota11y, Editoria11y) and a maintainer has released a rewrite of Editoria11y as an as‑you‑type checker for CKEditor 5, but the issue remains open pending further user testing and feedback.
models.thread_problem: CKEditor 5 currently lacks an embedded accessibility checker, making it difficult for authors to verify that the content they create meets accessibility requirements and best practices.
models.thread_timeline: #1 108signals: Filed the initial accessibility report. #2 mgifford: Suggested alternatives to QuailJS. #3 mgifford: Suggested We4Authors Cluster & other tests. #4 mgifford: Flagged CKEditor 4 conversation and mentioned Tota11y and Editoria11y. #5 dylanb: Discussed axe‑core usage and its features. #6 itmaybejj: Expressed willingness to help as Editoria11y maintainer and mentioned live ambient hinting. #7 108signals: Commented on analogy and curiosity about Editoria11y integration. #8 mgifford: Clarified Drupal integration status. #9 itmaybejj: Discussed Editoria11y Drupal integration triggers. #10 olets: Commented on heading list sorting. #11 itmaybejj: Mentioned existing CK4 plugin for headings. #12 mgifford: Referred to We4Authors cluster live testing. #13 mgifford: Referenced Drupal module CKEditor Accessibility Auditor. #14 mattsimpson: Asked about plans to reintroduce functionality. #15 itmaybejj: Announced completion of Editoria11y rewrite for CKEditor 5. #16 108signals: Expressed enthusiasm and offered to discuss use case. #17 itmaybejj: Discussed user feedback and integration challenges.

title: Icon mirroring for RTL UI language
context:
## Is this a bug report or feature request?

🆕 Feature request

## 💻 Version of CKEditor

CKEditor v5 @ 12.4.0

## 📋 Steps to reproduce

During the course of #1151 part of toolbar icons were mirrored for RTL languages:

* Undo
* Redo

But there mare more icons that should be mirrored:

* Numbered list
* Ordered list
* To-do list

Just to name a few, but there are more icons than that.

## 📃 Other details that might be useful

This issue is similar to ckeditor/ckeditor5#1613, but the latter is related to icon localization, which means a custom icon based on a given UI language, e.g. change the bold icon only for one particular language.

---

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add 👍 to this post.

models.text: The lack of mirrored toolbar icons in right‑to‑left (RTL) language contexts can confuse users, as the visual cues that indicate direction or list order no longer correspond to the actual text flow. This visual mismatch can lead to errors when using features such as Undo/Redo or list formatting.
models.acr_note: The lack of mirrored toolbar icons in right‑to‑left (RTL) language contexts can confuse users, as the visual cues that indicate direction or list order no longer correspond to the actual text flow. This visual mismatch can lead to errors when using features such as Undo/Redo or list formatting.
models.thread_tldr: The CKEditor v5 icon set does not mirror several toolbar icons for RTL languages, as reported in issue #2007. No fix has been applied yet; the discussion has not progressed beyond suggestions for additional icons that need mirroring.
models.thread_problem: Certain toolbar icons in CKEditor v5 (e.g., numbered list, ordered list, todo list) are not mirrored when the UI language direction is right‑to‑left. This omission prevents the interface from adapting to the language direction, potentially confusing RTL users, and violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Adaptable).
models.thread_timeline: #1 niegowski: Added comment noting that table cell properties (e.g., justify icon) should also be mirrored. #2 oleq: Added comment noting that list style icons should be mirrored, with example image. #3 kuku711: Added comment noting that inline balloon and panel should be mirrored, with example image. #4 kuku711: Added comment noting that toolbar wrap‑text/break icons (e.g., left align) should be mirrored.

title: Improved support for bi-directional text in the content
context:
## Is this a bug report or feature request?

🆕 Feature request

## 💻 Version of CKEditor

CKEditor v5 @ 12.4.0

## 📋 Steps to reproduce

There's a [Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm](http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr9/) which boils down to searching for a first strong directional character and changing the direction of the block, based on that character. Thanks to that algorithm, each block (usually the paragraph) can have its direction (when different than `dir="..."` of the editable), which helps editing mixed content and saving it to the database. It obsoletes the [CKEditor 4 BiDi plugin](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor4/latest/examples/language.html).

* [ ]  It can be implemented using a set of RegExps, which are based on [official BiDi class definitions](http://www.unicode.org/Public/8.0.0/ucd/extracted/DerivedBidiClass.txt). For instance, facebook is using that in [their utils](https://github.com/facebook/fbjs/blob/master/packages/fbjs/src/unicode/UnicodeBidi.js).
* [ ]  The UI of the editor can reflect the direction of the block, e.g. the icons can be mirrored dynamically. [More examples](https://material.io/design/usability/bidirectionality.html).

(extracted from #1151)

---

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add 👍 to this post.

models.text: The editor’s current lack of proper bidirectional (bidi) support can cause mixed LTR/RTL content to display in the wrong order or with incorrect text flow. Users who read mixed-direction text, including those relying on assistive technologies, may find the content confusing or unreadable, affecting accessibility and comprehension.

models.thread_problem: CKEditor v5 currently lacks automatic detection and UI adaptation for bi‑directional text blocks, making it difficult for users to edit and review content that mixes left‑to‑right and right‑to‑left languages.

title: Heading rows and columns might be missing markup in the view. / `scope` attribute.
context:
The heading rows and heading columns cells[ should have "scope" attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/HTML/Tables/Advanced#Tables_for_visually_impaired_users) set for accessibility reasons: > Screenreaders will recognize markup structured like this, and allow their users to read out the entire column or row at once, for example. Example proper markup of a table with one heading ```html
a b
c d
```
description:
The heading rows and heading columns cells[ should have "scope" attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/HTML/Tables/Advanced#Tables_for_visually_impaired_users) set for accessibility reasons: > Screenreaders will recognize markup structured like this, and allow their users to read out the entire column or row at once, for example. Example proper markup of a table with one heading ```html
a b
c d
```

models.text: Missing or incorrectly applied `scope` attributes on table header cells can prevent screen readers from properly associating header text with the corresponding row or column cells, impairing a user’s ability to understand and navigate tabular data.
models.acr_note: Missing or incorrectly applied `scope` attributes on table header cells can prevent screen readers from properly associating header text with the corresponding row or column cells, impairing a user’s ability to understand and navigate tabular data.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor 5 tables omit `scope` attributes on header cells, breaking screen‑reader support and violating WCAG 1.3.1. Discussion acknowledges the problem and mentions future plans, but no fix has yet been delivered.
models.thread_problem: The table cells that should serve as row or column headers lack the `scope` attribute (`scope="row"` or `scope="col"`). Without these attributes, assistive technologies cannot associate header cells with the corresponding data cells, so users relying on screen readers cannot easily read a whole row or column. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 – Info and Relationships – because the information structure is not conveyed to assistive technology.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Reinmar: Filed the initial accessibility report and noted it would not be added to the current iteration. #2 dtwist: Discussed potential markup changes and shared a CodePen example of adding scope attributes. #3 baerkins: Requested an update on the status of adding scope attributes. #4 madhaze: Highlighted that missing scope attributes are flagged by accessibility scans and provided an example from a Level Access scan. #5 jonnyhocks: Asked for any updates or solutions to automatically add scope attributes. #6 Witoso: Explained that attributes are preserved when General HTML Support is enabled. #7 jonnyhocks: Clarified the meaning of “yet” and asked about a roadmap. #8 Witoso: Stated the feature would likely be part of a larger table enhancement initiative but no timeline was available. #9 chrisrhymes: Asked whether CKEditor 5 could adopt the CKEditor 4 table scope functionality. #10 Witoso: Responded that CKEditor 5 is a different engine and porting is not immediate. #11 nathanv: Offered to implement the feature if guidance was provided. #12 ineswillenbrock: Requested an indication of the issue’s priority, expressing a wish to avoid switching editors. #13 tilensA11Y: Emphasized that the lack of scope attributes causes failure of WCAG 1.3.1 and EN 301 549 compliance. #14 agendartobias: Demanded a bug fix due to identical experience. #15 proudnerds‑typo3: Agreed that the issue is urgent. #16 A‑Kun: Reiterated the need for automatic inclusion of scope attributes during the CKEditor 5 transition. #17 Witoso: Noted that table enhancements are scheduled for v48 and that the scope issue will be considered.
models.thread_links: - [Using tables for visually impaired users – MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/HTML/Tables/Advanced#Tables_for_visually_impaired_users): Explains the role of `scope` attributes in accessible tables. - [WCAG 2.2 – 1.3.1 Info and Relationships](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/info-and-relationships.html): Defines the success criterion relevant to header scope markup. - [CKEditor 4 issue 5084 – Scope attribute support](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor4/issues/5084): Historical reference to the feature in CKEditor 4. - [CKEditor 5 General HTML Support](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/html/general-html-support.html): Notes that scope attributes are preserved when this feature is enabled.

title: Resizer should feature explicit size input
context:
## Is this a bug report or feature request?

🆕 Feature request

## 💻 Version of CKEditor

CKEditor v5 @ 12.4.0

## 📋 Steps to reproduce

This idea sparkled during ckeditor5-image#241.

The question how to do that remains open for discussion.

* How should it be displayed?
* Should there be a possibility to adjust height too? Should it be disconnected from width, thus allowing for breaking image aspect ratio?

There are several benefits of adding this feature:

* Users are able to get precise image size without instead of making a super precise resize operation.
* We make the resizer feature accessible.
* Fields can be used to see current image size, without triggering the resizer.

References: https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519117147, https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519400868, https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519443993, https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519898056

---

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add 👍 to this post.
description:
## Is this a bug report or feature request?

🆕 Feature request

## 💻 Version of CKEditor

CKEditor v5 @ 12.4.0

## 📋 Steps to reproduce

This idea sparkled during ckeditor5-image#241.

The question how to do that remains open for discussion.

* How should it be displayed?
* Should there be a possibility to adjust height too? Should it be disconnected from width, thus allowing for breaking image aspect ratio?

There are several benefits of adding this feature:

* Users are able to get precise image size without instead of making a super precise resize operation.
* We make the resizer feature accessible.
* Fields can be used to see current image size, without triggering the resizer.

References: https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519117147, https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519400868, https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519443993, https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519898056

---

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add 👍 to this post.

models.text: Users who rely on keyboard or screen readers cannot precisely set or verify the dimensions of an image because the current resizer only offers a mouse‑draggable handle with no accessible numeric input. This lack of a focusable, text‑based control prevents users with motor impairments or those using assistive technology from accurately resizing images, creating a barrier to effective content editing.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on keyboard or screen readers cannot precisely set or verify the dimensions of an image because the current resizer only offers a mouse‑draggable handle with no accessible numeric input. This lack of a focusable, text‑based control prevents users with motor impairments or those using assistive technology from accurately resizing images, creating a barrier to effective content editing.
models.thread_tldr: The issue requests adding an explicit size input to CKEditor’s image resizer to allow precise dimension control and improved accessibility. Three comments reference related proposals, but there is no evidence of a resolution or implementation; the current status remains unclear.
models.thread_problem: A feature that would let users enter exact width and optionally height values directly into the image resizer toolbar is missing. Without this input, users cannot easily set or view precise dimensions, which limits fine‑tuned resizing and may hinder accessibility for those who rely on explicit size information.
models.thread_timeline: #1 mlewand: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 oleq: Provided a reference to a related issue comment. #3 remizorrr: Asked for updates on the task and suggested combining pixel and percentage resizing in a single interface.
models.thread_links: - [CKEditor 5 image plugin issue #241 – proposal to add an input straight into the toolbar](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519400868): Initial proposal for a toolbar input. - [CKEditor 5 issue #5167 – related comment on resizing](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/5167#issuecomment-649757648): Additional discussion on resizing features. - [CKEditor 5 image plugin issue #241 – comment on resizing idea](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519117147): Reference to the original discussion. - [CKEditor 5 image plugin issue #241 – comment on resizing idea](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519443993): Additional resizing suggestion. - [CKEditor 5 image plugin issue #241 – comment on resizing idea](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519898056): Further discussion of the resizing feature.

title: Keystroke for BlockToolbar
context:
It is possible to navigate through block toolbar items using <kbd>arrow left</kbd> and <kbd>arrow right</kbd> keys. It is possible to close the block toolbar using <kbd>Esc</kbd> or moving focus back to the editable using <kbd>Tab</kbd>. The only missing feature is keystrok for opening and focusing the block toolbar.

![jun-27-2018 20-39-18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1057056/41992948-3784a946-7a4a-11e8-80f0-7954079cc9ac.gif)
description:
It is possible to navigate through block toolbar items using <kbd>arrow left</kbd> and <kbd>arrow right</kbd> keys. It is possible to close the block toolbar using <kbd>Esc</kbd> or moving focus back to the editable using <kbd>Tab</kbd>. The only missing feature is keystrok for opening and focusing the block toolbar.

![jun-27-2018 20-39-18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1057056/41992948-3784a946-7a4a-11e8-80f0-7954079cc9ac.gif)

models.text: Users who rely on keyboard navigation cannot access the block toolbar because there is no keyboard shortcut or focusable trigger to open it; this limits the ability to use formatting features without a mouse.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on keyboard navigation cannot access the block toolbar because there is no keyboard shortcut or focusable trigger to open it; this limits the ability to use formatting features without a mouse.
models.dev_note: Add a keyboard‑accessible trigger (e.g., a <button> with an accessible name) that toggles the toolbar.  The button should be focusable, have role="button", aria-haspopup="true", aria-controls="block-toolbar-id", and aria-expanded="false" until the toolbar is shown, then set to "true".  When the button receives focus or is activated via Enter/Space, open the toolbar and move focus to the first toolbar item.  The toolbar itself can use role="toolbar" and its items as <button> elements, with arrow navigation handled by the existing script.  Ensure that pressing Esc or Tab when the toolbar is focused closes it and returns focus to the editable area.  This follows the WAI‑ARIA 1.2 pattern for toolbars and keeps markup semantic.
models.thread_tldr: Users cannot open the block toolbar with a keyboard shortcut, limiting keyboard navigation of toolbar items. The issue was reported and discussed, but no resolution or implementation is evident in the thread.
models.thread_problem: The block toolbar lacks a dedicated keystroke to open and focus it, preventing keyboard‑only users from accessing its functionality. This barrier violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.1.1 (Keyboard accessibility).
models.thread_timeline: #1 oleq: Reported the missing keystroke needed to open and focus the block toolbar. #2 Reinmar: Proposed using the Tab key, raising concerns about potential conflicts. #3 oleq: Explained that Tab would collide with table navigation and list indentation shortcuts. #4 Reinmar: Rejected Tab as a suitable solution after understanding the conflicts.

title: Disable (or make it a buried feature) the ability to set more than one row/column of table headers.
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the new feature
A11y feature: Right now the UI makes it easy to create complex tables with more than one row/column of headers, which can be problematic for some screen readers. In fact, a whole table can be set as a header with the current UI. (See https://webaim.org/techniques/tables/data#complextables)

*What is the expected behavior of the proposed feature?*
Header toggle should only allow the first row/column of headers. (Anything more, since it compromises a11y should be hidden deeper into the UI.

---

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

*What is the expected behavior of the proposed feature?*
Header toggle should only allow the first row/column of headers. (Anything more, since it compromises a11y should be hidden deeper into the UI.

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The current UI allows users to create tables with multiple header rows or columns. This can confuse screen readers because the relationship between header cells and data cells is not always conveyed clearly. As a result, users relying on assistive technology may experience difficulty navigating or understanding the table, leading to frustration or misinterpretation of the data.
models.acr_note: The current UI allows users to create tables with multiple header rows or columns. This can confuse screen readers because the relationship between header cells and data cells is not always conveyed clearly. As a result, users relying on assistive technology may experience difficulty navigating or understanding the table, leading to frustration or misinterpretation of the data.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor 5’s table UI allows users to mark more than one row or column as table headers, creating complex table structures that can confuse screen readers. The discussion consists of the initial report and a few follow‑up comments; no solution or resolution has been documented.
models.thread_problem: CKEditor 5’s current table header toggle lets users designate multiple header rows or columns. This capability can result in complex, multi‑level header structures that some screen readers cannot correctly interpret, potentially impairing the ability of users who rely on assistive technology to understand table data.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Reinmar: Filed the initial accessibility report and expressed uncertainty about how often the feature is used, cc @Comandeer. #2 mgifford: Discussed the We4Authors cluster’s focus on authoring tools and table accessibility. #3 mgifford: Suggested simplifying the Header tool, noting that Drupal assumes the top row as header while CKEditor 5 requires individual header specification. #4 jakegibs617: Highlighted the need for multi‑level header support and linked to a W3C tutorial on complex tables.
models.thread_links: - [Complex tables](https://webaim.org/techniques/tables/data#complextables): Explanation of accessibility challenges with tables that have multiple header rows or columns. - [Multi‑level tables tutorial](https://www.w3.org/WAI/tutorials/tables/multi-level/): Guidance on creating tables with nested header cells. - [We4Authors authoring tool](https://accessibilitycluster.com/authoringTool/): Resource discussing improvements to authoring tools for better accessibility.

context:

### ✔️ Expected result

### ❌ Actual result

*Resize browser window ( ALT+ F10 is system shortcut )

## 📃 Other details

* OS: Ubuntu (Linux)
* CKEditor version: latest master

### ✔️ Expected result

models.text: The Alt + F10 keystroke is captured by the operating system, so users cannot bring the CKEditor toolbar into focus with this shortcut. This prevents keyboard‑only users from accessing toolbar controls, which reduces the editor’s operability for people who rely on keyboard navigation.
models.acr_note: The Alt + F10 keystroke is captured by the operating system, so users cannot bring the CKEditor toolbar into focus with this shortcut. This prevents keyboard‑only users from accessing toolbar controls, which reduces the editor’s operability for people who rely on keyboard navigation.
models.thread_tldr: The Alt + F10 keystroke in CKEditor conflicts with the Linux system shortcut, preventing keyboard focus from reaching the toolbar. The issue was reported on GitHub but only received an acknowledgement comment, with no resolution or follow‑up. Current status is unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The Alt + F10 combination, expected to move focus to the CKEditor toolbar, triggers the Linux system shortcut instead, blocking keyboard access to toolbar functions. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.1.1 “Keyboard” because the functionality cannot be accessed via keyboard alone.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Mgsy: Responded to the issue with acknowledgement and note of difficulty. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.1.1: Keyboard](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#keyboard): Requires all functionality to be operable via keyboard, which is not met when Alt + F10 is intercepted by the OS.

title: Add option to only allow absolute links
context:
You can currently enter any random text and have it link relatively, which is not what we want. But we can't change this. It would be good if we could make it so you can only do links that start with `http`.
We use ckeditor for a content creation platform, the content isn't used on our website. So a relative link will go to our website in a private area. You could think "just don't do that" but you allow anything in the link field which has 2 problems... one is that they can simple make a relative link. 

But the bigger issue, and made worse by google chromes hiding of the protocol, is people do not know the different between `http://google.com` and `www.google.com`. So there is a high chance when someone manually types out a link they do so without the protocol. 

eg `if ( url.match( /^https?/ ) ) {`

---

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The issue describes a content‑creation validation problem—preventing relative or protocol‑less URLs in CKEditor. It does not present an accessibility barrier to users who consume the content; therefore, no WCAG violation is identified.
models.acr_note: The issue describes a content‑creation validation problem—preventing relative or protocol‑less URLs in CKEditor. It does not present an accessibility barrier to users who consume the content; therefore, no WCAG violation is identified.
models.dev_note: To enforce absolute URLs in CKEditor, add a validation step in the link dialog.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor allows users to insert URLs without an explicit protocol, which can create unintended relative links that point to private areas. The discussion consists of brief suggestions from three contributors, with no resolution or implemented fix evident.
models.thread_problem: CKEditor permits the creation of links that lack an explicit protocol (e.g., `http://`), leading to relative URLs that can navigate users to unintended destinations such as private areas of the site. This behavior may result in broken or insecure links within the content created by users.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Reinmar: Proposes warning users or enforcing protocol specification, suggesting auto-prepending on blur. #2 Reinmar: CC @oleq @panr to bring them into the discussion. #3 robclancy: Suggests a short‑term solution using a callback validator that displays an error when a link fails validation. #4 oleq: Supports the callback approach, detailing that the validator should return a result and an error message.

title: Should readonly editor be focusable?
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

I recently stumbled upon one thing connected to editable focus in CKE5.

So, when the editor is in read only mode, it receives `contenteditable=false` which makes it not-focusable by the browser, as it doesn't have `tabindex` set. This messes up with some features that use editor's `FocusTracker` to operate (I mean focusing annotations for comments and track changes, in readonly mode).

This is not a critical issue for now, but I'd like us to think whether the editor should be or should not be focusable when it is in readonly mode. For me readonly and focusing are different properties. I mean, why should editor be not focusable if it is readonly? For example, for default browser fields, `readonly=true` fields are still focusable.

The easy fix around that is adding `tabindex="-1"` to the editable element when it is in readonly mode. This will not mess up tabbing (tabbing will behave the same as it did in both readonly and normal mode). But it will enable clicking into markers to highlight annotations. However, this is the easy fix solution. Maybe there's more to that issue.

@oleq prepared a fiddle you can play with: [https://jsfiddle.net/oleq/j6vdsx0q/5/](https://jsfiddle.net/oleq/j6vdsx0q/5/)
description:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

I recently stumbled upon one thing connected to editable focus in CKE5.

So, when the editor is in read only mode, it receives `contenteditable=false` which makes it not-focusable by the browser, as it doesn't have `tabindex` set. This messes up with some features that use editor's `FocusTracker` to operate (I mean focusing annotations for comments and track changes, in readonly mode).

This is not a critical issue for now, but I'd like us to think whether the editor should be or should not be focusable when it is in readonly mode. For me readonly and focusing are different properties. I mean, why should editor be not focusable if it is readonly? For example, for default browser fields, `readonly=true` fields are still focusable.

The easy fix around that is adding `tabindex="-1"` to the editable element when it is in readonly mode. This will not mess up tabbing (tabbing will behave the same as it did in both readonly and normal mode). But it will enable clicking into markers to highlight annotations. However, this is the easy fix solution. Maybe there's more to that issue.

@oleq prepared a fiddle you can play with: [https://jsfiddle.net/oleq/j6vdsx0q/5/](https://jsfiddle.net/oleq/j6vdsx0q/5/)

models.text: The editor’s read‑only mode disables focus (contenteditable="false" and no tabindex), which prevents keyboard users and assistive‑technology users from navigating to the editor to view or interact with annotations, track‑change markers, or other focus‑dependent features. This loss of access constitutes a barrier to keyboard navigation and content interaction.
models.acr_note: The editor’s read‑only mode disables focus (contenteditable="false" and no tabindex), which prevents keyboard users and assistive‑technology users from navigating to the editor to view or interact with annotations, track‑change markers, or other focus‑dependent features. This loss of access constitutes a barrier to keyboard navigation and content interaction.
models.thread_tldr: The thread discusses whether a read‑only editor in CKEditor 5 should remain focusable. The issue has been raised and debated by several contributors, but no consensus or fix has yet been adopted, leaving the accessibility barrier unresolved.
models.thread_problem: When an editor is set to read‑only, it receives `contenteditable="false"` and no `tabindex`, making it unfocusable by the browser. This prevents keyboard users from interacting with annotations, contextual balloons, and toolbar actions that rely on focus tracking, potentially violating WCAG 2.2 criteria for keyboard accessibility and operable interfaces.
models.thread_timeline: #1 oleq: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 scofalik: Suggested using `tabindex="0"` instead of `-1` and referenced a Slack discussion. #3 oleq: Questioned whether `tabindex="0"` is the correct pattern and asked for recommendations. #4 Comandeer: Explained that a read‑only element should be marked with `[aria-readonly]` and cited the ARIA spec. #5 mlewand: Argued that read‑only fields should remain focusable to support selection and copy operations. #6 Reinmar: Indicated that the idea is conceptually acceptable but that further investigation is needed. #7 scofalik: Noted that inline annotations and contextual balloons are hidden when the editor is not focused, and that toolbar access is lost in non‑classic builds. #8 usqr: Commented that only inline UI is affected, highlighting inconsistency.
models.thread_links: - [W3C ARIA Readonly definition](https://w3c.github.io/aria/#aria-readonly): Provides the definition of readonly elements and their intended behavior. - [jsFiddle reproduction](https://jsfiddle.net/oleq/j6vdsx0q/5/): Demonstrates the focus behavior of a read‑only editor.

title: Any keystroke with alt key causes editor to remove the content
context:
## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1.  Open [code blocks feature sample](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/18.0.0/features/code-blocks.html).
2.  Open dev console.
3.  Execute following code `editor.keystrokes.set( 'ALT+C', 'codeBlock' );` to register ALT+C hotkey for the code block.
4.  Focus the **second editor** in the sample.
5.  Select "some text in the" in the first line.
6.  Press ALT+C.

### ✔️ Expected result

Code block is inserted and contains the first paragraph.

### ❌ Actual result

Code block is inserted but the previously selected text is removed.

## 📃 Other details

It also affects any alt + other modifiers combination, e.g. ALT+SHIFT+C. You can see that after undoing the removed text is restored.

*   Browser: Any
*   OS: Win10 (probably cross system, didn't check other OSes)
*   CKEditor version: 18.0.0

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The keyboard shortcut ALT + any key (e.g., ALT + C) removes the currently selected text before inserting a code block. Users who rely on the keyboard, including those with motor impairments or who use assistive technology, risk unintentionally deleting content, causing data loss and reducing confidence in the editor’s reliability.
models.acr_note: The keyboard shortcut ALT + any key (e.g., ALT + C) removes the currently selected text before inserting a code block. Users who rely on the keyboard, including those with motor impairments or who use assistive technology, risk unintentionally deleting content, causing data loss and reducing confidence in the editor’s reliability.
models.thread_tldr: Alt‑key combinations trigger removal of selected text in CKEditor 5, causing unintended content loss. The issue was reported with reproduction steps, and community members discussed possible causes but no fix or resolution has been documented. Current status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: When a user selects text and presses an Alt‑key combination (e.g., Alt+C) in CKEditor 5, the editor deletes the selected content before inserting a code block. This keyboard interaction barrier can prevent users from performing expected editing actions and results in accidental data loss, impacting users who rely on keyboard controls.
models.thread_timeline: #1 caramdache: Filed initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 kuku711: Found a workaround by placing the selection on the element so it won’t remove content. #3 strohne: Discussed possible cause involving double handling of keydown event and cancel() logic.
models.thread_links: - [CKEditor 5 Code Blocks Feature](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/18.0.0/features/code-blocks.html): Provides context for the editor environment where the issue occurs.

title: Find a proper solution for table selection in case of Balloon and Balloon Block editors
context:
Currently when multiple cells are selected, the table toolbar takes the precedence. It means that in case of Balloon and Balloon Block editors it's impossible to use the primary toolbar on selected cells. Which means that e.g. formatting tables becomes hard as one has to do it for each cell manually.

A follow-up of #6443

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍  reaction to this post. Also please explain your use case.

models.text: The reported issue causes the primary formatting toolbar to become inaccessible when users select multiple table cells in Balloon and Balloon Block editors. This restriction forces users—particularly those who rely on keyboard or assistive technologies—to format each cell individually, increasing effort and hindering efficient table manipulation.
models.acr_note: The reported issue causes the primary formatting toolbar to become inaccessible when users select multiple table cells in Balloon and Balloon Block editors. This restriction forces users—particularly those who rely on keyboard or assistive technologies—to format each cell individually, increasing effort and hindering efficient table manipulation.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that when multiple cells are selected in tables using the Balloon or Balloon Block editors, the table toolbar overrides the primary toolbar, making cell formatting cumbersome. Only two participants have commented, and no further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: In the Balloon and Balloon Block editors, selecting multiple table cells triggers the table toolbar, preventing the use of the primary toolbar for cell formatting. This restricts users from applying formatting actions to entire cell groups efficiently.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Reinmar: Filed the initial accessibility report. #2 Oliver-Stevens: Responded with a comment about alternative editor usage.

title: Opt out for inserting new row in the last cell on presisng tab key
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the new feature

Currently if you press the <kbd>tab</kbd> key in _the last cell_ of a table there's a behavior that inserts a row new row.

The <kbd>Tab</kbd> key is typically used for navigation, and not being able to leave the table with this key might be confusing for some. As a workaround you can use keyboard arrows to leave the table and then continue to use <kbd>tab</kbd> key.

I was hoping it can be at least configured by disabling the `insertTableRowBelow` command. However, if you do this the <kbd>tab</kbd> key does nothing at all (ignoring the fact that you can't use the "Insert row below" option from the table toolbar).

---

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.
description:

I was hoping it can be at least configured by disabling the `insertTableRowBelow` command. However, if you do this the <kbd>tab</kbd> key does nothing at all (ignoring the fact that you can't use the "Insert row below" option from the table toolbar).

---

models.text: The feature causes the Tab key to trigger an unintended insertion of a new table row when pressed in the last cell. This prevents users from navigating out of the table with the expected Tab behavior, effectively trapping focus and confusing keyboard users. The barrier impacts anyone who relies on keyboard navigation, including users with motor, cognitive, or learning disabilities, as well as those using assistive technologies that expect consistent Tab navigation.
models.acr_note: The feature causes the Tab key to trigger an unintended insertion of a new table row when pressed in the last cell. This prevents users from navigating out of the table with the expected Tab behavior, effectively trapping focus and confusing keyboard users. The barrier impacts anyone who relies on keyboard navigation, including users with motor, cognitive, or learning disabilities, as well as those using assistive technologies that expect consistent Tab navigation.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that pressing the Tab key while focus is on the last cell of a table inserts a new row, blocking navigation out of the table. Disabling the insert command stops Tab entirely, and no further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: When focus is in the last cell of a table, pressing the Tab key inserts a new row instead of moving focus to the next cell or element. This behavior interferes with the expected keyboard navigation flow for users who rely on Tab to advance focus through the document.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

title: [a11y] Images with no text alternative should still have alt=""
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

_How the feature works now and what you'd like to change_?

Currently, if an image does not have a text alternative, the `img` element is generated in the data view with no `alt` attribute. According to the HTML spec for "[purely decorative images](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#a-purely-decorative-image-that-doesn't-add-any-information)", and accessibility standards, all `img` elements must have an `alt` attribute, but that attribute should be the empty string `alt=""` when the image does not add any information that would be described in the text alternative.

While the current code maintains an empty alt tag if it is added manually and loaded in through the data view, it does not add the empty alt tag by default to newly inserted images. I think this could be fixed by explicitly setting the `alt` attribute in [insertImage](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/blob/91075a303e5b003b3a82fd96f57a651b6a3c95a9/packages/ckeditor5-image/src/image/utils.js#L82) if it's not passed in - but I'm not sure if that's the best place to do it. I can pass in an empty attribute when I call the insert command, and that will fix this in our editor, but it seems better if CKEditor were to generate accessible HTML by default, without me having to know this.

## 📃 Other details

* `ckeditor5-image` plugin
* tested on v19.0.0

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.
description:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

_How the feature works now and what you'd like to change_?

Currently, if an image does not have a text alternative, the `img` element is generated in the data view with no `alt` attribute. According to the HTML spec for "[purely decorative images](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#a-purely-decorative-image-that-doesn't-add-any-information)", and accessibility standards, all `img` elements must have an `alt` attribute, but that attribute should be the empty string `alt=""` when the image does not add any information that would be described in the text alternative.

While the current code maintains an empty alt tag if it is added manually and loaded in through the data view, it does not add the empty alt tag by default to newly inserted images. I think this could be fixed by explicitly setting the `alt` attribute in [insertImage](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/blob/91075a303e5b003b3a82fd96f57a651b6a3c95a9/packages/ckeditor5-image/src/image/utils.js#L82) if it's not passed in - but I'm not sure if that's the best place to do it. I can pass in an empty attribute when I call the insert command, and that will fix this in our editor, but it seems better if CKEditor were to generate accessible HTML by default, without me having to know this.

## 📃 Other details

* `ckeditor5-image` plugin
* tested on v19.0.0

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The absence of an `alt` attribute on `` elements inserted into the editor causes non‑decorative images to lack a text alternative, violating the requirement that all non‑text content provide a text alternative. This omission can lead to poor experiences for users of assistive technologies and invalidates the generated HTML against current web standards.
models.acr_note: The absence of an `alt` attribute on `` elements inserted into the editor causes non‑decorative images to lack a text alternative, violating the requirement that all non‑text content provide a text alternative. This omission can lead to poor experiences for users of assistive technologies and invalidates the generated HTML against current web standards.
models.thread_tldr: A CKEditor 5 feature creates `` elements without an `alt` attribute when no alternative text is supplied, violating the requirement that all images must have a text alternative (empty string for decorative images). The issue was reported, reproduced, and noted as stale with no resolution, so the current state remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: CKEditor 5 inserts `` tags that lack an `alt` attribute when the user does not provide one. According to the HTML specification and WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.1.1 (Non‑Text Content), every image must have a text alternative, and for purely decorative images this must be an empty string (`alt=""`). The current behavior therefore fails WCAG 2.2 AA compliance for images inserted without explicit alternative text.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Reinmar: Thanks for reporting this. We worked on it (#7405) but apparently, the patch was only partial. #2 Reinmar: Provided reproduction steps showing that an `` inserted without `alt` is output without an `alt` attribute. #3 mgifford: Commented that an explicit button to mark an image as decorative is good practice. #4 CKEditorBot: Marked the issue as stale, noting no activity for the past year and planning to close it in 30 days.
models.thread_links: - [Purely decorative images – HTML spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#a-purely-decorative-image-that-doesn't-add-any-information): Defines that decorative images must have an empty `alt` attribute. - [WCAG 2.2 Quick Reference – Non‑Text Content (1.1.1)](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref?applyTo=all&lang=en#non-text-content): WCAG success criterion requiring text alternatives for non‑text content. - [A11yfirst – Decorative Image Handling](https://a11yfirst.gitlab.io/custom/a11yfirst.html): Example of providing a decorative image option in CKEditor 4.

title: Add a keyboard shortcut to show Block Balloon toolbar
context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the new feature

Based on [keyboard support docs](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/keyboard-support.html) it is possible to focus the toolbar using `ALT-F10` and then move between toolbar items with arrows. This works fine for the "classic" build, but not for "balloon block" build. So to be clear, I'd like to be able to invoke following toolbar using keyboard only:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/617641/115622754-93314180-a2f8-11eb-8faf-bb72bba69618.png)


If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Users accessing CKEditor 5 on small iOS devices encounter a floating toolbar that opens off the visible screen, making toolbar controls inaccessible to touch, keyboard, and assistive technologies. This limits the ability to apply formatting commands and disrupts the editing experience.
models.acr_note: Users accessing CKEditor 5 on small iOS devices encounter a floating toolbar that opens off the visible screen, making toolbar controls inaccessible to touch, keyboard, and assistive technologies. This limits the ability to apply formatting commands and disrupts the editing experience.
models.thread_tldr: The inline editor’s floating toolbar fails to position correctly on narrow screens, often being hidden or losing visual cues such as the box shadow. The issue has been reported and reproduced on multiple devices, but no resolution or fix has been documented in the thread.
models.thread_problem: The floating toolbar of CKEditor’s inline editor does not adjust its opening direction to fit small screen space, causing the toolbar to appear off‑screen or partially hidden and to lose its box shadow. This prevents users from accessing toolbar controls on narrow viewports, thereby limiting the editor’s usability on mobile and desktop devices with limited width.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Mgsy: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 nileshawtade: Asked for an update on the issue. #3 tony1377: Asked for an ETA on a fix. #4 cmak9149: Asked for an update. #5 pomek: Reproduced the issue in a broader editor and shared a screenshot. #6 jjroelofs: Discussed workaround attempts and noted visual issues such as the toolbar losing its box shadow and position. #7 jjroelofs: Inquired about a bounty to fund a fix. #8 Witoso: Declined the bounty offer and directed the reporter to contact the CKEditor team. #9 jjroelofs: Requested guidance on which component should be targeted for a fix.

title: Accessibility: Compose tips tables need better use of id's & summary elements
context: Accessibility: Compose tips tables need better use of id's & summary elements
description: Accessibility: Compose tips tables need better use of id's & summary elements

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may have difficulty identifying and understanding the content within the “Compose Tips” tables due to a lack of clear semantic structure and appropriate identifiers. This impacts the ability to navigate and comprehend the information presented.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may have difficulty identifying and understanding the content within the “Compose Tips” tables due to a lack of clear semantic structure and appropriate identifiers. This impacts the ability to navigate and comprehend the information presented.
models.dev_note: The issue relates to the accessibility of tables within the “Compose Tips” section. To address this, the developers should refactor the table structure to leverage semantic HTML elements for improved screen reader navigation. Specifically, replace the current tabular structure with appropriate `<th>` elements for header cells and `<td>` elements for data cells. Each table must have a unique `id` attribute assigned to the `<table>` element.  Ensure each `<th>` element has a descriptive `aria-label` attribute if the text within the cell is not sufficiently descriptive for screen reader users. Use `scope` attributes on `<th>` elements to clearly define the relationship between header cells and data cells.  Avoid using ARIA attributes to fundamentally change the structure of the table; use them only to supplement or clarify native semantics where necessary.  Consider using a table with a clear heading row.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of compose tips tables needing better use of id's and summary elements remains active, with mgifford identifying the need for scope and headers attributes. A related issue has been created to address this, but no patches or PRs have been submitted yet. The status is currently ‘Postponed’ awaiting further development.
models.thread_problem: mgifford identified the need for improved table semantics by adding scope or headers/id attributes to the theme_table() function.  A new issue (#1645308) has been created to address this. The discussion references WCAG 2.2 Level AA as the accessibility baseline and links to external resources outlining best practices for HTML table semantics, specifically regarding screen reader support and WAI-ARIA specifications.
models.thread_timeline: #1 by Jeff Burnz: Subscribed. #2 by mgifford: Provided links to W3C HTML5 table attributes and tink.co.uk screen reader support documentation, stating the need for enhanced semantics. #3 by mgifford: Postponed the issue due to the need for scope and headers attributes in the theme table. #6 by mgifford: Version:8.0.x-dev» 8.1.x-dev, indicating ongoing consideration. #16 by mgifford: Created new issue #1645308 to improve table semantics. #23 by mgifford: Tagged WCAG 2.2 Level AA.

Ensure proper association between table headers (`<th>`) and data cells (`<td>`) using the `headers` attribute if applicable, referencing the `id` of the corresponding header cells. Consider using the `<caption>` element for a more explicit table title.

models.text: The website lacks clear language identification for individual elements, potentially creating confusion and difficulty for users who rely on assistive technologies to understand the content and functionality of the page. This barrier impacts users with cognitive disabilities and those who use screen readers to navigate complex web pages.
models.dev_note: This issue addresses the requirement to associate language with specific parts of a web page, as outlined in WCAG 3.1.2.  The primary solution involves using semantic HTML elements to structure the content logically.  For example, if a section is related to "navigation," use an `<nav>` element. If a section contains "form controls," use `<form>`.  Within these elements, include appropriate headings (e.g., `<h1>` - `<h6>`) to delineate sections and subsections.

title: Allow a custom HTML element to be selected for a grouping field
context: Allow a custom HTML element to be selected for a grouping field
description: Allow a custom HTML element to be selected for a grouping field

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding and interacting with a grouping field if a custom HTML element is used as the selection option. This reduces the clarity of the interface and limits the ability to effectively use the grouping functionality.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding and interacting with a grouping field if a custom HTML element is used as the selection option. This reduces the clarity of the interface and limits the ability to effectively use the grouping functionality.
models.dev_note: The issue description suggests allowing a custom HTML element to be selected within a grouping field. This presents a potential accessibility barrier. The primary solution should always be to leverage native HTML elements for grouping and selection.  Specifically, consider using `<select>` or `<button>` elements depending on the intended interaction. If these are unsuitable, investigate if the custom element can be refactored to utilize a more accessible alternative.  If a custom element *must* be used, then thorough ARIA implementation is crucial.  Use `role="group"` to define the grouping, `role="button"` or `role="checkbox"` (if appropriate) for the selection element, and ensure `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` provides clear and concise context for screen reader users.  Avoid overly complex or custom ARIA attributes; prioritize clarity and straightforward descriptions. Ensure sufficient color contrast for any interactive elements.  Consider keyboard navigation thoroughly to ensure proper focus management.  Testing with multiple screen readers (JAWS, NVDA, VoiceOver) is essential.
models.thread_tldr: The issue relates to a custom HTML element within a Views field, specifically the grouping field, potentially leading to an undefined array key error. The issue is currently stalled due to a lack of recent activity and requires further investigation into the ViewsConfigUpdater functionality and its interaction with existing views.

If not, contribute a patch back to the Drupal community after implementing the fix.

models.text: Users may encounter difficulty understanding and interacting with a grouping field that accepts a custom HTML element if the interaction isn't clearly conveyed to assistive technology users. The lack of a standard, accessible control type creates an ambiguity for screen reader users, potentially hindering their ability to navigate and utilize the grouping function effectively.
models.acr_note: Users may encounter difficulty understanding and interacting with a grouping field that accepts a custom HTML element if the interaction isn't clearly conveyed to assistive technology users. The lack of a standard, accessible control type creates an ambiguity for screen reader users, potentially hindering their ability to navigate and utilize the grouping function effectively.
models.dev_note: This issue presents a challenge in creating a truly accessible experience when a custom HTML element is used within a grouping field. The primary focus should be on leveraging semantic HTML to achieve the desired grouping functionality.
models.thread_tldr: The issue is a custom HTML element in a views field not rendering properly, resulting in an undefined array key error when grouping is applied. The issue is currently stalled due to a configuration update dependency and requires further investigation into the ViewsConfigUpdater code.
models.thread_problem: The issue stems from an inconsistency in how grouping elements are rendered within views. Specifically, a custom HTML element is not being correctly set to null, leading to an “Undefined array key 'grouping_label_element’” error when using grouping fields. A proposed fix via a pull request is currently awaiting review, and there has been no recent activity concerning the core Views module. WCAG 1.1.1 (Non-text Content) is relevant as the grouping field is not displaying correctly.

description: Allow modules to classify blocks when defining them, so WAI-ARIA roles can automatically be added in the theme layer

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience reduced discoverability and navigation if block types are not correctly identified. The current approach potentially hinders the automatic application of WAI-ARIA roles, impacting the accessibility of theme layers and potentially leading to a less predictable and consistent user experience for individuals with disabilities.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience reduced discoverability and navigation if block types are not correctly identified. The current approach potentially hinders the automatic application of WAI-ARIA roles, impacting the accessibility of theme layers and potentially leading to a less predictable and consistent user experience for individuals with disabilities.
models.dev_note: This issue addresses the need to ensure screen reader users receive appropriate semantic information about blocks within modules. The core strategy should be to leverage semantic HTML elements as much as possible. Specifically, correctly identifying the type of block within the module definition is key.
models.thread_tldr: The issue relates to insufficient ARIA landmark roles for block-level content, potentially impacting accessibility for screen reader users. The current patch attempts to address this but requires further testing and refinement, with no recent activity.
models.thread_problem: The issue concerns the lack of properly defined ARIA landmark roles for blocks, specifically referencing WCAG 2.2.A.1.1 (Name, Role, Value) and potentially leading to navigation difficulties for screen reader users.  User `xem8vfdh` submitted a patch (#55) attempting to add landmark roles, but it’s currently awaiting further review and testing.

models.text: The absence of clear semantic roles for content blocks may cause assistive technology users to miss important context, reducing the discoverability and navigation of page sections.
models.acr_note: The absence of clear semantic roles for content blocks may cause assistive technology users to miss important context, reducing the discoverability and navigation of page sections.
models.thread_tldr: An issue was reported to allow modules to classify blocks so that WAI‑ARIA roles can be added automatically in the theme layer, but only one comment has been posted and no further discussion or resolution is visible.
models.thread_problem: The current system does not provide a mechanism for modules to classify blocks when defining them, preventing automatic assignment of WAI‑ARIA roles in the theme layer. This limitation could hinder the generation of appropriate semantic markup required by assistive technologies, potentially affecting the accessibility of the rendered content.
models.thread_timeline: #Comment42.0 (not verified): Issue summary:View changesAdded a third option

models.text: The lack of semantic classification for blocks by modules hinders the ability to programmatically assign appropriate WAI-ARIA roles in the theme layer. This can result in missing or incorrect ARIA roles, leading to a degraded user experience for assistive technology users.
models.acr_note: The lack of semantic classification for blocks by modules hinders the ability to programmatically assign appropriate WAI-ARIA roles in the theme layer. This can result in missing or incorrect ARIA roles, leading to a degraded user experience for assistive technology users.
models.dev_note: Implement a system allowing modules to define block classifications during block definition. This could involve a new property within the block definition array. These classifications should be accessible in the theme layer, allowing theme developers to programmatically add appropriate WAI-ARIA roles based on the block's function (e.g., `navigation`, `search`, `complementary`). Check Drupal.org for existing patches or contributed modules addressing this specific issue before implementing a custom solution. Use `hook_block_info_alter` or similar hooks to modify block definitions.
models.thread_journey: #42 (not verified) added a third option relating to viewing changes, suggesting a development iteration. There is no other information.
models.thread_todo: * Understand what the third option proposed in comment #42 relates to and what the impact is. * Flesh out the initial proposal regarding module-defined block classifications and automatic WAI-ARIA role application. * Determine what classifications are needed. * Address the specifics of where this role would be applied in the theme layer. * Develop a patch demonstrating this functionality. * Test the patch, including screen reader testing.

models.text: Users may experience reduced accessibility if blocks defined within modules lack appropriate semantic markup, preventing screen readers from correctly interpreting their structure and function. This can lead to navigation difficulties and a fragmented user experience.
models.acr_note: Users may experience reduced accessibility if blocks defined within modules lack appropriate semantic markup, preventing screen readers from correctly interpreting their structure and function. This can lead to navigation difficulties and a fragmented user experience.
models.dev_note: The core issue is a lack of control over the semantic classification of blocks defined within modules. To address this, prioritize using semantic HTML elements (e.g., `<article>`, `<aside>`, `<nav>`, `<header>`, `<footer>`) to structure the content within the module. When native HTML semantics aren't sufficient to convey the intended purpose and relationship of the block, then judicious use of WAI-ARIA roles can be employed. Specifically, the theme layer should be designed to *apply* these ARIA roles based on the block classification defined during module creation.  Consider utilizing a design system with pre-defined block types and associated ARIA attributes for consistency.  Refer to WAI-ARIA 1.2 for best practices on role usage.  Example: If a module represents a "sidebar," use the `role="banner"` ARIA attribute on the relevant HTML element to indicate its navigational function.  Crucially, this should be configured during module definition, not as a post-hoc fix.
models.thread_tldr: This issue relates to ARIA landmark roles and potentially incorrect classification of blocks for accessibility. Currently, the issue is stalled with no recent activity and the patch #55 is not being actively worked on.
models.thread_problem: The issue centers around applying ARIA landmark roles to blocks, aiming to improve accessibility based on WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Contrast).  Patch #55 attempts to implement this, but the discussion reveals the implementation might be misinterpreting the relevant ARIA specifications. There is no recent technical activity or review.
