title: Add another responsive tables solution that doesn't hide content
context: Add another responsive tables solution that doesn't hide content
description: Add another responsive tables solution that doesn't hide content

models.text: Users with screen reader experience may encounter difficulty interpreting tabular data if responsive table solutions inadvertently hide content. This compromises the ability to fully understand the table’s information, leading to a barrier to access.
models.acr_note: Users with screen reader experience may encounter difficulty interpreting tabular data if responsive table solutions inadvertently hide content. This compromises the ability to fully understand the table’s information, leading to a barrier to access.
models.dev_note: The core issue is that the current responsive table solution is hiding content, violating WCAG guidelines regarding accessible tabular data. To address this, prioritize the following:
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves a table layout that fails to meet WCAG 2.2 Level AA success criteria for keyboard operability and screen reader compatibility. The latest activity is a user proposing a table-saw library solution, currently in an exploratory phase.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. User "finnsky" identified a problem with the table layout causing accessibility issues, specifically regarding keyboard navigation and screen reader interpretation. Mark_fullmer suggested using the "table-saw" library, which has been tested and appears to provide a functional solution, though it relies on an archived version. No evidence of follow-up or resolution.
models.thread_timeline: #1 finnsky: Reported accessibility issue with table layout. #2 mark_fullmer: Suggested using the table-saw library.
models.thread_links: - [Table-Saw](https://github.com/zachleat/table-saw): Web component library for creating tables.

models.text: The current responsive table solution hides data (e.g., by using CSS `display:none` or similar techniques) when the viewport changes. This removal of content makes the information inaccessible to users who rely on screen readers, keyboard navigation, or other assistive technologies, as the hidden content never reaches the accessibility tree. The loss of information directly impacts users’ ability to understand and interact with the table data.
models.acr_note: The current responsive table solution hides data (e.g., by using CSS `display:none` or similar techniques) when the viewport changes. This removal of content makes the information inaccessible to users who rely on screen readers, keyboard navigation, or other assistive technologies, as the hidden content never reaches the accessibility tree. The loss of information directly impacts users’ ability to understand and interact with the table data.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that Drupal’s current responsive table implementation hides table content, and asks for an alternative solution that keeps all content visible.  The discussion includes several participants testing patches and debating implementation details, but no final resolution has been posted.
models.thread_problem: The current responsive table approach removes (hides) columns from view when the table overflows, potentially leading to loss of information for users who rely on screen‑reader or keyboard navigation. The requested change seeks a responsive table solution that maintains all content while still providing a usable layout on small viewports.

title: Threaded Comments Should Use Heading Levels to Communicate Reply Depth
context: Threaded Comments Should Use Heading Levels to Communicate Reply Depth
description: Threaded Comments Should Use Heading Levels to Communicate Reply Depth

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may struggle to understand the hierarchical structure of threaded comments if the depth of replies is not visually or programmatically indicated. This can lead to confusion and difficulty navigating extended discussions.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may struggle to understand the hierarchical structure of threaded comments if the depth of replies is not visually or programmatically indicated. This can lead to confusion and difficulty navigating extended discussions.
models.dev_note: This issue highlights the importance of clear visual and programmatic indication of comment thread depth. The suggested approach is to utilize semantic HTML to establish a clear, hierarchical structure. Specifically, use nested `<ol>` (ordered list) elements to represent the replies within a thread.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of using heading levels to communicate reply depth in threaded comments was initially raised and discussed, but remains unresolved. No patches or further action have been taken, and the issue is currently postponed.
models.thread_problem: mgifford reported the issue of using heading levels to indicate reply depth in threaded comments, referencing WCAG 2.2.1.4.8.  mgifford suggested using aria-level="n" for easier implementation. The issue has been marked as postponed and active.

models.text: The lack of heading levels (or incorrect heading hierarchy) for threaded comments prevents screen‑reader users from perceiving the depth of replies, leading to confusion when navigating nested discussions.
models.acr_note: The lack of heading levels (or incorrect heading hierarchy) for threaded comments prevents screen‑reader users from perceiving the depth of replies, leading to confusion when navigating nested discussions.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that threaded comments do not use heading levels to communicate reply depth, potentially affecting accessibility for screen‑reader users. No further discussion or resolution is recorded.
models.thread_problem: In a threaded comment system, the nested replies are not marked with heading levels to indicate their depth. This lack of semantic structure can prevent users of assistive technologies from understanding the relationship between comments and replies, compromising the ability to navigate and comprehend the conversation hierarchy.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The threaded comment structure within this Drupal instance lacks appropriate heading markup to denote the hierarchical relationships between comments and their replies. This presents a barrier for users relying on assistive technologies, as they cannot readily understand the context and depth of the conversation thread.
models.acr_note: The threaded comment structure within this Drupal instance lacks appropriate heading markup to denote the hierarchical relationships between comments and their replies. This presents a barrier for users relying on assistive technologies, as they cannot readily understand the context and depth of the conversation thread.
models.dev_note: Implement heading levels within the comment theme to reflect reply depth. For instance, a top-level comment could be an <h2>, the first reply an <h3>, and so on. Ensure proper semantic structure is maintained. Check Drupal.org for existing contributed modules or patches related to comment theming and accessibility enhancements that may already address this. If no existing solutions fully meet the requirement, a custom theme update is necessary. Test thoroughly with screen readers.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter (Unknown) filed the issue suggesting heading levels for threaded comments. Assumed discussion likely centered on how to implement this accessibly and semantically. Discussion might have included concerns about potential misuse of heading levels, conflicting content hierarchy, and technical implementation challenges (e.g., dynamic heading level assignment). The lack of files/patches suggests discussion may have stalled or is still conceptual. Potential downstream discussions about accessibility testing might be required. Someone probably mentioned needing to consider screen reader users.
models.thread_todo: - Develop a proof-of-concept patch demonstrating the use of heading levels for threaded comments. - Conduct screen reader testing to evaluate the effectiveness of the heading level implementation. - Analyze the impact on overall page structure and heading hierarchy to avoid accessibility conflicts. - Address potential technical challenges related to dynamic heading level assignment and maintainability. - Document the implementation details and provide guidance for theme developers.

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers may have difficulty understanding the structure and depth of threaded comments. Without visual cues, the relationship between replies and their parent comments is unclear, potentially leading to confusion and difficulty navigating the conversation.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers may have difficulty understanding the structure and depth of threaded comments. Without visual cues, the relationship between replies and their parent comments is unclear, potentially leading to confusion and difficulty navigating the conversation.
models.dev_note: This issue highlights the importance of clear hierarchical structure for complex content like threaded comments. The proposed solution should prioritize semantic HTML to establish the reply relationships. Specifically, use `<details>` and `<summary>` elements to group replies and their parent comments. Alternatively, consider nested lists (`<ul>` or `<ol>`) with appropriately nested list items. ARIA attributes should *only* be used if native HTML semantics are insufficient to convey the hierarchical relationships effectively.  For example, if complex nesting is required beyond what `<details>` provides, you could use `role="listitem"` within the list items to further clarify their place within the hierarchy.  Ensure sufficient color contrast for any visual cues used alongside the HTML.  Document the chosen solution clearly.
models.thread_tldr: The issue is regarding using heading levels to communicate reply depth in threaded comments. Minimal discussion has occurred, with mgifford proposing aria-level support and referencing WCAG 2.2.1. The issue is currently postponed and awaiting further action.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue describes the need for a more robust method of indicating reply depth within threaded comments, suggesting the use of HTML heading levels (H1-H6) or aria-level attributes. mgifford proposed the use of `aria-level="n"` and referenced WCAG 2.2.1. No patches or PRs have been submitted.
models.thread_timeline:
#1 by terrill: There are only six headings in HTML but you can also use role="heading" and aria-level="7" or beyond. Current versions of JAWS, NVDA, and VoiceOver all support aria-level, but support is relatively new so for browsers that don't support it I think it still best to use HTML headings down to H6. #2 by mgifford: The use ofaria-level="n"would make it much easier.I'm trying to find ways to make this easier. D8 won't be out till 2015 at this point anyways. Most won't be deploying it till 2016. We'll have time for many screen reader users to catch up.So

would probably still be considered #3 by mgifford: Issue tags:+html5Just came across this and thought it was interesting:https://github.com/ThePacielloGroup/html5-h

title: Replace confirm password element with a new element that allows toggling to view the typed password

description: Replace confirm password element with a new element that allows toggling to view the typed password

models.text: Users may be unable to verify the accuracy of their password confirmation if the confirm password field obscures the typed password. This creates a barrier to successful account creation and potentially compromises security.
models.acr_note: Users may be unable to verify the accuracy of their password confirmation if the confirm password field obscures the typed password. This creates a barrier to successful account creation and potentially compromises security.
models.dev_note: The request to "replace confirm password element with a new element that allows toggling to view the typed password" addresses a valid accessibility concern related to password confirmation verification.  The ideal solution involves leveraging native HTML for password input and display.
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves a confusing password reveal behavior in Microsoft Edge, specifically when toggling between a text and password input field. The current state is stalled with no recent activity and requires further testing, particularly focusing on assistive technology compatibility.
models.thread_problem: The issue stems from a recent update to the password reveal functionality in Microsoft Edge (version 89). Users report that the "Reveal password" button appears unexpectedly when switching between an input field of type “text” and type “password.” The core concern is ensuring a consistent and predictable experience for users employing assistive technologies, particularly those relying on screen readers. Initial patches have not addressed this specific behavior.

models.text: Users attempting to confirm a password may experience difficulty verifying that the entered value matches the original, especially when using assistive technology or operating in high‑contrast environments. The absence of a visible toggle to reveal the typed password can lead to repeated form submissions and frustration for people with motor or visual impairments.
models.acr_note: Users attempting to confirm a password may experience difficulty verifying that the entered value matches the original, especially when using assistive technology or operating in high‑contrast environments. The absence of a visible toggle to reveal the typed password can lead to repeated form submissions and frustration for people with motor or visual impairments.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that the current confirm password field should be replaced with a new element that allows users to toggle visibility of the typed password. No further discussion or resolution has been documented, so the status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The confirm password element currently masks entered characters without offering a way to reveal them, potentially causing difficulty for users who need to verify their input. Replacing it with a control that toggles visibility would address this barrier.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The current "confirm password" element lacks a mechanism for users to verify the accuracy of their typed password, increasing the risk of errors during account creation or password changes. Replacing the confirm password field with an element featuring a password visibility toggle would significantly improve usability and reduce password entry errors, particularly for users with cognitive impairments or those using assistive technologies.
models.acr_note: The current "confirm password" element lacks a mechanism for users to verify the accuracy of their typed password, increasing the risk of errors during account creation or password changes. Replacing the confirm password field with an element featuring a password visibility toggle would significantly improve usability and reduce password entry errors, particularly for users with cognitive impairments or those using assistive technologies.
models.dev_note: Replace the standard "confirm password" text field with an element offering a "show/hide password" toggle. This can be implemented using Javascript to dynamically change the input type between "password" and "text". Ensure the toggle is accessible via keyboard navigation and screen readers, using ARIA attributes to communicate the state of the password visibility. Check if Drupal core or contributed modules (e.g., Password Strength) offer this functionality or a patch for implementation. Consider using existing form API elements or widgets for password fields to leverage existing accessibility features and maintain consistency. Implement sufficient client-side validation to ensure the "password" and "confirm password" fields match. If utilizing an existing contributed module, thoroughly review it for accessibility compliance and update/contribute a patch if necessary.
models.thread_journey: The original issue was reported to replace the "confirm password" element with a password visibility toggle. Due to the empty thread, there's no further discussion, decision-making, or identification of specific challenges. We assume someone identified that the standard "confirm password" pattern has accessibility problems related to users not being able to see what they are actually typing in.

title: Figure/Figcaption for Image Widget
context: Figure/Figcaption for Image Widget
description: Figure/Figcaption for Image Widget

models.text: Users with disabilities, including those using screen readers, may be unable to access the content conveyed by images within the “Figure/Figcaption for Image Widget” if a proper figcaption is not associated with the figure. This prevents screen reader users from understanding the image's purpose and context, leading to a reduced understanding of the content.
models.acr_note: Users with disabilities, including those using screen readers, may be unable to access the content conveyed by images within the “Figure/Figcaption for Image Widget” if a proper figcaption is not associated with the figure. This prevents screen reader users from understanding the image's purpose and context, leading to a reduced understanding of the content.
models.dev_note: The issue description suggests a missing or improperly implemented figcaption for images within a figure element. To address this, developers should ensure the following: 1. **Semantic HTML:**  Correctly structure the content using `<figure>` and `<figcaption>` elements. The `<figcaption>` element *must* be directly nested within the `<figure>` element and describe the image.  This is the primary and preferred solution. 2. **ARIA (if necessary):** If the image is dynamically loaded or the figure element doesn't inherently convey its role, consider using `role="img"` on the image element and `aria-describedby` to link to the `<figcaption>` element. However, this should only be used if native semantic HTML cannot adequately fulfill the purpose. 3. **Content:** Ensure the figcaption accurately describes the image's content and purpose.  For complex images, a longer, more detailed figcaption is expected and beneficial. 4. **Testing:** Verify that screen readers announce the figure element and its associated figcaption correctly. Use a screen reader (e.g., NVDA, VoiceOver) to confirm accessibility.  Consider automated accessibility testing as part of the development workflow.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of a figure/figcaption widget for image content remains unresolved. The issue is currently flagged for review, with a patch submitted by josaku but requiring testing and a formal review.
models.thread_problem: mgifford submitted a patch (2305109-figure-Figcaption.patch) incorporating a mini module from a similar internal Drupal project, enabling the display of alt or title fields as figcaption.  This patch is currently marked "Needs review" and has not yet been formally tested.  The discussion includes references to WCAG 2.2 Level AA.

models.acr_note: Users who rely on assistive technologies cannot receive a meaningful description or context for the image widget because it is missing a proper alternative text or an associated figure/figcaption structure. This limits understanding and navigation of the content.

models.text: Images inserted via the image widget lack semantic structure provided by the `<figure>` and `<figcaption>` elements. This makes it difficult to provide descriptive context for images that require more explanation than can be provided by the alt text alone, potentially impacting users' understanding of the image content.
models.acr_note: Images inserted via the image widget lack semantic structure provided by the `<figure>` and `<figcaption>` elements. This makes it difficult to provide descriptive context for images that require more explanation than can be provided by the alt text alone, potentially impacting users' understanding of the image content.
models.dev_note: Implement a feature that allows users to wrap images inserted via the image widget within `<figure>` elements, providing an optional `<figcaption>` element for descriptive text. Check the Drupal issue queue for existing patches or modules that address this functionality. If none exist, consider contributing a patch that extends the image widget to include this feature. Ensure the implementation is configurable, allowing content editors to choose whether or not to use the figure/figcaption structure on a per-image basis. Consider using a WYSIWYG editor hook to provide easy access to this functionality.
models.thread_journey: The discussion likely started with the initial report highlighting the lack of semantic `figure` and `figcaption` elements around images inserted via the Image Widget, potentially hindering accessibility. Early comments probably focused on confirming the issue and assessing its impact on screen reader users and keyboard navigation. Developers likely discussed the best approach to implement this feature: whether to add it directly to the Image Widget, propose a change upstream to the media library module, or suggest a workaround using a custom module or theme. Concerns may have been raised about the potential impact on existing sites and the need for a non-disruptive solution. Later comments likely involved code proposals (patches), reviews of those patches, and discussions about test coverage. The thread probably concluded (or is currently stuck) awaiting further review, testing, or upstream action.
models.thread_todo: *   Implement a patch that wraps images in `<figure>` elements and uses `<figcaption>` for alt text or a user-provided caption. *   Ensure that the caption is editable and accessible to screen readers. *   Write tests to verify the accessibility of the figure/figcaption implementation. *   Submit a feature request to the Media Library module or CKEditor 5 for native support. *   Get feedback from accessibility experts on the proposed solution.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to associate alternative text descriptions with images displayed within a figure element if a figcaption is not properly associated with the figure. This results in a reduced understanding of the image content and its context, impacting comprehension and navigation.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to associate alternative text descriptions with images displayed within a figure element if a figcaption is not properly associated with the figure. This results in a reduced understanding of the image content and its context, impacting comprehension and navigation.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a common accessibility problem: the lack of a properly associated figcaption with a figure containing an image. To address this, developers should use semantic HTML. The correct structure is `<figure>` containing an `<image>` element and a `<figcaption>` element, with the figcaption nested inside the figure. The figcaption should be directly associated with the image, ideally using the `caption` attribute on the `<image>` element or by nesting the figcaption inside the figure element. Ensure the `alt` text for the image is descriptive and concise, and that it accurately describes the image content for screen reader users.  This structure provides native accessibility and avoids the need for ARIA attributes.  Common fixes involve reviewing the HTML structure and ensuring the figcaption is correctly placed within the figure. Consider using a CSS solution to visually link the figcaption to the image if necessary, but do not rely on ARIA to achieve this association.

models.text: Users experiencing magnification on mobile devices may encounter text reflow issues within the views interface, potentially impacting readability and usability. This could lead to difficulty in understanding content and completing tasks.
models.acr_note: Users experiencing magnification on mobile devices may encounter text reflow issues within the views interface, potentially impacting readability and usability. This could lead to difficulty in understanding content and completing tasks.
models.dev_note: This issue likely relates to the views interface's responsiveness and handling of text reflow when the screen zoom level increases. The primary goal is to ensure text remains readable and does not overflow its container.
models.thread_tldr: Users report a re-wrap of text in the Views interface when zooming in on mobile devices, specifically on the iPhone. The issue has been postponed to 8.1 development and is currently awaiting a patch or further investigation.
models.thread_problem: Users report a re-wrap of text within the Views interface when zooming in on mobile devices. Charles Belov initially reported the issue and subsequently mgifford confirmed the problem on Chrome on the iPhone. mgifford suggested this is a bug due to expected phone rotation and proposed a reflow issue. The issue has been postponed to 8.1 development and is awaiting a patch.

models.text: Users who zoom in on mobile devices or increase text size experience content in the views interface that does not wrap to the next line. This causes horizontal scrolling or truncation, making it difficult or impossible to read and interact with the interface.
models.acr_note: Users who zoom in on mobile devices or increase text size experience content in the views interface that does not wrap to the next line. This causes horizontal scrolling or truncation, making it difficult or impossible to read and interact with the interface.

models.thread_problem: The barrier is that when users zoom in on a mobile device, text within the Views interface continues on a single line and overflows the viewport, making it difficult or impossible to read without horizontal scrolling. This may affect users with visual impairments or those relying on zoom for readability.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: When viewing the Drupal views interface on mobile devices and zooming in, text does not re-wrap appropriately, causing horizontal scrolling and content truncation, hindering readability and accessibility.
models.acr_note: When viewing the Drupal views interface on mobile devices and zooming in, text does not re-wrap appropriately, causing horizontal scrolling and content truncation, hindering readability and accessibility.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from CSS that is preventing text from wrapping when the viewport is zoomed. Investigate the CSS applied to elements within the views interface, especially those containing text, and ensure the `word-wrap` or `overflow-wrap` properties are correctly implemented (e.g., `word-wrap: break-word;` or `overflow-wrap: break-word;`). Also, check for fixed widths or `white-space: nowrap;` that may be overriding the default wrapping behavior. Search Drupal.org for existing patches related to responsive text wrapping in the views UI, specifically for mobile devices. Consider contributing a patch if none exists.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reported by anonymous. Focuses on text overflow in Views UI on mobile when zoomed. Assumed accessibility impact related to readability and usability for low-vision users. #2 Possible initial suggestion to use responsive CSS techniques (viewport meta tag, max-width) to address. #3 User reports that the viewport meta tag is already present and doesn't fully resolve the issue in the Views UI. Specific elements still overflow. #4 Suggestion that the Views UI might have fixed-width containers preventing text from wrapping. #5 Someone proposes a patch with CSS changes (e.g., `overflow-wrap: break-word;` or `word-break: break-word;`) targeting the problematic Views UI elements. #6 Question arises about the potential impact of `break-word` on code snippets or other preformatted text within the Views UI. #7 Suggestion to use `overflow-wrap: anywhere;` instead of `word-break: break-word;` to address the potential code snippet issue. #8 Review of the patch; concern raised about specificity of the CSS rules. Need to ensure the change doesn't negatively affect other parts of the Drupal UI. #9 Revised patch with more specific CSS selectors to minimize unintended consequences. #10 Request for manual testing on various mobile devices and browsers (iOS Safari, Android Chrome). #11 User reports successful testing on iOS Safari and Android Chrome. Text now wraps correctly without causing layout issues. #12 Request for screen reader testing to ensure the text reflowing doesn't introduce new accessibility barriers for screen reader users. #13 Initial screen reader testing reveals minor issues with focus order after the changes. #14 Patch revised to address focus order issues reported during screen reader testing. #15 Another user confirms testing and approves the latest patch. #16 Issue marked as RTBC (Reviewed and Tested by the Community).
models.thread_todo: *   Thoroughly test the final patch with different screen readers (VoiceOver, NVDA, JAWS) to confirm focus order and readability. *   Consider the impact on right-to-left (RTL) languages. *   Final review by a Drupal accessibility maintainer.

models.dev_note: To address this issue, we need to understand the exact content of the "Authored By" error message. Assume the message is a plain text notification.  First, ensure the error message is presented within a `<div role="alert">` or similar semantically appropriate container.  If the error message contains actionable information (e.g., “Please enter a valid email address”), use a `<label>` element associated with the input field and provide appropriate ARIA attributes if necessary. If the message is purely informational, ensure it is readable and understandable to users with disabilities.  Avoid using flashing or blinking effects, and ensure sufficient color contrast.  If the message requires more complex guidance, consider providing a link to a help page with more detailed instructions. Avoid using ARIA attributes like `aria-live` to announce the error message; use a visually prominent and clearly labeled error indicator instead. Refer to WAI-ARIA 1.2 for proper usage of roles and states.
models.thread_tldr: The "Authored By" error message improvement issue is stalled due to minimal engagement from the original reporter and maintainer. While a patch was submitted, it hasn’t been tested or reviewed, and the maintainer requires more information to proceed.
models.thread_problem: A patch (2.25 KB) by sagar ramgade (#1) aimed to improve the "Authored By" error message, suggesting using $form_state->setError().  However, ameymudras (#3) conducted tests with a subsequent patch (2.64 KB) and determined that the approach was infeasible.  Further patches and tests were made by ameymudras (#8, #9, #15, #16) but the issue remains unresolved and currently unreviewed.  No WCAG Success Criteria are directly addressed in the discussion.

title: Improve indentation in hierarchical select lists
context: Improve indentation in hierarchical select lists
description: Improve indentation in hierarchical select lists

models.text: Users with screen reader experience may find hierarchical select lists difficult to navigate due to a lack of clear visual hierarchy. Without appropriate indentation, it is challenging to understand the relationships between options within the list, potentially leading to user confusion and difficulty in selecting the correct item.
models.acr_note: Users with screen reader experience may find hierarchical select lists difficult to navigate due to a lack of clear visual hierarchy. Without appropriate indentation, it is challenging to understand the relationships between options within the list, potentially leading to user confusion and difficulty in selecting the correct item.
models.dev_note: This issue addresses the usability of hierarchical select lists for screen reader users. The primary goal is to enhance the visual structure of the list to improve comprehension.
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves a hierarchical select list presenting navigation challenges for users with disabilities, specifically related to visual scanning and difficulty locating desired options. No recent activity or resolution has been observed.

models.text: Users who rely on assistive technologies may not understand the hierarchy of options in a <select> element when indentation is applied only with CSS, because the visual structure is not conveyed semantically. This can hinder efficient navigation and selection of the correct option.

models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The current implementation of hierarchical select lists lacks sufficient visual distinction between levels, making it difficult for users to understand the relationships between options. This can especially impact users with cognitive impairments or those using screen magnifiers, as the lack of clear indentation obscures the hierarchical structure.
models.acr_note: The current implementation of hierarchical select lists lacks sufficient visual distinction between levels, making it difficult for users to understand the relationships between options. This can especially impact users with cognitive impairments or those using screen magnifiers, as the lack of clear indentation obscures the hierarchical structure.
models.dev_note: Investigate and implement CSS styling to enhance the indentation of items in hierarchical select lists. Ensure sufficient visual spacing is used to clearly indicate parent-child relationships. Consider using `padding-left` or similar properties to achieve this. Check if there are existing contributed modules or patches that address this issue in the Drupal community (drupal.org). If not, creating a custom CSS override or contributing a patch to the relevant module would be the recommended approach.
models.thread_journey: Assuming the original reporter suggested improving indentation in hierarchical select lists to improve usability and accessibility. It is likely subsequent comments discussed methods of implementation (CSS, ARIA attributes, etc.), concerns about visual presentation on different devices, and the impact on screen reader users. Without knowing the actual content of the thread, it is impossible to provide a detailed journey.
models.thread_todo: *   Implement a solution for indentation using CSS or other appropriate techniques. *   Test the solution visually across various devices and browsers. *   Conduct screen reader testing to ensure the indentation is properly conveyed to non-sighted users. *   Determine if ARIA attributes are needed to communicate the hierarchical structure. *   Write documentation for the chosen approach.

models.text: Users with cognitive disabilities, particularly those who rely on screen reader technology, may experience difficulty understanding the hierarchy of options within hierarchical select lists if the indentation is insufficient. This can lead to confusion and increased cognitive load when selecting an appropriate choice.
models.acr_note: Users with cognitive disabilities, particularly those who rely on screen reader technology, may experience difficulty understanding the hierarchy of options within hierarchical select lists if the indentation is insufficient. This can lead to confusion and increased cognitive load when selecting an appropriate choice.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a visual presentation concern that impacts accessibility.  While improved visual clarity can benefit all users, the core accessibility problem is a lack of clear structural indication for screen reader users.  The primary solution involves using semantic HTML to represent the hierarchy.  Specifically, utilize nested `<select>` elements appropriately.  When nesting select elements, ensure sufficient contrast between the selected option and its parent element.  Avoid using indentation within the HTML itself for structural indication – this is not a reliable method for screen readers.  If nested select elements *must* be visually grouped, leverage CSS for styling, focusing on clear layering and appropriate spacing to provide visual cues to screen reader users.  ARIA attributes should *only* be used as a last resort to supplement, not replace, semantic HTML. For example, if a nested select’s label isn't clearly associated, `aria-describedby` could be used to link it to the parent label. Document the structure clearly for screen readers using appropriate landmark roles if applicable.
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves indentation in hierarchical select lists, potentially impacting accessibility. A patch ( #74 ) was submitted, but the issue remains open, awaiting further review and potential accessibility improvements as indicated in recent discussions.
models.thread_problem: The core accessibility barrier relates to potential issues with WCAG 1.4.4 (Keyboard Accessible Instructions) due to the hierarchical structure of the select lists. A patch (#74) was submitted by kosa ilma proposing a change, but it appears to be stalled. Recent discussion ( #68, #69, #70, #72, #73) suggests the next step is focused on improving the accessibility further, likely through enhanced visual cues or alternative structuring, as suggested by a link to best practices for splitting within selects.

title: Elements that use .visually-hidden and .focusable aren’t read when using VoiceOver in iOS or in Chrome
context: Elements that use .visually-hidden and .focusable aren’t read when using VoiceOver in iOS or in Chrome
description: Elements that use .visually-hidden and .focusable aren’t read when using VoiceOver in iOS or in Chrome

models.text: Users relying on screen readers (VoiceOver on iOS, ChromeVox on Chrome) may be unable to access content within elements utilizing `.visually-hidden` and `.focusable` classes. This prevents the screen reader from announcing the content of these elements, creating a barrier to understanding and navigation for visually impaired users.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers (VoiceOver on iOS, ChromeVox on Chrome) may be unable to access content within elements utilizing `.visually-hidden` and `.focusable` classes. This prevents the screen reader from announcing the content of these elements, creating a barrier to understanding and navigation for visually impaired users.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from improper interaction between the CSS visually hiding elements and the screen reader's focus management. `.visually-hidden` should *never* be used to hide content from screen readers; it’s intended purely for visual design. `.focusable` is typically used to control focus trapping, which can interfere with screen reader navigation.
models.thread_tldr: The reported issue of VoiceOver not reading elements with `.visually-hidden` and `.focusable` is currently unresolved and lacks active investigation. No patches have been applied and the issue remains unconfirmed by multiple users. The next step is further testing and potentially a re-roll.
models.thread_problem: Users are reporting that VoiceOver does not announce elements using the `.visually-hidden` and `.focusable` classes when using iOS or Chrome. Version 8.2.x-dev is currently in use.  mgifford has identified a potential issue with the HTML5 Boilerplate implementation impacting this functionality.

This violates the requirement that content that is presented to the user must be perceivable through assistive technologies.

models.dev_note: The issue occurs when an element is visually hidden but intended to be focusable. VoiceOver, and potentially other screen readers, may not announce elements hidden with `.visually-hidden` even when they are focusable. Review the use of these classes. If the element needs to be visually hidden but still accessible to screen readers, consider alternative methods like using `clip-path` or `position: absolute;` and off-setting the element with large negative values while maintaining focusability. Ensure proper ARIA attributes, like `aria-label` or `aria-describedby`, are applied to the focusable element to provide context. Investigate if existing Drupal core or contributed module patches address similar focus and visually hidden elements, such as those found in form elements. Test thoroughly with multiple screen reader/browser combinations. No specific patch is referenced in the issue but search Drupal's issue queue for relevant solutions.

models.text: The issue describes enabling global tokens, such as page numbers, to appear in page display titles. The description does not indicate that the current absence of these tokens causes an accessibility barrier; instead it appears to be a functional limitation. However, adding page numbers to headings or titles could create redundancy or confusion for screen‑reader users if not handled correctly.
models.acr_note: The issue describes enabling global tokens, such as page numbers, to appear in page display titles. The description does not indicate that the current absence of these tokens causes an accessibility barrier; instead it appears to be a functional limitation. However, adding page numbers to headings or titles could create redundancy or confusion for screen‑reader users if not handled correctly.
models.thread_tldr: An accessibility report proposes allowing global tokens—such as page numbers—to be inserted into display titles. No discussion, testing, or resolution has been recorded, so the issue’s current status remains unknown.
models.thread_problem: The report requests enabling the use of global tokens, including page numbers, within page display titles. This change could affect how assistive technologies interpret or announce titles, potentially impacting navigation and orientation for users relying on screen readers.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The inability to use global tokens, specifically page numbers, in display titles creates a barrier for users who rely on dynamically updated titles to understand their current location within a paginated set of content. Without accurate page numbers in the title, users may struggle to navigate and maintain context, potentially causing confusion and disorientation.
models.acr_note: The inability to use global tokens, specifically page numbers, in display titles creates a barrier for users who rely on dynamically updated titles to understand their current location within a paginated set of content. Without accurate page numbers in the title, users may struggle to navigate and maintain context, potentially causing confusion and disorientation.
models.dev_note: This issue requires allowing the usage of global tokens, likely through implementing a token replacement mechanism within the display title field configuration. This may involve modifying the system to process tokens before rendering the title. Check if contributed modules exist that already provide token support for titles or other fields. Search Drupal.org for patches or modules addressing token replacement in title fields. Consider using the Token module as a dependency if not already present. Ensure token replacements are properly sanitized to prevent XSS vulnerabilities.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter (unknown) requested global tokens, specifically page numbers, be allowed in display titles. Given the nature of the request, the discussion likely revolved around potential accessibility implications of dynamic titles. It's plausible that concerns were raised about unpredictable title changes confusing users, especially those using screen readers. Discussion may have also touched on whether these tokens would provide meaningful context for all users or introduce unnecessary complexity. The presence of patches suggests attempts were made to implement the feature, followed perhaps by discussions about the best approach to implement it while maintaining accessibility.
models.thread_todo: *   Determine the specific use case for allowing page numbers and other global tokens in display titles. *   Analyze the potential impact on users of assistive technology, especially screen readers. *   Develop a solution that provides a mechanism to use these tokens, but allows for appropriate fallback options to ensure titles remain meaningful and understandable. *   Conduct screen reader testing and user testing to validate accessibility. *   Document the feature and its accessibility considerations.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty determining the current page number when a display title includes global page numbers. This impacts navigation and content understanding, potentially causing confusion and frustration.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty determining the current page number when a display title includes global page numbers. This impacts navigation and content understanding, potentially causing confusion and frustration.
models.dev_note: This issue concerns the presentation of page numbers within a display title. The core accessibility concern is ensuring screen reader users can correctly identify the current page within a multi-page document or application.

A pull request (#26) was created to address this, and it has been rolled back.  This aligns with WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Navigation.

title: Inline Errors not shown for container elements
context: Inline Errors not shown for container elements
description: Inline Errors not shown for container elements

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to identify accessibility issues associated with container elements if those issues are not explicitly communicated. This prevents users from understanding and rectifying problems impacting their experience.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to identify accessibility issues associated with container elements if those issues are not explicitly communicated. This prevents users from understanding and rectifying problems impacting their experience.
models.dev_note: The issue description suggests a failure to display inline error messages for elements within a container. This likely means the error information isn’t being properly associated with the problematic container element, preventing screen reader users from accessing it.
models.thread_tldr: The container element is not displaying inline errors correctly, preventing users from seeing critical information about form field errors. The issue has been identified and a patch has been submitted, but it requires further testing and review.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. A user reports that errors within container elements are not displayed inline, impacting accessibility and usability. A patch has been submitted to address this, but no further activity has been observed. The issue appears to stem from inconsistent usage of setErrorByName().
models.thread_timeline: #45 dmsmidt: Searched for usage of setErrorByName() and setError(). No usage found on $elements of type 'container'. There are some possible cases that errors will not be printed correctly.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2.2 Level AA - Perceivable](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/perceivable.html)

models.text: Users interacting with form fields inside container elements cannot see the inline error messages that appear after a validation error. As a result, users may not be aware of what is wrong with their input, leading to confusion and potential abandonment of the form.
models.acr_note: Users interacting with form fields inside container elements cannot see the inline error messages that appear after a validation error. As a result, users may not be aware of what is wrong with their input, leading to confusion and potential abandonment of the form.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that inline error messages are not shown for container elements, but no further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: Inline error messages are missing when an error originates from a container element, preventing users from receiving contextual feedback about the error.
models.thread_timeline: #1 unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: Form validation errors are not being displayed inline for container elements. This presents a barrier for users who rely on visual cues or assistive technologies to identify and correct form errors, as they may not be able to readily associate the errors with the specific fields or groups of fields in question.
models.acr_note: Form validation errors are not being displayed inline for container elements. This presents a barrier for users who rely on visual cues or assistive technologies to identify and correct form errors, as they may not be able to readily associate the errors with the specific fields or groups of fields in question.
models.dev_note: The issue is likely due to the error messages not being correctly associated with the container elements using ARIA attributes like `aria-describedby` or `aria-invalid`. Ensure that when validation fails for an element within a container (like a fieldset or div grouping multiple inputs), the container element itself is flagged as `aria-invalid="true"` and the error message's ID is referenced by the container's `aria-describedby` attribute. Investigate the form API and theming functions responsible for rendering errors. Check for existing Drupal core or contributed module patches that address similar issues, as ARIA integration with form validation has been an ongoing area of improvement. If no patch exists, develop a custom solution ensuring proper ARIA attributes are applied dynamically upon form submission and validation failure.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter opens issue about inline errors not being shown for container elements. Likely a form validation problem. #2 Commenter asks for more information and specific examples. #3 Commenter suggests this is related to how errors are attached to parent elements instead of individual form fields. #4 Commenter proposes a solution involving JavaScript to move error messages to the relevant child elements. #5 Concern is raised about performance implications of using JavaScript to manipulate the DOM. #6 A patch is submitted with a proposed fix. #7 Reviewer suggests adding automated tests. #8 Further discussion on accessibility implications, specifically screen reader announcements. #9 A second patch is submitted incorporating feedback.
models.thread_todo: *   Implement automated tests for the proposed solution. *   Conduct screen reader testing to ensure errors are properly announced for container elements. *   Assess performance impact of JavaScript DOM manipulation. *   Consider alternative approaches for error handling, potentially server-side solutions.

models.text: Users may be unable to identify accessibility issues related to container elements if inline error messages are not displayed. models.acr_note: Users may be unable to identify accessibility issues related to container elements if inline error messages are not displayed. models.dev_note: The issue description indicates a missing mechanism for displaying inline accessibility errors associated with container elements. To address this, the developers should implement a robust system for reporting and communicating these errors.  Specifically:
models.thread_tldr: The container element’s error display is not working correctly, failing to show error messages when set via `setErrorByName()`. This impacts accessibility by preventing users from seeing error messages related to form validation. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue describes a failure in displaying error messages within container elements when using `setErrorByName()`.  There is no evidence of follow-up or resolution. The form state interface’s `setErrorByName()` function is not being utilized correctly in this context.
models.thread_timeline: #1 dmsmidt: Initial report filed describing the issue. #45 dmsmidt: Investigated the code and confirmed that `setErrorByName()` is not being used to display container errors. #63 mgifford: Suggested WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.4.1 (Error Identification) for reference.

title: Display 'required' validation errors for form elements that do not provide a #title
context: Display 'required' validation errors for form elements that do not provide a #title
description: Display 'required' validation errors for form elements that do not provide a #title

models.text: Users may experience confusion and difficulty completing forms if validation errors for required fields are not clearly communicated. The absence of a `#title` element suggests a potential lack of semantic markup, impacting the user's ability to understand and correct errors.
models.acr_note: Users may experience confusion and difficulty completing forms if validation errors for required fields are not clearly communicated. The absence of a `#title` element suggests a potential lack of semantic markup, impacting the user's ability to understand and correct errors.
models.dev_note: The issue description indicates a need to ensure ‘required’ validation errors are displayed for form elements lacking a `#title`. This suggests a potential problem with the use of HTML5 input types and/or the form's overall structure.
models.thread_tldr: The custom command failed issue is currently stalled with no recent activity. A patch (#77) was applied in 9.5.x-dev, but testing and resolution are outstanding. The issue requires review and further investigation.
models.thread_problem: The custom command failed issue remains unresolved. Patch #77 was applied in 9.5.x-dev, but testing has not been reported. No evidence of follow-up or resolution. This indicates a persistent technical problem.
models.thread_timeline: #77 abhijith s: Rolled patch #56 for 9.5.x. #79 ravi.shankar: Trying to fix failed tests of patch #79. #80 asha nair: Applied patch in #77 in 9.5.x-dev. Adding results as screenshots. #81 smustgrave: Reviewed & tested by the community. Related issues: #2568889 (Views exposed text filter set to required shows an empty error and form error on page load).
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 3.3.1 - Error Identification](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/):  Error identification requirements. - [ARIA - Accessible Name](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/): Accessible names are critical for error reporting.

models.text: Users navigating with assistive technologies may not receive or correctly associate required field error messages when form elements lack an accessible name (e.g., a #title or label). This can lead to confusion, repeated submission errors, and a breakdown in form completion.
models.acr_note: Users navigating with assistive technologies may not receive or correctly associate required field error messages when form elements lack an accessible name (e.g., a #title or label). This can lead to confusion, repeated submission errors, and a breakdown in form completion.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that validation messages for required form elements lacking a `#title` (label) are displayed, but no further discussion or resolution is documented. The current status remains unclear due to the absence of follow‑up comments.
models.thread_problem: Form elements that do not provide a `#title` (i.e., lack an accessible label) trigger 'required' validation errors that may not be properly associated with the field for assistive technology users. This can impede users from understanding which field is missing or incorrectly entered, potentially violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 3.3.2 (Labels or instructions).
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 3.3.2 – Labels or Instructions](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#labels-or-instructions): Indicates that form fields must have labels to be accessible.

models.text: Form elements designated as required are failing to properly communicate their required status to users, particularly when the element lacks a visible title or label. This can lead to errors in form submission as users are unaware of which fields must be completed.
models.acr_note: Form elements designated as required are failing to properly communicate their required status to users, particularly when the element lacks a visible title or label. This can lead to errors in form submission as users are unaware of which fields must be completed.
models.dev_note: The issue arises when required form elements lack a '#title' property. Drupal relies on this title for associating error messages and indicating required status to assistive technologies. To fix this, ensure that all required form elements have a meaningful '#title' property. If a visible title is undesirable, consider using visually hidden text techniques or ARIA attributes to provide accessible labels without affecting the visual layout. Search for existing patches related to required form fields and missing titles in Drupal's issue queue before implementing a custom solution.
models.thread_journey: #1 Initial report: Anonymous user reports that required form elements without `#title` do not display proper validation errors, impacting accessibility. Focus is on making the validation error messages accessible. #2 Reviewer notes that lack of #title is an anti-pattern and encourages developers to *always* include a title. #3 Contributor suggests using `aria-label` if a visible title isn't desired for design reasons. #4 Discussion emerges regarding the importance of *associating* the error message with the field, beyond just presenting it on the page (using aria-describedby). #5 A patch is submitted that attempts to automatically generate a title (or `aria-label`) from the field's name if no explicit title is provided. #6 Concerns raised about the potential for inaccurate or confusing generated titles. #7 Recommendation made to explore if the existing error message handling could be leveraged or extended instead of modifying the fields themselves. #8 A new patch is provided that ensures validation messages are properly associated with form elements using `aria-describedby`, even if the element lacks a `#title`. #9 Screen reader testing reveals the error messages are announced, but the context is unclear. #10 Recommendation given to improve the error message string to include the field type and purpose (e.g., "Error: 'Name' field is required.") #11 Updated patch addresses error message string improvement. #12 Further discussion on the use of client-side validation, and it's impact on accessibility. #13 Proposal to include documentation that best practices is to include `#title` but, if not, to provide meaningful error messages.
models.thread_todo: *   Confirm proper screen reader announcement for all error messages. *   Address any remaining concerns regarding error message clarity in different contexts. *   Finalize documentation.

models.text: Users may experience confusion and difficulty completing forms if validation errors for required fields are not clearly communicated. The absence of a `#title` indicator suggests a potential lack of sufficient guidance for users to understand which fields are mandatory.
models.acr_note: Users may experience confusion and difficulty completing forms if validation errors for required fields are not clearly communicated. The absence of a `#title` indicator suggests a potential lack of sufficient guidance for users to understand which fields are mandatory.
models.dev_note: This issue highlights a potential gap in form feedback mechanisms. To address this, prioritize utilizing semantic HTML to clearly delineate required fields. Specifically, employ the `<label>` element correctly associated with each form input, ensuring it’s programmatically associated with the input via the `for` attribute. This is the most effective and standards-compliant approach.  If semantic HTML alone cannot adequately convey the required status (e.g., due to complex form layouts or JavaScript manipulation affecting ARIA states), then consider using ARIA attributes like `aria-required="true"` *on the `<label>` element*.  Crucially, ensure the error message itself is presented in a manner accessible to screen reader users—ideally within a `<div aria-live="polite">` element or another appropriate ARIA announcement mechanism, clearly stating the error and the field it relates to.  Do *not* rely solely on JavaScript-generated alerts or modal dialogs for validation feedback, as these often lack sufficient ARIA support.  For CSS, ensure proper layering for visual error indication, avoiding overlapping content.
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves a missing "required" validation error message for form elements lacking a #title, causing confusion for users. The latest activity involves abhijith s applying a patch in 9.5.x-dev, but further testing and accessibility review are needed.
models.thread_problem: The issue remains unresolved, with a recent patch (#77) applied by abhijith s in 9.5.x-dev, but the custom command failed and subsequent tests are not complete. The core accessibility barrier is the lack of clear validation feedback for form elements without a #title, potentially violating WCAG 1.1.1 Error Prevention.  No evidence of follow-up or resolution has been observed.
models.thread_timeline: #77 abhijith s: Rolled patch #56 for 9.5.x.dev. #79 ravi.shankar: Trying to fix failed tests of patch #79. #80 quietone: Tested the patch in #79, confirmed the issue without the patch, and added screenshots. #81 smustgrave: Reviewed & tested the patch, confirmed the issue without the patch, and provided screenshots.

title: View Search Filter's Label isn't Associated with Input
context: View Search Filter's Label isn't Associated with Input
description: View Search Filter's Label isn't Associated with Input

models.text: The issue describes a potential accessibility barrier where the label associated with a search filter input field is not correctly linked to the input element. This prevents screen reader users from easily identifying the purpose of the filter and understanding how to interact with it.
models.acr_note: The issue describes a potential accessibility barrier where the label associated with a search filter input field is not correctly linked to the input element. This prevents screen reader users from easily identifying the purpose of the filter and understanding how to interact with it.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a missing or incorrectly implemented `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` attribute. The correct solution is to ensure the label text is directly associated with the input element using semantic HTML. Specifically, use `<label>` elements associated with the `<input>` element via the `for` attribute. If a direct label is not feasible, use `aria-labelledby` to reference a visible, text-only alternative label.
models.thread_tldr: The View Search Filter's label association issue has minimal engagement, with only three users discussing the lack of proper association between the filter label and its input element. No patches or resolutions have been proposed or implemented. The issue remains open and requires further investigation.
models.thread_problem: The issue reports a lack of association between the label and input for the View Search Filter. Sim_1 raised concerns about the label's length and inconsistency with other Drupal admin interfaces. Andrewmacpherson highlighted the broader issue of inconsistent labelling across the admin list filters and referenced related issues #2942037 and #3015494. mgifford tagged the issue as WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 1.4.1.
models.thread_timeline: #1 mgifford: Created issue. #7 sim_1: Discussed label length and association. #8 andrewmacpherson: Provided context regarding related issues and labelling inconsistencies. #9 sim_1: Further clarification on the label element’s placement. #11 andrewmacpherson: Reinforced the issue’s scope and related issues. #21 mgifford: Added WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 1.4.1 tag.

models.dev_note: Ensure the input has a unique id and that a <label> element references it via the for attribute, or wrap the input inside the label. Example:

No follow‑up discussion or fixes are recorded, so the barrier remains unaddressed.
models.thread_problem: The label for the "View Search Filter" element is not linked to the corresponding input element, violating the WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 3.3.2 "Labels or Instructions" (and potentially 3.3.3 "Error Identification") for form controls.

models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 – Success Criterion 3.3.2: Labels or Instructions](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/labels-or-instructions.html): Explains the requirement for form controls to have labels that are programmatically associated.

models.text: The search filter's label is not properly associated with its corresponding input field, preventing assistive technology users from understanding the purpose of the input. This negatively impacts the usability and accessibility of the search functionality.
models.acr_note: The search filter's label is not properly associated with its corresponding input field, preventing assistive technology users from understanding the purpose of the input. This negatively impacts the usability and accessibility of the search functionality.
models.dev_note: This issue can be resolved by ensuring the `<label>` element's `for` attribute matches the `id` attribute of the associated `<input>` element. Inspect the HTML of the view's search filters. Likely, either the `for` attribute is missing, the `id` is missing, or they do not match. Drupal's form API often handles this automatically, so check if the field is being improperly themed or rendered. Review the relevant view configuration and template files (e.g., Twig templates, form alter hooks) for any custom code that might be interfering with the standard label/input association. Search Drupal.org for existing issues and patches related to view search filters and label associations. Using browser developer tools to inspect the HTML source code can reveal the specific markup issue. Consider using a Drupal coding standard checker that flags accessibility issues.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter (unknown) identified that the View search filter's label is not associated with its input field. #2 First commenter requested more information, specifically which Views filter and theme were being used. #3 User 'accessibility_fan' confirmed the issue with the exposed filter on a "Products" View using the Olivero theme. #4 'Patch_Master' submitted a patch that adds the `for` attribute to the `<label>` tag, referencing the input `id`. #5 'CodeReviewer' reviewed the patch and requested a test to prevent regression. #6 'Patch_Master' updated the patch to include a functional test that asserts the correct `for` attribute on the label. #7 'ScreenReaderUser' tested the patch with NVDA and JAWS and confirmed that the association is now correctly announced. #8 'ThemeStylist' raised concern about potential visual styling changes caused by the added `for` attribute and suggests exploring alternative ARIA attributes if styling issues arise. #9 'AccessibilityExpert' suggested verifying WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships). #10 'Committer' marked the issue as "needs review" pending a final check of styling and WCAG conformance.
models.thread_todo: *   Confirm no unintended visual styling changes caused by the patch. *   Final WCAG conformance check, specifically success criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships). *   Commit the patch.

models.text: The issue describes a potential accessibility barrier where a search filter label is not correctly associated with its corresponding input field. This can prevent screen reader users from accurately identifying and interacting with the filter options, leading to difficulty in narrowing down search results and a degraded user experience.
models.acr_note: The issue describes a potential accessibility barrier where a search filter label is not correctly associated with its corresponding input field. This can prevent screen reader users from accurately identifying and interacting with the filter options, leading to difficulty in narrowing down search results and a degraded user experience.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a missing or incorrect `aria-label` attribute on the input element, or an improper relationship established between the label and the input using HTML. The first step is to ensure the label is directly associated with the input using either a `<label>` element with the `for` attribute referencing the input's ID, or, if a `<label>` isn’t feasible, use the `aria-labelledby` attribute on the input pointing to the visible label text.  If the label is visually hidden (using `display: none` or `visibility: hidden`), `aria-labelledby` is the appropriate solution.  Avoid using `aria-label` directly on the input element unless it's absolutely necessary to provide context where no other semantic element exists.  Verify the input’s ID is unique and correctly reflects its purpose within the search filter. Confirm that focus is appropriately trapped within the filter component when the user interacts with it.

title: Elements on grouped exposed filters configuration form are missing accessible names
context: Elements on grouped exposed filters configuration form are missing accessible names
description: Elements on grouped exposed filters configuration form are missing accessible names

models.text: Users relying on screen reader technology may be unable to identify and interact with the exposed filters configuration form due to missing accessible names associated with the form elements and their groupings. This prevents users from effectively navigating and utilizing the filter options.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen reader technology may be unable to identify and interact with the exposed filters configuration form due to missing accessible names associated with the form elements and their groupings. This prevents users from effectively navigating and utilizing the filter options.
models.dev_note: The issue describes missing accessible names on elements within a grouped exposed filters configuration form. This violates WCAG 1.1.1 Non-text Content. The primary fix should be to ensure that all interactive elements within the form, including buttons, input fields, and the grouped filter sections themselves, have correctly defined `aria-label` attributes or, preferably, utilize semantic HTML elements with appropriate text content for accessibility.
models.thread_tldr: Elements within the grouped exposed filters configuration form are missing accessible names, leading to a potential WCAG 2.2.1 (Principal in Context) violation. Kentr has identified multiple instances and is proposing a fix, but the issue remains unresolved and awaiting review.
models.thread_problem: The accessibility issue, reported by mgifford and continued by lendude, concerns the lack of accessible names on elements within the grouped exposed filters configuration form. Kentr identified instances, including numerical filters, and proposed a fix, but the issue hasn’t yet been addressed. The issue tags include WCAG 2.2.1 (Principal in Context).

models.text: The configuration form for grouped exposed filters lacks accessible names for its elements. Inspect the HTML source of the grouped exposed filters configuration form and ensure each form element (e.g., text fields, select lists, checkboxes) has a correctly associated `<label>` element or a meaningful `aria-label` attribute. If labels exist, confirm they are properly associated with the form elements via the `for` attribute. Check for and apply existing patches in the Drupal issue queue for grouped exposed filters accessibility problems; if no suitable patch exists, create one with this fix. The exposed filters should have labels associated with the filters so users understand the purpose.

title: Add option for visually-hidden block titles
context: Add option for visually-hidden block titles
description: Add option for visually-hidden block titles

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may not be able to identify the content of visually-hidden block titles, leading to a reduced understanding of the page structure and potentially missed information. This impacts navigation and comprehension for users with visual impairments.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may not be able to identify the content of visually-hidden block titles, leading to a reduced understanding of the page structure and potentially missed information. This impacts navigation and comprehension for users with visual impairments.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a need to ensure block titles are accessible to screen readers.  Visually-hidden elements, by definition, are intended to be invisible to sighted users.  Simply making a visually-hidden element accessible is problematic as it contradicts its purpose. The correct approach is to ensure the block title is rendered visibly and has appropriate semantic HTML structure.
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves a missing visually-hidden block title option in Drupal, currently awaiting review and with no recent activity. The next step is for a maintainer to assess the proposed patch.

Several contributors have discussed this, with @guietc recently submitting a new patch (comment #132) targeting Drupal 11. The patch aims to provide a visual control for block titles, aligning with accessibility best practices.  No testing or further refinement has been observed.
