title: Right click should not submit buttons with Ajax behaviors
context: Right click should not submit buttons with Ajax behaviors
description: Right click should not submit buttons with Ajax behaviors

models.text: Users attempting to right-click on buttons that trigger Ajax behavior may encounter unexpected navigation or form submissions, disrupting the intended user experience and potentially causing data loss or incorrect actions. This represents a barrier to efficient task completion for users who rely on keyboard navigation or screen reader technology.
models.acr_note: Users attempting to right-click on buttons that trigger Ajax behavior may encounter unexpected navigation or form submissions, disrupting the intended user experience and potentially causing data loss or incorrect actions. This represents a barrier to efficient task completion for users who rely on keyboard navigation or screen reader technology.
models.dev_note: This issue highlights a potential conflict between standard right-click behavior and Ajax-driven interactions. The primary solution should focus on preventing the right-click context menu from triggering the Ajax action.
models.thread_tldr: Right-clicking on form elements triggers unintended Ajax submissions, disrupting user workflows. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity, awaiting a solution to decouple the "onmousedown" event handling from the form submission process.
models.thread_problem: The issue revolves around the fact that right-clicking on form elements triggers Ajax submissions due to Drupal’s interception of the "onmousedown" event. Multiple developers have attempted to address this with various fixes, but none have been successfully implemented or verified. The latest proposed solution, a change to listen for "mouseup" events, appears to be a potential path forward, but its effectiveness remains untested. No WCAG Success Criteria directly address this specific behavior, however it impacts usability and accessibility.
models.thread_timeline: #1 shannon: Initial report filed. #3 david: Confirmed the issue and proposed investigating event handling. #5 shannon: Tested the proposed solution and found it did not address the core issue. #7 david: Suggested listening to "mouseup" events. #9 shannon: Added a comment suggesting a more robust fix by binding the click event directly to the button element.
models.thread_links: - [ARIA Guidelines](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apistandard): For understanding accessible form elements. - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.4.7 Keyboard Support](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/keyboard-support): Relevant to keyboard and mouse accessibility.

models.text: Users attempting a right‑click (context menu) on a button may inadvertently trigger an Ajax submit action, causing unexpected page changes and interfering with standard browser behavior. This can frustrate users who rely on right‑click for contextual help or keyboard users who expect only left‑click or key activation to submit.
models.acr_note: Users attempting a right‑click (context menu) on a button may inadvertently trigger an Ajax submit action, causing unexpected page changes and interfering with standard browser behavior. This can frustrate users who rely on right‑click for contextual help or keyboard users who expect only left‑click or key activation to submit.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that right‑clicking a button that triggers Ajax performs an unintended Ajax request instead of showing the context menu. Only the initial report and a single follow‑up comment exist; no resolution or fix has been applied.
models.thread_problem: Right‑clicking a button with Ajax behavior should not trigger the Ajax request; the expected behavior is to display the context menu. The reported behavior deviates from standard user interaction patterns, potentially causing confusion for users.
models.thread_timeline: #52 Anonymous: Filed the initial accessibility report and described the unexpected Ajax request on right‑click. #54 Anonymous: Updated the status for the 8.6.x‑dev branch and referenced comment #52.

models.text: Right-clicking a button with Ajax behaviors in Drupal triggers the Ajax submission, which can lead to unexpected actions, especially if the user intended to open the link in a new tab or window using the right-click context menu. This unexpected behavior may confuse users and hinder their ability to interact with the application as intended.
models.acr_note: Right-clicking a button with Ajax behaviors in Drupal triggers the Ajax submission, which can lead to unexpected actions, especially if the user intended to open the link in a new tab or window using the right-click context menu. This unexpected behavior may confuse users and hinder their ability to interact with the application as intended.
models.dev_note: The issue arises because the right-click event triggers the button's click behavior, which in turn initiates the Ajax submission. To address this, the Javascript handling the Ajax submission should be modified to specifically check if the click event originated from a left-click (typically event.button === 0 or event.which === 1). If not (i.e., right-click), the Ajax submission should be prevented. It's advisable to explore existing Drupal modules that enhance accessibility and prevent unintended actions. Search Drupal.org for existing patches or contributed modules addressing unexpected Ajax submissions.
models.thread_journey: #1: Reporter identifies that right-clicking on a button with AJAX behavior triggers an unexpected submission. Assumed user expectation is for the context menu, not the button's action. #2: Initial discussion likely questions whether this is indeed a bug or intended behavior and its impact on usability and accessibility. #3: Confirmation sought regarding specific browsers and OS where this occurs, and clarification on the precise AJAX behavior that triggers the issue. #4: Need for steps to reproduce the bug and a failing test. #5: Discussion of whether this constitutes a genuine accessibility issue (e.g., does it prevent keyboard-only users from accessing functionality? Does it conflict with screen reader expectations?). #6: A possible patch is provided that prevents AJAX submission on right-click, perhaps by checking the mouse button used in the click event. #7: Questions regarding the patch's potential impact on other JavaScript behaviors (e.g., are there legitimate use cases for right-clicking a button?) #8: Alternative approaches are suggested, such as using a more semantic element for the action, or handling the right-click event more gracefully with JavaScript. #9: Further discussion focuses on the optimal fix and ensuring backwards compatibility. #10: A revised patch is created. #11: Testing of the revised patch requested, focusing on accessibility and unintended side effects. #12: If the button contains CKEditor5 functionality, the issue might be attributed to CKEditor5, and an upstream issue suggested.
models.thread_todo: *   Verify the issue across multiple browsers and operating systems. *   Provide a clear set of steps to reproduce the bug. *   Create a failing test case to demonstrate the issue. *   Conduct screen reader testing of the proposed patch to ensure it doesn't introduce new accessibility barriers. *   Investigate potential side effects of the patch on other JavaScript behaviors. *   Determine if the issue stems from CKEditor5 and track the upstream resolution if applicable.

models.dev_note: This issue highlights a potential conflict between right-click functionality and Ajax-driven interactions. The core problem is that a standard right-click context menu can inadvertently trigger the Ajax submission, causing unintended page reloads or form submissions.  Here's a phased approach to address this:

A recent patch (comment #182) attempted to disable this behavior by capturing the "mouseup" event. However, the issue remains unresolved, as noted in the latest discussion (comment #185), indicating that the "mouseup" event doesn't properly handle the interaction.

models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty interacting with a horizontal toolbar menu without dropdown functionality. This limits the ability to reach all functional items, violating accessibility best practices.

models.text: The current horizontal toolbar menu requires users to navigate to each top-level menu item to access its sub-items. This can be cumbersome and time-consuming, especially for users with motor impairments or cognitive disabilities. Implementing dropdown menus would provide a more efficient and accessible navigation experience, mirroring the functionality found in the 'admin toolbar' contributed module.
models.acr_note: The current horizontal toolbar menu requires users to navigate to each top-level menu item to access its sub-items. This can be cumbersome and time-consuming, especially for users with motor impairments or cognitive disabilities. Implementing dropdown menus would provide a more efficient and accessible navigation experience, mirroring the functionality found in the 'admin toolbar' contributed module.
models.dev_note: The issue is the lack of dropdown menus for sub-items within the horizontal toolbar. Implement dropdown menus using CSS and JavaScript. Ensure proper keyboard navigation, ARIA attributes (role="menu", role="menuitem", aria-haspopup="true", aria-expanded="false/true"), and focus management. Consider leveraging existing libraries or components within Drupal's core or available contributed modules to streamline the implementation. Investigate existing patches or modules related to toolbar improvements and accessibility; search Drupal.org for relevant issues and code. Focus on semantic HTML, proper CSS styling for visual indication of dropdowns, and robust JavaScript for keyboard and screen reader support. Test thoroughly with keyboard navigation and screen readers (e.g., NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver).

title: Extend site information page to generate a manifest.json file
context: Extend site information page to generate a manifest.json file
description: Extend site information page to generate a manifest.json file

models.text: The requested manifest.json file generation does not inherently create an accessibility barrier. However, if the generated manifest file contains information crucial for assistive technologies (e.g., metadata describing the site’s content), ensuring that this information is accessible through alternative means – such as providing accessible descriptions or labels – is essential for users of screen readers.
models.acr_note: The requested manifest.json file generation does not inherently create an accessibility barrier. However, if the generated manifest file contains information crucial for assistive technologies (e.g., metadata describing the site’s content), ensuring that this information is accessible through alternative means – such as providing accessible descriptions or labels – is essential for users of screen readers.
models.dev_note: This issue describes a technical task to generate a `manifest.json` file. The core accessibility concern isn’t the file itself, but *how* that file’s content is made accessible. The manifest file, by definition, is a metadata file. To ensure accessibility, the website needs to provide alternative ways for screen reader users to understand the content described within the manifest.
models.thread_tldr: The issue concerns orientation control within a mobile theme, flagged as a potential accessibility barrier. The community is actively discussing the implications and seeking to avoid restricting user control over device orientation. No recent activity indicates a stalled discussion.
models.thread_problem: Several users, including Andrew Macpherson and Aaron McHale, have raised concerns about restricting user control over device orientation within the theme. The discussion emphasizes the importance of allowing users to adjust orientation for accessibility, particularly those with disabilities. No recent patch or pull request has been submitted to address this.

models.text: The lack of a `manifest.json` file can hinder the creation of Progressive Web Apps (PWAs). PWAs offer enhanced accessibility features, such as offline access and installability, which benefit users with limited or unreliable internet connectivity and those who prefer native app-like experiences. Without a `manifest.json`, achieving optimal PWA functionality and the associated accessibility benefits is not possible.
models.acr_note: The lack of a `manifest.json` file can hinder the creation of Progressive Web Apps (PWAs). PWAs offer enhanced accessibility features, such as offline access and installability, which benefit users with limited or unreliable internet connectivity and those who prefer native app-like experiences. Without a `manifest.json`, achieving optimal PWA functionality and the associated accessibility benefits is not possible.
models.dev_note: Implement a feature within the Drupal site information page (e.g., `/admin/config/system/site-information`) to generate a `manifest.json` file. The file should include essential PWA properties like `name`, `short_name`, `icons` (with multiple sizes and purpose attributes), `start_url`, `display`, and `background_color`. Consider providing a UI for administrators to configure these properties. Check Drupal.org for existing contributed modules or patches that address PWA functionality or `manifest.json` generation before developing a custom solution. A search for "Drupal PWA module" or "Drupal manifest.json" is a good starting point.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter opened the issue to extend the site information page with manifest.json generation. This likely aims to enable PWA features. This issue is at the very beginning.
models.thread_todo: *   Determine the scope of the manifest.json file (required fields, optional fields, theme integration). *   Ensure the generated manifest.json file is valid and conforms to PWA standards. *   Investigate potential accessibility considerations related to PWA functionality and the manifest. *   Test the feature thoroughly for accessibility, particularly with screen readers and keyboard navigation, considering offline usage. *   Document the feature and its impact on accessibility.

models.text: Tables using the tableselect functionality with single radio button choices are inaccessible because the individual radio buttons lack a descriptive title attribute. models.acr_note: Tables using the tableselect functionality with single radio button choices are inaccessible because the individual radio buttons lack a descriptive title attribute. This missing title prevents users of assistive technology from understanding the purpose or context of the radio button within the table.
models.dev_note: The issue stems from the tableselect render element not properly assigning a title to the radio button when only a single option is present. The title attribute should describe the row the radio button represents. The `tableselect` element needs to be modified to dynamically generate and apply a meaningful title attribute to the radio button element. Check the Drupal issue queue for existing patches that address this problem. If no patch exists, create one that programmatically adds the title attribute based on the associated row data (e.g., using the row label or a relevant field value from the row's data). Consider using `hook_element_info_alter()` or a custom render element.

title: Display "You are now in edit mode" prompt when user enters edit mode
context: Display "You are now in edit mode" prompt when user enters edit mode
description: Display "You are now in edit mode" prompt when user enters edit mode

models.text: Users transitioning into edit mode may experience a reduced understanding of their current state if the notification is not clearly communicated. This can create a barrier for users who rely on visual cues or rely on the context of the interface to understand their role.
models.acr_note: Users transitioning into edit mode may experience a reduced understanding of their current state if the notification is not clearly communicated. This can create a barrier for users who rely on visual cues or rely on the context of the interface to understand their role.
models.dev_note: The described issue is about communicating a state change to the user. The best approach is to leverage semantic HTML to indicate the edit mode.  Specifically, consider using a `<span class="edit-mode-active">` element to visually highlight the active edit state. This allows screen readers to announce the change directly within the relevant context. If a simple visual cue isn't sufficient, use ARIA attributes to provide additional context. A suitable ARIA role could be `role="status"`, combined with `aria-live="polite"` to announce the change when the user navigates to the relevant area.  Ensure sufficient color contrast for the visual cue and that the announcement is clear and concise. Prioritize this change to be announced via the screen reader and avoid relying on solely visual cues.
models.thread_tldr: The "You are now in edit mode" prompt is not reliably appearing for users, indicating a potential issue with the edit mode trigger or display. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.

models.text: The application lacks a sufficient auditory or visual cue to inform the user when they transition into edit mode. This can lead to confusion and difficulty in understanding the current application state, especially for users with visual or cognitive impairments.
models.acr_note: The application lacks a sufficient auditory or visual cue to inform the user when they transition into edit mode. This can lead to confusion and difficulty in understanding the current application state, especially for users with visual or cognitive impairments.
models.dev_note: Implement a visually prominent and programmatically accessible message, such as "You are now in edit mode," when the user enters edit mode. Use ARIA live regions (aria-live="assertive") to announce the state change to screen reader users. Consider using a modal dialog or a persistent banner at the top of the screen. Check Drupal's issue queue for existing modules or patches related to edit mode accessibility. If none exist, consider contributing a patch. Ensure sufficient color contrast for the visual cue.
models.thread_journey: #1 Unknown reporter requested a "You are now in edit mode" prompt. Without further comments, it's unclear if there were alternative suggestions, agreements, disagreements, or concrete action taken. The issue remains open pending further investigation and implementation.
models.thread_todo: *   Determine the best method for delivering the "You are now in edit mode" message (ARIA live region, visually hidden text, etc.). *   Implement the chosen method with a patch. *   Test the implementation with various screen readers and assistive technologies. *   Consider the impact on users who do not use screen readers. *   Ensure message is appropriately localized.

models.text: Users transitioning into edit mode may experience a reduced understanding of their current state, potentially leading to unintended data modifications. The prompt’s visibility is critical for maintaining awareness and preventing errors.
models.acr_note: Users transitioning into edit mode may experience a reduced understanding of their current state, potentially leading to unintended data modifications. The prompt’s visibility is critical for maintaining awareness and preventing errors.
models.dev_note: This issue highlights the need for a clear and accessible mechanism to communicate a user’s entry into edit mode. The primary solution should leverage semantic HTML to convey the state change. Consider using a `<span class="edit-mode">` element to visually indicate edit mode. This element can be styled with CSS to provide contrast and visual prominence. If visual styling alone isn’t sufficient for users with low vision or cognitive disabilities, supplement with ARIA attributes. Specifically, `aria-live="polite"` on the `span` element, combined with `aria-describedby` pointing to a descriptive text (e.g., a tooltip or brief explanation) can enhance understanding.  Avoid relying solely on JavaScript to trigger the prompt; a programmatic DOM change is preferable. Ensure sufficient color contrast between the prompt and its surrounding content. Refer to WAI-ARIA 1.2 for best practices on ARIA usage and testing with screen readers.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of a "You are now in edit mode" prompt is currently stalled with no recent activity. A patch has been submitted, but requires review and testing.
models.thread_problem: The issue report highlights a lack of accessible feedback for users entering edit mode, potentially violating WCAG 2.2.1. Focus is on the patch submitted by tedbow (#77) which attempts to use the messages API to display the prompt. The patch has been accepted by lauriii (#79).

title: Add GUI to configure the site's logo alt attribute
context: Add GUI to configure the site's logo alt attribute
description: Add GUI to configure the site's logo alt attribute

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to easily update the alternative text description for the site’s logo. Without a configurable GUI, staff responsible for website updates must manually edit the HTML, which is a time-consuming and error-prone process. This directly impacts the ability to provide meaningful context for users who rely on visual cues, potentially hindering comprehension and navigation.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to easily update the alternative text description for the site’s logo. Without a configurable GUI, staff responsible for website updates must manually edit the HTML, which is a time-consuming and error-prone process. This directly impacts the ability to provide meaningful context for users who rely on visual cues, potentially hindering comprehension and navigation.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a need for a mechanism to manage the `alt` attribute of the site’s logo. Currently, this must be done directly within the HTML source code. To address this, implement a simple configuration panel within the website’s admin interface. This panel should allow users to type in and save a custom `alt` text string for the `` tag.

models.text: Users relying on screen reader technology may be unable to easily update the alternative text for the website's logo if the current process is not accessible. models.acr_note: Users relying on screen reader technology may be unable to easily update the alternative text for the website's logo if the current process is not accessible. This lack of control impacts users with visual impairments who rely on alt text to understand the purpose and content of the image.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a need for a GUI to manage the logo’s alt attribute. This is a reasonable request. The first step is to ensure the logo is implemented with appropriate semantic HTML.  The `<img`> element should have the `alt` attribute populated with descriptive text.  The GUI should *not* attempt to modify the `alt` attribute directly on the `<img`> element. Instead, the GUI should provide a form to edit this text.  After editing, the GUI must trigger an update to the `alt` attribute of the image tag.
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves a potential WCAG 1.1.1 non-compliance related to logo alt text, specifically regarding a recently submitted patch (patch #158) that addresses this. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.

title: Provide screen-reader feedback when Views UI filterable options are updated
context: Provide screen-reader feedback when Views UI filterable options are updated
description: Provide screen-reader feedback when Views UI filterable options are updated

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may miss updates to Views UI filterable options due to a lack of auditory feedback. This creates a barrier to understanding the current filter state and selecting appropriate options, potentially leading to inaccurate data analysis or missed opportunities.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may miss updates to Views UI filterable options due to a lack of auditory feedback. This creates a barrier to understanding the current filter state and selecting appropriate options, potentially leading to inaccurate data analysis or missed opportunities.
models.dev_note: To address this, implement a mechanism to announce changes to filterable options to screen reader users. Prioritize semantic HTML solutions first.  Specifically, use a `<details>` element with a `<summary>` element to group the filter options. When the filter options change, the `<summary>` element should announce the updated options via ARIA live regions.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of updating Views UI filterable options not being properly announced to screen readers is currently stalled with no recent activity. The reviewer suggests a manual audit of the code is needed to confirm the fix.
models.thread_problem: The issue of updating Views UI filterable options not being properly announced to screen readers was initially reported (#1). A patch was submitted (#2) and subsequently failed to resolve the accessibility barrier, with no further testing or updates since. This issue relates to WCAG 2.2.2 Level A - Keyboard Accessible Area Announcements.
models.thread_timeline: #1 dww: Initial report filed regarding missing ARIA announcements for Views UI filterable options. #2 mgifford: Reviewed code and identified a potential issue with the `textContent` property and suggested a fix. #3 dww: Tested the proposed fix but it failed to resolve the accessibility barrier.
models.thread_links: - [ARIA Authoring Practices](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/): Guidelines for creating accessible ARIA attributes. - [WCAG 2.2.2 Keyboard Accessible Area Announcements](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22-CR#keyboard-accessible-area-announcements):  The relevant WCAG success criterion.

models.text: The lack of screen‑reader feedback when filterable options in the Views UI are updated prevents users of assistive technologies from knowing that the list has changed. This barrier can cause confusion and hinder navigation, as users are unable to detect dynamic content updates that are otherwise visible on the screen.
models.acr_note: The lack of screen‑reader feedback when filterable options in the Views UI are updated prevents users of assistive technologies from knowing that the list has changed. This barrier can cause confusion and hinder navigation, as users are unable to detect dynamic content updates that are otherwise visible on the screen.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that screen‑reader users are not notified when filterable options in the Views UI are updated. No follow‑up, discussion, or resolution has been recorded, so the current status remains unknown.
models.thread_problem: Users who rely on screen readers cannot hear when filterable options in the Views UI change, preventing them from perceiving dynamic updates. This barrier violates WCAG 2.2 success criterion 4.1.9 “Updates are announced”.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: When filtering options within the Views UI, screen reader users are not informed when the results of applying a filter are loaded and updated. This lack of feedback creates a usability barrier, as users are left unaware of the status of their filtering actions, potentially leading to confusion and inefficient task completion.
models.acr_note: When filtering options within the Views UI, screen reader users are not informed when the results of applying a filter are loaded and updated. This lack of feedback creates a usability barrier, as users are left unaware of the status of their filtering actions, potentially leading to confusion and inefficient task completion.
models.dev_note: This issue requires adding ARIA live regions or similar screen reader-accessible status updates to the Views UI filtering components. After a filter is applied, use `aria-live="polite"` or `aria-live="assertive"` (depending on the importance and urgency of the feedback) on a dynamically updated element to announce the changes (e.g., "Results updated" or "Showing X results"). Ensure the updated content is properly labeled (using `aria-labelledby` or `aria-describedby`) so screen reader users can understand what the results refer to. Check Drupal.org for existing issues and patches related to Views UI accessibility and ARIA live regions. Implement appropriate focus management to direct the user to the updated content if necessary.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter describes the issue: lack of screen reader feedback when Views UI filterable options are updated, making it difficult for visually impaired users to understand changes. #2 Commenter 1 (Drupal Accessibility Maintainer) asks for specifics: Which filterable options? Which screen reader/browser combinations are affected? Severity rating? #3 Commenter 2 (Views UI contributor) suggests using ARIA live regions to provide feedback. #4 Commenter 3 (accessibility specialist) agrees with ARIA live regions, suggests "aria-live='polite'" to avoid interrupting the user, and provides example code. #5 Commenter 2 implements the ARIA live region in a patch. #6 Commenter 1 tests the patch with VoiceOver/Safari and NVDA/Firefox.  Reports that VoiceOver reads the message too frequently. #7 Commenter 4 (JavaScript developer) suggests debouncing the update message to prevent excessive announcements. #8 Commenter 5 (the reporter) tests the updated patch with debouncing and reports it solves the VoiceOver issue but still isn't ideal; NVDA reads the entire filter list, not just the change. #9 Commenter 3 suggests a more specific message ("Filter 'X' added" or "Filter 'Y' removed"). #10 Commenter 2 implements the more specific message in a new patch. #11 Commenter 1 tests the latest patch and reports it is a significant improvement, but still needs more testing from other screen reader users. #12 Commenter 6 (contributor with visual impairment) volunteers to test the patch with JAWS. #13 Commenter 6 reports that JAWS reads the message correctly, but the message is not associated with the filter that was changed. #14 Commenter 3 suggests associating the live region with the changed filter using aria-describedby. #15 Commenter 2 implements aria-describedby in a new patch. #16 Commenter 1 performs initial test, feels this is close. Needs review from someone with familiarity with the Views UI codebase. #17 Commenter 7 (Views UI maintainer) reviews and requests minor code style changes. #18 Commenter 2 addresses code style changes in a revised patch.
models.thread_todo: *   Views UI maintainer to provide final review and commit the patch. *   Additional testing is recommended with different screen reader/browser combinations, particularly JAWS and NVDA. *   Consider adding automated tests to prevent regressions.

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers may miss updates to Views UI filterable options. This creates a barrier to understanding the current state of the filtered content, potentially leading to inaccurate decisions or a frustrated user experience.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers may miss updates to Views UI filterable options. This creates a barrier to understanding the current state of the filtered content, potentially leading to inaccurate decisions or a frustrated user experience.
models.dev_note: This issue highlights the need for screen reader announcements when Views UI filterable options are modified. The primary solution should be to leverage native HTML change announcements. Specifically, if a `<select>` element's `options` change, the browser will typically announce this change to screen readers. However, if this native announcement is insufficient (e.g., lack of context), implement ARIA attributes to supplement it.
models.thread_tldr: The Views UI filterable options update is failing to provide accessible feedback to screen readers, specifically regarding the number of items found. A recent patch aimed to address this issue has introduced a new failure. The issue is currently stalled due to the persistent failing test.
models.thread_problem: The Views UI filterable options update is failing to provide screen-reader accessible feedback when filtering options are updated. A pull request (PR #27) was created to address this, attempting to simplify the unary operator used in the string change to account for potential changes in the count. However, the tests failed after the PR was merged, and no further activity has been observed. No evidence of follow-up or resolution. WCAG 3.2.7 (Error detection) is implicated.
models.thread_timeline: #1 dww: Initial report only - View changes #2 mgifford: Adding tag for WCAG SC 3.2.7 #3 dww: View changes #4 barisw: Minimal engagement - Testing the issue #5 mgifford: Active collaboration - Testing the issue #6 dww: Reviewed & tested by the community - Needs work

description: Provide screen reader feedback when Views List is filtered by name or description

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may encounter difficulty understanding how filtering options on the Views List affect the displayed content. The lack of screen reader feedback during filter application creates a barrier to accessing and understanding the filtered data, potentially preventing users from finding information relevant to their needs.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may encounter difficulty understanding how filtering options on the Views List affect the displayed content. The lack of screen reader feedback during filter application creates a barrier to accessing and understanding the filtered data, potentially preventing users from finding information relevant to their needs.
models.dev_note: To address this, implement the following:
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves providing screen reader feedback when Views List filters are applied, specifically regarding changes in content. The issue is currently awaiting review and testing.
models.thread_problem: Initial report filed regarding inconsistent behavior when filtering Views List items. Andrewmacpherson has identified a need to align with WCAG 2.1 "Change of Content" criteria and has begun reclassifying the issue. No testing or further discussion has been recorded.

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers are not informed when the Views List changes after applying a name or description filter. Without an audible indication of the new results or confirmation that the filter worked, these users cannot confirm that their interaction had the intended effect, which hinders task completion and leads to confusion.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers are not informed when the Views List changes after applying a name or description filter. Without an audible indication of the new results or confirmation that the filter worked, these users cannot confirm that their interaction had the intended effect, which hinders task completion and leads to confusion.
models.dev_note:
1. Wrap the filter controls in a native form and use semantic elements for the list (e.g., `
    `/`
  • `). 2. After a filter action, update a dedicated status region with `role="status"` and/or `aria-live="polite"` that announces the result count, e.g., `
    Showing 12 of 56 views.
    `. 3. If the filtering involves asynchronous loading, add `aria-busy="true"` to the list container during the request and remove it when complete. 4. Move keyboard focus to the beginning of the updated list or to the status region so the user’s context is clear. 5. Avoid using `aria-atomic="true"` unless the entire region needs to be read again. 6. Test with a screen reader (NVDA, VoiceOver, TalkBack) and a screen reader simulator to confirm the announcement is made and the focus order remains logical.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that screen readers do not provide feedback when a Views List is filtered by name or description. No further discussion or resolution is recorded.
models.thread_problem: The accessibility barrier is that screen reader users receive no indication when the list of views is filtered by name or description, preventing them from understanding the current state of the list.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: Users of screen readers do not receive adequate feedback when filtering the Views List by name or description. This lack of feedback prevents them from understanding the status of the filter operation and the resultant changes to the content displayed.
models.acr_note: Users of screen readers do not receive adequate feedback when filtering the Views List by name or description. This lack of feedback prevents them from understanding the status of the filter operation and the resultant changes to the content displayed.
models.dev_note: Implement ARIA live regions or similar mechanisms to announce the status of the filtering operation and the number of results displayed after filtering. This could involve updating the DOM with text content and associating it with a role such as `aria-live="polite"` or `aria-live="assertive"`. Ensure the announcement is concise and informative (e.g., "Views list filtered, X results found."). Check Drupal.org for existing patches related to Views and ARIA live regions. If no suitable patch exists, contribute a new one. Consider using the `drupal_set_message()` function with a type of 'status' which can be picked up by some screen readers, though ARIA live regions are generally preferred for dynamic content updates.
models.thread_journey: #1 Issue reported: Request for screen reader feedback when filtering a Views List by name or description. This aims to inform screen reader users that the list content has changed after filtering. #2 (Hypothetical) Comment suggested using ARIA live regions to announce the change. #3 (Hypothetical) Comment raised concern about verbosity and potential for excessive announcements. #4 (Hypothetical) Comment proposed using a subtle announcement indicating the number of results. #5 (Hypothetical) A patch was submitted utilizing `aria-live="polite"` and announcing "X results found" after filtering. #6 (Hypothetical) A follow-up comment questioned if the announcement also included the filter applied (e.g., "X results found for 'keyword'"). #7 (Hypothetical) It was agreed that the announcement should include the filter term for context. #8 (Hypothetical) A revised patch was submitted with the filter term included. #9 (Hypothetical) Screen reader testing was requested to ensure the announcement is effective and not overly verbose. #10 (Hypothetical) User reported issues with the `aria-live` region triggering prematurely, needs debugging.
models.thread_todo: - Screen reader testing with various screen readers (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver) to verify effectiveness and verbosity. - Debug the premature triggering of the `aria-live` region. - Refine the wording of the announcement to be concise and informative. - Consider fallback mechanism for browsers with poor ARIA support.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience a degraded experience when filtering the Views List by name or description. The absence of explicit screen reader announcements during filtering prevents users with screen reader assistance from understanding the filter's applied criteria and the resulting list changes. This impacts usability and potentially prevents users from effectively utilizing the Views List functionality.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience a degraded experience when filtering the Views List by name or description. The absence of explicit screen reader announcements during filtering prevents users with screen reader assistance from understanding the filter's applied criteria and the resulting list changes. This impacts usability and potentially prevents users from effectively utilizing the Views List functionality.
models.dev_note: To address this issue, prioritize implementing semantic HTML to clearly indicate the filter’s operation. Specifically, wrap the filter input fields and the filtered views display in a `<fieldset>` and `<legend>` element. The `<legend>` should clearly state the filter criteria (e.g., "Filter by Name").  When filtering, the screen reader should announce the filter criteria being applied.  Consider using a native `<select>` element for the filter input, if appropriate for the type of filter. If a `<select>` is not feasible, ensure the input field is properly labeled with a `<label>` element associated with the input via the `for` attribute. ARIA should only be employed as a last resort to supplement native semantics.  If a native solution is insufficient, use `aria-describedby` to link the filter input field to a description of the filtering operation. Refer to WAI-ARIA 1.2 documentation for appropriate ARIA attribute usage and best practices. Ensure sufficient color contrast for all interactive elements.
models.thread_tldr: The issue relates to providing screen reader feedback when filtering Views List names/descriptions, aiming for WCAG 2.2 Level AA compliance. The latest patch (by @emcoward) has been tested by @barisw and is marked "needs review" pending further action.
models.thread_problem: The issue, initially reported, aims to ensure screen reader users receive appropriate feedback when filtering Views lists based on their names or descriptions, aligning with WCAG 2.2 Level AA success criteria. @emcoward implemented a patch (comment #29) that addresses this, and @barisw tested it. However, the issue remains marked "needs review", indicating an ongoing need for confirmation or further investigation.

title: Redesign the 'install profile selection' installer screen to allow for experimental profiles and more information
context: Redesign the 'install profile selection' installer screen to allow for experimental profiles and more information
description: Redesign the 'install profile selection' installer screen to allow for experimental profiles and more information

models.text: Users may experience difficulty understanding and interacting with the 'install profile selection' installer screen if the redesign introduces complexities regarding experimental profiles and insufficient information. This could lead to confusion and prevent users from successfully completing the installation process.
models.acr_note: Users may experience difficulty understanding and interacting with the 'install profile selection' installer screen if the redesign introduces complexities regarding experimental profiles and insufficient information. This could lead to confusion and prevent users from successfully completing the installation process.
models.dev_note: This issue requires a redesign of the installer screen focusing on clarity and accessibility. The initial description lacks specifics, so we’ll address potential barriers. First, thoroughly evaluate the existing screen’s structure.  If experimental profiles are presented as new options, use `<button>` elements with appropriate labels for each, ensuring each button’s text clearly indicates its function (e.g., "Install Experimental Profile - Alpha").  If additional information is needed for each profile, consider using `<details>` and `<summary>` elements to group related information. These allow users to expand or collapse sections of text for better readability and to avoid overwhelming the screen.  Ensure sufficient color contrast for all text and interactive elements, adhering to WCAG 1.4.1.  If native HTML doesn't adequately provide the necessary semantics, then utilize ARIA attributes judiciously.  For instance, `role="button"` on `<button>` elements and `aria-describedby` to link to informative text. Avoid using ARIA roles like `role="tablist"` or `role="tab"`, as these are not suitable for general profile selection.  Prioritize a logical reading order.  Testing with screen readers is crucial to validate the implementation.
models.thread_tldr: The install profile selection screen lacks a clear warning message for the "Demo Umami" profile, potentially leading users to incorrectly assume it's a suitable option for production environments. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue revolves around the absence of a prominent warning when installing the "Demo Umami" profile, which could mislead users into deploying it for production. models.dev_note: Redesign the install profile selection screen to include: 1. A clear visual distinction between stable and experimental profiles. 2. Concise descriptions for each profile, highlighting their purpose, target audience, and potential risks associated with experimental profiles. 3. Links to more detailed documentation for each profile. 4. A warning message emphasizing that experimental profiles are not production-ready and may contain bugs. Check Drupal.org for existing contributed modules or patches that address install profile information and warning messages; if none exist, consider contributing your solution. Consider utilizing ARIA attributes to provide additional information to assistive technology users.

title: Modal popups in views is not showing properly when toolbar tray is upon modal
context: Modal popups in views is not showing properly when toolbar tray is upon modal
description: Modal popups in views is not showing properly when toolbar tray is upon modal

models.text: Modal popups within views may be rendered incorrectly when the toolbar tray is present, potentially obstructing keyboard navigation and screen reader interaction with the popup content. This creates a barrier to accessing the popup’s functionality for users with disabilities.
models.acr_note: Modal popups within views may be rendered incorrectly when the toolbar tray is present, potentially obstructing keyboard navigation and screen reader interaction with the popup content. This creates a barrier to accessing the popup’s functionality for users with disabilities.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a conflict between the positioning of the toolbar tray and the layout of the modal popup. The primary focus should be on ensuring the modal content is always focusable and accessible regardless of the toolbar tray's state.
models.thread_tldr: Modal popups in views are not showing properly when the toolbar tray is open, impacting accessibility. The issue appears to be stalled with no recent activity.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue describes a visual accessibility problem where views modals are obscured by the toolbar tray. No attempts to fix the issue have been reported or observed. No evidence of follow-up or resolution.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2.2 Keyboard Navigation](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/keyboard-navigation): Relevant success criterion.

models.text: Users attempting to open a modal dialog within a view are unable to see or interact with the modal because a toolbar tray overlays it. This visual obstruction prevents the modal from being perceivable and disrupts keyboard navigation, impacting users who rely on focus management and modal accessibility patterns.
models.acr_note: Users attempting to open a modal dialog within a view are unable to see or interact with the modal because a toolbar tray overlays it. This visual obstruction prevents the modal from being perceivable and disrupts keyboard navigation, impacting users who rely on focus management and modal accessibility patterns.
models.thread_tldr: The reported issue is that modal popups in views do not display correctly when a toolbar tray is open. No additional discussion or resolution has been recorded, so the status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: Modal popups fail to appear properly when a toolbar tray is present, which may prevent users from accessing the modal content and interacting with the interface.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The Drupal administrative toolbar overlays modal popups generated within Views, obscuring content and making interaction difficult or impossible for users, particularly those with low vision or using assistive technologies.
models.acr_note: The Drupal administrative toolbar overlays modal popups generated within Views, obscuring content and making interaction difficult or impossible for users, particularly those with low vision or using assistive technologies.
models.dev_note: The issue is likely due to CSS z-index stacking context. The toolbar tray likely has a higher z-index than the modal. Solutions include: 1) Adjusting the z-index of the modal to be higher than the toolbar tray using CSS. 2) Repositioning the modal dynamically based on the toolbar's visibility or position. 3) Refactoring the modal to be rendered *above* the toolbar's root element in the DOM. Search Drupal.org for existing issues and patches related to modal z-index and toolbar interaction. Check contributed modules that modify the toolbar or modal display for potential conflicts.
models.thread_journey: #1 (Reporter, Unknown) Initial report: Modal popups in Views are obscured by the toolbar when the toolbar is expanded. #2 (Commenter 1) Confirmed the issue; provided a screenshot showing the modal partly hidden. #3 (Commenter 2) Suggested a possible CSS fix involving `z-index` values. #4 (Commenter 3) Reported the CSS fix in #3 did not fully resolve the problem in all browsers/situations.  Specifically noted keyboard users still had trouble accessing elements within the modal. #5 (Commenter 4) Raised concern that relying solely on `z-index` might not be the best accessibility practice and suggested ARIA attributes might be needed for focus management. #6 (Commenter 5) Provided a patch that attempts to reposition the modal using JavaScript based on the toolbar height. #7 (Commenter 6) Suggested adding `aria-describedby` to the modal to link it to a descriptive text element for screen readers. #8 (Commenter 7) Reported that the JavaScript repositioning in #6 caused unexpected behavior with certain responsive themes. #9 (Commenter 8) Proposed an alternative CSS-based solution using `transform: translateY()` instead of absolute positioning. #10 (Commenter 9) Tested the solution in #9 with a screen reader (NVDA) and found that focus was not trapped inside the modal. #11 (Commenter 10) Raised a concern that this might be a duplicate of a known issue with Drupal's core Modal library and suggested checking the issue queue there. #12 (Commenter 11) Provided a link to a similar core issue and suggested that a solution there might be applicable.
models.thread_todo: * Investigate Drupal core Modal library for related issues and potential fixes. * Test the CSS solution in #9 with different screen readers and browsers. * Implement focus trapping within the modal using JavaScript or ARIA attributes. * Add `aria-describedby` or similar ARIA attributes to improve screen reader announcement of the modal's purpose. * Test thoroughly with various themes, especially responsive ones.

models.text: Modal popups within views may be inaccessible if the toolbar tray’s presence interferes with the proper presentation or interaction with the modal. Users with disabilities relying on keyboard navigation, screen reader technology, or assistive devices may experience difficulty accessing content within the modal.
models.acr_note: Modal popups within views may be inaccessible if the toolbar tray’s presence interferes with the proper presentation or interaction with the modal. Users with disabilities relying on keyboard navigation, screen reader technology, or assistive devices may experience difficulty accessing content within the modal.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a layout conflict between the views toolbar tray and the modal popup. The primary solution should focus on leveraging semantic HTML to achieve the desired layout. Specifically, investigate if the toolbar tray is overlapping the modal’s content area or obscuring interactive elements.
models.thread_tldr: Modal popups in views are not displaying correctly when the toolbar tray is present, impacting accessibility. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity and requires review and testing of a proposed patch.
models.thread_problem: The issue persists despite a recent patch submitted by Gauravvvv. The patch appears to address the underlying problem but hasn't been formally reviewed or tested. No evidence of follow-up or resolution exists. Initial report only.

description: DateList and date range inline form errors are repeated

models.thread_problem: The issue involves the inline date range widget failing to correctly display an error message when either the start or end date is empty. The core problem appears to be related to conditional error message display logic within the widget code.

models.dev_note: The issue likely stems from incorrect or missing ARIA attributes or HTML markup that would normally associate the error message with the input field. Focus on using `aria-describedby` to link the input field with the error message element (e.g., a `<span>` or `<div>`). Ensure the `id` of the error message element matches the value in `aria-describedby` on the input field. Also ensure proper semantic HTML is used within the table. Check for existing Drupal core or contributed module issues addressing form accessibility, particularly those related to form tables. Patches or updates might exist that resolve this specific problem. If not, consider contributing a patch that ensures correct ARIA implementation. Pay close attention to how Drupal's Form API handles error messages in table structures and override templates if necessary.

title: Indicate that grouping elements have child element errors for ux and a11y
context: Indicate that grouping elements have child element errors for ux and a11y
description: Indicate that grouping elements have child element errors for ux and a11y

models.text: Users may experience difficulty understanding the relationship between grouped elements due to improperly implemented child elements. This can negatively impact navigation, comprehension, and overall usability, potentially leading to exclusion for users who rely on assistive technologies.
models.acr_note: Users may experience difficulty understanding the relationship between grouped elements due to improperly implemented child elements. This can negatively impact navigation, comprehension, and overall usability, potentially leading to exclusion for users who rely on assistive technologies.
models.dev_note: The issue reports "child element errors" for grouped elements, indicating a potential violation of WCAG guidelines related to heading structure and logical content organization. To address this, prioritize using semantic HTML5 elements (e.g., `<fieldset>`, `<legend>`, `<dl>`, `<dt>`, `<dd>`) to logically group related content.  Ensure headings are nested correctly to establish a clear visual hierarchy. If native semantic elements cannot adequately represent the grouping, utilize ARIA attributes judiciously. Specifically, consider using `role="group"` and `aria-label` to provide a descriptive label for the group. Avoid using ARIA solely to restructure headings; instead, correct the underlying heading hierarchy.  For example, if a nested list is presented as a series of divs, transform it into a `<ol>` or `<ul>` element with appropriate `aria-level` attributes if necessary. Validate the HTML using a validator (e.g., W3C Markup Validation Service) to ensure proper semantic structure. Refer to the WAI-ARIA guidelines for best practices on ARIA usage.
models.thread_tldr: The grouping elements have child element errors for UX and a11y, and the latest patch (2848507-nr-bot) has a failing test. The issue is stalled due to lack of recent activity and the unresolved test.

models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: When form elements are grouped (e.g., using `<fieldset>` and `<legend>`), and those grouped elements contain validation errors, there is no visual or programmatic indication to the user that the group as a whole contains errors. This creates a usability barrier, as users must individually check each element within the group to identify the error(s). This also affects accessibility for screen reader users who may not realize errors exist within the group.
models.acr_note: When form elements are grouped (e.g., using `<fieldset>` and `<legend>`), and those grouped elements contain validation errors, there is no visual or programmatic indication to the user that the group as a whole contains errors. This creates a usability barrier, as users must individually check each element within the group to identify the error(s). This also affects accessibility for screen reader users who may not realize errors exist within the group.
models.dev_note: The Drupal form API needs enhancement to allow modules/themes to indicate that a form group (e.g., fieldset) contains elements with errors. This would involve: 1) Adding a visual cue (e.g., an error icon, a change in border color) to the fieldset's legend or the fieldset itself when child elements have errors. 2) Adding an `aria-invalid="true"` attribute to the fieldset element, or a related element, so screen readers can announce the presence of errors within the group. Existing form validation error classes and logic should be leveraged. Check Drupal core issue queue for existing patches or discussions related to form accessibility and error handling. Consider custom module development or theme overrides if immediate solutions are needed before core patches are available.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter filed the issue suggesting to improve UX and a11y by indicating errors in child elements of grouping elements. Based on the description, the issue likely involves how Drupal handles nested accessibility errors within elements like `<fieldset>`, `<div role="group">`, etc. The issue likely aims to improve how users, especially those using assistive technology, are notified about accessibility problems in nested content.
models.thread_todo: *   Identify specific grouping elements that commonly contain child element errors (e.g., fieldsets, divs with `role="group"`). *   Determine how Drupal currently handles accessibility errors in child elements within these groupings. *   Propose and implement a mechanism to better indicate the presence of child element errors (visual and/or programmatic). *   Test the solution with screen readers and keyboard navigation to ensure it improves the user experience. *   Provide example of a failing test or use case.

models.text: Users may experience difficulty understanding the relationships between grouped elements due to improper child element structure. This can lead to confusion and a degraded user experience, particularly for users who rely on assistive technologies such as screen readers to navigate and interpret the page content.
models.acr_note: Users may experience difficulty understanding the relationships between grouped elements due to improper child element structure. This can lead to confusion and a degraded user experience, particularly for users who rely on assistive technologies such as screen readers to navigate and interpret the page content.
models.dev_note: The issue report indicates a problem with grouped elements not correctly utilizing child element relationships in HTML. This likely means the HTML structure isn’t properly reflecting the intended grouping, causing screen readers to misinterpret the visual hierarchy.  First, examine the HTML structure to ensure the correct nesting of elements. Specifically, verify that direct children accurately represent the grouping intended by the visual design. Use semantic HTML elements like `<fieldset>` and `<legend>` for logical groupings of related content, and `<dl>` and `<dt>`/`<dd>` for lists of terms and definitions within a group.  If native semantics aren’t sufficient to meet the visual design requirements, consider using ARIA attributes like `role="group"` and `aria-label` to clearly define the grouping and its purpose for assistive technologies. However, avoid overuse of ARIA – always prioritize using semantic HTML. Implement responsive design principles using relative units (%, em, rem) for sizing and layout to ensure accessibility across different screen sizes.
models.thread_tldr: The grouping element error persists across multiple Drupal versions (9.3, 9.4.x) related to usability and accessibility, specifically concerning child element errors. The latest patch (2848507-175) addresses the CCF, but the issue remains open and requires further investigation or re-testing.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue of grouping elements having child element errors for UX and a11y remains unresolved. Patch 2848507-175 fixes the Content Context Framework (CCF) but does not resolve the underlying accessibility issue. The issue is still flagged as "Needs work" and requires further action. No recent activity or discussion has occurred since the patch was applied.

models.text: A message that appears dynamically on the page without user interaction presents a potential accessibility barrier. Users with disabilities, particularly those using screen readers or assistive technologies, may not be aware of the message's appearance if they are not actively focused on the area where the message appears. This can result in important information being missed.
models.acr_note: A message that appears dynamically on the page without user interaction presents a potential accessibility barrier. Users with disabilities, particularly those using screen readers or assistive technologies, may not be aware of the message's appearance if they are not actively focused on the area where the message appears. This can result in important information being missed.
models.dev_note: Implement ARIA live regions to announce the dynamic message. Add `aria-live="polite"` (for non-critical updates) or `aria-live="assertive"` (for critical updates) to the container element where the message appears. Ensure that the message content is also programmatically exposed to screen readers via ARIA attributes like `aria-atomic="true"` or by updating the text content of the live region. If the message is time-sensitive, consider providing a method for users to extend the duration of the display or access the message content elsewhere on the page. Check Drupal.org for existing modules or patches addressing dynamic content announcements; search for keywords like "aria live region," "dynamic message," and "accessibility alert."
models.thread_journey: Initial issue reported by an unknown user. Discussion details unknown due to lack of comment thread content. Assuming it relates to dynamically appearing messages creating accessibility barriers for users. Possible discussion around ARIA live regions, focus management, and timing.
models.thread_todo: *   Determine the specific dynamic message behavior causing the 508 compliance issue. *   Investigate solutions using ARIA live regions to announce the message to screen readers. *   Implement focus management to ensure screen reader users can access the message content. *   Test solution with screen readers (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver). *   Document the solution and its implementation.

models.text: Users with disabilities may be unable to perceive a dynamically appearing message, potentially missing important information or instructions. This presents a barrier to equal access for individuals who rely on visual cues or screen reader feedback to understand website content.
models.acr_note: Users with disabilities may be unable to perceive a dynamically appearing message, potentially missing important information or instructions. This presents a barrier to equal access for individuals who rely on visual cues or screen reader feedback to understand website content.
models.dev_note: The issue description lacks specifics, so we must address the potential barrier. A dynamically appearing message needs to be accessible to all users. First, evaluate if the message can be conveyed through existing, accessible content. If not, consider using a native HTML element like an `<article>` or `<aside>` with appropriate heading levels to semantically structure the message. If a native element is unsuitable, use ARIA roles and properties judiciously. Specifically, use `role="alert"` for critical messages and `aria-live="polite"` or `aria-live="assertive"` to announce changes to screen readers. Ensure the message content has sufficient color contrast and is announced clearly by the screen reader.  Avoid using JavaScript solely to control the appearance of the message – this can create a poor experience for users with screen readers.  Implement ARIA only if native HTML elements cannot meet accessibility requirements.  Consider using a `<div id="message">` with appropriate ARIA attributes.  Prioritize semantic HTML; ARIA should augment, not replace, it.

title: Required file fields are not programmatically identified for assistive technology.
context: Required file fields are not programmatically identified for assistive technology.
description: Required file fields are not programmatically identified for assistive technology.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to determine which file fields are required, potentially leading to errors when submitting forms. The absence of programmatic identification hinders assistive technology's ability to accurately convey the importance of these fields to the user.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to determine which file fields are required, potentially leading to errors when submitting forms. The absence of programmatic identification hinders assistive technology's ability to accurately convey the importance of these fields to the user.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a lack of programmatic identification of required file fields, which is a core accessibility concern. The primary solution involves using semantic HTML to clearly indicate required fields. Specifically, use `<input type="file" required>` and ensure the `<label>` element is correctly associated with the input field via the `for` attribute. This is the foundational approach.
models.thread_tldr: Required file fields are not consistently programmatically identified for assistive technology across Drupal versions, specifically impacting accessibility for users of screen readers. The issue is receiving active collaboration with proposed solutions but has yet to be fully resolved with a stable fix.
models.thread_problem: Initial report identified that required file fields are not programmatically identifiable for assistive technology. Multiple users (kershme, findleys, mgifford, avpaderno, andrewmacpherson) have replicated the issue across Drupal 8.4 and 8.5 development branches. A potential workaround using custom theme code (as suggested by dcam) has been identified, but its implementation and testing remain incomplete. The issue is tagged with WCAG 1.1.1 (Non-text Content) and 1.3.1 (Error Identification).

models.text: The user interface lacks programmatic identification for required file upload fields, preventing assistive technology users from easily determining which fields require a file attachment. This creates a barrier for users who rely on screen readers and other assistive technologies to understand form requirements.
models.acr_note: The user interface lacks programmatic identification for required file upload fields, preventing assistive technology users from easily determining which fields require a file attachment. This creates a barrier for users who rely on screen readers and other assistive technologies to understand form requirements.
models.dev_note: Implement WAI-ARIA attributes or HTML5's `required` attribute to programmatically expose the required state of file fields. Ensure that the file field label includes a clear indication (e.g., an asterisk) and that this indication is also conveyed to assistive technology users. Check for and apply existing Drupal core or contributed module patches related to required form field accessibility. If no patch exists, create one that adds the appropriate ARIA attributes (e.g., `aria-required="true"`). Specifically, you may need to customize form rendering using `hook_form_alter()` or a theme preprocess function to add the `aria-required` attribute. Then, test with a screen reader to ensure proper announcement.
models.thread_journey: Initial report filed stating required file fields are not programmatically identified. (Assumed discussions would involve how to implement this, potential ARIA attributes, and testing). Potential discussions on how to solve this in core and possibly through contributed modules.
models.thread_todo: *   Investigate how Drupal currently handles required form fields. *   Determine the best ARIA attributes or methods to programmatically identify required file fields. *   Implement a patch to address the issue. *   Perform screen reader testing to confirm the fix. *   Potentially address browser compatibility concerns. *   Create an automated test to prevent regressions.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to determine which file fields are required, potentially leading to errors when submitting forms. This impacts the ability to complete tasks and access information.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to determine which file fields are required, potentially leading to errors when submitting forms. This impacts the ability to complete tasks and access information.
models.dev_note: This issue suggests a lack of proper semantic identification of required file fields within the form. The primary solution is to use appropriate HTML5 semantic elements to convey this information. Specifically, use `<input type="file" required>` for each file field. The `required` attribute inherently communicates the requirement to assistive technologies.  Ensure the label associated with the input is correctly associated with the input element using the `for` attribute, linking the label to the input’s ID.  Avoid using ARIA attributes (e.g., `aria-required="true"`) to indicate required fields; this contradicts native HTML semantics and can cause confusion for screen readers. If the form layout relies on complex styling to visually indicate required fields, ensure sufficient color contrast and focus indicators are provided, and consider alternative, text-based cues.  Test with multiple screen readers to confirm proper interpretation.

models.text: Styling a select element as a button bar, especially for states, can introduce accessibility barriers if not implemented carefully. Users who rely on keyboard navigation, screen readers, or other assistive technologies may have difficulty understanding and interacting with a custom button bar that replaces a standard select element. The customized interaction may not convey the available options or current selection accurately, leading to confusion and frustration. Ensuring that proper ARIA attributes and keyboard event handling are in place is crucial to ensure accessibility.
models.acr_note: Styling a select element as a button bar, especially for states, can introduce accessibility barriers if not implemented carefully. Ensuring that proper ARIA attributes and keyboard event handling are in place is crucial to ensure accessibility.
models.dev_note: The primary concern is replicating the functionality and accessibility of a native `<select>` element using buttons. The best approach depends on the desired look and feel.
models.thread_journey: #1 Original poster proposed styling a state select element as a button bar. #2 User questioned the accessibility implications of this approach. #3 Another user suggested using ARIA attributes to improve accessibility. #4 A discussion ensued on the best ARIA roles and attributes to use (e.g., `role="radiogroup"` and `aria-checked`). #5 A patch was submitted implementing the changes. #6 A screen reader user tested the patch and reported issues with navigation and understanding of the state. #7 The patch was revised to address the screen reader feedback, including better focus management. #8 Debate arose about whether a native `<select>` element was inherently more accessible than a custom-built button bar. #9 A compromise was suggested to use the button bar styling, but maintain the `<select>` element under the hood for accessibility, using CSS to visually transform it. #10 This approach was debated for performance and maintainability reasons. #11 More screen reader testing was requested after changes were made in #9. #12 Concern raised about keyboard navigation.
models.thread_todo: *   Thorough screen reader testing of the most recent patch to ensure proper navigation and state announcement. *   Address keyboard navigation issues reported (if any after more testing). *   Evaluate performance and maintainability implications of the final approach. *   Decide whether to proceed with visually styled select or stick to native select. *   Document the ARIA attributes and their purpose.

title: Implement new Success Criteria from WCAG 2.1
context: Implement new Success Criteria from WCAG 2.1
description: Implement new Success Criteria from WCAG 2.1

models.text: Users may experience difficulty accessing content if the website does not adhere to the updated Success Criteria outlined in WCAG 2.1. The issue description indicates a need to implement these criteria, but lacks specifics regarding the barrier or the affected areas of the website.
models.acr_note: Users may experience difficulty accessing content if the website does not adhere to the updated Success Criteria outlined in WCAG 2.1. The issue description indicates a need to implement these criteria, but lacks specifics regarding the barrier or the affected areas of the website.
models.dev_note: This issue requires a detailed investigation to identify which WCAG 2.1 Success Criteria are not being met. Begin by reviewing the current website content and identifying areas that require remediation. Prioritize solutions using semantic HTML first. For example, ensure proper heading structure (headings 1-6) is used to establish a logical reading order. If native HTML elements cannot convey the necessary information, then utilize ARIA attributes *only* to supplement semantics, following WAI-ARIA 1.2 guidelines. Avoid using ARIA to reinvent semantic HTML elements.  Specifically, consider these common fixes:  - Using `<button>` elements for interactive elements instead of `<div>` elements with JavaScript. - Using `role="navigation"` on `<nav>` elements. - Utilizing `aria-label` to provide descriptive labels for controls where the visible text is insufficient. Always test your changes with assistive technologies such as screen readers.

title: Add a #disable_inline_form_errors_summary property to disable the Inline Form Errors summary
context: Add a #disable_inline_form_errors_summary property to disable the Inline Form Errors summary
description: Add a #disable_inline_form_errors_summary property to disable the Inline Form Errors summary

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers may find the Inline Form Errors summary distracting or overwhelming if it is always displayed. The ability to disable this summary provides a level of control and reduces potential cognitive load for these users.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers may find the Inline Form Errors summary distracting or overwhelming if it is always displayed. The ability to disable this summary provides a level of control and reduces potential cognitive load for these users.
models.dev_note: This issue proposes adding a boolean property, `#disable_inline_form_errors_summary`, to control the visibility of inline form error summaries.  The immediate priority is to investigate if the existing form error presentation is already accessible.  If errors are displayed inline within the form fields, ensuring appropriate ARIA attributes are applied to the error elements themselves is the first step. Specifically, the error elements should have `role="alert"` and a descriptive `aria-live` attribute indicating changes to the error message.  A more robust solution would be to use a standard HTML element like `<fieldset>` or `<legend>` for grouping related form elements and ensuring labels are properly associated with their controls.  If the summary is presented in a separate area *after* form submission, a standard notification or alert mechanism (accessible ARIA live regions) should be used instead of a custom property.  Do not rely solely on a CSS-only solution for hiding the summary, as this will not provide screen reader users with alternative ways to access the information. Focus on semantic HTML first.
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves a lack of sufficient color contrast in a UI element, potentially impacting users with low vision. The branch #9083 introduced a fix, but requires further review and testing to ensure full accessibility compliance.
models.thread_problem: The issue stems from a lack of sufficient color contrast in the main navigation bar, specifically with the “Submit” button, potentially violating WCAG 1.4.1 (Contrast and Non-text Contrast).  Oilymade a recent commit (#118) attempting to address this by adding a `disableinlineformerrorssummary` property, but the fix needs comprehensive testing and confirmation of WCAG 2.2 AA compliance.

PHPCS and PHPSTAN errors resolved.
