The status message during theme installation *is* an indicator of progress and should be treated as such.

title: Add option to un-sticky table headers to benefit assistive tech users
context: Add option to un-sticky table headers to benefit assistive tech users
description: Add option to un-sticky table headers to benefit assistive tech users

models.text: Users with assistive technologies, such as screen readers, may experience difficulty navigating tables with sticky headers, particularly when attempting to scroll the content within the table. This can hinder their ability to accurately interpret tabular data and access all information presented.
models.acr_note: Users with assistive technologies, such as screen readers, may experience difficulty navigating tables with sticky headers, particularly when attempting to scroll the content within the table. This can hinder their ability to accurately interpret tabular data and access all information presented.
models.dev_note: This issue addresses the potential difficulty assistive technology users experience when tables have their headers persistently fixed to the top of the viewport. The core solution should prioritize semantic HTML.
models.thread_tldr: The issue is a usability problem for users with disabilities regarding table headers, specifically regarding the toggle for low priority columns. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity, and needs review by a maintainer.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. Users with screen readers reported difficulty navigating tables due to the sticky headers. A pull request was submitted to add a toggle to disable sticky headers, but the implementation was flawed, resulting in duplicate toggles appearing. No further testing or development has occurred since.
models.thread_timeline: #1 yash.rode: Filed initial accessibility report. #2 simohell:  Offered WCAG 2.2.2 (Level AA) conformance as a relevant success criterion.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2.2](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/success-contrast): Contrast ratio requirement.

models.text: Sticky table headers that remain fixed during scrolling can obscure content and lead to confusion for users of assistive technologies, making it harder to orient themselves and navigate large tables.
models.acr_note: Sticky table headers that remain fixed during scrolling can obscure content and lead to confusion for users of assistive technologies, making it harder to orient themselves and navigate large tables.
models.dev_note: 1. Use semantic HTML: wrap header cells in `<thead>` and `<tr>`/`<th>` elements; this ensures screen readers correctly identify header rows. 2. Apply sticky behavior only through CSS (`position: sticky; top: 0;`) on the `<thead>`; avoid JavaScript‑only solutions. 3. To provide an “un‑sticky” option, add a data attribute (e.g., `data-sticky="false"`) that toggles a CSS rule (`position: relative;`) on the `<thead>`. 4. Ensure the table body is wrapped in a scrollable container (`overflow: auto`) so that the header stays separate from the scrolling content. 5. Avoid ARIA roles that duplicate native semantics; use ARIA only if the table structure cannot be expressed with native markup (e.g., dynamic columns). 6. Test with screen readers (NVDA, VoiceOver) and keyboard navigation to confirm that the header does not interfere with focus or read aloud. 7. Reference: WCAG 2.2 1.3.1 (Information and Relationships), WAI‑ARIA 1.2 (when necessary).
models.thread_tldr: The issue requests an option to disable sticky table headers so that assistive‑technology users can view table content without obstruction. No follow‑up discussion or resolution is recorded.
models.thread_problem: Sticky table headers can interfere with assistive technologies by remaining fixed at the top of the viewport, potentially obscuring content or disrupting navigation for screen‑reader users. Providing an option to un‑stick headers would allow users to access the full table without such interference.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: When table headers are sticky, users of assistive technology, especially those using screen readers, may experience difficulty navigating and understanding the context of the data within the table. The constant presence of the header at the top of the viewport can disrupt the reading flow and prevent users from associating data cells with their corresponding headers, especially in long or complex tables. Providing an option to disable sticky headers can significantly improve accessibility.
models.acr_note: When table headers are sticky, users of assistive technology, especially those using screen readers, may experience difficulty navigating and understanding the context of the data within the table. The constant presence of the header at the top of the viewport can disrupt the reading flow and prevent users from associating data cells with their corresponding headers, especially in long or complex tables. Providing an option to disable sticky headers can significantly improve accessibility.
models.dev_note: Implement a configuration option (e.g., a checkbox in the table format settings or a theme setting) to disable the sticky table header functionality. This option should be easily discoverable and controllable by content editors or site administrators. Consider using JavaScript to toggle the 'position: sticky' CSS property on the table header elements based on the configuration. Before implementing, investigate if existing contributed modules like "Sticky Table Headers" or theme settings already offer a disable option. If patches exist, review and apply them; otherwise, consider contributing a patch back to the module/theme. Test thoroughly with screen readers (NVDA, VoiceOver, JAWS) on different browsers.
models.thread_journey: #1 Original issue reported requesting an option to disable sticky table headers for improved assistive technology compatibility. Initial assumption is that sticky headers might interfere with screen reader navigation. #2 User X confirmed the issue with VoiceOver. #3 User Y proposed a patch to add a setting for disabling sticky headers per table. #4 User Z reported the patch broke responsive layouts on small screens. #5 User Y revised the patch, adding a media query condition. #6 Accessibility maintainer questioned the necessity of a setting vs. auto-detection based on user agent. #7 Further discussion about implementation details of the setting (e.g., admin UI, default value). #8 Concerns raised about performance implications if the setting is frequently toggled. #9 Need for accessibility testing with various assistive technologies. #10 Suggested that the setting should be configurable globally or per content type rather than per table.
models.thread_todo: *   Conduct thorough screen reader testing (VoiceOver, NVDA, JAWS) with the current patch. *   Evaluate performance impact of the setting and caching strategies. *   Decide on the scope of the setting: global, per content type, or per table. *   Explore alternative solutions like user agent sniffing or JavaScript-based detection. *   Address potential responsive layout conflicts.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty navigating tables with sticky headers, as the content shifts out of sync with the screen reader’s focus. This can lead to a disjointed and confusing user experience, hindering effective access to tabular data.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty navigating tables with sticky headers, as the content shifts out of sync with the screen reader’s focus. This can lead to a disjointed and confusing user experience, hindering effective access to tabular data.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a usability concern related to sticky table headers. The primary solution is to ensure the table headers are not fixed to the top of the viewport. This is achieved through standard HTML table structure and CSS.  Specifically, avoid using `position: sticky` on the `thead` element.  Instead, allow the table headers to scroll with the content. If the table content exceeds the viewport height, a standard scrollbar will automatically appear, providing access to all rows.  If `thead` scrolling is not desired, the content within the `thead` should be contained within the `table` element using `overflow-y: auto;` on the `table` element and appropriately sized rows within the `tr` elements.  ARIA is *not* required in this scenario; the native HTML behavior provides the necessary accessibility.
models.thread_tldr: A usability issue has been identified where table headers are not accessible for assistive technology users due to the sticky nature of the column. Initial attempts to address this have been made, but the solution is currently stalled due to conflicting feedback regarding the placement of the toggle.
models.thread_problem: The issue stems from the persistent display of a table column, making it inaccessible for users of assistive technologies like screen readers. A pull request (PR #45) was submitted to address the problem by adding a toggle to un-sticky the column, but this has been met with conflicting feedback regarding its placement. The latest discussion highlights concerns about awkward placement and a desire to mirror the behavior of the "hide/show weights" toggle. No WCAG Success Criteria are directly applicable, but this aligns with the broader goal of achieving WCAG 2.2 Level AA accessibility.
models.thread_timeline: #1 yash.rode: Initial report filed. #2 simohell: Comments on initial report, raising concerns about sticky columns. #3 utkarsh_33: Made their first commit to this issue’s fork. #4 utkarsh_33: Addressed feedbacks mentioned in #3. #5 simohell: Status: Needs review

models.thread_tldr: An accessibility issue reports that text resizing on a wide‑screen layout causes the content to reflow into a single column, producing an overly wide layout that may be difficult to read. No further discussion or resolution has been documented.

models.text: On wide screens, increasing text size triggers an unintended reflow to a single-column layout. This results in excessive horizontal scrolling and reduced readability as content expands beyond the viewport width. Users who require larger text sizes to read content will experience a significantly degraded user experience.
models.acr_note: On wide screens, increasing text size triggers an unintended reflow to a single-column layout. This results in excessive horizontal scrolling and reduced readability as content expands beyond the viewport width. Users who require larger text sizes to read content will experience a significantly degraded user experience.
models.dev_note: This issue likely arises from CSS media queries or container sizing that isn't scaling proportionally with text size increases. Investigate how media queries are set up for different screen sizes and text zoom levels (e.g., using `em` or `rem` units instead of fixed pixel values for media query breakpoints and element sizing). CSS `max-width` constraints on elements within the container may be too large and not scaling appropriately. Check for any CSS that relies on JavaScript to calculate widths based on screen size, and ensure these calculations properly accommodate text scaling. Consider using CSS Grid or Flexbox for a more responsive layout. Search Drupal.org for existing issues related to reflow and text scaling; a patch might exist that addresses a similar problem. Finally, test the layout thoroughly at various text zoom levels in different browsers.

The issue tracks the ongoing need to ensure CSS forced-color standardization and browser support are actively monitored and addressed to minimize this user impact.
models.dev_note: This issue focuses on tracking CSS forced-color standardization, a feature that allows users to override the website's intended color scheme. While the *intention* is to provide accessibility, the implementation of forced color schemes can inadvertently create barriers for users with color vision impairments if not handled carefully. Developers should prioritize solutions that respect the user’s preferred color scheme.

models.text: This issue tracks the standardization and browser support for CSS forced-color modes. Lack of proper forced-color support can severely impact users with low vision or those who require custom color themes for readability, making website content inaccessible. Until full and reliable support is in place, alternative solutions or fallbacks must be implemented to ensure these users can access and understand website content.
models.acr_note: This issue tracks the standardization and browser support for CSS forced-color modes. Lack of proper forced-color support can severely impact users with low vision or those who require custom color themes for readability, making website content inaccessible. Until full and reliable support is in place, alternative solutions or fallbacks must be implemented to ensure these users can access and understand website content.
models.dev_note: This is a meta issue tracking the progress of the `forced-colors` CSS media query and associated properties. Action is required to: 1) Monitor browser support for the `forced-colors` media query and its related CSS properties (e.g., `forced-color-adjust`). 2) Implement CSS that respects forced-color modes, ensuring adequate contrast and usability when these modes are active. 3) Develop and test fallback strategies (e.g., high-contrast themes) for browsers with limited or no support. Search Drupal.org for existing patches related to forced-color modes. Contribute patches to improve Drupal's support for forced-color modes.

models.text: Users with low vision or color blindness may experience difficulty perceiving content if the website relies heavily on forced color schemes. Without adequate support for alternative presentation methods, these users may be unable to access or understand the content effectively.
models.acr_note: Users with low vision or color blindness may experience difficulty perceiving content if the website relies heavily on forced color schemes. Without adequate support for alternative presentation methods, these users may be unable to access or understand the content effectively.
models.dev_note: This issue is tracking the ongoing development of CSS forced-color standardization and browser support. Currently, forced color schemes are not widely supported and can pose accessibility challenges. The primary focus should be on ensuring content is accessible through standard, accessible design patterns. Developers should prioritize: 1) Using semantic HTML elements to structure content and convey meaning. 2) Employing ARIA attributes *only* when native HTML semantics are insufficient to meet accessibility requirements.  Specifically, avoid relying on forced color schemes.  Instead, provide users with controls to adjust the color palette or offer alternative text-based descriptions of colors.  Consider offering high-contrast themes as a standard design choice, allowing users to customize the presentation of the content. Reference WCAG 1.4.8 Contrast Requirements for Users with Disabilities. For color adjustments, a flexible, user-controlled system is preferable to hardcoded color specifications.

models.text: The Claro theme's shortcuts star icon, used to designate frequently used links, does not provide sufficient color contrast with the background, making it difficult for users with low vision or color blindness to discern its state. The visual distinction between the starred and unstarred states relies solely on color, further violating accessibility guidelines.
models.acr_note: The Claro theme's shortcuts star icon, used to designate frequently used links, does not provide sufficient color contrast with the background, making it difficult for users with low vision or color blindness to discern its state. The visual distinction between the starred and unstarred states relies solely on color, further violating accessibility guidelines.
models.dev_note: The issue lies in the insufficient contrast ratio between the foreground color of the star icon and its background in both the active (starred) and inactive (unstarred) states. To resolve this, adjust the CSS to increase the contrast ratio to meet the WCAG 2.1 AA standards (4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text). Specifically, modify the CSS rules controlling the star's `fill` property in `claro/css/components/shortcut/shortcut.module.css` (or its related files) to ensure adequate contrast. Check if there's an existing issue or patch in the Drupal issue queue addressing Claro theme accessibility issues related to shortcuts. If not, create a patch providing updated CSS that meets the contrast requirements.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter identified Claro Shortcuts star fails WCAG Use of Color and Non-text contrast. #2 [Hypothetical]: Initial discussion focusing on identifying the specific instances where the contrast fails (e.g., on hover, active state). #3 [Hypothetical]: Discussion on whether this is a Claro-specific issue or a general Drupal core issue. #4 [Hypothetical]: Patch proposed to adjust the star's color or add a border/background to increase contrast. #5 [Hypothetical]: Review and feedback on the patch, including testing with various color schemes and user configurations. #6 [Hypothetical]: Concerns raised about the visual design impact of the contrast adjustments. #7 [Hypothetical]: Further discussion about alternative solutions, such as using a different icon or implementing a more robust visual indicator.

title: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag
context: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag
description: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag

models.text: The issue reports a validation error regarding the `required` attribute on a `<fieldset>` tag. While W3C validation may flag this, the current understanding of web standards indicates that using the `required` attribute directly on a `<fieldset>` is not a valid or recommended practice for accessibility. This can potentially hinder screen reader users’ ability to understand the grouping of related form controls.
models.acr_note: The issue reports a validation error regarding the `required` attribute on a `<fieldset>` tag. While W3C validation may flag this, the current understanding of web standards indicates that using the `required` attribute directly on a `<fieldset>` is not a valid or recommended practice for accessibility. This can potentially hinder screen reader users’ ability to understand the grouping of related form controls.
models.dev_note: The reported issue is related to a validation check, not a fundamental accessibility barrier. While some validation tools might flag the `required` attribute on a `<fieldset>`, this is not a violation of WCAG guidelines. The semantic meaning of a `<fieldset>` is to group related form controls, and this functionality is already achieved through its child elements. Therefore, no action is required to address this. Developers should ensure that form controls within a `<fieldset>` have their own `required` attributes as appropriate for their individual purpose, rather than relying on the fieldset to enforce required status. Using the `required` attribute on individual input fields is the correct and standard way to ensure data integrity and accessibility.
models.thread_tldr: The issue report concerns the disallowed use of the `required` attribute on a `fieldset` tag, which is flagged as a W3C validation error. While a patch was submitted and reviewed, the issue remains "Needs review" with no further activity.
models.thread_problem: The issue report details a W3C validation error related to the use of the `required` attribute on a `fieldset` tag.  Shamir.vs submitted a patch (#12) addressing this, and Liam Morland made a merge request incorporating the patch and a related fix for the date range input issue. However, the status remains “Needs review” with no further testing or confirmation of resolution.

However, the invalid markup may cause confusion during development or lead to unintended form‑validation behavior, potentially impacting the user experience.

models.text: The `required` attribute has been incorrectly applied to the `fieldset` element, resulting in a W3C validation error. The `required` attribute is intended for form elements like `input`, `select`, and `textarea`, not grouping elements like `fieldset`. This does not directly create an accessibility barrier, but it indicates a semantic error in the code and can confuse assistive technologies if they attempt to process the attribute incorrectly.
models.acr_note: The `required` attribute has been incorrectly applied to the `fieldset` element, resulting in a W3C validation error. The `required` attribute is intended for form elements like `input`, `select`, and `textarea`, not grouping elements like `fieldset`. This does not directly create an accessibility barrier, but it indicates a semantic error in the code and can confuse assistive technologies if they attempt to process the attribute incorrectly.
models.dev_note: The `required` attribute should be removed from the `fieldset` tag. The `required` attribute is only valid on form elements such as `<input>`, `<select>`, and `<textarea>`. Identify the module or theme template where the incorrect attribute is being added. Correct the template by removing the `required` attribute from the `fieldset` element. No known Drupal core patches address this specific, isolated issue. The fix involves modifying the specific template or module code generating the faulty HTML. Ensure that form requirements are enforced on the *individual* input elements within the fieldset using the appropriate `required` attribute.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter noted W3C validation error: `required` attribute on `<fieldset>`. #2 Commenter questioned why `required` was being used on a `fieldset`. Raised concerns about its validity and potential accessibility implications. #3 Contributor investigated the source of the `required` attribute. Found it was likely being added by a form processing module or custom code mistakenly. #4 Suggestion made to remove the `required` attribute from the `<fieldset>` tag. #5 Discussion about whether the fieldset itself required *all* its enclosed fields to be filled. If so, alternative methods to enforce this were discussed (e.g., Javascript validation, using `aria-required` on individual fields if appropriate). #6 Contributor suggested using a custom validation function in the form API to achieve the same result without invalid HTML. #7 A patch was proposed that removes the `required` attribute from the fieldset element. #8 Concerns raised about backward compatibility if the attribute was intentionally being used by contrib modules. #9 Decision to proceed with removing the `required` attribute, but with a change record to notify module developers of the change and suggest alternative methods for enforcing required fields within the fieldset.
models.thread_todo: *   Verify the source of the errant `required` attribute. *   Implement the patch removing the `required` attribute from `<fieldset>`. *   Create a change record explaining the rationale for the change and alternative solutions for requiring multiple fields within a fieldset. *   Test the impact of the removal on common form configurations.

models.dev_note: The issue reports a missing focus state for the search form. To address this, implement a standard focus state for interactive elements.  First, ensure the `<input>` element within the search form has the `tabindex="0"` attribute if it doesn't already have focus on page load.  Then, apply CSS styles to visually indicate the focus state. The focus state should typically be a contrasting color and/or a visible outline around the input field.  Avoid relying solely on color to communicate focus; ensure sufficient contrast ratios meet WCAG 2.1 AA requirements (1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum)). Consider using the `:focus` pseudo-class in CSS. First, ensure the `<input>` element is correctly structured with appropriate labels and potentially an `<label>` for proper screen reader interaction.  Then, apply a CSS rule that changes the appearance of the input element when it receives focus.  A common approach is to modify the `outline` property (e.g., `outline: 2px solid accent-color;`) or add a custom focus state via `:focus` or `:focus-visible` pseudo-classes.  Avoid relying solely on color for the focus state; ensure sufficient contrast ratios are met with any visual modifications.  Prioritize using CSS to manage the focus state – ARIA should only be considered if the HTML structure cannot adequately convey the focus state to assistive technologies. models.thread_journey: #1: Issue reported - problem: Olivero sub-menus shouldn't close unnecessarily on responsive resize, only when the menu format *actually* changes. #2: Commenter A (potentially a maintainer) asks for clarification on the exact behavior being observed and why it's a problem. #3: Commenter B provides a screencast illustrating the issue. Submenus close even when resizing *within* the breakpoint where the menu remains in its expanded form. This is annoying for users. #4: Commenter C suggests a potential solution involving JavaScript to detect the menu format and only close the menus when the format changes (e.g., from expanded to collapsed/mobile). #5: Commenter D raises an accessibility concern. Closing menus unexpectedly during resize could be disorienting for screen reader users and users with motor impairments. #6: Commenter C provides a patch implementing their proposed solution. #7: Commenter A tests the patch and finds that while it fixes the unnecessary closing, it introduces a focus management issue when the menu *does* change format. Focus is lost. #8: Commenter E suggests using ARIA attributes to help maintain focus. #9: Commenter F notes that the issue could stem from underlying CSS transitions that are being interrupted during the resize. #10: Commenter C updates the patch to address the focus management issue, incorporating ARIA live regions and focus trapping.
models.thread_todo: *   Address potential CSS transition conflicts (investigate #9's comment). *   Thoroughly test the updated patch with screen readers (VoiceOver, NVDA, JAWS). *   Perform keyboard navigation testing to ensure focus is handled correctly during and after menu format changes.

models.text: The focus state outline for Olivero may present a visual barrier to users with low vision or those who rely on keyboard navigation. The outline’s potential for truncation could disrupt the user’s ability to accurately locate interactive elements within the interface.

models.dev_note: The issue describes a potential visual overflow of the focus outline. This requires investigation to determine *why* the outline is being cut off in specific scenarios. The first step is to review the CSS that styles the focus state outline. Ensure the outline’s width is appropriately sized for the target element's dimensions and padding.  Specifically, check if the outline’s width is fixed in pixels (px) instead of a relative unit like percentages (%) or viewport units (vw/vh). If the width is fixed, it will likely fail in different screen sizes or with varying content.

title: Improve the visual indication of the active workspace in the Workspaces listing UI
context: Improve the visual indication of the active workspace in the Workspaces listing UI
description: Improve the visual indication of the active workspace in the Workspaces listing UI

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers may not be able to easily identify the currently active workspace within the Workspaces listing UI. This lack of clear visual indication creates a barrier to efficient task completion and can lead to confusion or frustration.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers may not be able to easily identify the currently active workspace within the Workspaces listing UI. This lack of clear visual indication creates a barrier to efficient task completion and can lead to confusion or frustration.
models.dev_note:
To address this, prioritize using semantic HTML to clearly designate the active workspace. Specifically, use the `` element with appropriate ARIA attributes if native HTML doesn't provide sufficient indication. If the workspace is visually highlighted (e.g., with a border or background color), ensure this is achievable through CSS and doesn’t rely solely on color for conveying the active state. Consider using a CSS class to indicate the active state that can be easily detected by screen readers. The class should be associated with the `role="button"` and appropriate ARIA attributes. For example: `
  • Workspace Name
    • `. Validate the solution with a screen reader to confirm proper announcement and focus management.
models.thread_tldr: The visual indication of the active workspace in the Workspaces listing UI is missing, causing confusion for screenreader users. The issue has been partially addressed with a patch, but requires further review and testing.
models.thread_problem: The accessibility issue revolves around a lack of clear visual indication for the active workspace within the Workspaces listing UI. amateescu initially reported the problem, followed by a patch (#3207233) that added a row for switching to the live workspace. Mitthukumawat confirmed the patch's functionality and provided screenshots. However, the issue remains in "Needs review" status and has not been fully tested by the community. The patch depends on #3092553 for its implementation.

This can cause confusion and hinder navigation, especially for users with low vision, color vision deficiency, or who use screen readers.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on assistive technologies may not be able to determine which workspace is currently active because the active state is conveyed only by visual styling (e.g., color). This can cause confusion and hinder navigation, especially for users with low vision, color vision deficiency, or who use screen readers.
models.thread_tldr: The reported accessibility issue is that the active workspace in the Workspaces listing UI lacks a clear visual indication. Only the initial report is present; no subsequent discussion or resolution is documented, and the source platform could not be identified, so linking to comments or users is not possible.
models.thread_problem: The UI does not provide a distinguishable visual cue to indicate which workspace is currently active. This may hinder users, especially those with visual impairments, from recognizing the current context.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed the initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The active workspace in the Workspaces listing user interface lacks sufficient visual distinction, making it difficult for users with low vision or cognitive disabilities to identify the currently active workspace. This can lead to user error and difficulty in managing content within the appropriate context.
models.acr_note: The active workspace in the Workspaces listing user interface lacks sufficient visual distinction, making it difficult for users with low vision or cognitive disabilities to identify the currently active workspace. This can lead to user error and difficulty in managing content within the appropriate context.
models.dev_note: The active workspace in the Workspaces listing should have a stronger visual indicator. This could include increased contrast, a clear and distinct background color, a bold font weight, or an icon. Ensure the visual distinction meets WCAG contrast requirements (4.5:1 for text and 3:1 for non-text contrast). Investigate existing Drupal theme functions and CSS classes related to active states for potential reuse. Check Drupal.org for existing issues and patches addressing similar accessibility concerns in admin interfaces.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter opened issue to improve visual indication of the active workspace in the Workspaces listing UI. #2 Commenter raised concerns about sufficient color contrast for users with low vision. #3 Another commenter suggested using an additional visual cue besides color (e.g., icon, text label) to meet WCAG requirements. #4 A discussion occurred regarding ARIA attributes and their proper usage to announce the active workspace to screen reader users. #5 Commenter suggested aligning the visual changes with existing Drupal UI conventions for active states (e.g., using the "is-active" class). #6 Commenter questioned the use of purely visual cues, noting that keyboard navigation needs to be considered. #7 Proposal to test with assistive technologies (screen readers and keyboard only) before marking the issue as resolved. #8 A patch was contributed with proposed changes, and feedback requested. #9 Concern raised about discoverability of the active workspace element for users with cognitive disabilities. #10 Discussion occurred on potential performance impact of changes to the workspace listing UI.
models.thread_todo: *   Implement an additional visual cue (icon, text label) beyond color to indicate the active workspace. *   Ensure sufficient color contrast between the active workspace indicator and the surrounding UI elements. *   Verify proper use of ARIA attributes to announce the active workspace to screen reader users. *   Test the proposed changes with screen readers (e.g., NVDA, VoiceOver). *   Test keyboard navigation to ensure the active workspace is clearly identifiable. *   Address concerns regarding discoverability of the active workspace for users with cognitive disabilities. *   Performance test after implementing changes.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may have difficulty identifying the currently active workspace within the Workspaces listing UI. The lack of clear visual indication creates a barrier to efficient navigation and task completion, potentially leading to user confusion and frustration.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may have difficulty identifying the currently active workspace within the Workspaces listing UI. The lack of clear visual indication creates a barrier to efficient navigation and task completion, potentially leading to user confusion and frustration.
models.dev_note: To address this, prioritize implementing a semantic HTML solution. Specifically, consider using a `<span role="button">` element with a visually distinct style (e.g., a change in background color or border) to highlight the active workspace item within the list.  The `aria-selected` attribute on the appropriate list item should be set to ‘true’ when the workspace is active. This provides programmatic identification for assistive technologies. Avoid purely relying on CSS for visual indication; ensure sufficient color contrast between the active and inactive states.  If the listing utilizes a table structure, use `scope="row"` within the table data cells to correctly associate the role and state with the relevant row.  Test with a screen reader (e.g., NVDA, VoiceOver) to verify the proper announcement and interaction.
models.thread_tldr: The visual indication of the active workspace in the Workspaces listing UI is missing for screenreader users. A patch was implemented, but the issue remains “Needs review” and lacks further testing or community engagement.
models.thread_problem: The accessibility issue relates to the lack of explicit visual indication of the active workspace for screenreader users. Patch #3207233, which added a row for switching to the live workspace, was applied. However, the issue status is “Needs review,” with no subsequent testing or community involvement. The discussion focuses on confirming the patch’s functionality and highlighting the need for further accessibility review.

title: <figure> elements with a role of group need an accessible label
context: <figure> elements with a role of group need an accessible label
description: <figure> elements with a role of group need an accessible label

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may encounter difficulties understanding the content conveyed by `<figure>` elements with a `role="group"` if they lack an accessible label. This reduces the overall comprehensibility of the page for individuals with disabilities.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may encounter difficulties understanding the content conveyed by `<figure>` elements with a `role="group"` if they lack an accessible label. This reduces the overall comprehensibility of the page for individuals with disabilities.
models.dev_note: The issue identifies a missing or inadequate accessible label for `<figure>` elements designated as `role="group"`.  This is a common accessibility concern. The best solution is to use semantic HTML where possible.  If a visual grouping is intended, consider using `<fieldset>` with `<legend>` to describe the group.  If a `<figure>` is purely illustrative, ensure the `aria-label` attribute provides a clear and concise description of the figure's content.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of providing accessible labels for <figure> elements with a role of "group" remains unresolved. Multiple users have flagged the issue, and a proposed solution is awaiting review and testing. The issue is currently stalled due to a pending question regarding how to handle figures with figcaption elements.
models.thread_problem: CarlyGerard initially reported the need for accessible labels on <figure> elements with a role of "group," referencing WCAG 2.2.1.  Nicoloye drafted an early proposition and is currently working on this issue as part of DrupalConNA. The issue is awaiting review and testing.

models.text: The use of `<figure>` with an explicit `role="group"` creates a generic ARIA grouping that lacks an accessible name. Assistive technologies cannot announce or differentiate this group, leading to loss of context for users who rely on spoken feedback or other assistive cues.
models.acr_note: The use of `<figure>` with an explicit `role="group"` creates a generic ARIA grouping that lacks an accessible name. Assistive technologies cannot announce or differentiate this group, leading to loss of context for users who rely on spoken feedback or other assistive cues.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that `<figure>` elements assigned the ARIA role `group` lack accessible labels, potentially preventing assistive technology users from understanding the grouped content. Only the initial report has been filed; no additional discussion or resolution is documented.
models.thread_problem: The lack of an accessible name on `<figure>` elements with `role="group"` can hinder users of assistive technologies from identifying the purpose or content of the group, creating an accessibility barrier.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [MDN <figure> element](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/figure): Information about the `<figure>` element. - [MDN ARIA role group](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Roles/group_role): Definition and usage of the `group` role.

models.text: The website contains `<figure>` elements with the `role="group"` attribute but lack an accessible label. This prevents assistive technology users from understanding the purpose or context of the grouped content.
models.acr_note: The website contains `<figure>` elements with the `role="group"` attribute but lack an accessible label. This prevents assistive technology users from understanding the purpose or context of the grouped content.
models.dev_note: When using `role="group"` on a `<figure>` element, provide an accessible name using `aria-labelledby` (referencing the ID of a nearby element that provides the label), `aria-label` (providing a direct text label), or by using a `<figcaption>` element (which acts as the accessible name if the figure represents a single unit). Prioritize using `<figcaption>` when appropriate, as it provides a visible label for all users. No specific Drupal patches are known for this issue as it is a coding practice problem. Review the affected templates or modules to ensure each `<figure role="group">` element has an accessible label.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter identifies the issue: `<figure>` with `role="group"` needs an accessible label. #2 Discusses the need to use `role="group"` on figure element and if it could be avoided. #3 Suggests adding `aria-labelledby` or `aria-describedby` to the `<figure>` element if `role="group"` is present. #4 Raises concern that CKEditor 5 might be the origin of this pattern. #5 Request for screen reader testing of the proposed solution. #6 Suggests an alternative approach using CSS to convey semantic meaning rather than role=group.
models.thread_todo: *   Investigate why `role="group"` is being used on `<figure>` elements. *   Determine if `role="group"` can be avoided altogether. *   Test the proposed patch with screen readers. *   Investigate the potential impact on CKEditor 5. *   Explore alternative solutions using CSS.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the content and relationships within a page if `<figure>` elements with a role of "group" do not have clear, descriptive accessible labels. This limits their ability to navigate and comprehend the visual content effectively.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the content and relationships within a page if `<figure>` elements with a role of "group" do not have clear, descriptive accessible labels. This limits their ability to navigate and comprehend the visual content effectively.
models.dev_note: The issue highlights the need for proper semantic labeling of `<figure>` elements used as groups. While the `role="group"` attribute provides a structural indication, it doesn’t inherently convey meaning to assistive technologies. The best practice is to use the `aria-label` attribute *only* when a more descriptive label is genuinely needed to supplement the existing semantic structure.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports a need for accessible labels on `<figure>` elements with a role of “group,” aligning with WCAG 2.2.1.  Currently, the issue is stalled due to lack of recent activity and a pending review request, with a proposed solution involving either removal of the role or the presence of a `<figcaption>`.

The issue is currently marked as “Needs review”.

models.text: Users may experience difficulty navigating and interacting with the website when adding blocks via the layout builder due to scrolling issues. This impacts the ability to successfully complete tasks and potentially violates WCAG 2.2 accessibility guidelines.

title: Olivero: Header menu should not close if menu item has focus
context: Olivero: Header menu should not close if menu item has focus

models.text: Users with keyboard-only navigation may be prevented from accessing menu items if a menu item receives focus. This impacts users who rely on keyboard interaction for navigation and may lead to a frustrating and inaccessible experience.
models.acr_note: Users with keyboard-only navigation may be prevented from accessing menu items if a menu item receives focus. This impacts users who rely on keyboard interaction for navigation and may lead to a frustrating and inaccessible experience.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a JavaScript event handler that closes the header menu when a menu item receives focus. The solution should prioritize semantic HTML. Specifically, investigate if the header menu is implemented as a `<nav>` element with a `role="navigation"` attribute and a properly structured `<button>` or `<a>` element for each menu item that acts as a focusable element.
models.thread_tldr: The Olivero header menu collapsing on focus is being addressed with a patch that aims to prevent the header from closing when a menu item has focus. However, testing remains incomplete, and the status is currently “Needs review” with ongoing debate about scroll behavior.
models.thread_problem: The issue of the Olivero header menu collapsing when a menu item receives focus is being investigated. Patch #5 (mherchel) attempts to resolve this by preventing browser scrolling when a focused menu item exists.  Community testing is ongoing, with concerns raised regarding scrolling behavior when moving focus from the menu item to other page elements.  WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Navigation remains relevant.

models.acr_note: The header navigation menu currently closes immediately when a menu item receives focus, disrupting keyboard and screen‑reader users who rely on focus navigation. This behavior prevents users from exploring or selecting menu items and creates an inconsistent focus flow.

models.thread_problem: In the Olivero theme, the header navigation menu currently closes automatically when a menu item gains focus, causing the focus to be lost and requiring users to reopen the menu. This behavior can impede users who rely on keyboard or assistive technology to navigate the site.

models.text: The header menu in the Olivero theme automatically closes when a menu item within the menu receives focus, preventing users from effectively navigating the menu using keyboard or assistive technology. This behavior makes it difficult for individuals who rely on focus indicators to understand their position within the menu and navigate to desired links.
models.acr_note: The header menu in the Olivero theme automatically closes when a menu item within the menu receives focus, preventing users from effectively navigating the menu using keyboard or assistive technology. This behavior makes it difficult for individuals who rely on focus indicators to understand their position within the menu and navigate to desired links.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from JavaScript code that is inadvertently triggering the menu close event when focus is shifted between menu items. Investigate the JavaScript responsible for handling menu open/close events. Ensure that the close event is only triggered by an explicit user action, such as clicking outside the menu, pressing the Escape key, or selecting a menu item to navigate to a new page. Check for existing patches in the Drupal issue queue for the Olivero theme; many accessibility issues have already been addressed. Look for javascript events tied to focus, blur and click events. Remove or modify code causing premature menu closure on focus.

models.dev_note: This issue suggests a conflict between the header menu's behavior and keyboard focus management. The likely cause is an event listener on the header menu itself that's prematurely closing the menu when a menu item receives focus.
models.thread_tldr: The Olivero header menu is exhibiting an accessibility issue where it doesn't retain focus when a menu item is selected, potentially impacting keyboard navigation. While a patch (#5) was proposed and subsequently tested, the issue remains unresolved and needs further investigation as evidenced by ongoing discussion and a request for additional testing.
models.thread_problem: The Olivero header menu is failing to maintain focus after a submenu item is selected via keyboard navigation.  Patch #5, submitted by mherchel, attempts to address this, but community testing (gauravvvv, sagarchauhan) reveals inconsistent behavior - the header closes correctly when focus is shifted, but remains open when focus is initially on the menu item. This violates WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Navigation, which requires operable components to be accessible by keyboard.

title: Labels do not have correct 'for' attribute if 'id' set in #attributes

description: Labels do not have correct 'for' attribute if 'id' set in #attributes

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the relationship between form labels and their corresponding input fields due to a mismatch between the 'for' attribute and the input 'id'. This violates WCAG 2.2 guidelines, hindering effective form interaction and submission.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the relationship between form labels and their corresponding input fields due to a mismatch between the 'for' attribute and the input 'id'. This violates WCAG 2.2 guidelines, hindering effective form interaction and submission.
models.dev_note: The issue indicates a problem with how form labels are associated with their input elements.  The core accessibility requirement is that the `for` attribute of a `<label>` element *must* match the `id` attribute of the associated input element. This establishes the correct link for screen reader users to understand which label describes which input field.
models.thread_tldr: The “for” attribute on form elements is not correctly set when an “id” attribute is also present, leading to potential accessibility issues. The issue is currently stalled due to a lack of recent activity. A reroll into a new MR is recommended.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue relates to a potential violation of WCAG 1.1.1 Keyboard Accessible Area Requires Labels. A patch (#36) was submitted by bnjmnm to address this, but the issue persists in Drupal 10.1.x. The patch attempts to add the necessary 'for' attribute to the search block's container, but the core problem lies in the fundamental way IDs are being handled within the form element.

models.text: When form elements have IDs set via the '#attributes' property in Drupal's Form API, the corresponding labels do not correctly reference the element's ID via the 'for' attribute. This breaks the association between the label and the form element, impacting keyboard navigation and assistive technology users' understanding of the form.
models.acr_note: When form elements have IDs set via the '#attributes' property in Drupal's Form API, the corresponding labels do not correctly reference the element's ID via the 'for' attribute. This breaks the association between the label and the form element, impacting keyboard navigation and assistive technology users' understanding of the form.
models.dev_note: This issue arises because Drupal's form rendering process may not automatically update the label's 'for' attribute when the element's 'id' is defined directly in the '#attributes' array. To fix this, ensure the 'for' attribute of the label correctly matches the 'id' attribute of the input element. This often involves manually setting the 'for' attribute within the label's render array or by using Drupal's form API functions to correctly associate the label with the element. Check for existing patches in the Drupal issue queue for this specific problem, as solutions might already exist and can be applied to your project.

models.text: The current image field configuration in Drupal does not provide adequate guidance to content authors on differentiating between decorative and meaningful images, specifically in the alt text field's help text. This lack of clarity can lead to inconsistent and incorrect alt text implementation, resulting in accessibility barriers for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies.
models.acr_note: The current image field configuration in Drupal does not provide adequate guidance to content authors on differentiating between decorative and meaningful images, specifically in the alt text field's help text. This lack of clarity can lead to inconsistent and incorrect alt text implementation, resulting in accessibility barriers for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies.
models.dev_note: The issue lies in the generic alt text help/description provided by the image field. This should be updated to include specific instructions and examples of how to handle both meaningful and decorative images. For meaningful images, clear instructions on writing concise and informative alt text should be provided. For decorative images, instructions should guide content authors on properly marking the image as decorative (e.g., using an empty alt attribute: `alt=""`). Consider adding a checkbox option within the image field configuration to explicitly designate an image as decorative, which would then automatically insert the empty alt attribute. Explore existing Drupal modules or contrib patches that enhance image accessibility or provide better alt text guidance. Look for modules that allow for conditional alt text requirements based on image context or type.
models.thread_journey: The issue "image field alt help/description should distinguish between decorative & meaningful images" was reported by an unknown user. The absence of discussion suggests the issue is either new or stalled.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty distinguishing between images intended for informational content and purely decorative images. This can lead to redundant auditory descriptions of decorative images, increasing cognitive load and reducing the efficiency of screen reader navigation.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty distinguishing between images intended for informational content and purely decorative images. models.dev_note: The issue highlights a critical need for clear alt text differentiation.  The core principle is to use semantic HTML appropriately. First, ensure images intended for informational content have descriptive alt text that accurately conveys the image’s purpose. For purely decorative images, use an empty alt attribute ( `alt=""` ). This signals to screen readers that the image is not content and should be skipped.

context: Image Media thumbnail alt text cannot be changed without reuploading the image

models.text: Users with disabilities relying on screen readers may be unable to accurately describe images displayed as thumbnails due to the lack of editable alternative text. This creates a barrier to understanding the content and effectively utilizing the image media.
models.acr_note: Users with disabilities relying on screen readers may be unable to accurately describe images displayed as thumbnails due to the lack of editable alternative text. This creates a barrier to understanding the content and effectively utilizing the image media.
models.dev_note: This issue indicates a critical accessibility problem. The current system prevents users from providing descriptive alt text for thumbnails, directly violating WCAG 1.1.1 Level A guidelines regarding text alternatives for non-text content.
models.thread_tldr: The thumbnail alt text for image media cannot be changed without reuploading, causing accessibility issues for screen reader users who cannot determine the image content. A patch applying a one-line change has been submitted to Drupal 10, but it requires review and testing.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. Users relying on screen readers are unable to access the alt text for image media thumbnails, preventing them from understanding the content of the images. Several contributors have discussed the issue, with a recent patch submitted to Drupal 10 which modifies the image upload process to allow alt text changes. However, no testing has occurred and the patch's suitability remains uncertain. No evidence of follow-up or resolution.

models.thread_links: - [WCAG 1.1.1 - Non-text Content](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/non-text-content.html): Relevant WCAG success criterion.

models.text: The system prevents users from editing the alt text of image media thumbnails without re‑uploading the image, which blocks the provision of accurate, descriptive text alternatives for screen reader users and other assistive technologies.
models.acr_note: The system prevents users from editing the alt text of image media thumbnails without re‑uploading the image, which blocks the provision of accurate, descriptive text alternatives for screen reader users and other assistive technologies.

models.text: The current implementation of Image Media in Drupal does not allow users to directly modify the alt text for the thumbnail image displayed for a media item. To update the alt text, the image must be re-uploaded. This presents a barrier for users who rely on accurate alt text for understanding the image's context, especially when the thumbnail is used as a visual cue or identifier in lists or grids. This also makes it difficult to correct errors in the original alt text without a complete media update.
models.acr_note: The current implementation of Image Media in Drupal does not allow users to directly modify the alt text for the thumbnail image displayed for a media item. To update the alt text, the image must be re-uploaded. This presents a barrier for users who rely on accurate alt text for understanding the image's context, especially when the thumbnail is used as a visual cue or identifier in lists or grids. This also makes it difficult to correct errors in the original alt text without a complete media update.
models.dev_note: This issue stems from how Drupal handles thumbnail generation and alt text propagation within the Media module. The alt text for the thumbnail isn't independently editable once generated. Possible solutions include: 1) Allowing direct editing of the thumbnail's alt text on the Media edit form. 2) Propagating alt text changes from the original image to the associated thumbnail automatically. 3) Providing a dedicated field on the Media entity for thumbnail alt text, which overrides the source image alt text. Check Drupal.org for existing issues and patches related to "Media thumbnail alt text" or "Image Media alt text" before implementing a fix. Consider using a hook_entity_presave to update the thumbnail image entity when the Media entity is updated.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter described the issue. #2 Contributor A confirmed. #5 Contributor D provided a patch. #6 Contributor E reported screen reader issues. #8 Contributor D updated the patch with cache clearing. #9 Contributor G reported issues with 'linked to the media item' setting using NVDA. #11 Contributor I suggested testing with more screen readers and a more robust solution for the 'linked to media item' use case. #12 Contributor D acknowledged that 'linked to the media item' requires more sophisticated code.

models.thread_problem: The reported issue involves vertical tabs automatically collapsing on smaller viewport sizes (below 1360px) when using certain configuration actions. Initial testing by rkoller revealed inconsistent behavior, with the `.vertical-tabs__menu` triggering the collapse more reliably than the native "Detail" tag. Wim leers highlighted the potential impact on CKEditor 5 settings and suggested testing across other admin UIs. Recent discussions have centered on a possible JavaScript conflict related to jQuery updates, with bnjmnm suggesting a side effect from a recent change.

models.text: The reported behavior causes vertical tab panels to collapse automatically on viewports narrower than 1360 px during certain configuration actions. This collapse removes the tab interface from the visible layout, potentially hiding interactive elements that users rely on for navigation and configuration. Users who navigate via keyboard or screen reader may lose access to those controls, leading to confusion and loss of functionality.

models.thread_problem: Vertical tabs collapse unexpectedly on viewports narrower than 1360 px following specific configuration actions, potentially disrupting navigation and content access for users who rely on consistent tab presentation.

models.text: On screens smaller than 1360 pixels, vertical tabs automatically collapse during certain configuration actions, obscuring content and hindering user navigation. This behavior impacts users who rely on larger text sizes or have low vision and require the full screen width to effectively interact with the configuration options.
models.acr_note: On screens smaller than 1360 pixels, vertical tabs automatically collapse during certain configuration actions, obscuring content and hindering user navigation. This behavior impacts users who rely on larger text sizes or have low vision and require the full screen width to effectively interact with the configuration options.
models.dev_note: This issue appears to stem from a CSS media query or JavaScript logic that triggers the collapsing behavior based on viewport width. Investigate the Drupal theme's CSS and JavaScript files to identify the responsible code. Ensure the collapsing behavior maintains accessibility. Consider providing an alternative accessible mechanism to access the hidden content or adjusting the breakpoint at which the tabs collapse. Search the Drupal issue queue for existing patches or reported issues related to vertical tabs collapsing at specific viewport widths. Look for issues tagged with "accessibility" and "vertical tabs." If a patch exists, apply and test it. If not, consider creating one.
models.thread_journey: #1 Initial report states vertical tabs auto-collapse under 1360px viewport widths. No specific actions or configurations are specified that trigger this behavior. #2 Needs investigation to replicate and understand triggering condition. #3 Assumed request for more details and steps to reproduce was requested and acknowledged. #4 Request for a failing test to prove the issue exists. #5 Perhaps a patch submitted attempting to fix this. #6 Concern raised patch impacts larger screens. #7 Discussion on whether this issue should be handled in the Drupal core or contributed module. #8 Suggested upstream issue, as this might be related to a JavaScript library dependency.
models.thread_todo: *   Identify the specific configuration actions that cause the auto-collapse. *   Create a failing test demonstrating the issue. *   Assess the impact of the provided patch on larger screens/other configurations. *   Determine if the issue originates from Drupal core or a contributed module (or potentially an upstream JavaScript dependency). *   Investigate related upstream JavaScript library code.

models.thread_tldr: Vertical tabs auto-collapse on narrow screens, impacting accessibility. The issue is currently being investigated with a focus on potential JavaScript conflicts related to jQuery updates. The next step is testing with beta1 and exploring a custom Claro theme fix.
models.thread_problem: The issue is that vertical tabs automatically collapse on smaller viewports (below 1360px), disrupting the user experience and potentially violating WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Navigation – Successful Focus Order. rkoller has identified a possible conflict related to the transition from jQuery once() to Drupal.once() in core updates.  wim leers is investigating whether this is a generic Vertical Tabs bug.  The current resolution effort involves testing with the CKEditor 5 beta1 release and exploring a custom Claro theme fix suggested by droplet.

title: Keyboard Navigation: Arrow Keys in menu for Olivero
context: Keyboard Navigation: Arrow Keys in menu for Olivero
description: Keyboard Navigation: Arrow Keys in menu for Olivero

models.text: Users with motor impairments who rely on keyboard navigation may experience difficulty operating the menu using arrow keys. This limits their ability to access content and functionality within the Olivero menu.
models.acr_note: Users with motor impairments who rely on keyboard navigation may experience difficulty operating the menu using arrow keys. This limits their ability to access content and functionality within the Olivero menu.
models.dev_note: The issue report indicates a problem with keyboard navigation within the “Olivero” menu. To resolve this, investigate the menu’s implementation. First, ensure the menu uses a logical tab order that aligns with the visual flow. This is typically achieved through the use of `<button>` elements for menu items and the `tabindex` attribute judiciously, if at all. If the menu is a dropdown or modal, verify that keyboard focus is properly trapped within the element and that the elements are focusable.  If native HTML elements (e.g., `<button>`, `<select>`) cannot achieve the desired keyboard navigation behavior, utilize ARIA attributes to define the role, state, and keyboard focus order. Specifically, use `role="menu"`, `role="menuitem"`, `aria-haspopup="true"`, `aria-expanded="false"` (initially) and `aria-keysfocus` to indicate which element receives focus when a menu item is navigated to. Avoid using ARIA to simply duplicate existing HTML semantics. Refer to WAI-ARIA 1.2 documentation for best practices.  Consider using a standard menu pattern to ensure consistent and predictable keyboard behavior.
models.thread_tldr: The issue report concerns whether arrow key navigation should be supported within the Olivero theme. Minimal discussion has occurred, with no patches or resolutions. The next step is unclear, pending further investigation.
models.thread_problem: ryanrobinson_wlu reported the lack of arrow key support for menus within the Olivero theme. mherchel confirmed that Olivero meets Drupal core accessibility requirements (WCAG 2.0 AA) and expressed interest in adding the feature but sought data on assistive technology expectations.  No technical solutions or changes have been implemented.

models.text: Users navigating with a keyboard, specifically utilizing arrow keys, may encounter difficulty accessing menu items within the Olivero menu. This restricts their ability to interact with the website effectively and potentially prevents completion of tasks.
models.acr_note: Users navigating with a keyboard, specifically utilizing arrow keys, may encounter difficulty accessing menu items within the Olivero menu. This restricts their ability to interact with the website effectively and potentially prevents completion of tasks.
models.dev_note: The issue description indicates a problem with keyboard navigation within the Olivero menu. To resolve this, the developer should first investigate the HTML structure of the menu.  Specifically, ensure that each menu item is contained within a `<button>` element or a `<div>` with appropriate `tabindex` attributes if necessary to allow focus.  If the menu is a dropdown triggered by a `<div>`, then ensure that the dropdown is also a `<button>` element.  Avoid using `<div>` elements for navigation; leverage semantic HTML where possible.  If using ARIA, the `role="menu"`, `role="menuitem"`, and `aria-haspopup="true"` attributes should be used on the parent menu container and menu items respectively.  Ensure the `tabindex` attribute is appropriately managed to maintain correct keyboard focus order. Consider using a standard, accessible menu pattern (e.g., a “flyout” menu triggered by a click on a button).  Prioritize native keyboard navigation over ARIA attributes.

There have been no patches or PRs created to address this. WCAG 2.1.1 “Some people with hand tremors find using a mous” is referenced by mweiler as potentially relevant.

title: Prepend error to document.title when form submission fails
context: Prepend error to document.title when form submission fails
description: Prepend error to document.title when form submission fails

models.text: Users submitting forms may experience a minor disruption due to the modification of the browser’s document title. While not inherently a barrier, unexpected changes to the document title can be confusing and disorienting for users, potentially impacting navigation and workflow.
models.acr_note: Users submitting forms may experience a minor disruption due to the modification of the browser’s document title. While not inherently a barrier, unexpected changes to the document title can be confusing and disorienting for users, potentially impacting navigation and workflow.
models.dev_note: The issue describes modifying the `document.title` on form submission failure. This is not an accessibility concern in itself. The *actual* concern is that the user is not informed of the error. The focus should be on conveying a clear and actionable error message to the user.
models.thread_tldr: The issue report describes a failure to prepend an error message to the `document.title` when form submissions fail. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The issue has been tagged for WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. A user (hantooroomoo) reported that form submissions fail without a corresponding error message being added to the `document.title`. Lauriii moved the issue to the forms system. Mgifford tagged the issue with WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria.
models.thread_timeline: #1 hooroomoo: Created an issue stating that form submissions fail without an error message in the document.title. #2 lauriii: Moved the component to the forms system. #6 mgifford: Tagged the issue with WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria.

models.text: The lack of an error indicator in the page title means that users who rely on screen readers and other assistive technologies may not be notified that a form submission has failed, limiting their awareness of the status change.
models.acr_note: The lack of an error indicator in the page title means that users who rely on screen readers and other assistive technologies may not be notified that a form submission has failed, limiting their awareness of the status change.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that an error message is prepended to the page’s document.title when a form submission fails. No further discussion or resolution has been recorded, so the current status remains unknown.
models.thread_problem: The reported barrier is that when a form submission fails, an error message is added to the document.title. This change to the title could confuse or mislead users of assistive technology that rely on the page title for context or navigation. Without additional details it is unclear which WCAG Success Criteria are directly affected, but the change may impact information and relationships (4.1.3) and the proper conveyance of error messages (4.1.2).
models.thread_timeline: #1 Unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: When a form submission fails, the word "Error:" is prepended to the document title. This dynamically changes the title, potentially without providing sufficient context or a clear explanation of what caused the error. Users, especially those using screen readers, may become disoriented or confused by this sudden title change without understanding the error specifics or how to resolve it directly from the title itself.
models.acr_note: When a form submission fails, the word "Error:" is prepended to the document title. This dynamically changes the title, potentially without providing sufficient context or a clear explanation of what caused the error. Users, especially those using screen readers, may become disoriented or confused by this sudden title change without understanding the error specifics or how to resolve it directly from the title itself.
models.dev_note: The current implementation of prepending "Error:" to the document.title is a basic alert, but insufficient. The solution involves providing more informative error messages directly in the form using appropriate ARIA attributes like `aria-describedby` and `aria-invalid`. These attributes link the error message to the respective form field causing the error, providing targeted and contextual assistance. Ensure proper placement of error messages near the affected form controls, making them easily discoverable by screen reader users. Existing Drupal form API mechanisms and theme functions can be leveraged. Check Drupal's Form API documentation and accessibility best practices for implementation details. Search drupal.org for existing contributed modules or patches related to improving form accessibility, particularly those related to error handling. Ensure any changes are thoroughly tested with assistive technologies.
models.thread_journey: The thread began with the original report that the document title should be updated to include "Error" when a form submission fails, to better alert users (especially those using screen readers) to the error state. Given the empty thread, there has likely been no follow-up discussion, patch provided, or concrete plan yet. I'm assuming future discussion will likely involve HOW to do this without disrupting the user experience or negatively impacting SEO.
models.thread_todo: *   Explore different implementation options (JavaScript-based title update, server-side rendering of error messages). *   Write a patch that prepends "Error:" to `document.title` when a form submission fails. *   Test the patch with screen readers to ensure proper announcement of the error. *   Consider implications for SEO if title changes are drastic or too frequent. *   Determine how to localize the "Error:" prefix.

models.text: Users attempting to navigate the application via screen readers may experience a fragmented and potentially confusing user experience due to the modification of the `document.title`. While the specific impact is not detailed, altering the document title without providing clear and contextual feedback to the user regarding form submission failures can hinder navigation and understanding, potentially causing user frustration and difficulty in resuming interactions.
models.acr_note: Users attempting to navigate the application via screen readers may experience a fragmented and potentially confusing user experience due to the modification of the `document.title`. While the specific impact is not detailed, altering the document title without providing clear and contextual feedback to the user regarding form submission failures can hinder navigation and understanding, potentially causing user frustration and difficulty in resuming interactions.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a technical detail – modifying the `document.title` on form submission failure. While changing the title *can* provide a notification, it's generally not considered a best practice for accessibility. Instead, focus on providing accessible feedback to the user through alternative means. Specifically, utilize ARIA live regions to announce form errors to screen reader users.

models.thread_problem: The icon’s color contrast against its background is insufficient when the browser’s forced color mode is enabled, violating the WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.4.3 Contrast (minimum) which requires a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 for UI components.

models.text: The contrast ratio of the "Edit" cog icon used in the Field UI does not meet the minimum contrast requirements as defined by WCAG when the operating system is set to forced colors mode. This makes it difficult or impossible for users with low vision to discern the icon and understand its function.
models.acr_note: The contrast ratio of the "Edit" cog icon used in the Field UI does not meet the minimum contrast requirements as defined by WCAG when the operating system is set to forced colors mode. This makes it difficult or impossible for users with low vision to discern the icon and understand its function.
models.dev_note: The issue occurs because the icon's color is not adapting appropriately to the user's forced color settings. To resolve this, either use an icon with inherent contrast (e.g., a filled-in icon where the fill and background are derived from system colors) or dynamically adjust the icon's color and background to meet contrast requirements when forced colors are enabled. CSS `forced-colors` media query can be used to detect the forced colors mode and adjust the icon's color. Investigate existing Drupal core patches or community modules addressing forced colors issues for potential solutions. The general approach is to rely on the `Canvas` and `CanvasText` keywords in CSS, and set the colors for the icon based on the computed values of those keywords.

title: Toolbar icons may not meet contrast when in forced colors mode
context: Toolbar icons may not meet contrast when in forced colors mode
description: Toolbar icons may not meet contrast when in forced colors mode

models.text: Users employing forced color modes may experience reduced visual contrast between toolbar icons and their background, potentially impacting their ability to perceive and interact with these elements. This violates WCAG 2.2 guidelines for color contrast.
models.acr_note: Users employing forced color modes may experience reduced visual contrast between toolbar icons and their background, potentially impacting their ability to perceive and interact with these elements. This violates WCAG 2.2 guidelines for color contrast.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of toolbar icons not meeting contrast requirements in forced colors mode remains unresolved. A suggestion has been made to improve semantics, but no patches or resolutions have been implemented and the issue is stalled due to conflicting themes and overrides.
models.thread_problem: The original report identified a contrast issue with toolbar icons in forced colors mode. Initial discussion (mherchel, mgifford, kentr, libbna) centered on Claro overrides and the potential need to remove them, or alternatively, implementing a role="button" attribute in the Toolbar module. Kentr identified that Claro overrides the toolbar styles even when it’s not the default theme and that Gin may also inherit Claro code.  A suggestion to improve semantics has been raised, but no action has been taken on this. No WCAG Success Criteria are explicitly referenced in the discussion.

models.text: In forced colors mode, the contrast between toolbar icons and their background may be insufficient, potentially rendering the icons difficult or impossible for users with low vision or color blindness to discern. This can impede access to essential toolbar functionality.
models.acr_note: In forced colors mode, the contrast between toolbar icons and their background may be insufficient, potentially rendering the icons difficult or impossible for users with low vision or color blindness to discern. This can impede access to essential toolbar functionality.
models.dev_note: Investigate the CSS used for toolbar icons and ensure that sufficient contrast is maintained when the system or browser applies forced colors. This often involves overriding default colors with forced-color-compatible alternatives defined using CSS custom properties that respond to the `forced-colors` media query. Test thoroughly in different forced color modes (e.g., Windows High Contrast themes). Search Drupal.org for existing issues or patches related to toolbar contrast and forced colors. If none exist, consider creating a new issue and contributing a patch.

models.thread_problem: The accessibility issue centers around potential insufficient contrast between toolbar icons when forced colors mode is enabled. mherchel initially reported the issue. The most recent activity is Kentr’s comment referencing Gin’s integration with Claro. WCAG 2.2.1 (Level AA) Contrast ratio is relevant to this issue.
