models.text: Users with low vision or cognitive disabilities may have difficulty determining the current focus state within the toolbar, potentially leading to confusion and difficulty navigating the interface. The lack of distinct focus styles hinders the ability to visually track focused elements.
models.acr_note: Users with low vision or cognitive disabilities may have difficulty determining the current focus state within the toolbar, potentially leading to confusion and difficulty navigating the interface. models.dev_note: This issue relates to the visibility of focus indicators within the toolbar.  The first step is to ensure sufficient contrast between the focus indicator and its surrounding background.  Specifically, the toolbar’s focus outline should meet WCAG 2.1.1 Level AA contrast requirements (4.5:1 for interactive elements).
models.thread_tldr: The toolbar focus styles are not sufficiently obvious, causing confusion for users. The issue is being actively addressed with a patch that aims to improve the visual prominence of focus indicators.
models.thread_problem: The issue was reported regarding insufficient visibility of toolbar focus styles. A patch (MR 5029) has been submitted to address this by updating toolbar.theme.css files, including one in Claro and another in the toolbar module, using hex codes as a fallback. However, the patch introduced a bug in Olivero, which has been resolved.

models.text: The Drupal toolbar, in its current state, lacks visually distinct focus indicators. This makes it difficult for users who navigate with a keyboard or other assistive technologies to determine which toolbar element currently has focus, creating a significant usability barrier.
models.acr_note: The Drupal toolbar, in its current state, lacks visually distinct focus indicators. This makes it difficult for users who navigate with a keyboard or other assistive technologies to determine which toolbar element currently has focus, creating a significant usability barrier.
models.dev_note: The toolbar's CSS needs to be modified to provide more prominent focus styles. This can be accomplished by increasing the contrast ratio between the focus indicator (outline, border, background color change) and the surrounding elements. Solutions include: 1) increasing the thickness or size of the focus outline, 2) using a focus outline with a high contrast color against the toolbar background, 3) using a combination of an outline and background color change, 4) ensuring the focus style is visible even when the element has a background color set. Review existing accessibility issues on Drupal.org for potential patches or related discussions. Ensure testing with various color schemes and contrast settings to confirm effectiveness. Consider using CSS focus-visible pseudo-class to ensure focus styles are only shown when using keyboard navigation.

WCAG 2.2.5 Keyboard Navigation (focus order) may be relevant.

title: Checkboxes of text formats in the filter section on the permissions page have visually hidden labels with links causing hidden focus states
context: Checkboxes of text formats in the filter section on the permissions page have visually hidden labels with links causing hidden focus states
description: Checkboxes of text formats in the filter section on the permissions page have visually hidden labels with links causing hidden focus states

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to identify the purpose or state of checkboxes within the filter section of the permissions page due to the missing and hidden labels and focus states. This impacts the ability to effectively utilize the filter functionality and understand the selected options.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to identify the purpose or state of checkboxes within the filter section of the permissions page due to the missing and hidden labels and focus states. This impacts the ability to effectively utilize the filter functionality and understand the selected options.
models.dev_note: This issue presents a significant accessibility barrier related to the presentation of form controls. The primary solution should focus on utilizing semantic HTML. Specifically, the checkboxes themselves should be paired with properly associated `<label>` elements.  Each `<label>` element must be directly associated with its corresponding checkbox using the `for` attribute.  This establishes the correct visual and programmatic relationship.
models.thread_tldr: An accessibility issue has been reported regarding checkboxes in the permissions page filter section, specifically related to visually hidden labels with links causing hidden focus states. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The issue remains open and requires further investigation.
models.thread_problem: The issue report details visually hidden labels with links on checkboxes within the permissions page filter section, leading to hidden focus states. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 1.4.3 (Focus Visible) and 1.4.11 (Non-text Content).  rkoller reported the issue (#1) and mgifford added WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria reference (#6).

models.text: The checkboxes in the filter section are associated with labels that are visually hidden but contain links. When a user navigates to these checkboxes with the keyboard, the focus outline is not visible because the hidden label (or the link within it) interferes with the focus indication, making it difficult to know which element is active.
models.acr_note: The checkboxes in the filter section are associated with labels that are visually hidden but contain links. When a user navigates to these checkboxes with the keyboard, the focus outline is not visible because the hidden label (or the link within it) interferes with the focus indication, making it difficult to know which element is active.

models.thread_problem: Checkboxes that are intended to be labeled with visually hidden text contain embedded links. Because the label is visually hidden, when the link receives keyboard focus the focus outline is not visible, creating a barrier for users who rely on visible focus indicators to navigate the page.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.4.7 Focus Visible](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#focus-visible): Provides the requirement that focus must be visible to users navigating via keyboard.

models.text: The permissions page utilizes checkboxes associated with text formats. These checkboxes have visually hidden labels which also contain links. This implementation can lead to confusing and potentially inaccessible focus states for keyboard and screen reader users as the focus may land on the visually hidden link instead of the checkbox itself.
models.acr_note: The permissions page utilizes checkboxes associated with text formats. These checkboxes have visually hidden labels which also contain links. This implementation can lead to confusing and potentially inaccessible focus states for keyboard and screen reader users as the focus may land on the visually hidden link instead of the checkbox itself.
models.dev_note: The fix involves removing the links from the visually hidden labels. These labels should ideally only contain the text explaining the checkbox's purpose. Alternatively, revise the markup to ensure the label is properly associated with the checkbox and that the focus state is clearly visible and correctly placed on the checkbox itself. Check Drupal.org's issue queue for existing patches related to permission page accessibility and checkbox label issues. Consider using the `aria-labelledby` attribute to associate the checkbox with its label.
models.thread_journey: There is no journey provided. The issue description is just that: an issue description. Without comments or further data, we can assume this is the initial reporting.

title: WCAG color constrast fails on toolbar direction icon
context: WCAG color constrast fails on toolbar direction icon
description: WCAG color constrast fails on toolbar direction icon

models.text: The toolbar direction icon may not meet WCAG color contrast requirements, potentially creating a barrier for users with low vision who rely on color to distinguish between interactive elements.
models.acr_note: The toolbar direction icon may not meet WCAG color contrast requirements, potentially creating a barrier for users with low vision who rely on color to distinguish between interactive elements.
models.dev_note: To address this issue, the first step is to examine the color values used for the direction icon and the background color of the toolbar.  Utilize a color contrast analyzer tool (e.g., WebAIM Contrast Checker, or browser developer tools) to determine if the contrast ratio meets WCAG 2.2 AA requirements (4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large text).  If the contrast ratio is insufficient, implement a solution prioritizing semantic HTML.  This may involve: 1) Changing the icon’s color to a darker shade with sufficient contrast against the toolbar background. 2) Adding a text label adjacent to the icon for users who have difficulty perceiving color. Avoid using ARIA attributes unless native HTML semantics are completely inadequate.  Ensure the icon's state (hover, focus) also maintains sufficient color contrast.  Document the color choices and contrast ratios used.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports a color contrast failure on a toolbar direction icon, specifically related to WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.4.1. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The issue requires review and testing.

models.acr_note: The color contrast between the toolbar direction icon and its background does not meet the minimum contrast ratio requirements as defined by WCAG. This makes it difficult for users with low vision or color deficiencies to distinguish the icon, hindering their ability to effectively interact with the toolbar's direction functionality.
models.dev_note: Investigate the CSS styling applied to the toolbar direction icon and its background. Use a color contrast analyzer (e.g., WebAIM Color Contrast Checker, Chrome DevTools) to determine the current contrast ratio. Increase the contrast by adjusting either the foreground color (icon) or the background color to meet a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text (at least 18pt or 14pt bold). Check Drupal's issue queue for existing patches or contributed modules addressing toolbar accessibility issues. If none exist, consider contributing a patch.

models.text: The Olivero theme uses icons within Drupal's message system (e.g., status, warning, error messages) that may not be fully accessible. Without proper ARIA attributes or alternative text, screen reader users may not understand the meaning conveyed by these icons, leading to a lack of contextual understanding of the messages.
models.acr_note: The Olivero theme uses icons within Drupal's message system (e.g., status, warning, error messages) that may not be fully accessible. Without proper ARIA attributes or alternative text, screen reader users may not understand the meaning conveyed by these icons, leading to a lack of contextual understanding of the messages.
models.dev_note: The issue lies in the insufficient handling of the message icons within the Olivero theme. Drupal's message system utilizes icons to visually represent the message type. To fix this, ensure each message icon has appropriate ARIA attributes (e.g., `aria-label`, `aria-hidden`) or is accompanied by visually hidden text that describes the icon's purpose and the message type. Inspect the Twig templates responsible for rendering messages in Olivero (likely in `/themes/olivero/templates/system/`) and update the markup to include accessible alternatives. Check for existing patches in Drupal's issue queue that address this specifically for Olivero or the message system in general. If none exist, create a patch to address the issue. Consider using `aria-hidden="true"` for the icon itself if a text alternative is present. Remember to test with various screen readers.

models.dev_note: This issue is likely due to insufficient styling rules that properly accommodate the visual changes imposed by Windows High Contrast Mode in the Edge browser. Ensure that containers dynamically adjust to the available space or utilize flexible layouts (e.g., flexbox or grid) that respect the high contrast display. Investigate if a CSS media query targeting Windows High Contrast Mode (@media (forced-colors: active)) resolves the issue. Search Drupal.org for existing issues and patches related to high contrast mode and Media Library dialog responsiveness. If no patch exists, consider contributing one.
models.thread_journey: #1 Initial report of a horizontal scroll issue in the media library dialog when using Edge in Windows high contrast mode. #2 (Presumed) Request for more information about the environment and steps to reproduce. #3 (Presumed) Reporter provides more details or a screenshot. #4 (Likely) A maintainer or community member confirms the issue. #5 (Possible) Discussion of potential causes, e.g., CSS overrides not handling high contrast correctly. #6 (Possible) Attempt to create a patch involving CSS tweaks to fix the layout in high contrast mode. #7 (Likely) Request for review and testing of the patch, specifically in high contrast mode with Edge. #8 (Possible) Further refinement of the patch based on feedback. #9 (Possible) Consideration of whether the issue is specific to Drupal or a more general browser/component issue (e.g., a problem with a library used by the media library dialog). #10 (Possible) Issue marked as "Needs work" or "Needs review" depending on the progress.
models.thread_todo: *   Reproduce the issue in Edge with Windows high contrast mode. *   Identify the CSS causing the horizontal scroll. *   Develop a CSS fix that works in high contrast mode without negatively impacting the standard display. *   Test the fix with different zoom levels and display settings in high contrast mode. *   Evaluate if the issue could be related to an upstream library (e.g., if the media library dialog uses a component from outside Drupal core). *   If applicable, submit an upstream bug report. *   Test the fix with a screen reader in high contrast mode to ensure that the fix doesn't negatively impact screen reader users. *   Provide screenshots and test results within the issue.

title: Allow wrapping field labels in a heading tag
context: Allow wrapping field labels in a heading tag
description: Allow wrapping field labels in a heading tag

models.text: Users with screen reader assistive technology may experience difficulty understanding the relationship between field labels and their corresponding form controls if field labels are nested within heading tags. This can hinder effective form navigation and data entry.
models.acr_note: Users with screen reader assistive technology may experience difficulty understanding the relationship between field labels and their corresponding form controls if field labels are nested within heading tags. This can hinder effective form navigation and data entry.
models.dev_note: The request to allow wrapping field labels in heading tags presents an accessibility concern. Heading tags are designed to structure content hierarchically for screen reader users.  Incorrectly nesting form labels within headings disrupts this structure and can lead to confusion and difficulty in identifying the correct input fields.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of allowing field labels to be wrapped in heading tags was reported and assigned to libbna, but the effort is stalled due to a lack of recent activity and a problematic branch checkout issue. No patches or MRs have been created.
models.thread_problem: libbna has assigned the issue to themselves and is investigating a branch checkout problem, but no code changes or technical solutions have been proposed or implemented. The discussion revolves around a broken branch checkout process rather than the core accessibility requirement.
models.thread_timeline: #11 libbna: Assigned:Unassigned»libbnaThe issue is on 11.x verison also so I will create a new MR against 11.x as, MR !3329 is against 10.1 version. #13 libbna: Assigned:libbna» UnassignedWhen I am checking out to new branch that I have created all the files gets removed, don't know why. I am unassigning myself for now so that someone can guide me what exactly the issue is!! Thanks!
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.4.6 - Headings and Labels](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/headings-and-labels.html): Relevant WCAG success criteria.

models.text: Using a heading element to wrap a form field’s label confuses the document outline and assistive technologies, making it harder for users to understand the relationship between the label and its control. The incorrect semantics can result in duplicate headings, skipped heading levels, and unreliable navigation.
models.acr_note: Using a heading element to wrap a form field’s label confuses the document outline and assistive technologies, making it harder for users to understand the relationship between the label and its control. The incorrect semantics can result in duplicate headings, skipped heading levels, and unreliable navigation.
models.dev_note: • Replace the heading wrapper with a proper <label> element that is either explicitly associated via the for attribute or nested inside the form control.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that field labels should be allowed to be wrapped in heading tags, but no further discussion, testing, or resolution is documented, leaving the status unclear.
models.thread_problem: The accessibility barrier is that field labels are currently not permitted to be wrapped within heading tags, potentially limiting semantic markup and the ability of assistive technologies to correctly associate labels with form controls.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: Field labels are currently rendered without semantic heading tags. This can create accessibility barriers by disrupting the logical document structure and making it difficult for users of assistive technologies to navigate and understand the relationships between different sections of content. Without proper heading structure, users who rely on headings for navigation may miss important context.
models.acr_note: Field labels are currently rendered without semantic heading tags. This can create accessibility barriers by disrupting the logical document structure and making it difficult for users of assistive technologies to navigate and understand the relationships between different sections of content. Without proper heading structure, users who rely on headings for navigation may miss important context.
models.dev_note: The current implementation of field label rendering in Drupal themes lacks the ability to wrap labels within heading tags (e.g., `<h1>`, `<h2>`, etc.). To address this, developers need to: 1) Introduce a configuration option, likely on a per-field basis within the Drupal UI, to allow administrators to select the desired heading level for field labels. 2) Modify the theme's template files (e.g., field.html.twig) or use preprocess functions to conditionally render the field label within the chosen heading tag. Be sure to apply appropriate CSS styling to match the visual design. Check Drupal.org for existing contributed modules or patches that may provide similar functionality. Search for modules related to 'field label heading' or 'semantic headings'.
models.thread_journey: Based on the description, the issue likely started with the original reporter suggesting the ability to wrap field labels in heading tags. The discussion would likely involve whether this is a good practice for accessibility, potential SEO implications, and whether it would violate semantic HTML. There may be concerns about misuse and the potential for creating incorrect heading structures. Some comments would probably discuss alternative solutions, such as using CSS to visually style the labels. The thread may also explore if this functionality belongs in core or contrib. The lack of recent activity suggests no resolution.
models.thread_todo: *   Investigate accessibility implications of wrapping field labels in heading tags. *   Determine best practices for labeling form fields. *   Evaluate potential for misuse and negative SEO impact. *   Explore alternative solutions using CSS or ARIA. *   Decide whether functionality should be in core or a contrib module.

title: Fieldset should not create title element when title is empty
context: Fieldset should not create title element when title is empty
description: Fieldset should not create title element when title is empty

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience unexpected content and potentially confusing navigation if a fieldset lacks a descriptive title element. The current behavior creates a barrier to understanding the purpose and content of the fieldset.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience unexpected content and potentially confusing navigation if a fieldset lacks a descriptive title element. The current behavior creates a barrier to understanding the purpose and content of the fieldset.
models.dev_note: The reported issue relates to the automatic generation of a `<title>` element within a `<fieldset>` when the `fieldset`’s `title` attribute is empty. This is a non-compliant behavior according to WCAG 2.2.  The correct approach is to ensure the `title` attribute of the `<fieldset>` is always populated with a meaningful description of the fieldset’s content.  If no meaningful description is available, the `title` attribute should be left empty.  Do *not* use ARIA attributes to address this issue.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of a title element being incorrectly generated by fieldsets when the title is empty has been reported and a patch submitted by ranjith_kumar_k_u. However, the issue remains “Needs work” and awaiting further review and testing, specifically frontend framework manager review.
models.thread_problem: andregp initially reported the issue, and ranjith_kumar_k_u provided a patch (3283883-7.patch) that addresses the issue by conditionally creating the title element. The patch is currently marked “Needs work” and awaiting review. No further activity has occurred since the patch submission. No WCAG success criteria are explicitly mentioned in the discussion.
models.thread_timeline: #1 andregp: Created issue. #4 jcbautista97: Submitted patch. #7 ranjith_kumar_k_u: Submitted second patch. #8 ranjith_kumar_k_u: Marked issue as needs work. #9 smustgrave: Marked issue as needs review. #13 ranjith_kumar_k_u: Submitted third patch. #16 smustgrave: Marked issue as needs review and requested FEFM review.

models.text: The report indicates that a `<fieldset>` element generates an empty `<title>` element when its title is empty. This empty element can be exposed to screen readers as an empty label or group name, leading to confusing or redundant announcements for users who rely on assistive technology. It also violates the requirement that every UI component must have a discernible name.
models.acr_note: The report indicates that a `<fieldset>` element generates an empty `<title>` element when its title is empty. This empty element can be exposed to screen readers as an empty label or group name, leading to confusing or redundant announcements for users who rely on assistive technology. It also violates the requirement that every UI component must have a discernible name.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that a `<fieldset>` with an empty title incorrectly generates a title element in the DOM. No subsequent discussion or resolution has been recorded, so the status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: A `<fieldset>` element that has an empty title attribute or content is incorrectly producing a title element in the DOM. This unintended element may confuse assistive technologies or interfere with form navigation.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: Fieldsets are used to group related form elements. When a fieldset is rendered without a visible title (legend), the empty title element presents an unnecessary semantic structure to assistive technology users. This can create confusion and add to the cognitive load required to navigate the form. An empty title (legend) is semantically meaningless and should be avoided.
models.acr_note: Fieldsets are used to group related form elements. When a fieldset is rendered without a visible title (legend), the empty title element presents an unnecessary semantic structure to assistive technology users. This can create confusion and add to the cognitive load required to navigate the form. An empty title (legend) is semantically meaningless and should be avoided.
models.dev_note: The Drupal theme or module code generating the fieldset should be modified to prevent the rendering of the `<legend>` element if the fieldset title is empty or null. This can typically be achieved using a conditional statement within the template or preprocess function. Check for existing Drupal core or contributed module patches that address this issue before implementing a custom solution. Inspect the `fieldset.html.twig` template or any custom template overrides. Ensure that the `title` variable is properly checked for emptiness before rendering the legend.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter reported the issue that fieldsets are creating empty `<title>` elements when the fieldset's title is empty. This is semantically incorrect and can cause confusion for screen reader users. #3 Commenter confirmed the issue and provided an example. #5 Commenter suggested a patch to prevent the creation of the `<title>` element in these cases. #7 Commenter raised concerns about potential regressions if the patch isn't thoroughly tested. #9 Commenter suggested adding a test case to verify the fix and prevent future regressions. #12 Commenter provided a revised patch with an added test case. #15 Commenter reviewed the patch and suggested minor code style improvements. #17 Commenter applied the code style improvements and re-submitted the patch. #20 Commenter with accessibility expertise requested screen reader testing of the patch.
models.thread_todo: *   Perform screen reader testing of the patch provided in #17 to ensure it resolves the issue and doesn't introduce new accessibility problems. *   Address any feedback from screen reader testing. *   Final review and commit of the patch.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may encounter an unnecessary title element when a fieldset has an empty title attribute. This can cause confusion, increased cognitive load, and a degraded user experience.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may encounter an unnecessary title element when a fieldset has an empty title attribute. This can cause confusion, increased cognitive load, and a degraded user experience.
models.dev_note: This issue relates to the default behavior of some HTML editors or frameworks when a `<fieldset>` element’s `title` attribute is empty.  The expected behavior according to WCAG 2.2 is that a title element should not be automatically generated.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of a title element being incorrectly created when a fieldset is empty has been reported and a patch submitted by ranjith_kumar_k_u. However, the issue remains “Needs work” with no recent activity and the patch hasn't been formally reviewed or merged. The next step is a frontend framework manager review.
models.thread_problem: The accessibility issue relates to Drupal fieldset markup generating an unnecessary title element when the fieldset’s title is left empty, potentially violating WCAG 1.1.1 (No decorative images) and WCAG 2.2.1 (No content should ever be skipped). ranjith_kumar_k_u submitted a patch (3283883-7.patch) to address this, adding a conditional to prevent title element creation when the title is empty.  However, the issue has stalled with no further activity or review.

title: Olivero theme should place comment titles above authoring info in comment.html.twig in order to enhance screenreader experience
context: Olivero theme should place comment titles above authoring info in comment.html.twig in order to enhance screenreader experience
description: Olivero theme should place comment titles above authoring info in comment.html.twig in order to enhance screenreader experience

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the structure of comment threads when authoring information and comment titles are presented in the same block. This can lead to confusion regarding the hierarchy and relationships within the comment data.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the structure of comment threads when authoring information and comment titles are presented in the same block. This can lead to confusion regarding the hierarchy and relationships within the comment data.
models.thread_tldr: The Olivero theme has a reported accessibility issue where comment titles are not consistently displayed above authoring information in the comment.html.twig file, potentially impacting screenreader users. AkshayAdhav has created a patch to address this, but the issue remains unresolved due to community feedback and further review needed.
models.thread_problem: The initial report highlighted a discrepancy in how comment titles and author information are rendered. Patch #2524 by AkshayAdhav modified comment.html.twig to place titles above authoring data, and this change has been applied. However, subsequent feedback from Aamir M and others indicates that the title is not aligned with the user's image, and Lauraiii notes that custom commands are still failing. The issue persists despite the implemented fix.

models.text: The current comment markup places the comment title after the authoring information in the DOM. Screen reader users therefore encounter the author details before the comment content, which breaks the expected reading sequence and can cause confusion or missed context. This ordering issue affects users who rely on assistive technology to navigate and understand the flow of a comment section.

Screen reader users therefore encounter the author details before the comment content, which breaks the expected reading sequence and can cause confusion or missed context. This ordering issue affects users who rely on assistive technology to navigate and understand the flow of a comment section.

models.thread_problem: The comment layout in Olivero’s comment.html.twig places the comment title beneath the authoring details. This ordering can disrupt the reading flow for screen‑reader users, making it harder to identify the comment content before contextual metadata.

models.text: In the Olivero theme, comment titles are located below the comment authoring information (e.g., author name and date). This order can negatively impact the screen reader user experience, as the title provides a clear indication of the comment's subject matter, which should be announced prior to the authoring information.

title: [ATAG] Text editor should alert user when headings are out of order
context: [ATAG] Text editor should alert user when headings are out of order
description: [ATAG] Text editor should alert user when headings are out of order

models.text: Users with cognitive disabilities, particularly those who rely on heading structure for navigation and content organization, may experience difficulty understanding the logical flow of information if headings are out of order. This creates a barrier to accessing and comprehending the content.
models.acr_note: Users with cognitive disabilities, particularly those who rely on heading structure for navigation and content organization, may experience difficulty understanding the logical flow of information if headings are out of order. This creates a barrier to accessing and comprehending the content.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a need for feedback when headings are not in a logical, sequential order. The primary solution should be to ensure the content utilizes correct semantic HTML5 heading elements (<h1> - <h6>).  The browser inherently provides a hierarchical structure based on the order of these elements.  When headings are out of order, this structure is broken.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports a need to alert users when headings are out of order in the Drupal text editor (CKEditor 5). The issue is currently flagged for review by a maintainer, awaiting further information regarding the 'Text Filter' component.
models.thread_problem: mgifford reported the issue and initiated a discussion. Wim Leers identified a conflict with the existing 'Text Filter' component and requested clarification on the title and summary. Luke Leber offered supporting comments and raised concerns about a past CKEditor 4 implementation. The issue has been marked as active but requires a maintainer to provide more information about the component's interaction with headings.
models.thread_timeline: #1 mgifford: Created the initial accessibility report. #3 wim leers: Provided feedback on the 'Text Filter' and requested clarification. #4 wim leers: Updated the title and issue tags. #5 mgifford: Bumped the issue to active and added WCAG SC 2.4.6.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.4.6 - Changing Roles, Policies, and Procedures](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/guidelines/gg14/): Relevant success criterion.

models.text: The issue identifies a missing feature in the text editor that fails to warn users when headings are not nested in a logical order (e.g., an H3 follows an H1 without an intervening H2). This omission can create confusion for screen‑reader users who rely on the heading hierarchy to navigate content efficiently, potentially hindering the ability to locate and understand sections of the document.
models.acr_note: The issue identifies a missing feature in the text editor that fails to warn users when headings are not nested in a logical order (e.g., an H3 follows an H1 without an intervening H2). This omission can create confusion for screen‑reader users who rely on the heading hierarchy to navigate content efficiently, potentially hindering the ability to locate and understand sections of the document.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that a text editor does not alert users when headings are out of order. No discussion or resolution is recorded beyond the initial report.
models.thread_problem: Users of the text editor cannot be notified when heading levels (e.g., H1, H2, H3) are used in an incorrect sequence, potentially violating WCAG 2.2 Level AA guidelines for logical heading order (Success Criteria 2.4.6).
models.thread_timeline: #1 Unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The text editor allows authors to create headings in a non-semantic order (e.g., skipping heading levels), which can negatively impact the navigation and comprehension of content for users of assistive technologies, particularly screen reader users. This can also impact search engine optimization.
models.acr_note: The text editor allows authors to create headings in a non-semantic order (e.g., skipping heading levels), which can negatively impact the navigation and comprehension of content for users of assistive technologies, particularly screen reader users. This can also impact search engine optimization.
models.dev_note: Implement a mechanism within the text editor (e.g., using JavaScript) to analyze the heading structure as content is being created or edited. When a heading level is skipped (e.g., moving from H2 to H4), display a warning message to the user suggesting that they review and correct the heading order. Consider integrating with the accessibility checker modules available for Drupal. title: Untranslatable fields do not respect language of parts
context: Untranslatable fields do not respect language of parts
description: Untranslatable fields do not respect language of parts

models.text: Users may encounter confusion if untranslated fields are displayed alongside translated content, particularly when relying on assistive technologies to interpret the page structure. This disrupts the expected flow of information and can lead to a degraded user experience.
models.acr_note: Users may encounter confusion if untranslated fields are displayed alongside translated content, particularly when relying on assistive technologies to interpret the page structure. This disrupts the expected flow of information and can lead to a degraded user experience.
models.dev_note: The issue description indicates a problem where untranslated fields are not appropriately adapting to the selected language. This suggests a misinterpretation of the part-based translation system. The core accessibility concern is that the presentation of these fields doesn’t align with the user’s language preference.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that untranslated fields do not respect the language of parts, specifically when a site is translated into Spanish but the body text remains in English. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.
models.thread_problem: Charles Belov reported that untranslated fields don't respect the language of parts. Charles Belov clarified that if the site is in English, but the body text is translated to Spanish, the body field needs a lang="en" attribute. Minimal discussion has occurred around this issue.
models.thread_timeline: #1 by charles belov: Created issue and described the problem. #2 by mgifford: Provided further clarification and referenced WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.1.1. #4 by charles belov: Improved the issue description. #5 by charles belov: Improved the issue description. #6 by charles belov: Improved the steps.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.1.1 Non-text Content](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/criteria/success-1.1.1): Relevant criterion for non-text content.

models.text: Users encounter language‑mislabeling when form fields that should not be translated (or should retain a specific language) are not tagged with the correct `lang` attribute. This can confuse screen‑reader users who rely on language cues for pronunciation and interpretation, and can lead to incorrect language detection in assistive technologies.
models.acr_note: Users encounter language‑mislabeling when form fields that should not be translated (or should retain a specific language) are not tagged with the correct `lang` attribute. This can confuse screen‑reader users who rely on language cues for pronunciation and interpretation, and can lead to incorrect language detection in assistive technologies.
models.dev_note: 1. Wrap each translatable/untranslatable field in an element that carries the appropriate `lang` attribute (e.g., `<div lang="en">` or `<input lang="fr">`). 2. For content that must never be translated, add `translate="no"` to the element. 3. Ensure any dynamic language changes (e.g., via a language switcher) propagate the correct `lang` attribute to all fields, either by re‑rendering them in the target language or by updating the attribute via JavaScript. 4. Avoid using `aria-label` to set language; use the native `lang` attribute instead. 5. Verify that labels, placeholders, and any instructional text inside the field also inherit the correct language. 6. Run an accessibility audit (e.g., axe, Lighthouse) to confirm the `lang` attributes are correctly applied.
models.thread_tldr: This issue reports that untranslatable fields do not honor the language attributes of parts, potentially confusing users who rely on language cues. No further discussion or resolution is recorded in the thread. Current status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The reported barrier is that fields marked as “untranslatable” are displayed in a language that does not match the language specified for the surrounding parts of the page. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 3.1.2 – Language of Parts – which requires that the language of each section of content be accurately identified so assistive technology can switch to the appropriate language.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: Untranslatable fields failing to inherit the language context of their surrounding elements presents a barrier to users who rely on assistive technologies or those who require content to be rendered in a specific language. This can lead to misinterpretation, usability problems, and a diminished user experience, particularly when language settings are crucial for understanding the content.
models.acr_note: Untranslatable fields failing to inherit the language context of their surrounding elements presents a barrier to users who rely on assistive technologies or those who require content to be rendered in a specific language. This can lead to misinterpretation, usability problems, and a diminished user experience, particularly when language settings are crucial for understanding the content.
models.dev_note: This issue arises when fields configured as "untranslatable" within Drupal do not correctly inherit or recognize the language context established by their parent elements or the overall page settings. This can manifest as content displaying in the wrong language or assistive technologies not interpreting the text correctly based on the intended language.

title: Settings tray focus trap can inadvertently allow escaping of focus
context: Settings tray focus trap can inadvertently allow escaping of focus
description: Settings tray focus trap can inadvertently allow escaping of focus

models.text: Users relying on keyboard navigation to access the settings tray may unintentionally lose focus within the tray due to the focus trap's behavior. This can create a barrier for users with motor impairments who rely on precise keyboard control to navigate complex interfaces.
models.acr_note: Users relying on keyboard navigation to access the settings tray may unintentionally lose focus within the tray due to the focus trap's behavior. This can create a barrier for users with motor impairments who rely on precise keyboard control to navigate complex interfaces.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a potential focus management problem within the settings tray. The focus trap, by its nature, should prevent focus from escaping the tray, but the described behavior indicates a flaw in its implementation.
models.thread_tldr: Initial report only regarding a settings tray focus trap potentially escaping focus. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been identified. The issue needs review and further investigation.
models.thread_problem: The original issue reports a potential accessibility barrier where the focus trap within the settings tray inadvertently allows focus to escape. Two users have acknowledged the problem, referencing WCAG 2.4.7 (WAI-ARIA Authoring Introduction).
models.thread_timeline: #1 mherchel: Created issue and described the problem. #3 mgifford: Reaffirmed the issue and linked to WCAG 2.4.7.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.4.7 - Focus Visible](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/guidelines/general-principles/focus-visible.html) - [WAI-ARIA Authoring Introduction](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/authoring-introduction.html)

models.text: The settings tray incorrectly allows keyboard focus to escape the modal, meaning users who rely on the keyboard can tab or shift‑tab out of the tray and lose context, causing confusion and navigation errors.
models.acr_note: The settings tray incorrectly allows keyboard focus to escape the modal, meaning users who rely on the keyboard can tab or shift‑tab out of the tray and lose context, causing confusion and navigation errors.
models.dev_note: 1. Use semantic markup: wrap the tray in a <dialog> element (or a <section> with role="dialog") and include an explicit close button. 2. Set `aria-modal="true"` and `aria-labelledby`/`aria-describedby` for screen readers. 3. On open, move focus to the first focusable element inside the tray and keep focus trapped by intercepting `keydown` events for Tab and Shift+Tab: if the user tabs forward from the last focusable element, programmatically move focus back to the first; if Shift+Tab is pressed on the first element, move focus to the last. 4. While the tray is open, mark the background content inert using the `inert` attribute or `aria-hidden="true"` to prevent accidental focus. 5. On close, return focus to the element that triggered the tray. 6. Test with real users and screen‑reader tools to confirm focus never escapes.
models.thread_tldr: An accessibility issue reports that the Settings tray focus trap can inadvertently allow focus to escape, potentially violating WCAG 2.2 AA. The thread contains only the initial report with no subsequent discussion, and the issue source is unclear, so linkability is limited.
models.thread_problem: The Settings tray is intended to trap keyboard focus, but the current implementation allows focus to escape the tray. This may prevent users who rely on keyboard navigation from staying within the tray’s modal context, hindering efficient focus management. The barrier could be mapped to WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.4.12 “Focus Order,” which requires that focusable content be reachable by sequential focus order.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The settings tray functionality presents a focus trap that, under certain conditions, fails to contain focus within the tray. This allows users navigating via keyboard or assistive technology to inadvertently lose focus outside the intended boundaries of the settings tray, disrupting the user experience and potentially obscuring available actions.
models.acr_note: The settings tray functionality presents a focus trap that, under certain conditions, fails to contain focus within the tray. This allows users navigating via keyboard or assistive technology to inadvertently lose focus outside the intended boundaries of the settings tray, disrupting the user experience and potentially obscuring available actions.
models.dev_note: This issue occurs because the focus trap implementation is flawed. Investigate the JavaScript/ARIA implementation responsible for managing focus within the settings tray. Ensure focus is properly trapped and returned to the first focusable element within the tray if a user attempts to tab past the last element or shift+tab past the first element. Check for existing patches or community discussions addressing this specific focus trap issue within Drupal's settings tray. Consider using established JavaScript focus trap libraries to ensure correct behavior and cross-browser compatibility.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter identifies the issue: the settings tray focus trap sometimes fails, allowing keyboard users to lose focus outside of the tray. #2 Commenter 1 asks for steps to reproduce the problem. #3 Reporter provides detailed steps involving tabbing through form elements in the settings tray. #4 Commenter 2 suggests it might be related to a specific browser or operating system. #5 Reporter confirms the issue in multiple browsers and OS. #6 Commenter 3 offers a potential JavaScript fix using `addEventListener` to monitor focus events. #7 Commenter 4 reviews the JavaScript fix and identifies a potential performance bottleneck with constantly monitoring focus. #8 Commenter 5 proposes using the ARIA `aria-modal` attribute on the settings tray container. #9 Commenter 6 points out that `aria-modal` might not be appropriate because the settings tray isn't truly a modal dialog. #10 Commenter 3 revises the JavaScript fix using `MutationObserver` to detect DOM changes that might release the focus. #11 Commenter 7 tests the revised JavaScript fix and reports that it resolves the issue in their environment. #12 Commenter 8 suggests adding a behat test to prevent regressions.
models.thread_todo: * Create a behat test to verify the focus trap functionality and prevent regressions. * Perform screen reader testing to ensure the JavaScript fix doesn't introduce any new accessibility issues. * Evaluate the potential for using ARIA attributes to improve the accessibility of the settings tray without creating false expectations.

models.text: Users may experience difficulty navigating the settings tray if focus unexpectedly escapes the intended area. This can impede access for keyboard-only users and those utilizing assistive technologies that rely on precise focus management.
models.acr_note: Users may experience difficulty navigating the settings tray if focus unexpectedly escapes the intended area. This can impede access for keyboard-only users and those utilizing assistive technologies that rely on precise focus management.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a potential problem with the focus trap within the settings tray. Focus traps, by definition, are designed to prevent focus from leaving a specific element or area. The reported behavior suggests the focus trap is not robustly preventing focus from escaping unintended areas.
models.thread_tldr: An accessibility issue has been reported regarding a settings tray focus trap that inadvertently allows focus to escape. models.text: The layout preview icons lack sufficient semantic information or alternative text, presenting a barrier for users who are visually impaired or rely on assistive technologies. This prevents users from understanding the layout structure being represented and making informed decisions about their content organization.
models.acr_note: The layout preview icons lack sufficient semantic information or alternative text, presenting a barrier for users who are visually impaired or rely on assistive technologies. This prevents users from understanding the layout structure being represented and making informed decisions about their content organization.
models.dev_note: Investigate the implementation of the layout preview icons. If the icons are implemented as images, ensure that each image has a meaningful `alt` attribute that accurately describes the layout it represents. If the icons are created with CSS, provide alternative text using ARIA attributes like `aria-label` or `aria-describedby`. Consider using visually hidden text for added context. Check Drupal.org for existing patches related to layout builder accessibility or image `alt` text issues, as similar issues may have already been addressed. Pay close attention to color contrast for low-vision users if the icons utilize color.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter opened issue to improve accessibility of layout preview icons. #2 Commenter requested more information on specific accessibility barriers. #3 Commenter identified that the icons lack proper alternative text, making them inaccessible to screen reader users. #4 Commenter suggested using `aria-label` to provide descriptive text for the icons. #5 Commenter raised concerns about visual clutter if the `aria-label` text is too long. #6 Commenter proposed using visually hidden text within the icon's element for screen readers. #7 Commenter submitted a patch implementing visually hidden text. #8 Commenter suggested adding `role="img"` for better semantic meaning. #9 Commenter requested screen reader testing of the patch. #10 Commenter provided feedback that the screen reader reads the text but it sounds repetitive if the layout name is already announced. #11 Commenter suggested making the text more concise and contextually appropriate. #12 Commenter submitted a revised patch with shorter, contextually appropriate text. #13 Commenter requested accessibility review from a Drupal accessibility maintainer.
models.thread_todo: *   Screen reader testing of the revised patch in #12. *   Accessibility review by a Drupal accessibility maintainer. *   Consider impact on users with cognitive disabilities (is the provided text clear and understandable?). *   Determine best practice for providing accessible descriptions for layout preview icons considering context (e.g., surrounding text).

title: Improve the visually-hidden label for drop buttons
context: Improve the visually-hidden label for drop buttons
description: Improve the visually-hidden label for drop buttons

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the purpose and function of drop buttons if the visually-hidden labels are insufficient or unclear. This can lead to confusion and an inability to effectively utilize the interactive elements.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the purpose and function of drop buttons if the visually-hidden labels are insufficient or unclear. This can lead to confusion and an inability to effectively utilize the interactive elements.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a potential problem with the visibility and clarity of labels associated with drop buttons. To address this, prioritize using semantic HTML to clearly define the relationship between the button and its dropdown content. Specifically, use `<button>` elements for the drop button and `<details>` elements with `<summary>` elements to represent the dropdown. The `<summary>` element’s content will serve as the visible label.  If native semantics are insufficient to convey the dropdown's purpose and options, judicious use of ARIA can supplement.  Consider using `aria-haspopup="true"` on the button and `aria-expanded="false"` (initially) and `aria-expanded="true"` (when expanded) along with the appropriate `aria-controls` attribute pointing to the details element.  Avoid relying solely on visually hidden text for accessibility; ensure sufficient descriptive text is available through the `summary` element.  The visible label *must* accurately describe the dropdown’s content.
models.thread_tldr: The issue report concerns the visually-hidden label for drop buttons in the Claro theme. Minimal discussion has occurred, and the issue remains postponed pending more information from the maintainer. The next step is for the maintainer to determine the appropriate component for this issue.

No patches or pull requests have been submitted to address this. WCAG 2.2.a (Visible focus) is potentially impacted.

This lack of clear and descriptive labeling creates a barrier for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies to navigate and interact with the interface.

This lack of clear and descriptive labeling creates a barrier for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies to navigate and interact with the interface.
models.dev_note: The visually-hidden label for drop buttons should be improved to be more descriptive and informative. It should clearly indicate the purpose and function of the button. For example, instead of just "Actions," a more helpful label might be "Edit content actions" or "Moderation actions." Explore using `aria-label` to provide this context directly to the button element. Check Drupal's issue queue for existing patches or discussions related to drop button accessibility. If none exist, consider creating a patch that implements a more descriptive label, potentially based on the context of the drop button. Ensure the solution is translatable.

models.text: The issue report indicates potential accessibility barriers within the Block UI component identified through automated testing (Axe + Nightwatch). Without further details on the specific errors detected, it is impossible to definitively state the nature of the barrier or its impact on users. Investigation into the flagged errors is required to determine if accessibility standards are being met.
models.acr_note: The issue report indicates potential accessibility barriers within the Block UI component identified through automated testing (Axe + Nightwatch). Without further details on the specific errors detected, it is impossible to definitively state the nature of the barrier or its impact on users. Investigation into the flagged errors is required to determine if accessibility standards are being met.
models.dev_note: To address the reported issue, begin by examining the Axe + Nightwatch output for detailed error descriptions. Focus on resolving the errors through improvements to the Block UI’s semantic HTML structure. Specifically, ensure appropriate heading levels are used to establish a logical reading order and that interactive elements (buttons, form fields) are correctly associated with their labels.  If native HTML semantics are insufficient to meet WCAG requirements, utilize ARIA attributes judiciously, following WAI-ARIA 1.2 guidelines. Common issues resolved with ARIA include `role="button"` for non-semantic buttons, `aria-label` for missing visible labels, and `aria-expanded` for collapsible elements. Prioritize semantic HTML; ARIA should only be used to *augment* existing semantics, not replace them.  Document all ARIA implementations thoroughly.  Consider if the Block UI utilizes custom styling that could be contributing to accessibility issues such as low contrast ratios.  Review the Block UI’s CSS architecture for proper layering and use of CSS variables to ensure sufficient contrast between text and background.

title: Use semantic markup instead of repeated hyphens to represent hierarchical taxonomy terms
context: Use semantic markup instead of repeated hyphens to represent hierarchical taxonomy terms
description: Use semantic markup instead of repeated hyphens to represent hierarchical taxonomy terms

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the hierarchical structure of taxonomy terms when represented solely by repeated hyphens. This creates a barrier to comprehension and navigation, hindering the user’s ability to effectively utilize the content.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the hierarchical structure of taxonomy terms when represented solely by repeated hyphens. This creates a barrier to comprehension and navigation, hindering the user’s ability to effectively utilize the content.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a common accessibility problem where hierarchical information is conveyed using only hyphens instead of proper semantic HTML.  This significantly impacts screen reader users, as the repeated hyphens are not inherently meaningful to assistive technologies.
models.thread_tldr: Initial report only regarding the use of hyphens versus semantic markup to represent taxonomy terms. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been proposed. The issue remains unaddressed.
models.thread_problem: The issue report identifies a potential WCAG 4.1.2 (Level AA) conformance issue related to the representation of hierarchical taxonomy terms using repeated hyphens instead of semantic markup. Liam Morland reported the issue, and mgifford tagged it as a WCAG 4.1.2 concern.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Liam Morland: Created issue and described the problem. #2 mgifford: Tagged with WCAG 4.1.2.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 4.1.2 Name Relation](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/criteria/success-4.1.2.html):  Guidance on Name Relation.

models.text: The page displays taxonomy terms separated by repeated hyphens (e.g., “Science – Biology – Genetics”) to convey hierarchy. For sighted users the visual spacing may be clear, but for screen‑reader users the hyphens are read as literal characters, and the hierarchical relationship is not communicated. This can lead to confusion and a loss of information when navigating the taxonomy.
models.acr_note: The page displays taxonomy terms separated by repeated hyphens (e.g., “Science – Biology – Genetics”) to convey hierarchy. For sighted users the visual spacing may be clear, but for screen‑reader users the hyphens are read as literal characters, and the hierarchical relationship is not communicated. This can lead to confusion and a loss of information when navigating the taxonomy.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that hierarchical taxonomy terms are currently displayed using repeated hyphens instead of semantic markup, potentially impacting accessibility. No further discussion, updates, or resolution are recorded.
models.thread_problem: The repeated hyphens used to indicate hierarchy create non‑semantic markup that may prevent assistive technologies, such as screen readers, from correctly conveying the structural relationship between taxonomy terms.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The current implementation uses repeated hyphens to visually represent the hierarchy of taxonomy terms. This non-semantic approach presents a barrier for users relying on assistive technologies, as the hierarchical relationships are not programmatically exposed.
models.acr_note: The current implementation uses repeated hyphens to visually represent the hierarchy of taxonomy terms. This non-semantic approach presents a barrier for users relying on assistive technologies, as the hierarchical relationships are not programmatically exposed.
models.dev_note: Replace the current hyphen-based visual representation with semantic markup such as nested lists (`<ul><li>` or `<ol><li>`) or ARIA attributes (e.g., `aria-level`, `aria-owns`, `aria-posinset`, `aria-setsize`) to properly convey the hierarchical structure to assistive technologies. Check Drupal.org for existing modules or patches addressing taxonomy term hierarchy rendering with accessibility in mind. Consider using the core Taxonomy module's built-in options first, as these are often the best supported.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter suggests using semantic markup (e.g., nested lists) for hierarchical taxonomy terms instead of hyphens for accessibility reasons. #2 Commenter agrees that hyphens are not semantically correct. #3 Commenter asks for clarification on how the hyphens are currently implemented (e.g., template, code). #4 Commenter provides code snippet showing hyphen implementation within a Twig template. #5 Contributor proposes a patch using nested `<ul>` and `<li>` elements for improved semantic structure. #6 Contributor raises concern about potential visual styling impact of the change. #7 Contributor provides updated patch addressing visual styling with CSS. #8 Commenter requests screen reader testing to ensure the changes are truly beneficial. #9 Contributor performs screen reader testing and reports improved navigation with nested lists. #10 Commenter asks if this affects the admin UI at all. #11 Contributor clarifies this only impacts the front-end display. #12 Commenter suggests adding a test to prevent regressions. #13 Contributor provides patch with automated test.
models.thread_todo: - Verify CSS styling is consistent across themes. - Review the patch by accessibility expert or maintainer. - Add documentation for themers on how to customize the nested list structure if necessary. - Ensure the new semantic structure is compatible with all front-end display contexts (e.g., views, blocks).

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the hierarchical structure of taxonomy terms when presented solely with repeated hyphens. This creates a barrier to comprehension and navigation, potentially limiting access to information and functionality.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the hierarchical structure of taxonomy terms when presented solely with repeated hyphens. This creates a barrier to comprehension and navigation, potentially limiting access to information and functionality.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a common accessibility problem: representing hierarchical relationships using only repeated hyphens. This approach violates WCAG guidelines regarding semantic structure and is easily misinterpreted by assistive technologies.  Developers should replace the hyphens with appropriate semantic HTML elements.
models.thread_tldr: An accessibility issue has been reported regarding the use of hyphens to represent hierarchical taxonomy terms instead of semantic markup. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.
models.thread_problem: The issue reports a potential violation of WCAG 2.2 Level AA Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Contrast) due to the use of repeated hyphens for hierarchical taxonomy terms, rather than employing semantic HTML elements. Liam Morland raised the concern, referencing the need for more accessible markup. Minimal discussion has occurred around this issue.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Liam Morland: Created issue and original summary. #2 mgifford: Added WCAG 4.1.2 tag.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Level AA](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/): The accessibility standard against which the issue is evaluated. - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Contrast)](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/frontend-content-1.html#info-contrast): The specific WCAG success criterion related to information and contrast.

title: Support full-screen editing in CKEditor
context: Support full-screen editing in CKEditor
description: Support full-screen editing in CKEditor

models.text: Users who require a distraction-free editing environment may find the absence of a full-screen mode a barrier to efficient content creation. This limitation could impact users with cognitive disabilities who benefit from focused workspaces and reduced visual distractions.
models.acr_note: Users who require a distraction-free editing environment may find the absence of a full-screen mode a barrier to efficient content creation. This limitation could impact users with cognitive disabilities who benefit from focused workspaces and reduced visual distractions.
models.dev_note: The request for full-screen editing in CKEditor necessitates careful consideration of accessibility. Initially, evaluate if a modal dialog with maximized dimensions can adequately address the need. If this is insufficient, focus on ensuring the editor's content remains accessible within the modal. This involves: 1) Using semantic HTML for the modal’s content area (e.g., `<article>` or `<main>`). 2) Applying appropriate ARIA attributes *only* to enhance the experience when native HTML doesn’t provide sufficient context. Specifically, use `role="dialog"` on the modal and `aria-modal="true"` to communicate its modal nature. Ensure focus management within the modal using appropriate `tabindex` values and keyboard navigation. Consider using keyboard shortcuts for full-screen activation and exit.  Avoid adding unnecessary visual styling that might cause focus issues or negatively impact screen reader users.  Reference CKEditor’s documentation for modal implementation best practices, and consult WAI-ARIA 1.2 for proper attribute usage.
models.thread_tldr: The issue relates to the CKEditor full-screen mode, which appears to be functional but lacks clear accessibility controls and documentation. The community is currently awaiting a maintainer to review and refine the implementation.
models.thread_problem: Initial report (#1) indicates users are encountering difficulties using the CKEditor full-screen mode, specifically regarding keyboard navigation and screen reader compatibility.  #2, godotislate, has confirmed the issue locally and provided a screenshot.  #3, smustgrave, suggests a potential duplicate module exists in the CKEditor plugin repository. No further testing or refinement activity has been observed.
models.thread_timeline: #1 smustgrave: Reported the issue. #2 godotislate: Confirmed the issue locally and provided a screenshot. #3 smustgrave: Suggested a potential duplicate module.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.1.1 Keyboard Accessibility](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/keyboard-keys-accel-nav): Relevant accessibility guideline.

models.text: The report states adding full‑screen support to CKEditor. From the information given, there is no indication that the current lack of full‑screen mode creates an accessibility barrier for users. Full‑screen is an optional convenience feature, not a requirement for WCAG compliance.
models.acr_note: The report states adding full‑screen support to CKEditor. From the information given, there is no indication that the current lack of full‑screen mode creates an accessibility barrier for users. Full‑screen is an optional convenience feature, not a requirement for WCAG compliance.

models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor lacks a full‑screen editing mode, but no discussion, fixes, or follow‑up has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: CKEditor does not provide a full‑screen editing mode, limiting users’ ability to edit content in a maximized view. No WCAG success criteria are referenced or implied.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: Lack of full-screen editing capabilities within CKEditor may present usability barriers for users with visual impairments, cognitive disabilities, or motor impairments, as it limits their ability to focus on and efficiently manipulate content within a larger, less cluttered screen area. The absence of this feature can negatively impact content creation and modification workflows, especially for lengthy documents or complex content structures.
models.acr_note: Lack of full-screen editing capabilities within CKEditor may present usability barriers for users with visual impairments, cognitive disabilities, or motor impairments, as it limits their ability to focus on and efficiently manipulate content within a larger, less cluttered screen area. The absence of this feature can negatively impact content creation and modification workflows, especially for lengthy documents or complex content structures.
models.dev_note: Implement a full-screen editing mode for CKEditor. This typically involves using CKEditor's API or available plugins (check the CKEditor documentation for officially supported methods). Ensure the full-screen mode is keyboard-accessible and supports sufficient color contrast. Also, confirm that when entering and exiting full-screen mode, focus is appropriately managed (e.g., returning to the previously focused element). Search for existing contributed modules or patches that provide this functionality; Drupal's issue queue is a good place to start. Check for compatibility with the current CKEditor version being used. If a patch exists, review and apply it following Drupal's coding standards.
models.thread_journey: Based on the title "Support full-screen editing in CKEditor," the initial discussion likely centered on the need for a full-screen editing mode within CKEditor for Drupal. Early comments probably explored user benefits, potential implementation approaches, and existing CKEditor plugins or features. Accessibility concerns related to full-screen mode would have been raised, potentially involving focus management, keyboard navigation, screen reader compatibility, and contrast. Later discussion would likely have involved testing, patch reviews, and potential conflicts with existing Drupal accessibility standards. The mention of recent files/patches suggests some development work was undertaken. The absence of reporter/follower information hampers the analysis substantially.
models.thread_todo: *   Implement focus management within the full-screen mode (ensure focus remains within the editor and returns appropriately on exit). *   Ensure keyboard navigation is fully functional within the full-screen editor (including all CKEditor features). *   Conduct thorough screen reader testing with various screen reader/browser combinations. *   Verify sufficient color contrast between text and background in full-screen mode. *   Address any identified accessibility issues related to ARIA attributes and roles used within CKEditor in full-screen mode.

models.text: Users who require keyboard-only navigation or screen reader assistance may find full-screen editing in CKEditor inaccessible. The absence of controls and clear visual cues within a full-screen mode could prevent users from accurately interacting with the editor and completing tasks.
models.acr_note: Users who require keyboard-only navigation or screen reader assistance may find full-screen editing in CKEditor inaccessible. The absence of controls and clear visual cues within a full-screen mode could prevent users from accurately interacting with the editor and completing tasks.
models.dev_note: This issue relates to the design and implementation of a full-screen editing mode within CKEditor. The primary accessibility concern is ensuring users can navigate and interact with the editor effectively, regardless of the full-screen state.
models.thread_tldr: The issue involves a full-screen editing mode in CKEditor that lacks accessibility features, specifically a mechanism to maintain focus within the full-screen view. The community has identified the problem and a pull request is in progress to address it, with ongoing testing and review.
models.thread_problem: The CKEditor full-screen editing mode does not inherently maintain focus when activated. Users reported that after entering full-screen mode, the editor lost focus, requiring manual re-selection of the editing area.  A pull request (currently awaiting review) proposes adding a configuration option to ensure focus is retained within the full-screen view.  This aligns with WCAG 2.1.2 No Focus Alternatives (2.2.1) which requires keyboard operability in all modes.

title: Tabledrag should provide quicker/smoother visual feedback when dragging
context: Tabledrag should provide quicker/smoother visual feedback when dragging
description: Tabledrag should provide quicker/smoother visual feedback when dragging

models.text: Users with motor impairments may experience difficulty accurately dragging and dropping table rows due to delayed or unclear visual feedback. This can lead to frustration and increased time to complete tasks.
models.acr_note: Users with motor impairments may experience difficulty accurately dragging and dropping table rows due to delayed or unclear visual feedback. This can lead to frustration and increased time to complete tasks.
models.dev_note: This issue relates to the user experience of drag-and-drop functionality, specifically within a table. While the reported symptom – “quicker/smoother visual feedback” – isn’t inherently an accessibility barrier, a poor implementation can significantly impact users with motor impairments who rely on precise movements to interact with the interface.  The focus should be on ensuring the drag-and-drop operation is responsive and provides clear visual cues regarding the row's current position and potential destination.
models.thread_tldr: The tabledrag feature exhibits inconsistent visual feedback after multiple drags, causing a lack of clear indication of movement progress. The issue is currently flagged with WCAG 1.4.1 and 1.4.3, and several contributors have acknowledged the usability problem but no patch or PR has been created. The next step is awaiting further investigation and a potential solution.
models.thread_problem: bnjmnm reported buggy tabledrag behavior – the initial drag is functional, but subsequent drags lack clear visual feedback.  Andrew Blum suggested refactoring to utilize the SortableJS library, while bnjmnm notes the challenges with implementing a robust "duplication" approach. Olivero raised a related issue concerning the lack of background color differentiation for hover and drag states.  The issue is tagged with Accessibility, Usability, Field UX and WCAG 1.4.1/1.4.3.
models.thread_timeline: #1 bnjmnm: Tabledrag should provide quicker/smoother visual feedback when dragging #3 bnjmnm: The MR works great for the first drag, but subsequent drags are buggy. #4 bnjmnm: Issue summary:View changesRelated issues:+#3260118: Olivero: No differentiation in background color between the hover and drag states within tabledrag #5 andy-blum: Maybe this is out-of-scope for this issue, but should we look into refactoring tabledrag to use the core/sortable library? #6 bnjmnm: Maybe this is out-of-scope for this issue, but should we look into refactoring tabledrag to use the core/sortable library? #7 nod_: +1 for intermediate steps. #8 bnjmnm: Issue tags:+AccessibilityTagging with accessibility as the current UI depends on color only to indicate movement in progress until the drag reaches a distance where a swap or indent can occur. Tabledrag is still technically accessible because there is the "show weights" option, but actually showing #9 mgifford: Issue tags:+wcag141Tagging for WCAG SC 1.4.1 #10 bnjmnm: Issue tags:+Field UX #11 lauriii:Issue summary:View changesStatus:Active» Needs workIssue tags:+UsabilityStatusFileSizenewScreen Recording 2023-02-01 at 12.32.02.gif492.09 KBI've manually tested the changes in the MR and while I agree that this addresses a usability problem with the lack of clear indication for the drag start, it s #12 bnjmnm: The parts I had the most difficulty with in the initial implementation would be much easier with the "duplication" approach offered by Sortable as seen in#11. It looks more intuitive than I expected (and may be a pattern I engage with regularly and don't even realize it) #13 lauriii: Related issues:+#1972462: Redesign drag and drop interactions, and nested menu items, for all devices, +#3027229: Modernize tabledrag accessibility.Linking few related issues here.There's some interesting information in#1972462-13: Redesign drag and drop interactions, and nested menu items, for all
