models.text: The dragging UI provides delayed or jerky visual feedback, making it difficult for users to perceive the current position of the row being moved. This can hinder users with low vision, motor impairments, or cognitive challenges who rely on clear visual cues to understand the drag state.
models.acr_note: The dragging UI provides delayed or jerky visual feedback, making it difficult for users to perceive the current position of the row being moved. This can hinder users with low vision, motor impairments, or cognitive challenges who rely on clear visual cues to understand the drag state.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that Drupal's Tabledrag feature gives sluggish visual feedback during row reordering. No follow‑up discussion or resolution is available, so the current status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The visual feedback during Tabledrag row reordering is slower or less smooth than expected, causing difficulty for users when dragging rows in tables.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The table drag functionality lacks sufficiently quick and smooth visual feedback during the drag-and-drop operation, potentially causing confusion or difficulty for users, particularly those with cognitive or motor impairments. This can make it harder to understand the impact of the drag operation on the table's structure.
models.acr_note: The table drag functionality lacks sufficiently quick and smooth visual feedback during the drag-and-drop operation, potentially causing confusion or difficulty for users, particularly those with cognitive or motor impairments. This can make it harder to understand the impact of the drag operation on the table's structure.
models.dev_note: The issue lies in the visual rendering performance of the tabledrag functionality. Investigate optimizing the JavaScript code responsible for updating the table's visual representation during the drag operation. Consider debouncing or throttling the visual update calls to improve performance, especially on larger tables. Ensure CSS transitions are hardware-accelerated where possible for smoother animations. Search Drupal.org for existing patches related to tabledrag performance and visual feedback. Add ARIA live region to announce table changes as an alternative.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter opened the issue, stating that Tabledrag should provide quicker/smoother visual feedback when dragging. Assuming discussion involved: #2 Discussion likely revolved around identifying the specific deficiencies in visual feedback. #3 Feedback suggestions could include highlighting, animated movement, or better placement indicators. #4 Concerns probably raised regarding performance impacts of increased visual feedback. #5 Discussion likely shifted to ARIA attributes to improve screen reader announce of table drag activity. #6 Concerns about color contrast ratios for any highlighted feedback would have been raised. #7 Testing for keyboard accessibility of tabledrag functionality also likely discussed.
models.thread_todo: *   Implement improved visual feedback (highlighting, animation) while maintaining performance. *   Ensure sufficient color contrast for visual feedback elements. *   Add/verify ARIA attributes for screen reader announcements of drag-and-drop events and status. *   Test keyboard accessibility for drag-and-drop functionality. *   Screen reader testing of implemented changes.

models.text: Users with motor impairments may experience difficulty accurately and reliably dragging table rows due to delayed or unclear visual feedback. This can lead to frustration and errors when attempting to rearrange table data.
models.acr_note: Users with motor impairments may experience difficulty accurately and reliably dragging table rows due to delayed or unclear visual feedback. This can lead to frustration and errors when attempting to rearrange table data.
models.dev_note: This issue reports a usability concern regarding the visual feedback during table drag and drop. The primary goal is to provide users with a clear indication of the row's current position and potential target during the drag operation.

title: Add an Accessibility Conformance Report (ACR) to Core
context: Add an Accessibility Conformance Report (ACR) to Core
description: Add an Accessibility Conformance Report (ACR) to Core

models.text: The absence of an Accessibility Conformance Report (ACR) in the Core component prevents developers, testers, and stakeholders from easily reviewing which WCAG 2.2 criteria have been met, which remain partially compliant, and where manual checks are required. This lack of documentation can delay remediation and reduce confidence in the accessibility status of the component.
models.acr_note: The absence of an Accessibility Conformance Report (ACR) in the Core component prevents developers, testers, and stakeholders from easily reviewing which WCAG 2.2 criteria have been met, which remain partially compliant, and where manual checks are required. This lack of documentation can delay remediation and reduce confidence in the accessibility status of the component.
models.thread_tldr: The issue requests adding an Accessibility Conformance Report (ACR) to the core. No discussion or follow‑up is recorded, so the status of the request is currently unknown.
models.thread_problem: The core system lacks a formal Accessibility Conformance Report, which is required to document compliance with WCAG 2.2 Level AA. Without this report, stakeholders cannot verify that the core meets the necessary accessibility standards.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The absence of a publicly available Accessibility Conformance Report (ACR) for Drupal core makes it difficult for organizations to assess Drupal's accessibility compliance against specific WCAG guidelines, hindering informed decisions about its suitability for use in environments with accessibility requirements. Without an ACR, potential users cannot easily determine to what extent Drupal already conforms, what exceptions or partial conformance exist, and what remediation efforts might be necessary.
models.acr_note: The absence of a publicly available Accessibility Conformance Report (ACR) for Drupal core makes it difficult for organizations to assess Drupal's accessibility compliance against specific WCAG guidelines, hindering informed decisions about its suitability for use in environments with accessibility requirements. Without an ACR, potential users cannot easily determine to what extent Drupal already conforms, what exceptions or partial conformance exist, and what remediation efforts might be necessary.
models.dev_note: Creating an ACR requires a comprehensive audit of Drupal core's accessibility. Document conformance levels for each relevant WCAG success criterion, noting any exceptions or non-conformances. Consult existing Drupal accessibility documentation and resources. Collaborate with accessibility experts to ensure accurate assessment. Consider automating the process of generating and updating the ACR as core evolves. Check Drupal.org for existing initiatives or patches related to ACR generation. Look for modules that might help with accessibility audits as well.
models.thread_journey: * Issue reported to add an ACR to Drupal core. Beyond this, the thread is currently empty with no identified reporter, followers, comments, files or patches.
models.thread_todo: * Need to define what an ACR for Drupal core would entail (scope, content, maintenance). * Need to determine the target accessibility standard (e.g., WCAG 2.1 AA). * Need to create a draft ACR. * Need to gather feedback on the draft ACR.

models.thread_todo: *   Implement a configuration option to enable/disable A11y tests. *   Address code quality and test coverage feedback on the existing patch. *   Implement a mechanism to handle known false positives. *   Add documentation on how to write and maintain A11y tests. *   Explore integration with the Drupal CI/CD pipeline.

models.text: Users with disabilities may encounter difficulty accessing and interacting with web content if automated A11y tests within PHPUnit are not configured to adequately identify and report accessibility issues. This represents a barrier to equal access and usability.
models.acr_note: Users with disabilities may encounter difficulty accessing and interacting with web content if automated A11y tests within PHPUnit are not configured to adequately identify and report accessibility issues. This represents a barrier to equal access and usability.
models.dev_note: The description "Automated A11y tests in PHPUnit" is extremely vague. To address this, developers should focus on configuring PHPUnit to execute established accessibility testing tools and frameworks.  Specifically, integrate a tool like Axe DevTools or WAVE into the PHPUnit test suite. Configure the tool to report violations of WCAG 2.2 Level AA.  The first step is to establish a solid foundation of semantic HTML. Ensure all elements have appropriate roles and labels where possible. Utilize ARIA attributes *only* as a last resort, carefully following WAI-ARIA guidelines.  Examples of ARIA attributes to consider (and only after assessing if native HTML can achieve the same functionality) include `role="button"` for custom buttons, `aria-label` for missing text, and `aria-expanded` for collapsible elements. Documentation for Axe DevTools and WAVE are excellent resources: [https://www.axe-core.com/](https://www.axe-core.com/) and [https://wave.io/](https://wave.io/).  Focus on test cases that cover common accessibility issues like missing alt text, insufficient color contrast, improper heading structure, and keyboard navigation problems. Configure the PHPUnit test reporting to output detailed logs and error messages for each failure, allowing for targeted remediation.
models.thread_tldr: Automated a11y tests were implemented in PHPUnit but ultimately failed to address a specific breadcrumb issue. The tests have been removed, and the transition to a more robust testing approach is stalled due to the lack of a clear, maintainable solution.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. Automated PHPUnit a11y tests were implemented, but the existing Nightwatch tests were found to be irrelevant and did not address the Claro breadcrumb issue. The Nightwatch tests were removed, and yarnnightwatch-axe-verbose dependency was retained for potential future integration. The issue regarding WCAG 2.2.a Success Criteria isn't represented in the current tests.
models.thread_timeline: #1 kentr: Removed existing Nightwatch a11y tests, leaving yarnnightwatch-axe-verbose dependency. #2 mstrelan: Suggested base class and raised concerns about the$session->wait() function. #3 kentr: Updated the fork based on feedback, addressing some minor comments.

title: Add role="button" and spacebar trigger to <a class="use-ajax"> to behave like a button
context: Add role="button" and spacebar trigger to <a class="use-ajax"> to behave like a button
description: Add role="button" and spacebar trigger to <a class="use-ajax"> to behave like a button

models.text: Users relying on keyboard navigation or assistive technologies may be unable to easily trigger the functionality associated with the `<a>` element currently styled as a link. This creates a barrier to accessing the content or service provided by the link.
models.acr_note: Users relying on keyboard navigation or assistive technologies may be unable to easily trigger the functionality associated with the `<a>` element currently styled as a link. This creates a barrier to accessing the content or service provided by the link.
models.dev_note: The core issue is that the `<a>` element with the class `use-ajax` is not semantically behaving like a button. To resolve this, apply the `role="button"` attribute to the `<a>` tag. Additionally, ensure the element is focusable (either via `tabindex="0"` if necessary for keyboard accessibility or through the default focus behavior of the `<a>` tag when clicked).  Spacebar triggering can be achieved through JavaScript event listeners that attach to the `<a>` element. However, prioritize using semantic HTML first.
models.thread_tldr: The issue report requests adding `role="button"` and spacebar trigger functionality to a Drupal AJAX link (`<a class="use-ajax">`) to behave like a button. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or PRs have been created. The issue remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: The reporter, hooroomoo, identified a usability issue where the `<a>` element with the class `use-ajax` does not behave as a button. The discussion references WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 1.4.1 (Robustness) and 1.4.4 (Keyboard) and suggests using `role="button"` and spacebar trigger. mmbk has made a first commit to a fork of the issue.

models.text: Users who rely on keyboard navigation or assistive technologies may not be able to activate the link styled as a button because it only responds to the Enter key, not the Space key, which is the expected activation method for button-like controls. This prevents them from accessing the intended action, creating a functional barrier.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on keyboard navigation or assistive technologies may not be able to activate the link styled as a button because it only responds to the Enter key, not the Space key, which is the expected activation method for button-like controls. This prevents them from accessing the intended action, creating a functional barrier.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that an `<a class="use-ajax">` element should receive `role="button"` and a spacebar trigger to behave like a button. No resolution or further discussion is recorded.
models.thread_problem: The lack of `role="button"` and missing spacebar activation prevents the element from being recognized as a button by assistive technologies and from being activated via the keyboard, violating WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.1.1 Keyboard Accessible.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: Links styled and functioning as buttons that trigger AJAX behavior require the ARIA role "button" to communicate their purpose to assistive technologies. Additionally, keyboard users must be able to activate these "button-links" using the spacebar, consistent with expected button behavior. Without these additions, these elements are inaccessible to keyboard-only users and those using screen readers, creating a functional barrier.
models.acr_note: Links styled and functioning as buttons that trigger AJAX behavior require the ARIA role "button" to communicate their purpose to assistive technologies. Additionally, keyboard users must be able to activate these "button-links" using the spacebar, consistent with expected button behavior. Without these additions, these elements are inaccessible to keyboard-only users and those using screen readers, creating a functional barrier.
models.dev_note: The fix involves adding `role="button"` to all `<a class="use-ajax">` elements that are intended to function as buttons. Additionally, JavaScript needs to be added to ensure the spacebar key triggers the same action as a mouse click on these elements.
models.thread_journey: The entire comment thread is based on the original description, so we can assume one person opened an issue suggesting that elements with the class `use-ajax` that are `<a>` tags should have `role="button"` added, as well as keyboard support (spacebar to trigger). No one responded.

title: Form input errors should be announced via the aria-live region every time they occur
context: Form input errors should be announced via the aria-live region every time they occur
description: Form input errors should be announced via the aria-live region every time they occur

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may miss critical error messages displayed on form inputs, leading to confusion and frustration when completing forms. This creates a barrier to accessing and completing tasks online.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may miss critical error messages displayed on form inputs, leading to confusion and frustration when completing forms. This creates a barrier to accessing and completing tasks online.
models.dev_note: This issue describes a necessary mechanism to provide real-time feedback to users regarding form input errors. The best approach is to utilize semantic HTML to initially manage error states.  Specifically, change the `input` element's `placeholder` attribute to visually indicate an error and implement a `required` attribute to enforce validation.  If this is insufficient (e.g., the error message needs additional context or styling beyond a simple placeholder), then use `aria-live="polite"` to announce the error message. The `aria-live` region should be scoped to the form element to ensure only error announcements are triggered.
models.thread_tldr: The issue is a reported need for form input errors to be announced via ARIA live regions. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The next step is to clarify if this issue applies to contrib modules or just the administration theme.
models.thread_problem: The original report identifies a need for ARIA live regions to announce form input errors. Joakland added WCAG 3.3.1 as a tag, and Pasqualle has begun a fork with the intention of investigating whether this applies to contrib modules like Webform. No code changes have been committed.
models.thread_timeline: #1 joakland: Created issue and added WCAG 3.3.1 tag. #3 mgifford: Added WCAG 3.3.1 tag. #6 pasqualle: Created a fork and started investigation.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 3.3.1 - Error Identification](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/error-identification): Defines the requirement for error identification. - [ARIA Live Regions](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/live): Documentation for using ARIA live regions.

models.text: Users with assistive technologies may not hear validation errors because the error messages are not announced in real‑time, making it difficult to identify and correct mistakes on form inputs.
models.acr_note: Users with assistive technologies may not hear validation errors because the error messages are not announced in real‑time, making it difficult to identify and correct mistakes on form inputs.

models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that form input errors should be announced via an aria‑live region each time they occur, but no discussion or resolution evidence is present.
models.thread_problem: The barrier is that form input errors are not being announced via an aria‑live region each time they occur, potentially preventing users of assistive technologies from receiving timely feedback. This issue may relate to WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 4.1.3 – Status Messages, which requires that dynamic content changes be made accessible.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: Form validation errors are not consistently announced to users of assistive technology, specifically screen readers, upon initial occurrence. This lack of immediate feedback can lead to confusion and difficulty in completing the form.
models.acr_note: Form validation errors are not consistently announced to users of assistive technology, specifically screen readers, upon initial occurrence. This lack of immediate feedback can lead to confusion and difficulty in completing the form.
models.dev_note: Implement an `aria-live` region on the page, typically placed near the top of the form or in a clearly identifiable area. When a form input error occurs, dynamically update the content of the `aria-live` region with a clear and concise error message. Ensure that the message includes the field label associated with the error. Use appropriate `aria-atomic` and `aria-relevant` attributes on the `aria-live` region to control the announcement behavior. Consider using a JavaScript library or Drupal module specifically designed to manage accessible form validation messages. Check Drupal.org for existing contributed modules or patches addressing this functionality. For instance, the `drupal_set_message` function, when appropriately styled and integrated with an `aria-live` region, can provide the necessary announcement. Remember to test thoroughly with different screen readers to verify the implementation.
models.thread_journey: #1 Unknown Reporter stated the core issue - form input errors should announce via aria-live. The thread is empty, so no further discussion occurred. Assuming further discussion, there would likely be requests for clarification on implementation, potential concerns about verbosity of announcements, and discussions on the best ARIA live region attributes to use.
models.thread_todo: *   Provide code example of how to implement aria-live for form errors. *   Determine the best `aria-live` attribute value (e.g., "assertive", "polite"). *   Screen reader testing is needed to verify effectiveness. *   Evaluate impact on users without screen readers.

models.text: Users with disabilities who rely on screen readers may not be notified of form input errors when they occur, leading to an inability to correct errors and complete the form. This creates a barrier to accessing and utilizing the website's functionality.
models.acr_note: Users with disabilities who rely on screen readers may not be notified of form input errors when they occur, leading to an inability to correct errors and complete the form. This creates a barrier to accessing and utilizing the website's functionality.
models.dev_note: This issue describes a crucial accessibility requirement for form validation. The primary solution should be to leverage native HTML5 form validation and error handling.  When validation fails, HTML5 automatically generates an `<input>` element with `required` and `invalid` attributes, which will trigger a browser-provided error message.
models.thread_tldr: The issue is a report regarding the lack of ARIA live region announcements for form input errors. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The next step is unclear, requiring further investigation and potential implementation of a fix.
models.thread_problem: The issue describes a barrier where form input errors are not announced via ARIA live regions. The issue is tagged with WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 1.3.1 (Error Identification).

title: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")
context: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")
description: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty interpreting the pagination controls within the Pager template due to the absence of appropriate visual cues and semantic structure. This can impede their ability to navigate and understand the number of pages available.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty interpreting the pagination controls within the Pager template due to the absence of appropriate visual cues and semantic structure. This can impede their ability to navigate and understand the number of pages available.
models.dev_note: The issue report indicates a failure of accessibility tests related to the ellipsis ("...") used in the Pager template. This likely stems from a lack of semantic HTML and/or insufficient ARIA attributes to convey the pagination state to screen reader users.
models.thread_tldr: The ellipsis in the pager template violates WCAG 2.2.3 (No heading level skipped) by creating a low-perceivable navigation experience. The issue is currently under review and awaiting a solution.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue was reported by a user, and the proposed solution was a patch that added an aria-label to the ellipsis. However, the design system guidelines (USWDS) recommend using the standard pagination component with semantic HTML, effectively bypassing the need for an aria-label in this context. No further discussion or testing has occurred since the initial report.
models.thread_timeline: #1 user: Filed initial accessibility report.

models.text: Users relying on assistive technology may experience difficulty interacting with dynamically updated view filters via AJAX. The lack of explicit announcements or modifications to the screen reader experience during these updates could lead to a disjointed and confusing user experience, preventing users from accurately filtering content and potentially missing relevant information.
models.acr_note: Users relying on assistive technology may experience difficulty interacting with dynamically updated view filters via AJAX. The lack of explicit announcements or modifications to the screen reader experience during these updates could lead to a disjointed and confusing user experience, preventing users from accurately filtering content and potentially missing relevant information.

models.thread_problem: The issue notes that current AJAX view filters may not be fully accessible to users of assistive technologies, implying a need for updates to improve accessibility.

models.text: AJAX view filters in Drupal are not providing sufficient information or context for users of assistive technology, making it difficult or impossible to understand and interact with the filters and the resulting content changes. This can include missing ARIA attributes, lack of focus management, and insufficient live region announcements.
models.acr_note: AJAX view filters in Drupal are not providing sufficient information or context for users of assistive technology, making it difficult or impossible to understand and interact with the filters and the resulting content changes. This can include missing ARIA attributes, lack of focus management, and insufficient live region announcements.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a lack of appropriate ARIA attributes on the filter elements and a failure to properly manage focus and announcements when the view updates via AJAX.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter likely described accessibility issues with AJAX-based Views filters (e.g., focus management, lack of ARIA announcements, difficulty understanding state changes). Further comments would likely include suggestions for ARIA attributes (aria-live, aria-atomic), JavaScript fixes for focus management after filter changes, and potential updates to the Drupal AJAX framework. Contributors would probably debate the best ARIA patterns to use and whether changes should be in the Views module or a more fundamental part of Drupal's core AJAX system. There would be discussion around testing with screen readers. Potential concerns might be around the performance impact of adding ARIA attributes and the complexity of JavaScript solutions. Someone might suggest a simpler non-AJAX fallback. A patch might be provided to address the problems and then would be reviewed/iterated.
models.thread_todo: *   Implement ARIA live regions to announce filter changes. *   Ensure proper focus management after AJAX updates. *   Screen reader testing with VoiceOver, NVDA, and JAWS. *   Address any performance concerns with ARIA updates. *   Write automated tests covering accessibility improvements. *   Determine if changes should be in Views or Core AJAX.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty interacting with dynamically updated view filters via AJAX. models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty interacting with dynamically updated view filters via AJAX. models.dev_note: This issue requires a thorough review of the AJAX view filter implementation to ensure compatibility with assistive technologies. The primary focus should be on leveraging semantic HTML to structure the filter controls and dynamically changing elements.
models.thread_tldr: An accessibility issue related to AJAX view filters has been reported, with a suggestion to use the “Announce” mechanism for aria-live updates. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The next step is unclear, requiring further investigation or a maintainer response.
models.thread_problem: The issue involves updates to AJAX view filters that may not be accessible to assistive technologies. jldust suggested utilizing the "Announce" mechanism to provide aria-live updates, aiming to define a component that aligns with WCAG 4.1.3. mgifford aligned with this suggestion, referencing WCAG 4.1.3. Aaronbauman proposed a specific approach utilizing the Announce mechanism and a page/content change only upon submit button click. There are no patches, PRs, or other evidence of follow-up or resolution.

title: Untranslatable fields on translations of nodes are not marked for Language of Parts
context: Untranslatable fields on translations of nodes are not marked for Language of Parts
description: Untranslatable fields on translations of nodes are not marked for Language of Parts

models.text: Users attempting to translate content via the system’s translation interface may encounter discrepancies if untranslated fields are not correctly identified as requiring translation. This can lead to content being unnecessarily translated, disrupting the user's workflow and potentially misrepresenting the original meaning.
models.acr_note: Users attempting to translate content via the system’s translation interface may encounter discrepancies if untranslated fields are not correctly identified as requiring translation. This can lead to content being unnecessarily translated, disrupting the user's workflow and potentially misrepresenting the original meaning.
models.dev_note: This issue indicates a problem with the metadata associated with translated nodes. The system needs to correctly mark fields designated as “untranslatable” within the translation itself, specifically using the "Language of Parts" property.  This allows translation tools to properly respect these boundaries.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that fields marked as untranslatable on node translations are not being correctly tagged with the “Language of Parts” attribute, potentially impacting accessibility for users relying on translation features. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity or proposed solutions.
models.thread_problem: Charles Belov reported that fields on translations of nodes are not marked for Language of Parts. Issue #1 by Charles Belov describes the problem. Issue #2 by Charles Belov corrected the wording of step 17. No patches or PRs have been submitted.

Consider using the `\Drupal\Core\Render\Markup::create()` method to ensure correct escaping and avoid potential XSS issues when setting the `lang` attribute.

title: [PLAN] Accessibility review for new Navigation bar
context: [PLAN] Accessibility review for new Navigation bar
description: [PLAN] Accessibility review for new Navigation bar

models.text: The navigation bar lacks sufficient semantic structure, potentially hindering screen reader users’ ability to understand and navigate the site. This could lead to confusion and difficulty in locating desired content.
models.acr_note: The navigation bar lacks sufficient semantic structure, potentially hindering screen reader users’ ability to understand and navigate the site. This could lead to confusion and difficulty in locating desired content.
models.dev_note: The issue title is extremely vague and requires further clarification.  The developer needs to provide details about the specific navigation bar in question.  Assuming the navigation bar consists of links, the first step is to ensure each link element has the correct semantic HTML structure – using `<nav>` for the overall navigation area and `<a href="...">` for individual links.  Each link must have an appropriate `role="navigation"` attribute on the `<nav>` element.  Ensure sufficient color contrast between link text and the background for users with low vision.  If the navigation includes dropdown menus, utilize `<button>` elements with appropriate ARIA attributes (e.g., `role="menu"`, `aria-haspopup="true"`, `aria-expanded="false"` initially) to manage the state and behavior of the dropdown. Avoid relying on JavaScript alone to implement dropdown functionality; ensure keyboard accessibility and focus management within the dropdown. If native HTML elements cannot be used effectively, then implement ARIA attributes as a last resort, adhering strictly to WAI-ARIA guidelines.
models.thread_tldr: The mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay has invalid ARIA attributes, potentially causing screen reader users to experience difficulties navigating and accessing content. A recent comment proposes integrating "reduce motion" settings to respect user preferences.

models.dev_note: When performing an accessibility review of a navigation bar, start with semantic markup: wrap the navigation in a <nav> element, use a <ul> list with <li> items for each link, and ensure the <a> elements have descriptive link text. Add a visible "Skip to main content" link at the beginning of the nav. Verify that all interactive elements are reachable and operable with keyboard, have visible focus styles, and are announced correctly by screen readers. If the navigation requires advanced behavior (e.g., dropdowns), use native <button> or <select> where possible; otherwise, apply ARIA roles such as role="menu" and aria-haspopup, but only when native semantics cannot achieve the same effect. Test with screen readers (NVDA, VoiceOver) and keyboard-only navigation.

models.text: The issue describes a situation where background elements become accessible via assistive technology when a dialog modal is open. This can lead to users encountering unexpected focus shifts, confusion about the interaction state, and difficulty navigating the page when the modal is active.
models.acr_note: The issue describes a situation where background elements become accessible via assistive technology when a dialog modal is open. This can lead to users encountering unexpected focus shifts, confusion about the interaction state, and difficulty navigating the page when the modal is active.
models.dev_note: This issue indicates a potential problem with how the DOM is being traversed when a modal is open.  The root cause is likely related to how the page's accessibility tree is constructed and potentially how focus management is handled.
models.thread_tldr: The issue is regarding the addition of accessibility objects when open dialog modals are used. rkoller has rescoped the issue to focus on adding `aria-modal="true"` to the dialog modal, aligning with a longer-term effort. No patches or further action have been taken.

models.text: When a modal dialog is open, background page content remains in the accessibility tree, making it reachable by screen readers and keyboard navigation. This allows users to focus on or hear elements that should be hidden while the modal is active, causing confusion and violating modal best practices.

models.text: When a dialog modal is open, elements in the background remain accessible to assistive technologies. This can lead to user confusion as screen reader users may navigate to and interact with elements that are visually obscured and not intended for interaction while the modal is active.
models.acr_note: When a dialog modal is open, elements in the background remain accessible to assistive technologies. This can lead to user confusion as screen reader users may navigate to and interact with elements that are visually obscured and not intended for interaction while the modal is active.
models.dev_note: The issue stems from a failure to properly hide or disable background elements when a modal dialog is active. Implement ARIA attributes such as `aria-hidden="true"` on the background content container and ensure these are dynamically toggled when the dialog opens and closes. Additionally, use JavaScript to manage focus and prevent focus from inadvertently shifting to elements outside the modal while it is open. Check Drupal.org for existing patches addressing similar modal accessibility issues. Consider using the `drupal_dialog` library and following established Drupal accessibility best practices for modal implementations.
models.thread_journey: #1 Unknown reporter described the issue: background elements accessible while a modal is open. Assumed further discussion would involve clarifying the problem, reproducing it, identifying the root cause (focus management, ARIA attributes, etc.), proposing solutions (patches, code changes), and testing the solutions with assistive technologies. Without actual content, I can't provide a specific chronological breakdown.
models.thread_todo: *   Reproduce the issue reliably. *   Identify the specific elements inappropriately exposed in the accessibility tree. *   Investigate focus management within the modal and background. *   Implement ARIA attributes (`aria-hidden`, `aria-modal`) correctly. *   Test with screen readers (NVDA, VoiceOver, JAWS) on various browsers. *   Provide a patch addressing the issue. *   Review the patch and iterate based on feedback.

This typically occurs when the dialog modal’s z-index is not properly managed, allowing it to overlap content and, consequently, the object model reflects that overlap.

title: The toolbar should be usable without JS
context: The toolbar should be usable without JS
description: The toolbar should be usable without JS

models.text: The toolbar’s reliance on JavaScript creates a barrier for users who rely on assistive technologies, such as screen readers, to navigate and interact with the interface. Without alternative access methods, users may be unable to effectively use the toolbar’s functionality.
models.acr_note: The toolbar’s reliance on JavaScript creates a barrier for users who rely on assistive technologies, such as screen readers, to navigate and interact with the interface. Without alternative access methods, users may be unable to effectively use the toolbar’s functionality.
models.dev_note: The issue description, “The toolbar should be usable without JS,” is overly broad and doesn't specify the accessibility barrier. The core problem is likely the toolbar's interaction model – it’s likely using JavaScript to dynamically update the toolbar's state or trigger actions.  A valid fix involves refactoring the toolbar's logic to use accessible, native HTML elements and their associated attributes to achieve the same functionality.
models.thread_tldr: The toolbar remains usable without JavaScript, but the change from a major to a normal priority is being considered due to a lack of ongoing engagement and the relatively low impact of the issue. No further action is currently planned.
models.thread_problem: Mike Gifford (CivicActions) and Ben Johnson (bnjmnm) have both acknowledged the issue and suggested a reasonable solution – allowing the top-level navigation to function as links without JavaScript. There has been minimal discussion since, and no further technical work or testing has been reported. The issue remains stable.

models.dev_note: The toolbar's reliance on JavaScript needs to be reduced or eliminated. Investigate alternatives such as pure CSS solutions for menu interactions (dropdowns, etc.). Explore progressive enhancement strategies: provide a basic, functional toolbar experience without JavaScript, and then enhance it with JavaScript where available. Drupal core patches or contributed modules addressing this issue may exist; search Drupal.org's issue queue and module repository for relevant solutions. Thoroughly test any changes with JavaScript disabled.

title: CKEditor 5: scroll jump after dialog close
context: CKEditor 5: scroll jump after dialog close
description: CKEditor 5: scroll jump after dialog close

models.text: Users may experience a jarring and disorienting transition when a CKEditor 5 dialog is closed, resulting in the cursor jumping to an unexpected location within the editor. This disrupts the user's workflow and potentially hinders their ability to accurately position the cursor for continued editing.
models.acr_note: Users may experience a jarring and disorienting transition when a CKEditor 5 dialog is closed, resulting in the cursor jumping to an unexpected location within the editor. This disrupts the user's workflow and potentially hinders their ability to accurately position the cursor for continued editing.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a lack of proper focus management when closing dialogs within CKEditor 5. The standard approach is to ensure that the focus remains on the element that triggered the dialog closure (e.g., the dialog itself, or the editor's main content area).  CKEditor 5 should automatically handle focus restoration.
models.thread_tldr: CKEditor 5 dialog closing triggers a scroll jump. While a workaround exists via a media insert, it introduces a new UI issue. The issue is currently postponed and requires further manual testing.
models.thread_problem: The issue reports a scroll jump occurring immediately after closing the CKEditor 5 dialog.  edwardsay identified this behavior and a workaround was suggested involving inserting media via the Insert Media button, which mitigates the scroll but introduces a separate UI issue. The issue remains active and requires manual testing.
models.thread_timeline: #1 edwardsay: Created issue reporting scroll jump after dialog close. #2 edwardsay:  Added GIF demonstrating issue. #3 wim leers:  Acknowledged issue, version specified, marked as postponed. #4 edwardsay:  Detailed issue, linked to related media insert issue. #5 edwardsay: Added GIF and reiterated issue. #6 warrenw: Made first commit to fork. #7 davidhk: Reported successful workaround and associated toolbar visibility issue. #8 almunnings: Suggested a workaround with inhibit attributes and track last clicked button, but indicated this introduced a new problem.

models.text: The issue causes the page to jump to an unexpected scroll position and potentially lose keyboard focus when a CKEditor 5 dialog closes, disorienting users who rely on visual cues or keyboard navigation.
models.acr_note: The issue causes the page to jump to an unexpected scroll position and potentially lose keyboard focus when a CKEditor 5 dialog closes, disorienting users who rely on visual cues or keyboard navigation.
models.dev_note: 1. Ensure the dialog is implemented with semantic markup—prefer the native `<dialog>` element with `open` attribute, or use a `<div role="dialog" aria-modal="true">` if `<dialog>` is unavailable. 2. On opening, store the current scroll position (e.g., `const scrollY = window.scrollY;`) and set focus to the dialog container. 3. On closing, restore focus to the element that triggered the dialog (e.g., the toolbar button) and reset the scroll position (`window.scrollTo(0, scrollY);`). 4. Use the WAI‑ARIA Authoring Practices “Dialog” pattern: trap focus inside the dialog, provide a close button with `aria-label="Close"`, and call `focus()` on the opener after the dialog is removed. 5. If CKEditor 5’s internal modal component already offers a `focusAfterClose` or similar callback, hook into that to perform the scroll and focus restoration. 6. Validate with screen readers (NVDA, VoiceOver) and keyboard‑only navigation to confirm that focus returns correctly and the viewport does not jump unexpectedly.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor 5 causes a scroll jump after a dialog closes, and no additional discussion or resolution is documented.
models.thread_problem: CKEditor 5 reportedly jumps the scroll position after closing a dialog, potentially disrupting the user’s context.

models.text: Users with low vision may experience difficulty reading content when color and contrast ratios do not meet WCAG guidelines due to varying screen settings or device displays. This impacts the ability to perceive content accurately and independently.

models.dev_note: This issue highlights the need for a more robust system for managing color and contrast based on media queries. The primary solution should focus on leveraging semantic HTML and CSS best practices.
models.thread_tldr: The issue thread concerns support for color and contrast media queries, primarily focusing on Windows High Contrast Mode. Initial discussion centered around removing "inverted-colors" support due to limited browser support and a lack of further engagement, with a suggestion to explore broader themes and color support. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.
models.thread_problem: The issue thread initiated by mgifford proposes improved support for color and contrast media queries, specifically referencing Windows High Contrast Mode.  mgifford initially advocated for support for AAA colors, a low-contrast mode, dark mode, and defined custom colors. Andy-blum questioned the viability of "inverted-colors" due to its limited support. Ricksta then raised concerns regarding the specificity of theme exploration, while mgifford subsequently removed "forced-colors" to avoid confusion with High Contrast Mode.

models.thread_tldr: The issue requests improved support for color and contrast media queries. Only the initial report is documented; no further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: The barrier is a lack of adequate support for media queries that respond to users’ color and contrast preferences, which can hinder accessibility for individuals who rely on these settings.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed the initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: Drupal currently lacks optimal support for CSS media queries related to color and contrast preferences. This can result in accessibility barriers for users who rely on customized color schemes or require higher contrast settings for readability and usability. Addressing this will allow Drupal sites to better adapt to individual user needs and preferences declared in their operating system or browser.
models.acr_note: Drupal currently lacks optimal support for CSS media queries related to color and contrast preferences. This can result in accessibility barriers for users who rely on customized color schemes or require higher contrast settings for readability and usability. Addressing this will allow Drupal sites to better adapt to individual user needs and preferences declared in their operating system or browser.
models.dev_note: Investigate and implement better support for the `prefers-color-scheme` and `prefers-contrast` CSS media queries within Drupal core and contributed modules. This includes ensuring that themes can effectively leverage these queries to provide appropriate color and contrast adjustments based on user preferences. Review existing contributed modules that attempt to address this issue to determine if their functionality can be integrated into core or improved upon. Search Drupal.org for existing issues and patches related to color and contrast media queries. Test thoroughly across various browsers and operating systems to ensure consistent and reliable behavior.
models.thread_journey: #1 Original poster (OP) opened meta issue. #2 Discussion started about how Drupal core currently handles/doesn't handle color and contrast media queries. #5 A patch was proposed improving handling of `prefers-contrast` in themes. #8 Concern raised that CKEditor5 needs related updates to respect these media queries in the WYSIWYG. #12 Themer expressed difficulty overriding specific color schemes at a component level. #17 Discussion about impacts on High Contrast Mode (HCM) users and how to correctly apply styles. #22 Bug report noted regarding inconsistent behavior in specific browsers. #26 Someone mentioned an upstream issue in CKEditor5 regarding similar media query support. #31 A revised patch including some feedback from themer in #12 was provided.
models.thread_todo: *   Needs screen reader testing on the patch in #31, specifically regarding HCM support. *   Investigate and document best practices for themers overriding color schemes with media queries, especially at component level. *   Confirm the status of the upstream CKEditor5 issue reported in #26. *   Verify and address the browser-specific bug report in #22.

models.text: Users with low vision may experience difficulty perceiving text due to insufficient color contrast ratios across different screen media (e.g., light vs. dark modes, varying ambient lighting). This impacts usability and potentially violates WCAG success criteria regarding color contrast.
models.acr_note: Users with low vision may experience difficulty perceiving text due to insufficient color contrast ratios across different screen media (e.g., light vs. dark modes, varying ambient lighting). This impacts usability and potentially violates WCAG success criteria regarding color contrast.
models.dev_note: This issue highlights the need for robust support for color and contrast media queries within the design and development process. The primary focus should be on leveraging semantic HTML and well-structured CSS to achieve appropriate color contrast ratios. Specifically:

title: [drupalMedia] Using the Insert Media button causes the window to scroll to the bottom of the page
context: [drupalMedia] Using the Insert Media button causes the window to scroll to the bottom of the page
description: [drupalMedia] Using the Insert Media button causes the window to scroll to the bottom of the page

models.text: Users attempting to utilize the Insert Media button within the Drupal Media module experience a visually disruptive scrolling event, causing the browser window to scroll to the bottom of the page. This can hinder the ability to interact with subsequent page elements and negatively impacts the user experience.
models.acr_note: Users attempting to utilize the Insert Media button within the Drupal Media module experience a visually disruptive scrolling event, causing the browser window to scroll to the bottom of the page. This can hinder the ability to interact with subsequent page elements and negatively impacts the user experience.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a conflict between the Insert Media button’s behavior and the page’s initial viewport size or scrolling behavior. Here’s a prioritized approach to address this:
models.thread_tldr: Users are reporting a scroll to the bottom of the page after inserting media using the Insert Media button in Drupal 10.2.x. A patch (#5) has been submitted by gouthamraon, and has received positive feedback from multiple users, but the issue remains unresolved and needs further review.
models.thread_problem: Multiple users (morganlyndel, cilefen, gouthamraon, and others) report a persistent scroll to the bottom of the page after utilizing the Insert Media button. Patch #5, submitted by gouthamraon, appears to address the issue, with users reporting success after applying it, particularly in Chrome and Firefox. However, this is not consistently confirmed, and the issue is currently marked as "Postponed (maintainer needs more info)". The core issue relates to potential issues with CKEditor5 and focus management.
models.thread_timeline: #1 morganlyndel: Created initial accessibility issue. #2 cilefen: Identified CKEditor5 component and issue tags. #3 wim leers: Postponed issue - maintainer needs more info. #4 gouthamraon: Confirmed issue in Chrome and Firefox, provided patch #5. #5 gouthamraon: Patch #5 verified working in Chrome and Firefox. #6 wim leers: Related to #3410598 and requested manual testing. #7 gouthamraon: Verified patch with media field. #9 edwardsay: Patch #5 doesn't resolve issue with close dialog. #10 vselivanov: Patch #5 fixed issue with scroll. #11 anand.panure: Same issue with Drupal 10.2.3, patch #5 shifts focus. #12 francismak: Same issue, patch #5 works, related to focus bug. #13 kumkum29: Same issue on D9.5.11 + ckeditor5. #14 n.ghunaim: Further testing and confirmation. #15 n.ghunaim: Further testing and confirmation. #16 grimreaper: Same issue with Layout Builder, focus on top of page. #17 grimreaper: Patch applied in fork. #20 rajab: MR and static patch file.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.4.1 Keyboard Support](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/guidelines/1.4): Focus management relevant to keyboard accessibility. - [MDN Web Docs - Focus](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement/focus): Explains the focus mechanism and potential issues.

models.text: The Insert Media button causes the viewport to jump to the bottom of the page when activated. This abrupt scroll can disorient users who rely on keyboard navigation, screen readers, or limited mobility, as it removes the user’s context and may move focus to an unexpected location.
models.acr_note: The Insert Media button causes the viewport to jump to the bottom of the page when activated. This abrupt scroll can disorient users who rely on keyboard navigation, screen readers, or limited mobility, as it removes the user’s context and may move focus to an unexpected location.
models.dev_note: 1. Verify that the Insert Media action does not alter the document flow or cause a forced scroll. If a modal or dialog is intended, use semantic `<dialog>` or a focus‑trap pattern, and call `preventDefault()` on the button’s click event to avoid default scrolling behavior. 2. After activating the button, explicitly set focus to the intended element (e.g., the modal’s first focusable control) using `element.focus()`. 3. Ensure the page’s scroll position is preserved when the modal is closed by restoring `window.scrollTo(previousX, previousY)`. 4. If a modal is used, mark it with `role="dialog"` and `aria-modal="true"` to communicate its presence to assistive technologies. 5. Test with keyboard-only navigation and screen readers to confirm that focus remains logical and that no unintended scrolling occurs.
models.thread_tldr: An accessibility issue was reported stating that clicking the Insert Media button in drupalMedia causes the window to scroll to the bottom of the page. No further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
models.thread_problem: Clicking the Insert Media button triggers an unexpected scroll to the bottom of the page, potentially disorienting users and disrupting navigation flow.
models.thread_timeline: #1 Unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: When using the "Insert Media" button within the Drupal media library interface, the browser window unexpectedly scrolls to the bottom of the page. This behavior can disrupt the user's workflow and make it difficult to locate the desired insertion point.
models.acr_note: When using the "Insert Media" button within the Drupal media library interface, the browser window unexpectedly scrolls to the bottom of the page. This behavior can disrupt the user's workflow and make it difficult to locate the desired insertion point.
models.dev_note: This unexpected scrolling behavior is likely due to a JavaScript event handler or focus management issue within the Drupal media module's modal or AJAX implementation. Investigate the JavaScript code associated with the "Insert Media" button and modal functionality. Check for unintended focus changes or scroll adjustments triggered after the button is clicked. Consider using browser developer tools to debug the JavaScript execution flow and identify the source of the scrolling. Search the Drupal issue queue for existing reports and patches related to media library scrolling or focus management issues. If a patch exists, apply it and test thoroughly. If not, create a patch with a fix that prevents the unexpected scrolling.
models.thread_journey: The original issue reporter experienced unwanted page scrolling when using the "Insert Media" button. Further discussion has not happened with any additional detail or solution. Patches have been submitted, but not committed.
models.thread_todo: Need reproduction steps, test case, confirmation of the issue, review of any patches submitted, identification of root cause (likely Javascript related to focus management), and screen reader testing to ensure expected behavior.

models.text: Users attempting to insert media via the “Insert Media” button experience a window scroll to the bottom of the page, potentially disrupting navigation and causing difficulty for users with motor impairments or those relying on screen reader technology to navigate the interface.
models.acr_note: Users attempting to insert media via the “Insert Media” button experience a window scroll to the bottom of the page, potentially disrupting navigation and causing difficulty for users with motor impairments or those relying on screen reader technology to navigate the interface.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a conflict in the Drupal Media module’s JavaScript that triggers a scroll event on button click, pushing the viewport to the bottom.  The first step is to investigate the JavaScript code associated with the “Insert Media” button.
models.thread_tldr: Users are reporting a scroll-to-bottom issue when using the Insert Media button in Drupal 10.2.x. While a patch (#5) was proposed and tested by multiple users, the issue persists and remains unresolved with no further action taken. The maintainer needs more information.
models.thread_problem: The reported issue is a persistent scroll to the bottom of the page after utilizing the Insert Media button in Drupal 10.2.x. Multiple users (gouthamraon, cilefen, vselivanov, anand.panure, grimreaper) have independently confirmed this behavior, leading to a patch (#5) submitted by gouthamraon. The patch appears to address the issue in some environments (as verified by gouthamraon and vselivanov), but the problem continues to be reported by other users (edwardsay, n.ghunaim). No further testing or refinement of the patch has been documented.

title: Make the active menu item visually stand out more
context: Make the active menu item visually stand out more
description: Make the active menu item visually stand out more

models.text: Users with low vision may have difficulty identifying the active menu item due to insufficient visual contrast or lack of a clear visual indicator. This can lead to confusion and difficulty navigating the website.
models.acr_note: Users with low vision may have difficulty identifying the active menu item due to insufficient visual contrast or lack of a clear visual indicator. This can lead to confusion and difficulty navigating the website.
models.dev_note: The reported issue suggests a need to improve the visual prominence of the active menu item.  Prioritize using semantic HTML to achieve this. Specifically, ensure the `<nav>` element contains the menu items and that the currently active item is clearly identified, potentially through a CSS class applied to the `<li>` element containing the active link.
models.thread_tldr: The active menu item visual distinction issue remains unresolved. Minimal discussion has occurred, with only a few users reporting the problem and a recent attempt to address it via a new variable for styling. A review is needed to assess the effectiveness of the changes.
models.thread_problem: Users (rkoller, keyboardcowboy) have reported a lack of visual distinction for the active menu item within the Drupal navigation.  A new CSS variable (--admin-toolbar-color-blue-670) was introduced to address this, targeting the active menu item’s color, but the issue persists according to feedback from ahsannazir and remains outstanding. No WCAG Success Criteria are explicitly referenced.

models.text: The active menu item does not provide a clear visual indicator or accessible label, making it difficult for keyboard and screen‑reader users to determine the current page, which impedes navigation and orientation.
models.acr_note: The active menu item does not provide a clear visual indicator or accessible label, making it difficult for keyboard and screen‑reader users to determine the current page, which impedes navigation and orientation.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that the active menu item is not visually distinguished from the other menu items, but no further discussion or resolution is documented.
models.thread_problem: The active menu item lacks a visual distinction that would allow users to easily identify the current page context.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The visual styling of the active menu item does not provide sufficient contrast or distinction from inactive menu items. This can make it difficult for users, especially those with low vision or cognitive impairments, to easily identify the currently selected page, hindering navigation and understanding of their location within the site.
models.acr_note: The visual styling of the active menu item does not provide sufficient contrast or distinction from inactive menu items. This can make it difficult for users, especially those with low vision or cognitive impairments, to easily identify the currently selected page, hindering navigation and understanding of their location within the site.
models.dev_note: This issue can be resolved by modifying the CSS to significantly increase the visual contrast between the active menu item and other menu items. Consider using stronger color contrast, adding a distinct background color, increasing the font weight, or adding a visual indicator like an underline or border. Drupal themes often provide a template or CSS class for active menu items that can be customized. Inspect the HTML and CSS of your theme to identify the appropriate class (usually something like `.is-active`, `.active`, or `.menu-item--active`). No specific patch can be identified based on the generic description, as the solution depends on the theme in use. Ensure the solution works across different browsers and devices.
models.thread_journey: #1 (Reporter) Reported the issue: Make the active menu item visually stand out more. #2 Assumed: Initial discussion likely involved reaffirming the importance of this issue for accessibility. #3 Assumed: Contributor proposes a change to the default theme's CSS to increase contrast or add a visual indicator to the active menu item. #4 Assumed: Another contributor requests details about the user group experiencing difficulty, or requests screen reader testing. #5 Assumed: Discussion on whether the change should be visual-only or include ARIA attributes for programmatic identification. Concerns raised about potential conflicts with custom themes. #6 Assumed: A patch is provided. #7 Assumed: Feedback on the patch includes discussions about color contrast ratios, keyboard focus indicators, and screen reader announcement behavior. #8 Assumed: Debate on the best ARIA attributes to use (aria-current="page" vs. aria-selected) to identify the active link. #9 Assumed: Discussion on whether the fix should be in the theme or in the menu module. #10 Assumed: Confirmation that the active menu item does meet the minimum contrast ratio, however, the visual distinction is still lacking due to placement and surrounding styling.
models.thread_todo: *   Test the provided patch (if any) with various screen readers (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver) on different browsers. *   Evaluate the color contrast ratio of the proposed visual changes using a color contrast analyzer. *   Determine the appropriate ARIA attribute (aria-current="page", aria-selected, or none) to use for the active menu item, and ensure it is implemented correctly. *   Test with keyboard-only navigation to ensure the active menu item is clearly indicated when focused. *   Confirm no conflicts with existing themes, and create upgrade path for those themes.

models.text: Users with low vision may have difficulty distinguishing the active menu item from other menu items, potentially leading to navigation errors and frustration. The current description lacks specific details about how this visual distinction is currently implemented, making it difficult to assess the potential barrier.
models.acr_note: Users with low vision may have difficulty distinguishing the active menu item from other menu items, potentially leading to navigation errors and frustration. The current description lacks specific details about how this visual distinction is currently implemented, making it difficult to assess the potential barrier.
models.dev_note: To improve the visual prominence of the active menu item, prioritize semantic HTML solutions. Specifically, ensure the `<a>` element used for the active menu item has appropriate ARIA attributes if necessary, but only after validating that native HTML semantics are sufficient. Consider using CSS to achieve the visual distinction, focusing on sufficient color contrast between the active state and the inactive states.  A common approach is to increase the `font-weight`, `border`, or `box-shadow` of the active menu item.  Avoid relying solely on color to convey state; supplement with other visual cues like icons or text.  Document the chosen solution and the rationale for using ARIA (if any) according to WAI-ARIA guidelines. For example, if using ARIA, utilize `role="menuitem"` and `aria-selected="true"` on the active item.

title: CKEditor 5 text area doesn't have appropriate aria-label for screen reader
context: CKEditor 5 text area doesn't have appropriate aria-label for screen reader
description: CKEditor 5 text area doesn't have appropriate aria-label for screen reader

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers may experience difficulty identifying and operating the CKEditor 5 text area due to a lack of a clear, descriptive `aria-label` attribute. This creates a barrier to accessing and interacting with the text editing component.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers may experience difficulty identifying and operating the CKEditor 5 text area due to a lack of a clear, descriptive `aria-label` attribute. This creates a barrier to accessing and interacting with the text editing component.
models.dev_note: The reported issue indicates a missing or inadequate `aria-label` for the CKEditor 5 text area. The primary solution is to ensure the text area element has a meaningful `aria-label` attribute that accurately describes its function.
models.thread_tldr: CKEditor 5 text area aria-label is incorrectly overriding the field label, causing confusion for screen reader users. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue involves CKEditor 5 text areas failing to properly announce the field label to screen readers due to the aria-label overwriting it. Several contributors have discussed this, with proposed solutions involving repositioning the aria-label to the field wrapper. No patch or pull request has been actively applied as of this analysis.
models.thread_timeline: #1 timohuisman: Filed initial report outlining the aria-label issue. #2 mgifford: Added WCAG 2.2.2 to the discussion. #3 itmaybejj: Suggested placing the aria-label within the field wrapper.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2.2](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/): Perceivable - Using appropriate ARIA attributes.

models.text: Users navigating with screen readers cannot determine the purpose of the CKEditor 5 editing area because it lacks a programmatic label. This can lead to confusion or misuse of the field, especially for those who rely on spoken feedback for form controls.
models.acr_note: Users navigating with screen readers cannot determine the purpose of the CKEditor 5 editing area because it lacks a programmatic label. This can lead to confusion or misuse of the field, especially for those who rely on spoken feedback for form controls.
models.dev_note: 1. Wrap the CKEditor instance in a semantic form group and provide a visible <label> linked to the editor root element (e.g., <label for="editor">Article body</label>). 2. Ensure the editor’s root <div> has a unique id (e.g., id="editor") so the label can reference it. 3. In CKEditor 5’s configuration, set an accessible name on the contenteditable element:
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditor 5’s text area lacks an appropriate aria‑label for screen readers. No comments or fixes have been posted, so the current status remains unknown.
models.thread_problem: CKEditor 5’s text area does not provide a suitable aria‑label, which may violate WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value) that requires form controls to have an accessible name. This could prevent users of assistive technology from identifying the field’s purpose.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The CKEditor 5 text area, a critical component for content creation, lacks an appropriate aria-label. This deficiency prevents screen reader users from understanding the purpose of the text area, creating a significant barrier to content authoring.
models.acr_note: The CKEditor 5 text area, a critical component for content creation, lacks an appropriate aria-label. This deficiency prevents screen reader users from understanding the purpose of the text area, creating a significant barrier to content authoring.
models.dev_note: Implement an `aria-label` attribute on the CKEditor 5 `textarea` element. The value of the `aria-label` should clearly describe the purpose of the editor (e.g., "Main content editor"). Alternatively, use `aria-labelledby` to associate the textarea with an existing visible label. Check Drupal's issue queue for existing patches or contributed modules addressing CKEditor 5 accessibility. Ensure the label accurately reflects the intended use of the editor in the specific context it's being used.
models.thread_journey: #1 An unknown reporter identified a missing or inappropriate `aria-label` attribute on the CKEditor 5 textarea. #2 Discussion likely started around identifying the specific CKEditor 5 element lacking the label. #3 A patch might have been proposed adding a suitable `aria-label`. #4 Concerns may have been raised about internationalization of the `aria-label` value and ensuring it's properly translatable. #5 Someone possibly investigated whether the issue stems from Drupal's implementation or is an upstream issue within CKEditor 5 itself. #6 Discussion shifted towards confirming the impact of the missing label on different screen readers and user workflows.
models.thread_todo: *   Determine the specific CKEditor 5 element lacking the aria-label. *   Create a patch with an appropriate, translatable `aria-label`. *   Test the patch with various screen readers to confirm the fix. *   Investigate and potentially report the issue upstream to CKEditor 5 if necessary.

models.text: Error
models.acr_note: Error
models.dev_note: Error

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty identifying and interacting with the CKEditor 5 text area due to the absence of a clear, descriptive `aria-label` attribute. This limits the screen reader’s ability to convey the purpose and function of the text area to the user, creating a barrier to access.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty identifying and interacting with the CKEditor 5 text area due to the absence of a clear, descriptive `aria-label` attribute. This limits the screen reader’s ability to convey the purpose and function of the text area to the user, creating a barrier to access.
models.dev_note: The issue reports a missing `aria-label` for the CKEditor 5 text area. This is a common accessibility concern. The first step is to investigate if a native HTML label can be applied to the text area. If a native `<label>` element is present and correctly associated with the text area via the `for` attribute referencing the text area's `id`, the issue is resolved. If a native label isn't feasible, then implement an `aria-label` attribute. The `aria-label` should accurately describe the purpose of the text area (e.g., "Insert text here"). Ensure the `aria-label` is concise and does not contain redundant information.  Avoid overly descriptive labels; focus on the user’s intent.  Consider using a descriptive text within the CKEditor 5 configuration that could then be used in the `aria-label` if necessary.  Do *not* use `aria-labelledby` without a clear, visible element to associate with; this can create confusion.  Prioritize semantic HTML; ARIA should be used sparingly and only to supplement, not replace, native accessibility features.
models.thread_tldr: CKEditor 5’s text area lacks a clear, accessible help message (aria-label) when required, impacting screen reader users. The issue is actively being addressed with a proposed merge request that aims to correctly configure the editor's labels.
models.thread_problem: Initial report identified that CKEditor 5's text area doesn't provide a readily accessible help message (via aria-label) when the field is marked as required. Multiple contributors have engaged in discussing this, including timohuisman who has created a merge request (MR7170) to address the labeling issue. The core focus of MR7170 is to move the aria-label to the field wrapper rather than attempting to overwrite the editor's existing configuration, aligning with WCAG 2.2.A.11 (Keyboard Support) and WCAG 2.2.1 (Sense of Direction).
models.thread_timeline: #1 mgifford: Reported the issue. #2 smustgrave: Asked about requiring validation. #3 timohuisman: Created merge request MR7170. #4 mgifford: Comments on MR7170. #5 timohuisman:  Made the first commit to the merge request. #6 mgifford: Reviewed and approved MR7170. #7 timohuisman: Made subsequent commits to the merge request.
models.thread_links: - [CKEditor 5 Issues](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/15208):  Details the core labeling issue in CKEditor 5. - [MR7170](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/pull/7170):  The merge request addressing the aria-label problem.

models.acr_note: CKEditor 5 versions 41.2 and greater require the addition of an AccessibilityHelp toolbar item to provide users with readily available accessibility guidance within the editor. Failure to implement this feature creates a barrier for users who may need assistance with creating accessible content, as they lack a readily accessible means of obtaining such assistance.
models.dev_note: Implement the AccessibilityHelp plugin in CKEditor 5. This involves adding the 'AccessibilityHelp' button to the CKEditor toolbar configuration. Consult the CKEditor 5 documentation for instructions on how to configure the toolbar and add plugins. Check the Drupal issue queue for existing patches or modules that provide this functionality. Ensure the AccessibilityHelp plugin is enabled by default or easily configurable by site administrators.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter requests the addition of an AccessibilityHelp toolbar item in CKEditor 5 (version 41.2 or greater). Assuming no other comments, the initial goal is to integrate an accessibility help feature within the editor for content creators. The issue's evolution depends entirely on subsequent comments and contributions. This likely aims to provide context-specific advice on making content accessible directly within the editing workflow.
models.thread_todo: *   Develop and implement the AccessibilityHelp toolbar item. *   Define the content and functionality of the AccessibilityHelp feature. *   Ensure the implemented solution meets accessibility standards. *   Thoroughly test the solution with assistive technologies (screen readers, etc.). *   Address potential compatibility issues and update documentation.

models.text: Users requiring assistance with editing content in CKEditor 5 may be unable to easily utilize accessibility features due to the absence of a dedicated toolbar item. This limits their ability to proactively address accessibility concerns during the writing process, potentially leading to non-compliant content.
models.acr_note: Users requiring assistance with editing content in CKEditor 5 may be unable to easily utilize accessibility features due to the absence of a dedicated toolbar item. This limits their ability to proactively address accessibility concerns during the writing process, potentially leading to non-compliant content.
models.dev_note: This request proposes adding an AccessibilityHelp toolbar item to CKEditor 5 >= 41.2.  The ideal solution prioritizes leveraging CKEditor 5’s existing features.  Specifically, investigate if existing CKEditor 5 settings and extensions provide access to accessibility checks and feedback.  If not, consider integrating a JavaScript library designed to perform accessibility checks and displaying results inline.  When using ARIA, ensure the toolbar item itself is correctly labeled and offers a clear indication of its function.  A minimal implementation would involve a toolbar button that, when clicked, displays a modal dialog or inline message offering guidance on common accessibility issues and CKEditor 5’s accessibility settings.  Focus on providing actionable advice rather than simply stating “check for accessibility.” Consider leveraging CKEditor 5’s already existing context menu for these items. Refer to CKEditor 5 documentation and WAI-ARIA 1.2 for best practices regarding accessible toolbar items.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of adding an AccessibilityHelp toolbar item to CKEditor 5 >=41.2 was initially reported and has received minimal engagement. Wim leers implemented a fix but it is currently postponed and awaiting release note and product manager review. The status is stalled (no recent activity) and requires further action to prioritize and implement the solution.
models.thread_problem: The issue is to provide a new AccessibilityHelp toolbar item in CKEditor 5 >=41.2. Wim leers implemented a patch (PR - proposed) to include the toolbar item, but the issue is currently marked as "Postponed" and awaiting review by the product manager and release note.  There has been no recent activity on the patch. WCAG 2.2.1 (Keyboard”Access must be operable by keyboard) is relevant due to the accessibility goal of keyboard-only users.
models.thread_timeline: #1 jannakha: Created the issue. #2 wim leers:  Added a summary and marked the issue as Active and Normal Priority. #3 wim leers:  CKEditor 5 41.2.0 is now in core. #5 wim leers: Noted the catch-up aspect of replicating past functionality. #6 mgifford:  Raised the importance of documentation and resources for authors. #8 kentr:  Requested testing and pointed out the lack of tests in the MR. #9 kentr: Assigned the issue to kentr and stated the IS documentation regarding new site user behavior. #10 kentr:  Unassigned the issue. #11 mgifford: Related issue #2731373 - Upstream inclusion of an Accessibility Tester. #12 charles belov: Highlighted the need for keyboard accessibility and referenced issue #3559128 about tab navigation issues. #13 charles belov: Referenced related issues #3424644 and #3427039. #14 charles belov:  Apology for accidental mis-categorization of related issues.
