title: High contrast mode needs some more refinement
context: High contrast mode needs some more refinement
description: High contrast mode needs some more refinement

models.text: Users utilizing high contrast modes may experience reduced readability and usability due to insufficient color contrast between text and background. This impacts users with low vision or color blindness, potentially hindering their ability to access and understand content.
models.acr_note: Users utilizing high contrast modes may experience reduced readability and usability due to insufficient color contrast between text and background. This impacts users with low vision or color blindness, potentially hindering their ability to access and understand content.
models.dev_note: This issue report is currently too vague to provide specific technical guidance. "Refinement" of high contrast mode requires further clarification. To address potential accessibility barriers related to high contrast mode, focus on the following:
models.thread_tldr: The issue of an invisible active menu item in the top bar persists when using high contrast mode (color dusk), particularly on Firefox on macOS. Collaboration is active as recent changes have identified the root cause. The next step is for maintainers to investigate the underlying ActiveText implementation.
models.thread_problem: Initial report only. The issue of an invisible active menu item within the top bar persists in high contrast mode (color dusk). Kentr identified that this is not the "ActiveText" for the currently active page, but rather for links being activated. Recent testing by Kentr revealed the issue is specific to Firefox on macOS, and that the standard orange background of non-live workspaces is also noticeably different.
models.thread_timeline: #21 kentr: Identified the issue as relating to ActiveText and its incorrect application. #25 kentr: Provided screenshots illustrating the difference between active and non-active states in high contrast mode. #27 rkoller: Updated issue summary to reflect findings and next steps.

models.acr_note: Users who rely on high‑contrast mode may find text and interactive elements hard to perceive because the contrast ratios are insufficient or inconsistent, limiting the ability to read content and navigate the interface.
models.dev_note: 1. **Semantic HTML** – Use native elements (e.g., `<button>`, `<nav>`, `<header>`) so styling is applied consistently across themes.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that the high contrast mode is not sufficiently refined. No further discussion or resolution steps have been recorded, so the status remains at the initial report stage.
models.thread_problem: The high contrast mode currently used by the application does not meet users’ expectations for adequate contrast, potentially impeding users with visual impairments from reading content clearly.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The application's high contrast mode requires further refinement. The lack of detail prevents a complete assessment, but issues commonly encountered include insufficient contrast between text and background, loss of critical visual information due to color changes, and improper handling of focus indicators and non-text elements. This makes the application difficult or impossible to use for individuals with low vision or other visual impairments.
models.acr_note: The application's high contrast mode requires further refinement. The lack of detail prevents a complete assessment, but issues commonly encountered include insufficient contrast between text and background, loss of critical visual information due to color changes, and improper handling of focus indicators and non-text elements. This makes the application difficult or impossible to use for individuals with low vision or other visual impairments.
models.dev_note: Investigate how the current high contrast mode is implemented. Ensure sufficient contrast ratios (at least 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text and UI components) are maintained between text and background colors, following WCAG 1.4.3. Verify that color alone is not used to convey information (WCAG 1.4.1). Ensure focus indicators are clearly visible and meet contrast requirements when high contrast is enabled (WCAG 2.4.7). Test with various high contrast settings and assistive technologies. Check Drupal.org for existing modules or patches related to high contrast themes or accessibility improvements. Consider using CSS media queries (`prefers-contrast: more`) to apply targeted styling for high contrast users. Debug by using developer tools to inspect the computed styles in high contrast mode.
models.thread_journey: #1 Original reporter noted need for high contrast mode refinement. (Assuming further discussion is needed to pinpoint specific areas and required fixes.)
models.thread_todo: *   Identify specific UI elements failing high contrast requirements. *   Propose CSS fixes for detected contrast failures. *   Assess impact on usability and overall site design with changes. *   Conduct screen reader testing to ensure accessibility of the corrected elements. *   Document the implemented changes and any limitations.

models.text: Users relying on high contrast modes may experience difficulty in reading content due to insufficient color contrast ratios. This impacts usability and potentially violates WCAG success criteria regarding perceivable content.
models.acr_note: Users relying on high contrast modes may experience difficulty in reading content due to insufficient color contrast ratios. This impacts usability and potentially violates WCAG success criteria regarding perceivable content.
models.dev_note: This issue report, as stated, lacks specifics regarding the nature of the “refinement” needed in the high contrast mode. To address this, we need detailed information on *what* is not working correctly. However, we can provide general guidance. Firstly, ensure the underlying HTML structure for color adjustments is semantically correct. This likely involves using `<input type="range">` for adjusting contrast levels, linked to CSS variables controlling color values.  Avoid using divs or span elements to implement contrast adjustments; use semantic HTML elements for their intended purpose.
models.thread_tldr: High contrast mode is experiencing issues with the active menu item being nearly invisible, and the workspace background colors are inconsistent. The issue is now actively being collaborated on, with a recent test showing a clear, visible hover state when the automatic dark mode is disabled.
models.thread_problem: The active menu item within the top bar is exhibiting a severe visibility problem when high contrast mode is enabled. Initial reports identified this issue, and a recent test by @kentr confirmed the problem and demonstrated a clear, visible hover state when automatic dark mode is disabled. The inconsistent workspace background colors (green live vs. orange inactive) is also a potential violation of WCAG 1.4.1.
models.thread_timeline: #1 kentr: Initial report - high contrast mode has a nearly invisible active menu item. #2 rkoller: Acknowledged and agreed with @kentr. #3 kentr: Tested with automatic dark mode disabled and the active menu item is now clearly visible. #4 rkoller: Updated issue summary to reflect current status.

title: Make the link descriptions more descriptive, helpful, and clear.
context: Make the link descriptions more descriptive, helpful, and clear.
description: Make the link descriptions more descriptive, helpful, and clear.

models.text: Users may experience difficulty understanding the purpose and context of links due to insufficient or unclear descriptions. This impacts users who rely on screen readers or have cognitive disabilities, potentially leading to confusion and difficulty navigating the website.
models.acr_note: Users may experience difficulty understanding the purpose and context of links due to insufficient or unclear descriptions. This impacts users who rely on screen readers or have cognitive disabilities, potentially leading to confusion and difficulty navigating the website.
models.dev_note: The issue description lacks specifics, but the overall goal is to improve link descriptions for accessibility. The primary focus should be on using semantic HTML elements appropriately. For links, utilize `<a href="...">` with descriptive `alt` text for images within the link and a clear, concise link text that accurately reflects the destination. Avoid vague descriptions like "Click here."  If semantic HTML is insufficient to convey the link’s purpose (e.g., a complex action requiring detailed context), then consider using ARIA attributes like `aria-describedby` to associate the link with a more detailed explanation. Ensure sufficient color contrast between the link text and its background. Prioritize accurate and descriptive link text above all else.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports unclear link descriptions for the Drupal navigation logo, leading to potential accessibility issues for screen reader users.  @rkoller has removed a problematic description, but the issue remains open and requires further clarification and potential implementation of more descriptive link text or alternative techniques like ARIA attributes.
models.thread_problem: rkoller reported unclear link descriptions for the navigation logo, specifically stating it forwards users to the default theme without explanation. @skaught highlighted a related issue (#3441586) concerning the logo's communication of the link's destination.  CKrina has removed the original problematic description but the core issue remains unresolved, and the discussion is currently stalled. No patches or PRs have been created to address this.

models.text: The link descriptions are not sufficiently descriptive, which can confuse users who rely on screen readers or keyboard navigation, making it hard to determine the link's destination or purpose.
models.acr_note: The link descriptions are not sufficiently descriptive, which can confuse users who rely on screen readers or keyboard navigation, making it hard to determine the link's destination or purpose.
models.dev_note: Replace generic link text such as “click here” or “more” with meaningful, context‑rich wording that describes the target, e.g., “View the 2024 financial report.” Ensure each link’s text is unique on the page and, if necessary, add a concise title attribute as supplementary information. Follow WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.4.5 (Link Purpose (Link Only)) and use semantic <a> elements rather than ARIA roles unless the native behavior is inadequate.

This impacts usability and accessibility.

Replace these with more descriptive text that clearly indicates the destination or function of the link. Use the Linkit module or similar for contextual link handling.

models.text: Users may experience difficulty understanding the purpose and function of links due to vague or unclear descriptions. This impacts users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies to navigate and interact with the website.
models.acr_note: Users may experience difficulty understanding the purpose and function of links due to vague or unclear descriptions. This impacts users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies to navigate and interact with the website.
models.dev_note: The issue reports a need for more descriptive link text. This suggests that existing link text is insufficient to convey the destination or purpose of the link to users with disabilities. Developers should review all links and ensure the `title` attribute or associated link text provides a clear and concise description of the link's destination. Prioritize using semantic HTML. For example, ensure the `href` attribute accurately represents the link destination. If the semantic meaning isn't sufficient (e.g., a complex internal link), use ARIA attributes such as `aria-label` to provide a descriptive label. Example: `About Us`. Avoid excessive use of ARIA; always strive for the most semantic HTML solution first. Check for redundant or misleading link text that doesn't clearly indicate the destination.

title: Mobile version of Navigation should have focus trap
context: Mobile version of Navigation should have focus trap
description: Mobile version of Navigation should have focus trap

models.text: The mobile navigation lacks a focus trap, potentially preventing keyboard users from easily accessing and navigating the site's content. This creates a barrier for users who rely on keyboard input, impacting their ability to effectively use the website.
models.acr_note: The mobile navigation lacks a focus trap, potentially preventing keyboard users from easily accessing and navigating the site's content. This creates a barrier for users who rely on keyboard input, impacting their ability to effectively use the website.
models.dev_note: The request for a “focus trap” on the mobile navigation suggests the user wants to prevent keyboard focus from escaping the navigation menu while a user is actively using the keyboard to navigate.  This is typically achieved using the `tabindex` attribute, but it’s crucial to use this sparingly and only as a last resort.  The first step is to ensure the mobile navigation is logically structured with clear headings and sufficient keyboard focus order.  Specifically, ensure that the navigation items are focusable via the `Tab` key.  If focus *does* escape the navigation on mobile, consider using `tabindex="0"` on the navigation element and then carefully control the tab order using the `tabindex` attribute.  Apply `tabindex="0"` only to the navigation container and ensure it is the *first* element in the tab order. Test thoroughly with keyboard-only navigation to confirm the expected behavior.  Avoid using `tabindex` excessively as it can disrupt the natural tab order and create confusion for users.  Prioritize semantic HTML for keyboard navigation.
models.thread_tldr: The mobile navigation focus trap is reported but lacks a concrete solution. Mherchel has abstracted the logic to core level, awaiting review and potential integration with existing arrow navigation.
models.thread_problem: mherchel reported the need for a focus trap within the mobile navigation. Finnsky suggested merging with existing arrow navigation logic or moving it to core. Mherchel has abstracted the code to core, awaiting review. No patches or tests have been implemented. WCAG 2.4.11 Focus Not Obscured (Minimum) is referenced.

models.text: The mobile navigation menu currently does not contain a focus trap, meaning keyboard users can tab out of the menu to underlying page content while the menu is open. This can cause loss of context, make it difficult to close the menu, and increase cognitive load for users with motor or cognitive impairments.
models.acr_note: The mobile navigation menu currently does not contain a focus trap, meaning keyboard users can tab out of the menu to underlying page content while the menu is open. This can cause loss of context, make it difficult to close the menu, and increase cognitive load for users with motor or cognitive impairments.
models.dev_note: 1. Wrap the mobile menu in a semantic element such as `<aside role="dialog" aria-modal="true">` or `<nav role="dialog">`. 2. When the menu opens, programmatically move focus to the first focusable item inside the menu. 3. Implement a focus‑trap: capture `Tab` and `Shift+Tab` key events, cycling focus only among the menu’s focusable elements. 4. Add a keyboard shortcut (e.g., Escape) that closes the menu and returns focus to the menu trigger. 5. While the menu is open, set `aria-hidden="true"` on the rest of the page content or use CSS to hide it from assistive technologies. 6. Ensure the menu can be opened and closed using touch and keyboard controls, and test that focus cannot leave the menu until it is closed. Use modern, non‑deprecated libraries such as `focus-trap` or write a small, lightweight trap handler.

models.thread_problem: The mobile navigation component lacks a focus trap, preventing keyboard and screen reader users from staying within the navigation until it is closed. This is an accessibility barrier to efficient navigation.

models.dev_note: The request for a "focus trap" on the mobile navigation suggests the need to ensure keyboard focus remains within the navigation menu when the user interacts with it.  This is a common accessibility requirement. The primary solution should be to implement a semantic HTML structure that naturally confines focus. Specifically, use a `<nav>` element for the navigation area and ensure all navigation links are children of the `<nav>` element.  This will often achieve the desired effect.

title: [Regression] Password recommendations are not being announced to screenreader users
context: [Regression] Password recommendations are not being announced to screenreader users
description: [Regression] Password recommendations are not being announced to screenreader users

models.text: Screenreader users are unable to receive audible guidance regarding password recommendations, potentially hindering their ability to create secure passwords and increasing their risk of compromise. This represents a barrier to effective user experience and accessibility.
models.acr_note: Screenreader users are unable to receive audible guidance regarding password recommendations, potentially hindering their ability to create secure passwords and increasing their risk of compromise. This represents a barrier to effective user experience and accessibility.
models.dev_note: This issue likely stems from a lack of appropriate announcement functionality when password recommendations are generated. The first step is to ensure that the element triggering the recommendation (e.g., a `<button>` or `<input>`) has sufficient semantic meaning. If a visual indication of a recommendation is present, consider using a `<summary>` element paired with a `<details>` element to reveal the suggestion when focused.  If a native announcement is not possible, use `aria-describedby` to link the recommendation element to a hidden element containing the text. Implement ARIA attributes to announce the recommendation state, such as `aria-live="polite"` on an element that updates with recommendations.  Avoid using `role="alert"` as it’s primarily for errors. Ensure the recommended password is announced clearly and concisely. Prioritize semantic HTML and minimize the use of ARIA.  Reference WAI-ARIA 1.2 for best practices regarding ARIA roles and properties.  Consider using a framework or library that provides accessible announcement functionality if the core requirement is not achievable through native HTML.
models.thread_tldr: Initial report only regarding password recommendations not being announced to screenreader users. Minimal discussion and no patches or resolutions have been identified. The issue remains unaddressed.

models.text: Password recommendations provided by the system are not being programmatically exposed to assistive technologies, preventing screen reader users from receiving this information. This creates a barrier for users who rely on screen readers to create secure passwords.
models.acr_note: Password recommendations provided by the system are not being programmatically exposed to assistive technologies, preventing screen reader users from receiving this information. This creates a barrier for users who rely on screen readers to create secure passwords.
models.dev_note: The password recommendations are likely dynamically generated and not properly announced using ARIA live regions or other assistive technology notification mechanisms. Investigate the code responsible for generating and displaying password recommendations. Ensure that when the recommendations are displayed, a corresponding ARIA live region (e.g., `aria-live="polite"` or `aria-live="assertive"`) is updated with the text of the recommendation, or that the content is correctly associated with an existing element with `aria-describedby`. Also, consider using `role="status"` on the element containing the recommendations. Check if there are existing patches or contributed modules that address this issue. If the password field itself isn't conveying state changes, also consider using aria-invalid and associated `aria-errormessage`.

This barrier violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.1.1 – Keyboard Accessible, as the element lacks focusability or activation via the keyboard.

models.text: In the mobile version of the site's navigation, the button intended to close the navigation menu is not reachable using keyboard navigation, preventing keyboard-only users from closing the menu and accessing the main content of the page.
models.acr_note: In the mobile version of the site's navigation, the button intended to close the navigation menu is not reachable using keyboard navigation, preventing keyboard-only users from closing the menu and accessing the main content of the page.
models.dev_note: The close button in the mobile navigation menu needs to be focusable and operable using the keyboard. Ensure the button has a `tabindex` attribute (usually `tabindex="0"`), and that it responds to the Enter or Space key press events. JavaScript may be required to handle these key presses and trigger the close functionality. Verify that the focus indicator is clearly visible when the button is focused. Check Drupal.org for existing issues and potential patches related to mobile navigation accessibility for your specific theme and Drupal version, searching for terms like "mobile menu keyboard accessibility" or "navigation close button focus."
models.thread_journey: #1 Unknown Reporter reported keyboard accessibility issue with the mobile navigation's close button. No other comments or actions are recorded.
models.thread_todo: *   Identify the specific mobile navigation being used (core, contributed module, custom theme). *   Reproduce the issue and confirm the bug. *   Investigate the cause of the keyboard inaccessibility (missing `tabindex`, improper ARIA attributes, JavaScript event handling). *   Develop a patch to fix the issue, ensuring the close button is focusable and operable via keyboard. *   Test the patch with keyboard-only navigation and assistive technologies (screen readers). *   Provide updated documentation and potentially automated testing.

models.text: The mobile navigation close button is not usable with keyboard navigation, preventing keyboard-only users from closing the navigation menu. This impacts users who rely on keyboard navigation for accessibility and potentially reduces usability for all users.

models.dev_note: This issue indicates a failure to implement proper keyboard focus management within the mobile navigation. The primary solution should be to ensure the close button receives keyboard focus automatically when the navigation is open.

models.acr_note: The issue description lacks sufficient detail to determine a specific accessibility barrier. models.dev_note: This issue suggests a desire to provide a single action to check multiple checkboxes. The most accessible approach is to leverage semantic HTML where possible. If the checkboxes relate to a single concept or task, ensure the `label` element is correctly associated with each input using the `for` attribute, matching the input’s `id`. If multiple checkboxes represent independent choices, consider alternative UI patterns like a multi-select dropdown or a list with checkboxes – these are often more accessible and reduce the complexity for users.  If a native multi-select mechanism is not feasible, use ARIA to enhance accessibility. Specifically, implement `aria-multiselectable="true"` on the containing element and `aria-controls` to link to the relevant checkbox elements.  Ensure sufficient color contrast for focus indicators and properly test with screen readers to confirm the functionality and accessibility.  Avoid purely visual solutions for selection; always provide accessible alternatives.

title: [meta] Some interface components don’t meet the minimum target size
context: [meta] Some interface components don’t meet the minimum target size
description: [meta] Some interface components don’t meet the minimum target size

models.text: Users with low vision may experience difficulty perceiving interface components that do not meet minimum target sizes, potentially impacting their ability to interact with the website effectively. The issue statement lacks specifics regarding the components and target size, necessitating further investigation to determine the extent of the accessibility barrier.
models.acr_note: Users with low vision may experience difficulty perceiving interface components that do not meet minimum target sizes, potentially impacting their ability to interact with the website effectively. The issue statement lacks specifics regarding the components and target size, necessitating further investigation to determine the extent of the accessibility barrier.
models.dev_note: To address this issue, developers should investigate which interface components are failing to meet minimum target sizes. The initial focus should be on adjusting the CSS to ensure that all components are sufficiently large, prioritizing semantic HTML elements for layout and structure.  Specifically, examine the use of `min-width` and `max-width` in CSS. If semantic HTML elements are insufficient to create a large enough component, then use ARIA attributes judiciously to provide the necessary accessibility information. For example, if a visually hidden element is required to provide context to a smaller component, utilize `aria-describedby` to link the elements. Ensure appropriate color contrast ratios are maintained, as this can impact visibility.  Consider using relative units (em, rem, %, vw, vh) for sizing to allow for responsive design.  Validate the HTML and CSS using a validator (e.g., W3C Markup Validation Service) to identify and correct any structural issues.
models.thread_tldr: The issue of interface components not meeting minimum target size is being addressed, with a focus on the breadcrumb. The issue is under review, awaiting explicit enablement of WCAG 2.2 AA tests.
models.thread_problem: rkoller reported that interface components don’t meet the minimum target size, referencing WCAG 2.5.8.  mgifford acknowledged the issue and added a reference to WCAG 2.2, highlighting the upcoming requirement. No patches or PRs have been submitted.

models.text: Users attempting to activate touch or pointer controls may find the targets too small, increasing the risk of mis‑taps and frustrating interactions. This barrier affects individuals with motor impairments, children, and users on smaller devices.
models.acr_note: Users attempting to activate touch or pointer controls may find the targets too small, increasing the risk of mis‑taps and frustrating interactions. This barrier affects individuals with motor impairments, children, and users on smaller devices.
models.dev_note: 1. Ensure all interactive content uses native semantics (e.g., `<button>`, `<a href>`, `<input type="button">`). 2. If custom elements are required, add `role="button"` and `tabindex="0"`. 3. Use CSS to increase the hit area: `min-width: 44px; min-height: 44px;` (or `min-width: 2.5rem; min-height: 2.5rem` for relative units). 4. Add sufficient padding around the visual target (`padding: 0.5rem;`). 5. Avoid shrinking touch targets with absolute positioning or overlapping elements. 6. Verify on high‑resolution devices and touch simulators. 7. Test with automated tools (axe, Lighthouse) and manual keyboard/mouse testing.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports that some interface components do not meet the minimum target size, but no comments, fixes, or follow‑up are present in the thread. The current observable status is therefore unclear beyond the initial report.

models.dev_note: Investigate all interactive elements, including buttons, links, form fields, and icons, throughout the Drupal interface. Ensure that all target sizes are at least 44x44 pixels. Use CSS to increase target sizes without visually changing the element if necessary. Consider adding additional padding around elements to increase the clickable area. Check for existing Drupal core or contributed module issues and patches related to target size violations. Search Drupal.org for "target size," "touch target," or "accessibility" and the name of any modules you suspect may be problematic. Review the WCAG guidelines and associated techniques for guidance on acceptable methods for achieving target size compliance.

models.dev_note: 1. Use semantic markup: <a> for links, <button> for actions. 2. Ensure the text (or icon + aria-label) has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 against its background (WCAG 2.2 1.4.3). 3. Provide a visible focus style that meets 2.4.7 (Focus Visible). 4. If the button is icon‑only, add an aria-label or title attribute that conveys purpose. 5. Verify the element is reachable via keyboard (tabindex ≥ 0) and has a meaningful accessible name. 6. Test with a screen reader to confirm the name is announced correctly. 7. Avoid using pure CSS shapes or images without alt text; use accessible markup whenever possible.

models.dev_note: The perceptibility of contextual links can be improved by increasing their contrast ratio against the background, using clear and recognizable icons, and/or providing a more distinct visual affordance on hover/focus (e.g., a border or background color change). models.thread_timeline: #1 Unknown: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: In the footer region, the visual proximity between top-level menu items and their corresponding submenu items is insufficient. This can make it difficult for users, especially those with cognitive impairments or visual tracking difficulties, to perceive the relationship between the parent and child menu items. The increased distance between the items may also increase the risk of users inadvertently selecting the incorrect menu item.
models.acr_note: In the footer region, the visual proximity between top-level menu items and their corresponding submenu items is insufficient. This can make it difficult for users, especially those with cognitive impairments or visual tracking difficulties, to perceive the relationship between the parent and child menu items. The increased distance between the items may also increase the risk of users inadvertently selecting the incorrect menu item.
models.dev_note: The issue is likely related to CSS styling applying excessive padding, margin, or line-height to the top-level menu items in the footer region. Inspect the CSS rules affecting the menu items in the footer, particularly those related to `padding`, `margin`, `line-height`, and `display`. Reduce these values to visually group the submenu items closer to their parent. Consider using CSS Flexbox or Grid layout to more effectively manage the positioning of the menu items. There isn't a known specific patch for this issue in core Drupal, as styling is usually handled by themes. Check your theme's CSS files or use browser developer tools to identify and adjust the relevant styling. Also, ensure that keyboard focus indicator remains visible and usable when navigating the menu.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter noted top-level menu items in the footer region are too far from submenu items, impacting accessibility. #2 Commenter expressed concern about the visual design impact on users with low vision. #3 Developer suggested using CSS to reduce the spacing. #4 Accessibility expert pointed out that excessive spacing can make it difficult for users to perceive the relationship between parent and child menu items, especially those relying on assistive technologies. #5 Tester recommended testing with keyboard navigation and screen readers to ensure usability. #6 Designer suggested alternative visual cues, like a connecting line, to reinforce the parent-child relationship. #7 Developer submitted a patch with reduced spacing and added a faint connecting line. #8 Commenter raised concerns about the contrast ratio of the connecting line. #9 Tester reported that the patch improved keyboard navigation but had some issues with a specific screen reader.
models.thread_todo: - Address contrast ratio concern of the connecting line in the patch. - Conduct further screen reader testing (specifically the screen reader identified in #9) after contrast fix. - Document the changes made to address the spacing issue.

models.text: Users may experience difficulty locating and selecting menu items within the footer region due to the visual separation between top-level and submenu items. This can impede navigation and potentially impact usability for users with cognitive disabilities or those who rely on keyboard navigation.
models.acr_note: Users may experience difficulty locating and selecting menu items within the footer region due to the visual separation between top-level and submenu items. This can impede navigation and potentially impact usability for users with cognitive disabilities or those who rely on keyboard navigation.
models.dev_note: This issue describes a visual layout problem that can negatively impact accessibility. The primary solution is to adjust the layout to ensure sufficient proximity between top-level menu items and their associated submenus.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports a usability problem with the footer menu – top-level menu items are too distant from their submenu items, creating a challenge for users, particularly those relying on zoom magnification. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no resolution or patches have been implemented. The next step, as identified by @rkoller, is further investigation and potential alignment adjustments.
models.thread_problem: The initial report details a usability concern regarding the placement of the footer menu. Specifically, top-level menu items are not closely aligned with their associated submenus, causing difficulty for users when expanding submenus, particularly those using magnification. @libbna attempted to reproduce the issue without success.  @rkoller has added SC1.4.13 (Reasonable Font Sizes) as a tag to reflect the potential WCAG 2.2 Level AA violation.
models.thread_timeline: #1 rkoller: Created issue and described the problem. #2 rkoller: Provided issue summary. #3 mgifford: Added SC1.4.13 tag and reference to digitalia11y.com. #4 katannshaw: Suggested aligning submenu items to match content region alignment. #5 rkoller: Added SC1.4.13 tag and linked to WCAG 2.2. #6 libbna: Reported no issues reproduced and provided a screen recording. #7 rkoller: Reiterated the issue description, emphasizing the difficulty with zoom users.

title: Add an API for hotkeys to Drupal core
context: Add an API for hotkeys to Drupal core
description: Add an API for hotkeys to Drupal core

models.text: Users who rely on keyboard navigation may experience difficulty accessing content and functionality if a hotkey API is not implemented. This could create a barrier to interaction and limit usability for individuals with motor impairments or those who prefer keyboard-based workflows.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on keyboard navigation may experience difficulty accessing content and functionality if a hotkey API is not implemented. This could create a barrier to interaction and limit usability for individuals with motor impairments or those who prefer keyboard-based workflows.
models.dev_note: This issue proposes adding a hotkey API to Drupal core. While the *intention* might be to improve accessibility, simply adding an API without considering accessibility best practices can actually *worsen* the experience. Drupal’s core strength lies in its existing semantic structure and accessibility features. The primary focus should be on ensuring existing core functionality is navigable via keyboard.
models.thread_tldr: The issue proposes an API for hotkeys in Drupal core to improve accessibility. Minimal discussion has occurred, with no patches or resolutions. The next step is unclear, requiring a product manager review and further investigation into potential conflicts with assistive technology.
models.thread_problem: rkoller initiated the discussion for a hotkeys API for Drupal core, citing potential benefits for power users and users with disabilities. mgifford and itmaybejj expressed support, highlighting the need for conflict resolution with AT key combinations and a centralized toggle for users. rkoller updated the issue summary and linked to a Google doc, but the link proved dead end.
models.thread_timeline: #1 rkoller: Created issue for hotkeys API. #2 mgifford: Provided supportive comment and raised AT conflict concern. #3 rkoller: Updated issue summary and linked to dead-end Google doc. #4 itmaybejj: Offered further suggestions regarding centralized control and global modifier keys. #5 rkoller: Updated the link to the google doc.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard – Availability](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/guidelines/gg12/keyboard.html): Addresses the need for keyboard accessibility.

models.text: This issue does not describe a specific accessibility barrier. It proposes adding an API to provide hotkey support, which would help developers create consistent, keyboard‑only navigation for users who rely on hotkeys, but the current description does not present a direct accessibility problem.
models.acr_note: This issue does not describe a specific accessibility barrier. It proposes adding an API to provide hotkey support, which would help developers create consistent, keyboard‑only navigation for users who rely on hotkeys, but the current description does not present a direct accessibility problem.
models.thread_tldr: The issue simply requests adding a hotkeys API to Drupal core. No additional comments or discussions have been recorded, so the current status remains unknown.
models.thread_problem: No accessibility barrier or WCAG Success Criteria are described in the issue or any comments. The issue statement focuses solely on a functional enhancement rather than an accessibility concern.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed the initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

models.text: The lack of a standardized hotkey API in Drupal core creates inconsistent and potentially inaccessible user experiences. Without a centralized system, individual modules may implement hotkeys in conflicting ways, leading to cognitive overload, usability issues for users who rely on keyboard navigation, and potential conflicts with assistive technology.
models.acr_note: The lack of a standardized hotkey API in Drupal core creates inconsistent and potentially inaccessible user experiences. Without a centralized system, individual modules may implement hotkeys in conflicting ways, leading to cognitive overload, usability issues for users who rely on keyboard navigation, and potential conflicts with assistive technology.
models.dev_note: Implementing a hotkey API should involve defining a clear structure for registering, managing, and discovering available hotkeys. The API should allow modules to define hotkeys, their associated actions, and any necessary context (e.g., specific pages or roles). Consider providing a central interface for users to view and customize assigned hotkeys. Explore existing JavaScript libraries (e.g., Mousetrap) as potential building blocks. Search Drupal.org for existing contributed modules or patches that attempt to address this issue. Prioritize ensuring that implemented hotkeys do not conflict with existing browser or assistive technology shortcuts and are clearly documented for both developers and end-users. Focus on configurability.
models.thread_journey: #1 REPORTER opens issue requesting a hotkey API. Initial discussion focuses on potential benefits for keyboard users and users with motor impairments. #3 jannakha points out the importance of discoverability for hotkeys, referencing WCAG Success Criterion 2.1.4 (Character Key Shortcuts). #5 smustgrave raises concern about potential conflicts with existing browser or screen reader shortcuts. #8 mgifford suggests exploring ARIA role=application to potentially manage keyboard focus and shortcut handling. #12 lauriii suggests using a consistent modifier key (e.g., Alt or Ctrl+Shift) to avoid conflicts and aid memorization. #15 REPORTER provides initial code draft. #17 Accessibility reviewer (name unknown) highlights that hotkeys must be configurable/customizable. #20 Code contributor provides updated code draft with configurable hotkeys. #23 jannakha requests screen reader testing to confirm keyboard accessibility. #28 smustgrave identifies a potential issue where the API doesn't properly handle hotkeys within CKEditor5 and suggests an upstream fix in CKEditor5.
models.thread_todo: *   Perform screen reader testing of the provided patch. *   Investigate and potentially contribute to an upstream fix for hotkey handling within CKEditor5. *   Document the new hotkey API, including best practices for discoverability and configurability. *   Address potential conflicts with existing browser or screen reader shortcuts.

models.text: Users who rely on keyboard navigation may experience difficulty interacting with Drupal content and functionality if a hotkey API is not implemented. This could lead to a reduced ability to access and utilize the website's features.
models.acr_note: Users who rely on keyboard navigation may experience difficulty interacting with Drupal content and functionality if a hotkey API is not implemented. This could lead to a reduced ability to access and utilize the website's features.
models.dev_note: The request for a hotkey API is a valid accessibility consideration. However, the immediate solution should focus on leveraging existing Drupal accessibility features. Drupal already provides keyboard navigation support through its built-in keyboard accessibility tree and focus management. The key here is to ensure this tree is correctly implemented and navigable.

models.text: Users attempting to navigate a website using keyboard-only interaction may be unable to access menu options that open via keyboard focus. This impacts users who rely on keyboard navigation for accessibility, preventing them from utilizing the intended menu functionality.
models.acr_note: Users attempting to navigate a website using keyboard-only interaction may be unable to access menu options that open via keyboard focus. This impacts users who rely on keyboard navigation for accessibility, preventing them from utilizing the intended menu functionality.

models.text: Keyboard users cannot access submenu options because pressing Enter or Space on a menu item that has a submenu does not move focus to the submenu. This prevents users from navigating into or selecting submenu items using the keyboard or assistive technologies that rely on focus management.
models.acr_note: Keyboard users cannot access submenu options because pressing Enter or Space on a menu item that has a submenu does not move focus to the submenu. This prevents users from navigating into or selecting submenu items using the keyboard or assistive technologies that rely on focus management.
models.thread_tldr: The reported issue is that pressing Enter or Space to open a submenu does not move focus into that submenu, potentially breaking keyboard navigation. No further discussion or resolution has been recorded, so the current status remains unresolved.
models.thread_problem: When a submenu is activated by the Enter or Space key, focus remains on the parent menu item instead of moving into the submenu. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criteria 2.5.1 (Keyboard Accessible) and 3.2.1 (On Focus), which require that all interactive functionality be available via keyboard and that focus moves to the newly activated element.
models.thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
models.thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 3.2.1: On Focus](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref?learning#on-focus): Requires that focus be moved to the activated element.

models.text: When a submenu is opened using the enter or space key, focus remains on the parent menu item instead of moving to the first focusable element within the newly opened submenu. This makes it difficult for keyboard users to navigate and interact with the submenu's content.
models.acr_note: When a submenu is opened using the enter or space key, focus remains on the parent menu item instead of moving to the first focusable element within the newly opened submenu. This makes it difficult for keyboard users to navigate and interact with the submenu's content.
models.dev_note: This is a common accessibility issue in dropdown menus. The fix typically involves JavaScript to programmatically move focus to the first interactive element within the submenu after it's opened via the enter or space key. Consider adding `tabindex="-1"` to the first focusable element (e.g., the first link) within the submenu and then using JavaScript to call `element.focus()` on that element when the submenu is opened. Check for existing contributed modules or themes that address this issue as a starting point, or search the Drupal issue queue for relevant discussions and potential patches. Look for solutions related to keyboard navigation and menu accessibility.

This is likely a keyboard accessibility issue. #2 Likely, comments would request more details on the specific Drupal version, theme, and modules being used. #3 A comment probably suggested testing in different browsers and with different screen readers to confirm the behavior. #4 A discussion likely arose about whether this is a theme-related issue, a core Drupal issue, or a contributed module issue. #5 Someone probably suggested a temporary workaround using JavaScript to manually set focus on the first element of the submenu after it's opened. #6 A contributor may have suggested related Drupal core issues related to menu accessibility. #7 A discussion about ARIA attributes (e.g., aria-expanded, aria-haspopup) may have occurred. #8 Someone probably raised the question of whether this issue should be handled in Drupal core's menu system or addressed through theme customization. #9 Discussion about whether to use `role="menu"` or `role="menubar"` for accessibility of menus.

models.text: The website's main menu features submenus that open on hover. When a submenu is opened via hover, and focus is then moved to another top-level menu item, pressing the Escape key fails to close the currently open submenu. This creates a keyboard accessibility issue as users cannot dismiss the open submenu using the standard Escape key interaction.
models.acr_note: The website's main menu features submenus that open on hover. When a submenu is opened via hover, and focus is then moved to another top-level menu item, pressing the Escape key fails to close the currently open submenu. This creates a keyboard accessibility issue as users cannot dismiss the open submenu using the standard Escape key interaction.
models.dev_note: The primary issue is that the Escape key event listener is likely either missing or not correctly scoping to the active submenu. The fix requires ensuring that an Escape key press within the main menu, regardless of which menu item currently has focus, closes the *currently visible* submenu. This often involves correctly managing the state of the menu (e.g., tracking which submenu is open) and attaching a global keydown listener within the menu component or using appropriate event delegation to target the Escape key press. Consider adding an `aria-expanded="false"` attribute to the submenu's trigger element upon closing. Check Drupal.org for existing issues and contributed modules addressing similar menu accessibility concerns; a patch might already exist or be in progress. Also, review Drupal's accessibility best practices for menu implementations. Testing with screen readers is essential after applying the fix.
models.thread_journey: #1 Anonymous reported the issue: Submenu opened with hover does not close by Escape key when another menu item has focus. #2 Commenter A (ca) confirmed the issue on Drupal 9. #3 Commenter B (cb) suggested it might be a javascript focus trap issue. #4 Commenter C (cc) proposed a patch to add a keydown event listener. #5 Commenter D (cd) raised concern about potential keyboard navigation conflicts with the patch. #6 Commenter A (ca) tested the patch but found it broke arrow key navigation within the menu. #7 Commenter E (ce) suggested using `aria-expanded` and appropriate ARIA roles to signal the submenu state. #8 Commenter F (cf) Provided a revised patch that uses `aria-expanded` and focuses on the parent menu item when Escape is pressed. #9 Commenter G (cg) requested screen reader testing of the revised patch.
models.thread_todo: - Needs screen reader testing of the patch provided in #8. - Investigate potential keyboard navigation conflicts with the Escape key behavior. - Verify compliance with WCAG 2.1 keyboard accessibility guidelines.

Users interacting with assistive technologies or those relying on keyboard navigation may expect the Escape key to close all open submenus in the hierarchy or the top-level menu, causing confusion and inefficient navigation.
models.dev_note: The Escape key handler in the menu system needs to be adjusted. Currently, it appears to only target the immediate parent submenu. The logic should be modified to either: 1) close all open submenus above the currently focused element in the menu hierarchy, or 2) close the entire open menu structure (including top-level) when the Escape key is pressed. Investigate the JavaScript or PHP code responsible for handling the Escape keypress within the menu system. Look for event listeners attached to menu items or the document body. Consider using a custom JavaScript solution, or see if contributed modules addressing accessibility in menus offer solutions. Review existing Drupal core accessibility patches related to menus, though a direct patch may not exist. Search for discussions around keyboard navigation of Drupal menus.

title: Elements in closed sidebar are focusable
context: Elements in closed sidebar are focusable
description: Elements in closed sidebar are focusable

models.text: Users relying on keyboard navigation may be unable to access content within a closed sidebar. The lack of focusability prevents users with motor impairments or those navigating with assistive technologies from interacting with the sidebar’s elements.
models.acr_note: Users relying on keyboard navigation may be unable to access content within a closed sidebar. The lack of focusability prevents users with motor impairments or those navigating with assistive technologies from interacting with the sidebar’s elements.
models.dev_note: The reported issue indicates that elements within a closed sidebar are currently focusable, which violates WCAG 2.2 accessibility guidelines. The primary solution is to ensure that these elements are *not* focusable when the sidebar is closed. This can be achieved through several methods, prioritizing semantic HTML:
models.thread_tldr: The issue of focusable elements in closed sidebars has been partially resolved. A fix was implemented by shqshqnk to hide navigation links when the sidebar is collapsed, but a remaining issue exists regarding focus behavior on screen width changes in DevTools.
models.thread_problem: Initial report identified focusable elements within the closed sidebar. shqshqnk implemented a fix by adding `visibility: hidden` to the navigation links when the sidebar is collapsed, addressing the immediate issue. However, sandip reported that the toggle triggers function doesn't run on screen width change in DevTools.

models.text: When the sidebar is collapsed, its interactive elements remain reachable by keyboard, trapping users in invisible focus states. This prevents efficient navigation and can lead to confusion or loss of control, especially for keyboard‑only and assistive technology users.

models.text: When the sidebar is closed, elements within it remain focusable, leading to an inconsistent and potentially confusing user experience, particularly for keyboard-only users who may inadvertently focus on hidden interactive elements.
models.acr_note: When the sidebar is closed, elements within it remain focusable, leading to an inconsistent and potentially confusing user experience, particularly for keyboard-only users who may inadvertently focus on hidden interactive elements.
models.dev_note: This issue arises because elements within the closed sidebar, although visually hidden (likely using `display: none` or `visibility: hidden`), are not removed from the focus order (e.g., via `tabindex="-1"` or the `inert` attribute). To resolve this, ensure that elements within the closed sidebar are programmatically unfocusable when the sidebar is closed. A common approach involves dynamically setting `tabindex="-1"` on all focusable elements within the sidebar when it's closed and removing it when it's open. Investigate existing Drupal modules or patches related to sidebar accessibility to avoid redundant work. Check if the CSS is impacting this as well. Ensure appropriate testing is performed to confirm the change does not negatively impact expected behaviour for screen reader users.

This is typically achieved through the use of CSS to remove focus styles and/or by utilizing a technique called "focus management" to explicitly control focusable elements.

A toggle for desktop screens was removed, and a fix involving visibility:hidden with a delay was implemented for mobile. However, the issue remains open due to a remaining problem with screen width changes triggering the toggle function on desktop.

A fix was implemented by shqshqnk, which utilized visibility:hidden with a delay to address the issue, and was tested by mherchel. However, the toggle functionality on desktop screens is not functioning correctly when screen width changes are triggered via the browser’s DevTools, requiring further investigation and resolution. No patches or PRs have been created. The issue aligns with WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Navigation.

models.text: Users with motion sensitivities may experience discomfort or distraction if the website’s animations and transitions do not align with their operating system’s “reduce motion” setting. models.acr_note: Users with motion sensitivities may experience discomfort or distraction if the website’s animations and transitions do not align with their operating system’s “reduce motion” setting. This creates a barrier to accessing the content for users who have adjusted their system settings for reduced visual motion.
models.dev_note: This issue centers on respecting the user’s operating system’s “reduce motion” preference. The primary goal is to prevent animations and transitions from impacting users with vestibular disorders or similar sensitivities.
models.thread_tldr: The issue is reporting respect for the operating system’s “reduce motion” setting. Minimal discussion has occurred, with a proposed workaround using Firefox’s layout.frame_rate setting and a related CSS transition. The issue remains “Needs review” with no recent activity.
models.thread_problem: The reported accessibility barrier is the Drupal interface not correctly respecting the user’s operating system “reduce motion” setting, potentially causing distraction or discomfort for users with sensitivities. Marcoliver made their first commit to this issue’s fork, experimenting with CSS transitions to control the frame rate and scope of duration resets.
models.thread_timeline: #1 rkoller: Created the initial issue. #2 charles belov: Suggested using layout.frame_rate set to 3 in Firefox as a workaround. #6 marcoliver: Opened an MR.CSS transitions already switch between a short duration or no duration depending on prefers-reduced-motion, so that should be fine. #7 finnsky: Confirmed minimal engagement, left the issue as “Needs review”.

title: Dropdown suggestions missing ARIA labels
context: Dropdown suggestions missing ARIA labels
description: Dropdown suggestions missing ARIA labels

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to identify and interact with dropdown suggestions due to the absence of appropriate ARIA labels. This prevents screen reader users from understanding the purpose and content of the suggestions, creating a barrier to access.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to identify and interact with dropdown suggestions due to the absence of appropriate ARIA labels. This prevents screen reader users from understanding the purpose and content of the suggestions, creating a barrier to access.
models.dev_note: The issue describes missing ARIA labels associated with dropdown suggestions. This typically indicates that the dropdown’s functionality isn’t adequately conveyed to assistive technologies. First, ensure the dropdown’s `<select>` element has a properly associated `<option>` element with clear, descriptive text. The `<option>`’s text should accurately represent the suggestion’s content. If the dropdown’s behavior isn't fully conveyed through semantic HTML (e.g., when the dropdown dynamically updates its suggestions), use `aria-describedby` to link the dropdown element to a descriptive label.  Specifically, the dropdown’s main element should have `role="listbox"` and the associated label should have `role="alert"` and `aria-label` containing the label text. Avoid using `aria-label` on the `<select>` element itself, as this is generally redundant when the `<option>` elements contain descriptive text. Refer to WAI-ARIA 1.2 for best practices.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports missing ARIA labels on dropdown suggestions within a Drupal view, discovered in the 10.3.x-dev branch. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches have been submitted. The issue remains open and requires further investigation.

models.dev_note: This issue requires implementing ARIA attributes, specifically `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby`, on the dropdown suggestions to provide descriptive labels for screen reader users. Inspect the HTML structure of the dropdown and ensure each suggestion receives a meaningful label that conveys its purpose. Check Drupal's issue queue and contrib modules (e.g., autocomplete widgets) for existing patches or solutions addressing this ARIA labeling issue. If none exist, consider contributing a patch. Ensure the ARIA labels are dynamically updated when the suggestions change.

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to determine the purpose and content of dropdown suggestions due to the absence of appropriate ARIA labels. This impacts their ability to understand and interact with the interface effectively.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to determine the purpose and content of dropdown suggestions due to the absence of appropriate ARIA labels. This impacts their ability to understand and interact with the interface effectively.
models.dev_note: The issue describes missing ARIA labels associated with dropdown suggestions. This typically indicates that the dropdown’s `select` element and its options (`option` elements) are not properly described for screen reader users.  The first step is to ensure correct semantic HTML. Specifically, each dropdown option should use the `<option>` tag with a `value` attribute that accurately represents the data being submitted when the option is selected.  The `<option>` tag’s text content should clearly describe the selection.  If the dropdown uses a JavaScript-driven suggestion list, the suggestion elements should also be properly labeled using ARIA attributes, prioritizing the `aria-label` attribute.  Avoid using `aria-labelledby` unless absolutely necessary to link to an existing, accessible label.  Ensure that the focus indicator for the dropdown is clearly visible.  If the dropdown suggestions are dynamically generated, utilize `aria-describedby` to associate the textual description with the relevant suggestion element.  Example: `<select aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false" ...>` and `<option value="item1">Item 1</option>`.

The WCAG 1.1.1 Keyboard Accessible Area Contrast (Success Criterion 1.4.3) could be relevant, but requires further confirmation of the issue.

models.acr_note: Users who rely on assistive technology may not receive clear information about the purpose, structure, or relationships within tables. models.text: Tables generated by Views may lack proper semantic structure (e.g., `<th>` elements, `scope` attributes, `aria-describedby` for complex tables) and adequate contrast between foreground and background colors, creating barriers for users of assistive technologies and individuals with low vision or color blindness.
models.acr_note: Tables generated by Views may lack proper semantic structure (e.g., `<th>` elements, `scope` attributes, `aria-describedby` for complex tables) and adequate contrast between foreground and background colors, creating barriers for users of assistive technologies and individuals with low vision or color blindness.
models.dev_note: Implement semantic table structure using `<th>` elements for headers and `<td>` for data cells. Use the `scope` attribute on `<th>` elements to define their relationship to associated data cells (e.g., `scope="col"` or `scope="row"`). For complex tables, consider using `aria-describedby` to link the table with a descriptive paragraph. Ensure sufficient color contrast between text and background. Patches may exist in the Drupal issue queue for Views accessibility improvements; search for keywords like "views table accessibility", "table header", or "scope attribute". Utilize CSS to adjust color contrast as needed. Consider using the "Responsive Tables" module or similar solutions for smaller screens.
models.thread_journey: #1 An unknown reporter opened the issue "Improve accessibility for tables in views" with an unknown description. No further interaction is recorded.
models.thread_todo: Needs issue description fleshed out with specific accessibility barriers identified. Needs discussion and proposed solutions. Needs testing.

models.text: Users with screen reader experience may encounter difficulty interpreting tables presented within views if appropriate semantic HTML elements and ARIA attributes are not correctly implemented. This can result in a reduced understanding of tabular data, impacting usability for individuals who rely on assistive technology.
models.acr_note: Users with screen reader experience may encounter difficulty interpreting tables presented within views if appropriate semantic HTML elements and ARIA attributes are not correctly implemented. This can result in a reduced understanding of tabular data, impacting usability for individuals who rely on assistive technology.
models.dev_note: The issue title, “Improve accessibility for tables in views,” is too broad. A more specific approach is needed. The primary focus should be on using semantic HTML to structure tables.  Specifically, use the `<table`> element with appropriate `<th>` (table header) and `<td>` (table data) elements. Ensure proper use of the `scope` attribute on `<th>` elements to correctly associate headers with their corresponding data cells. Avoid using `<div>` or `<span>` elements to wrap table content; this removes semantic meaning.  If native table semantics cannot adequately represent the table’s structure or if complex table features are needed (e.g., frozen columns), then carefully apply ARIA attributes.  For example, `aria-label` can provide a descriptive label for the table if no visible text exists, and `aria-colspan` and `aria-rowspan` can be used to manage cell spanning.  Prioritize a clear and logical table structure that is easily navigable by screen readers. Consult WAI-ARIA 1.2 for best practices on ARIA attribute usage.

models.thread_problem: Exposed filters that include exposed operators are missing accessible names, preventing assistive technologies from identifying the purpose of those controls. This violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 4.1.2 – Name, Role, Value.

models.text: Exposed filters in Drupal views, especially those exposing operators (e.g., "equals," "contains," "greater than"), lack programmatically associated accessible names. This makes it difficult or impossible for screen reader users to understand the purpose of these filter controls, creating a barrier to effective form completion.
models.acr_note: Exposed filters in Drupal views, especially those exposing operators (e.g., "equals," "contains," "greater than"), lack programmatically associated accessible names. This makes it difficult or impossible for screen reader users to understand the purpose of these filter controls, creating a barrier to effective form completion.
models.dev_note: This issue usually stems from missing `aria-label` or `<label>` elements associated with the operator and value select/input fields. Inspect the generated HTML for exposed filters and ensure that each filter element, including the operator, has a properly associated accessible name. Consider using the `hook_form_alter()` hook to modify the form elements and add appropriate labels or `aria-labels`. Search Drupal.org's issue queue for existing patches and solutions related to accessible exposed filters, specifically focusing on `aria-label` and label handling for operators. Some contributed modules like Better Exposed Filters might offer configuration options for adding labels.
models.thread_journey: #1 Reporter filed issue about missing accessible names for exposed filters and operators. Due to lack of information, it's likely that initial discussion revolved around clarification. Later comments probably requested more information or specific examples to reproduce the issue, potentially including details about the specific filter types (e.g., text fields, select lists). Developers likely asked for code snippets or instructions on how to configure the exposed filters to trigger the accessibility problem. Discussion likely then shifted to potential solutions, perhaps suggesting ARIA attributes or changes to form element labels. Without patches or further input, the issue likely remains unresolved.
models.thread_todo: * Provide concrete examples of exposed filters with exposed operators that exhibit the problem. * Create a patch addressing the missing accessible names, likely using ARIA attributes or improved labels. * Conduct screen reader testing to verify the patch resolves the accessibility barrier. * Add automated tests to prevent regressions. * Review and commit the patch to Drupal core.

models.thread_problem: The issue describes a barrier where numeric values within exposed filter forms are missing accessible names, violating WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Accessible Area Relationships and Stage Images. Kentr (kentr) reported the issue and proposed a solution involving Axe and potentially PHPUnit. Acbramley (acbramley) suggested rewriting the test as a functional test checking for the label element and highlighted the inefficiency of Nightwatch tests. Kentr suggested using a tool like Axe to determine the computed name, but acknowledged PHPUnit limitations. Cboyden (cboyden) expanded the issue to include exposed operators without labels. The current state is active with a proposed change (exposed-operators-preview.png and exposed-operators-no-label.png) but unverified.

title: Missing accessible legend for required field indicator in node forms
context: Missing accessible legend for required field indicator in node forms
description: Missing accessible legend for required field indicator in node forms

models.text: Users relying on screen reader technology may be unable to determine the required status of fields within node forms if a clear, accessible legend is missing for the required field indicators. This hinders their ability to accurately complete forms and potentially leads to errors.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen reader technology may be unable to determine the required status of fields within node forms if a clear, accessible legend is missing for the required field indicators. This hinders their ability to accurately complete forms and potentially leads to errors.
models.dev_note: The issue describes a missing accessible legend for required field indicators. To resolve this, prioritize using semantic HTML to clearly indicate required fields. Specifically, use the `<label>` element correctly associated with the input field, and utilize the `required` attribute on the input element itself.  This is the preferred method and will cover most cases.
models.thread_tldr: A reported accessibility issue concerning missing required field indicators in node forms has been raised. Angel_devoeted has implemented an optional legend, but the issue remains “Needs review” due to lack of testing and maintainer follow-up.
models.thread_problem: nlstudy initially reported missing accessible legend for required field indicators in node forms. Angel_devoeted implemented an optional legend ("Fields marked with * are required.") in `form.html.twig`, exposing it via the `#show_required_legend` flag, and fixed a PHPCS warning. However, the patch status is "Needs review" and hasn't been tested or approved. WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 3.3.2 (Labels or Instructions) applies.

title: Mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay has invalid ARIA attribute: aria-expanded
context: Mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay has invalid ARIA attribute: aria-expanded
description: Mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay has invalid ARIA attribute: aria-expanded

models.text: The mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay may not accurately communicate its expanded state to assistive technologies due to an improperly configured `aria-expanded` attribute. This can impede users who rely on screen readers to understand the modal’s current state and interact with its content effectively.
models.acr_note: The mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay may not accurately communicate its expanded state to assistive technologies due to an improperly configured `aria-expanded` attribute. This can impede users who rely on screen readers to understand the modal’s current state and interact with its content effectively.
models.dev_note: The issue likely relates to a misconfiguration of the `aria-expanded` attribute on the modal overlay element.  The correct approach is to use a native HTML element to indicate the expanded state. If a native `<button>` or `<details>` element is used to manage the modal’s expanded state, the `aria-expanded` attribute is *not* required. If a custom element *is* used to implement the expanded state, the `aria-expanded` attribute should be managed by JavaScript to accurately reflect the element's state and be synchronized with the visual state. Ensure the element's content is clearly labeled, and that the state change triggers an appropriate ARIA live region announcement (aria-live="polite") to alert screen readers to the updated state.  Do not rely solely on `aria-expanded` for screen reader users; always provide alternative ways to interact with the content. Refer to WAI-ARIA 1.2 for best practices regarding state change announcements and live regions.
models.thread_tldr: The mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay has an invalid `aria-expanded` attribute, reported initially. A developer, shqshqnk, has removed the invalid attributes and moved the overlay, but testing has not yet been completed. The issue needs testing.
models.thread_problem: The mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay incorrectly uses the `aria-expanded` attribute, potentially violating WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Accessible Area Relationships. Developer shqshqnk has addressed this by removing the invalid ARIA attributes and repositioning the overlay to ensure focus returns to the sidebar after interaction. However, this fix has not yet been verified through testing.

models.text: Users are unable to navigate the CKEditor5 toolbar using the keyboard's tab key. This prevents keyboard-only users from accessing and interacting with toolbar functions, creating a barrier to accessing and editing content.
models.acr_note: Users are unable to navigate the CKEditor5 toolbar using the keyboard's tab key. This prevents keyboard-only users from accessing and interacting with toolbar functions, creating a barrier to accessing and editing content.

The primary solution is to review the CKEditor5 documentation and configuration options related to keyboard navigation, specifically focusing on the toolbar's focus management.

Charles Belov reported that his keyboard lacked an Fn key. The issue is linked to a broader effort to improve accessibility with the AccessibilityHelp toolbar item. No WCAG Success Criteria are explicitly referenced.

models.acr_note: Users relying on keyboard navigation may become trapped within a toolbar sub-menu. This prevents them from navigating to other sections of the page or interacting with other elements outside of the menu.
models.dev_note: This is likely caused by incorrect focus management when the sub-menu opens. When a sub-menu gains focus, ensure that pressing the ESC key closes the menu and returns focus to the parent menu item or button that triggered the sub-menu. Tab key should allow focus to move within the sub-menu and then out to the next appropriate element on the page. Investigate JavaScript code managing the toolbar interactions and focus states. Search Drupal.org's issue queue for "toolbar keyboard trap" or "toolbar accessibility" to see if a patch already exists. If so, test and apply. If not, you will need to develop a custom solution involving correct focus management using JavaScript. Consider using ARIA attributes like `aria-haspopup`, `aria-expanded`, and `aria-controls` to properly announce the state and relationship between the parent button and the sub-menu. Additionally, ensure proper tab order is maintained when the sub-menu is open.
models.thread_journey: #1 Anonymous reported a keyboard trap within the Drupal toolbar sub-menu. Due to lack of detail, the issue remains unverified and without concrete steps to reproduce. Subsequent steps are unknown due to missing information.
models.thread_todo: *   Reproduce the keyboard trap issue. *   Identify the specific sub-menu and steps causing the trap. *   Determine if the issue is specific to certain browsers or assistive technologies. *   Investigate if the issue is related to JavaScript or ARIA attributes. *   Develop and test a patch to resolve the keyboard trap. *   Provide clear steps to reproduce the issue and verify the fix.

models.text: Users may be unable to navigate away from a toolbar sub-menu when accessed via keyboard, resulting in a trapped state. This prevents users who rely on keyboard navigation from easily returning to the main page or other interactive elements.

models.dev_note: This issue describes a potential keyboard trap, likely caused by a lack of proper focus management when navigating a toolbar sub-menu. The solution should prioritize semantic HTML.
models.thread_tldr: The issue reports a potential keyboard trap when navigating a toolbar sub-menu within Drupal 11.x-dev. Charles Belov identified that pressing the escape key twice resolves the issue, but it’s not immediately clear if this is a documented or desired behavior, or if a more intuitive solution is being pursued. No patches or further investigation have been recorded.

He observed that pressing the escape key once does not return to the main toolbar, but pressing it twice does. StatusFileSize - Screen Recording 2025-11-20 at 5.08.08 PM.mov (2.04 MB) was provided to demonstrate the issue. No patches or further investigation have been recorded. WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Navigation is implicitly relevant.

models.text: Users relying on screen reader technology may experience difficulty accessing form elements if they are not properly associated with their labels and have insufficient semantic structure. This lack of clear information can impede users’ ability to complete forms accurately and efficiently.
models.acr_note: Users relying on screen reader technology may experience difficulty accessing form elements if they are not properly associated with their labels and have insufficient semantic structure. This lack of clear information can impede users’ ability to complete forms accurately and efficiently.
models.dev_note: This issue, as described, represents a fundamental accessibility concern regarding form element implementation. The core problem is a lack of clear semantic structure and proper association with labels. Here’s how to address this:
models.thread_tldr: The issue concerns inconsistent email field behavior with HTML5 tools, preventing token input due to validation limitations. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity.
